column2: LIMA, Oct. 3, via Galveston.--El Puebla states authentically that Igleslas with his army will arrive on Oct. 15 at Ancon, which has been declared a neutral port, and that the evacuation of Lima will take place on Oct. 30. Senor Ignacio Osma has been named for Prefect of Lima, and Senor Vidal Garcia-y-Garcia for Prefect of Callao.

UPON THE SAME TERMS AS BEFORE. One hundred representative citizens of Brooklyn met in the Art Building in Montaguestreet last evening to approve the administration of Mayor Seth Low and to pave the way for his renomination and re-election.
STAMFORD, Conn., Oct. 3.--There is trouble here. The laws of the country are set at naught, and the requirements of the fifteenth amendment are ignored.

DES MOINES, Oct. 3.--The last of the series of joint debates between Gov. Sherwan and Mr. Kinne took place in the Court-house-square to-day, Gov. Sherman having the opening and closing. Both gentlemen have spoken from six to eight times a week during the canvass, but both showed less wear than might have been expected.

The Board of Education at their meeting yesterday adopted an amendment to the by-laws, making it incumbent on all female teachers who marry to report their marriage name and residence within 30 days.
A meeting of the military order of Loyal Legion of the United States, Commandery of the State of New-York, was held at Delmonico's last night.

NEW-ORLEANS, Oct. 3.--At the meeting of the City Council last night the Mayor was directed to take steps forthwith to relieve the necessities of the people in the matter of water, the cost to be met hereafter. It's no eexaggeration to declare that ...

WASHINGTON, Oct.3--The Hon. Richard T. Merrick to-night addressed a large and bright looking class of young men who are about to resume or begin the study of the law as members of the Georgetown University School of Law.

BOSTON, Oct.3--The annual meeting of the Harvard University Boat Club took place this evening in Holden Chapel, Cambridge. G.R. Agasaiz, '84. Vice-President last year, called the meeting to order, and Secretary Walter Baylies. '84, read a detailed report of the doings of the club during the past year.

The sale of subscription tickets for the 24 performances to be given by Mr. Henry Irving at the Star Theatre began at the box-office of the theatre yesterday morning at 9 o'clock. The disposal of these seats attracted great attention among the ticket speculators.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 3.--The second biennial conference of American church-workers among the deaf will be opened here on Saturday, Oct. 13, and will be presided over by Bishop Stevens, of the Diocese of Pennsylvania.

BOSTON, Oct. 3.--Hill Rowe, boot and shoe manufacturers, of No. 2 High-street, have failed. Considerable surprise is expressed at the failure, the firm being an old and well known one. They have a factory at Stoneham.
The Fall meeting of tho American Jockey Club, which was interrupted by the storm of Tuesday, will be resumed to-day. There is an excellen programme of six races, with the following entries:
ALBANY, Oct. 3.--Edward Newcomb, Receiver of the Atlantic Mutual Life Insurance Company, has filed a report covering the whole period of his incumbency, from Aug. 7, 1887, to Sept. 1, 1883.
RICHMOND, Oct. 3.--It is stated here in Mahone circles that Gov. Cameron has contributed $1,500 to the coalition campaign fund. What Ma hone has himself contributed for the same object is not stated.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Oct. 3.--Fifteen miles from Decatur. Ala., this evening, the steamer Anderson encountered a severe storm, which carried away her upper works besides doing other damage. The steamer is almost a total wreck. Three deckhands, whose names were not learned, were drowned.

HEBRON, Conn., Oct. 3.--The society if this rustic village in southern Tolland County has been rent asunder by a recent sermon of the Rev. G. B. Cutler, of the Congregational Church, in which he vigorously denounced Mr. J.B. Fillmore, a prominent member of his flock and an earnest ...
That Tuesday's prize-fight at Flushing was not a particularly bloody contest was not the fault of those who aided and abetted it.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 3.--The thirty-third general convention of the Protestant Episcopal Church in the United States was opened this morning with services held in the venerable Christ Church, on Second-street, near Market, the cornerstone of which edifice was laid in 1772.

The Third Ward was well represented, last evening, at Mr. Mike Sweeney's reception, at No. 203 Washington-street. Mr. Sweeney is as well known as a poet and a patron of the Muses as for the excellence of his beer, and society circles in the ...

BOSTON, Mass., Oct. 3.--Col. Plympton, Insurance Examiner, is pursuing an investigation into the affairs of one of the leading insurance companies of the State, and it is said his report, which will probably be made on Monday, will disclose a worse condition of affairs than existed in the Metropole Company.

John McIntosh, retail dealer in laces at No. 16 West Twenty-third-street, made an assignment yesterday to John R. Hunt, giving seven preferences aggregating $2,414. He was for 13 years a partner in the firm of G. Richmond Co., and bought out the business for $5,000 in February, 1879.

LONDON, Oct.3.--The London World has the following notos to-day; Matthew Arnold will leave Liverpool for New-York on Saturday of next week in the Servia, accompanied by his wife and daughter. Mr. Arnold intends to return at the end of February.
Samuel C. Nelson, who for the past eight years has held the office of Controller of Jersey City, died at his residence last evening from Bright's disease.

NEW-ORLEANS, Oct. 3.--The British steamer Wellfield came in from sea through South-west Pass yesterday, and passed on up to the city without detention. Sixteen feet of water was reported throughout the pass, and but for the sills laid therein some years ago by Capt. Eads to divert the current of water into South Pass a much deeper channel would be available. The Wellfield is the first steamer to go through this channel for several years.

MONTREAL, Quebec, Oct. 4.--Some excitement was created here to-day in financial circles upon its leaking out that Thomas Craig, President and General Manager of the suspended Exchange bank, had made advances to himself to a large amount.

Several hundred ladies witnessed the lawntennis games at Camp Washington, Staten Island, yesterday. The number of games played was greater than on the first day, the most exciting and closely contested of which was in the ladies' final single between Miss Robinson, the champion of the New-Brighton Club, and Miss Goodwin, of the Franklin (New-Jersey) Club.

The County Committee of the County Democracy assumed last evening an attitude more deflant even than that of the Tammany Committee on Organization earlier in the week. By an overwhelming vote it declined to make overtures to ...

The second day of the Fall meeting at Jerome Park was well attended, although fashion did not make a display at the club-house, or in the ladies' part of the grand stand. This was doubtless caused by the unfavorable weather, for the ...

INDIANAPODIS, Ind., Oct. 4.--Harry New, Jr., proprietor of the Indianapolis Journal, assaulted John G. Thompson, editor of the Washington Sunday Chronice on the street this evening, strieking him two severe blows in the face.

RICHMOND, Oct. 4.--The political campaign in this State is being pressed now by both sides with an energy and vigor never before known in the politics of Virginia. The methods resorted to and the enterprise displayed exceed the old days of reconstruction.
LIVERPOOL, Oct. 4.--Col. Mapleson and the majority of the members of his operatic company sailed from this port for New-York to-day on the steamer City of Berlin.
John Rowan, who is charged with having abandoned his wife in Jersey City after a mock marriage in New-York, had a further examination in Justice Davis's court yesterday.

MILWAUKEE, Oct. 4.--Mlle. Celestia, a rider with Barnum's circus, who was thrown from her horse in this city and badly injured, died at Stevenspoint yesterday. A rider, whose name cannot be learned, was thrown from his horse during the performance at that place yesterday and was instantly killed.

The traveler in a European railway carriage makes it the object of his life to secure an entire compartment to himself, if possible. It is strange that railway travel should develop this form of selfishness in men who are ordinarily generous and courteous.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Oct. 4.--A terrible murder occurred yesterday evening near Gadsden, Ala. Henry Hart entered the residence of Levl Smith, and, without saying a word, shot him through the body with a shot-gun. Smith fell dead and the murderer escaped. Smith was a farmer of good reputation, and formerly lived at Fayetteville, Va.

It appears by the dispatches of to-day that efforts are making to effect a compromise between the Polish priest at Nanticoke and his Polish parishioners who insist on keeping their saloons open on Sunday.

To all who know John Warner Willcomb the news of his death on Wednesday last was received with profound regret. His acquaintances not only admired him because of his honesty, integrity, and uprightness, but revered him because of a life rounded out and made perfect by heroism such as is, unfortunately, rarely known.

Miss Christine Griffin Kean, daughter of Mr. John Kean, and a niece of the Hon. Hamilton Fish, was married yesterday in St. John's Episcopal Church. Elizabeth, N.J., to Mr. Emlen Roosevelt, of New-York. The church was crowded.

It is well that everybody in Government employment, either of the United States or of the State or of any city in this State, should understand that the law in regard to political contributions has been radically changed since last year and exactly what the law now is. The Federal law will be found ...

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 4.--One of the most important enterprises ever established on the Pacific coast was incorporated to-day under the name of the Pacific Steam Agricultural Manufacturing Company. The capital stock of the company is $5,000,000. Among the Directors are Leland Stanford, Moses Hopkins, Irving M. Scott, and Gov. Perkins.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 4.--Mrs. Sarah Goldthwaite, age 65, while crossing Baltimore-street this afternoon was run over by one of the cars of the city passenger railway and so seriously injured that she died at the City Hospital to-night.

The Republican State Committee will begin to-day to distribute a circular letter asking for contributions for campaign purposes. It will be sent to Republicans generally, to private citizens as well as to office-holders, and as it is the only document of its kind that will be distributed during the campaign a liberal response ought to follow.

RALEIGH, N.C., Oct. 4.--At the Democratic Convention at Edenton to-day Thomas G. Skinner was nominated for Congress from tho First North Carolina District to fill the vacancy caused by the death of W.F. Pool.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., Oct. 4.--George Rogers, employed by the Central Bridge Company of Buffalo on the construction of the Michigan Central canillever bridge across the Niagara River, was engaged yesterday in adjusting an iron pier of 500 pounds weight in place.

The New-York State Bar Association will give a reception to Lord Chief-Justice Coleridge, in the Academy of Music, on Thursday next. ChiefJustice William C. Ruger, of the Court of Appeals of this State, will preside and deliver the opening address, after which ex-Secretary of State William ...

BOSTON, Oct. 4.--A novelty in the way of campaign documents is to be scattered broadcast throughout the State by Butler's managers.
ST. JOHN, La., Oct. 4.--Felix Demas, a brother of State Senator Demas, fell from a pecan tree yesterday and received internal injuries, from the effects of which he died to-day.

A prominent officer of the New-York Central and Hudson River Railroad said yesterday that the railroad company had not refused to abolish the charge of 1 cent per bushel for elevating grain into vessels and would not. It simply had not abolished ...

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Oct. 4.--The wedding of Richard Smith, Jr., son of the Hon. Richard Smith, of the Cincinnati Commercial Gazette, and Miss Carrle M. Tilden, daughter of Judge D.R. Tilden, occurred here to-night and was a brilliant affair.
A row, which might easily have resulted fatally, occurred last evening at 7:30 o'clock at the Twenty-eighth-street up-town-station of the Thirdavenue elevated railroad.
SANDUSKY, Oct. 4.--Judge Hoadly addressed a crowded house here last night. To-day he was prostrated and decided not to address the Toledo meeting. He left for Cincinnati via Toledo this evening.

Mr. J.J. Donohoe, the San Francisco banker, whose baggage was seized by the Customs Inspectors at this port several days ago, went to Washington last week and laid his case before the Secretary of the Treasury.

Delegates from the various news-dealers' organizations in this City and its vicinity met at No. 267 West Thirty-fourth-street last evening, Mr. Stevens, of the Up-town West Side Association, acted as Chairman.

Far over in the wilds of Brooklyn, away from the strife and turmoil of the city, is the little suburb of Picklesville, which is bounded by Bushwick Creek, the old Bushwick road, and Johnsonavenue. So rural is this place that no cars run through its quiet streets, beer saloons are infrequent, ...

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 4.--To-night, while the firemen were exercising with the Skinner truck, the ladders of which were being thrown up to a height of 90 feet, and two firemen were within five feet of the top, the ladders careened over and finally broke.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 4.--The members of the Legislative Committee on the Standard Oil Company investigation met this morning. Telegrams were received stating that ex-Auditor-General Miles was sick and unable to come to Philadelphia, and that ex-State Treasurer Butler would ...

RISING FAWN, Ga., Oct. 4.--In a quarrel over a business dispute to-day Benjamin Johnson shot Wat Woodson, killing him instantly. The ball entered Woodson's mouth and came out near the top of his head.

Lawyers, as a rule, will be found to approve the decision of the Court of Appeals affirming the legality of the Western Union stock watering. The court could not, or did not, find in the statutes any specific prohibition of the issue of stock dividends.

MENOMONEE, Wis., Oct. 4.--Last evening Christ Begulin, residing a few miles from this place, went hunting a bear that had been near his farm. While on the watch he thought he saw the bear and shot it. Being afraid to go further he returned home and said that he had shot the bear and that they would go out for it in the morning.

The inhabitants of Far Rockaway were aroused to a high pitch of indignation yesterday over a report that there was a diphtheria epidemic in the place, that the disease existed in nearly every house and was fast spreading to adjacent towns, and that 25 deaths had occurred since Sunday.
ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 4.--Fully 5,000 spectators were present at the Island Park races to-day. The first race was for a purse of $1,000; for the 2:22 class, and was won in three straight heats.

Hundreds of the regular daily patrons of the Roosevelt-street ferry sought in vain yesterday afternoon an opportunity to purchase tickets as they have been in the habit of doing from street arabs. They were compelled to buy their little pasteboards at the office of the ferry company.
President Arthur and party reached the Fifth-Avenue Hotel last night about 8:30, the special car in which they were traveling by the Wickford route being two hours late.

Our esteemed contemporary, the Sun, has taken the trouble to combat a popular error. The popular error is that a newspaper of eight pages costs much more money to produce than a paper of four pages.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4.--The extension of leave of absence on Surgeon's certificate of disability granted First Lieut. David J. Gibbon, Ninth Cavalry, has been further extended six months on Surgeon's certificate of disability. Leave of absence for six months has been granted Capt. Henry S. Howe, Seventeenth Infantry.
HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 4.--The seventh annual trotting meeting of the Horse Breeders' Association closed with the completion of to-day's programme. The attendance was very small.

John Chisholm, who is on trial at Newark, N.J., for the murder of his wife in that city on the evening of June 23, seemed to be ill at ease when he was led into Judge Depue's court-room yesterday morning.

With the death of Mrs. Susan Dayton Anderson comes into view another evidence of the ungratefulness of republics. Mrs. Anderson died on Wednesday last at the home of her daughter, Mrs. John F. Coyle, at Monroe, Orange County, N. Y. She was aged 84 years, 60 of which she had lived ...

LONDON, Oct. 4.--The Paris correspondent of the Times says it is now positively known that illness was not the cause of the absence of Gen. Thibandin, Minister of War, from the reception given to King Alfonso at the palace of the Elysee on Sunday.

Mrs. Augusta Cherrill, who is better known by her stage name of Miss Augusta Roche, is seeking her child, Rose Cherrill, aged 6 years. She says that her husband, Roderick Cherrill, has stolen the girl from her.

Dr. E.H. Janes and Assistant Engineer Golden have completed their investigation of the foul odors which have caused so much discomfort in the new County Court-house, and have filed their report with Public Works Commissioner Thompson.

Seventy-three large cases, containing scenery and properties to be used in the Star Theatre during Mr. Irving's engagement, were yesterday transferred from the pier of the Monarch Line, in Jersey City, to Manager Abbey's two storehouses, in West Sixteenth-street, between Tenth and Eleventh ...

Over $1,300 worth of opium was seized on the steamer Oceanic yesterday. Custom-house Officer John H. Breeze was in charge of the vessel, and his attention several times was attracted to two blocks of wood lying in close proximity to the coal shute.

DUNDEE, Oct. 4.--The whaling steamer Polynia, which has arrived here from Davis's Straits, reports that the natives at Saunders's Island stated that they saw five men at Etah, in Smith's Sound, north of Baffin's Bay,...

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4.--Several propositions are understood to have been made to the Treasury Department to secure permanency to the national banks. One is that the banks be allowed to deposit other securities than Government bonds to secure their circulation.
The fifth annual report of the Eighth Ward Mission, under the management of Mrs. M. Laidlaw, for the year ending Aug. 31, states that the object of the institution is to provide a home for ...
John Fisher, aged 60, a widower, committed suicide yesterday by shooting himself in the head at his home in Hicksville, Long Island.

A gentleman saw a powder-hern which he fancied in a pawnbroker's window in Thirdavenue, last Saturday, and brought it. After taking it home, while examining his new purchase, he noticed that there was something in the flask, and pulled out a five-hundred-dollar greenbank.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 4.--The jury in the case of Capt. Lewis C. Barker, on trial in the United States Circuit Court, charged with wrecking the schooner Mary D. Leach, to-day, under instructions of the court, returned a verdict of not guilty, the Judge stating that the evidence was not sufficient to warrant a conviction.

NEW-ORLEANS, Oct. 4.--At the meeting of the Board of Health to-night the Governor was requested to withdraw the quarantine proclamation from and after Nov. 1 and to modify the existing regulations so that from Oct. 15 vessels from infected ports will be detained not less than three days for inspection and disinfection.
CHICAGO, Oct. 4.--Delibe's new opera, "Lakme," which scored a Parisian success, had its initial presentation in America in this city tonight before a large audience.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4.--Secretary Folger said to-day that he had heard no complaint from the Civil Service Commissioners or from any one else in regard to the employment of packers at the New-York Appraiser's Office by Mr. Ketchum.

PITTSBURG, Oct. 4.--The scene of yesterday morning's fire attracted large crowds to-day. Men are at work clearing the debris away and delving into the heaps of charred ruins in the hope of finding something of value.

DUBLIN, Oct. 4.--The United Ireland, the League organ, states that an official intimately connected with the detection of crime in Dublin has been suspended from office. The cause of the suspension, it says, is likely to create a sensation when it is made public.

WHEELING, West Va., Oct. 4.--The excitement in the vicinity of Phillippi and Clarksburg over the exposure of the "Red Men" continues. Kittles, the man who confessed, pleaded guilty this morning on an "omnibus" charge, and was sentenced to imprisonment for nine years and four months.

MILWAUKEE, Oct. 4.--A sensational story which was lately telegraphed from Erie, Penn., to a Cleveland paper and widely copied by the press of the country, has set persons everywhere to rummage around where old books are stored, and...

THE NEW-YORK TIMES has reduced its price to 2 cents, or $6 per year. The Republicans of the United States will be grateful to THE TIMES for the step. The paper is the leading Republican organ in the country, free in its criticism, but faithful to party principle.
Mr. Alexander Sullivan, President of the Irish National League of America, addressed the New-York State Convention of the Ancient Order of Hiberniaus in this City last night.

ALLENTOWN, Penn., Oct, 4.--The General Conference of the Evangelical Church convened here this morning, and will remain in session 15 days. Ninety-four delegates are present, two coming from Switzerland, two from Germany, and five from Canada. The opening address was made by Bishop Esher, of Chicago, after which the Committees ...

DES MOINES, IOWA, Oct. 4.--The Post Office at Oskaloosa was burglarized last night. The safe was blown open and $600 worth of stamps, $100 in money, and 17 registered letters were taken. The stamps were mostly of an old issue of 2 and 1 cent denominations.

POTTSVILLE, Penn., Oct. 4.--Mrs. Cooch, wife of Thomas Cooch, one of the wealthiest and most prominent citizens in this city, was fatally burned this afternoon, and her daughter, a beautiful and accomplished young lady, was seriously, if not fatally, burned in trying to save her mother.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Oct. 4.--James McSteen was hanged this morning in the yard of the county jail. The execution was conducted quietly, and was witnessed by 200 persons. The doomed man retired early last evening and slept all night.
CHARLESTON, S.C., Oct. 4.--On last Saturday a whisky wagon passed through Anderson County, S.C., selling moonshine whisky. It stopped near Townville, and was visited by a number...
The launch of the cutter ileen, owned by Arthur Padelford, of Baltimore, took place yesterday, at Greenpoint.

William Cilley, formerly of the police force, but at present the special officer at the Reading Railroad station in this city, met with quite an adventure this morning. At an early hour he started out on a hunt for game among the numerous islands in the river.

Nearly 1,000 persons witnessed a display of stubbornness on the part of the liveried driver of an empty coupe in Wall-street, near the SubTreasury Building, about 2:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon. On one side of the street a long wagon was unloading some heavy blocks of stone.

MILLEDGEVILLE, Ga., Oct. 4.--William Barnes, aged 78 years, a prominent citizen and one of the publishers of the Recorder, committed suicide this morning by taking, strychnine. The act was brought about by intense physical suffering.

OSWEGO, N.Y., Oct. 4.--The Neal Block at the east end of the lower bridge, one of the finest business blocks in the city, was gutted by fire last night. The flames started in the attic over the Masonic Hall, which occupies the fourth floor, and...

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 4.--Ex-Senator Sharon yesterday began a suit in the United States Circuit Court against Aggie Hill, declaring that the alleged contract of marriage between himself and her (claimed by Miss Hill to be in her possession) is a fraudulent document, and the no such contract was ever signed by him or promise of marriage given.

MILWAUKEE, Oct. 4.--There was to have been a wedding on the south side yesterday, but it was indefinitely postponed on account of the mysterious disappearance of the bride-elect, John Sitichy wooed and, as he supposed, won the heart of, a handsome young lady named Mary Sherra. Preparations were made for an elaborate wedding.

Mgr. Capel lectured in the Academy of Music last night before a very large audience on "Charity versus Philanthropy." The proceeds of the lecture were for the benefit of St. Vincent's Hospital. ST. LOUIS, Mo., Oct. 4.--The State Federation of Trade and Labor Organizations met again this morning, with the President, R.W. Saur, in the chair.

Gen. A.P. Ketchum, United States Appraiser at this port, explained yesterday his reasons for appointing several additional openers and packers at slightly reduced salaries. He said that the amount of business required to be done in his department at this season of the year was unusually large, and to enable him to handle it properly ...

ROCHESTER, Oct. 4.--The delegates to the Republican Convention for the Seventh Judicial District assembled at noon to-day for the purpose of nominating two candidates for Justices of the Supreme Court. The district is composed of Cayuga, Monroe, Wayne, Livingston, Seneca,...
CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Oct. 4.--The miners at Pratt Mines, Ala., yesterday demanded an increase of pay from 45 to 50 cents per ton, which was acceded to by the company without discussion.
UTICA, N.Y., Oct. 4.--The benefits of railway competition are already apparent here. The West Shore route is nearly seven miles shorter than the New-York Central between Utica and Syracuse.
The Trustees of the Peabody education fund concluded their labors yesterday and adjourned to meet on the first Wednesday of October, 1884, unless sooner called together by President Winthrop.

"Ticket speculators are the most persevering and ingenious class of men on earth," said a boxoffice agent to a TIMES reporter yesterday. "If they had a little more capital and would devote their energies to some more extensive business, they would make their fortunes."
WILKESBARRE, Penn., Oct. 4.--An interesting case was decided by a jury here to-day. Henry A. Bates was employed by the Lehigh Valley Coal Company as a breaker boy.

The Metropolitans again defeated the Providence Club on the Polo Grounds yesterday. The visitors scored five unearned runs from the pitching of Lynch in the first inning.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 4.--The game of baseball played here to-day between the Cleveland League team and the Athletics, champions of the Association, was remarkable for the number of accidents that happened.

The New-York Academy of Medicine was crowded to overflowing last evening, the reason for the unusual gathering being the anticipation of a renewal of the angry discussion on the subject of the ethical code which was left undecided at the previous meeting.

ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 4.--At an adjourned meeting of the State Board of Equalization this morning Francis Lynde Stetson argued that the personal tax of New-York was too large by $29,547,074, this property being assessed under the corporation tax law.

While attempting to cross Atlantic-avenue at Waverly-avenue, Brooklyn, about 9 o'clock last evening, ex-Police Captain James Cassidy was run over and so badly injured that he died in the ambulance while being taken to his home, at No. 62 Underhill-avenue.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Oct. 4.--The National Association of Window Glass Workers has taken the first steps in a movement which will sadly cripple the window glass interests in this city if it is ever carried out successfully.
BOSTON, Oct. 4.--A decree of divorce was granted Harriet W. Levick from her husband, Gustavus Levick, to-day, in the Supreme Court.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 4.--H.B. Norman, age 55, an actor connected with the Modjeska company, which is now playing here, died suddenly today at his room in this city.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 7.--Archbishop Gibbons will leave this city to-morrow morning accompanied by the Rev. Dr. O'Connell, of Winchester, Va., for New-York, and will sail on Wednesday in the steamer Gallia, for Liverpool, en route for Rome.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Oct. 7.--A fine horse belonging to W.N. Seoville ran away to-day, the axl of the buggy to which it was attached broke, and one of the animal's hoofs was nearly torn off. The horse continued running, however, until it reached the railroad, where it balked in front of a train and was dashed to pieces, Nobody was seriously injured.
NEW-HAVEN, Oct. 6.--The sensational sermons of the Rev. M.H. Houghton on the Rose Ambler murder do not seem to have worked very greatly to his advantage.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 7.--Thirty-two of the drivers on the Belt Line of street cars quit work today, on an order from the Knights of Labor, of which organization they are members.

A tub of warm water stood in one corner of a room in a down-town museum. Four large glass cases took up most of the floor. One contained a dusty-looking alligator, nearly 5 feet long, with a nick in his tail. Monkeys of various kinds and degrees occupied two high cases.
A peculiar thunder-storm passed over Sudbury last Saturday evening. Only a sprinkling of rain fell, but the thunder and lightning for half an hour were incessant and almost deafening and blinding.

Early yesterday morning a fire broke out in Hoffner's fat-boiling establishment, at Blissville, Long Island. The building, a large frame structure, was destroyed. A few days ago the Sheriff of Queens County visited the place and destroyed the kettles in the building. The place had been indicted as a nuisance by the Grand Jury. The value of the building could not be ascertained. The fire is believed to have been of incendiary origin.
A young woman who landed at Castle Garden yesterday went into the office of the Commissioners of Emigration and in an agitated manner stated that she had been grossly insulted.
Chief-Justice C.D. Drake was a passenger by the steamer Spain which arrived from Liverpool yesterday.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 7.--Maud S. came through from New-York without accident and in excellent condition. Her groom says she recognized her old quarters at Chester Park, and showed unmistakable signs of pleasure at getting back again.
Elias Holm, a Russian sailor, apparently about 20 years of age, entered the East Fifty-firststreet police station at 8:30 o'clock last evening, and asked Sergt. Wassner for a night's lodging.

The Franklin Yacht Club held an open regatta yesterday on Newark Bay. Fifteen or 20 boats anchored off Ulrich's Bay Shore House, at Greenville, N.J., and waited for the wind to blow. At 2 P.M. 13 of them determined to start.

LONDON, Sept. 25.--A sort of international esprit de corps seems to influence theatrical audiences on both sides of the Atlantic, more particularly in regard to the performances of English and American artists.
CHICAGO, Oct. 7.--The committee recently appointed at a meeting of Irish citizens to confer with the Senators and Representatives of the State ...
The steam-ship Arizona, of the Guion Line, was sighted off Fire Island yesterday afternoon and is expected to reach her pier early this morning.

There will be a large supply of peaches--for the season of the year--in the market this week. There are a flood many nice Smocks to come yet from New-Jersey from the highlands of Huntingdon and Warren County, and nearly all of the New-Jersey crop of white clings, and what will be sent here from Morris White are yet to come.
The Rev. Dr. Henry C. Potter, Assistant Bishop-elect of the Diocese of New-York, preached last evening in Grace Chapel, in East Fourteenthstreet.

Anton Schilling, of No. 450 West Sixteenthstreet, had a self-cocking pistol. His friend, Elias Lutz, was examleing it last night, when it was discharged, and Schilling received a wound which will probably be fatal.
A farmer stepped into Wells, Stone Co.'s office yesterday morning and wanted to sell a load of apples.

The Rev. Mr. Eaton delivered a very fair and exhaustive sermon in the Church of the Divine Paternity last evening on "The Roman Catholic Church," taking for his text the golden rule, "Whatsoever ye would that men should do to you, do ye even so to them."

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Oct. 7.--A great case which had been in liquidation for 20 years was settled in the courts here on Saturday. It involved 2,000 acres of valuable coal land. In the Fall of 1880 a nephew of Col. C.M. Deringer, named J. Jones Clark, living in Philadelphia, obtained ...
They are having rain and snow in NewEngland. We are having drought and a thermometer in the nineties hero.

RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 7.--In a speech delivered by Senator Mahone at Zuni, Isle of Wight County, on Wednesday last, he was reported to have said that Mr. John Goode held his seat in Congress by fraudulent votes, and was therefore a cheat.

Because New-England is in advance of the other sections of the country--because there woman has, in the progres of civilization, become more of a unit than of a cipher in her individuality--is the reason that more divorces are granted there than in any other section.

Judge FULLERTON and Gen. PRYOR, who have been deputed to beard the British lion in his den, and, if possible, to rescue O'DONNELL from his clutches, are not perhaps the lawyers who could have been most appropriately selected for that mission.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 7.--William Franklin, Master of Transportation for the Ohio division of the Baltimore and Ohio Road, fell dead in the street at Newark, Ohio, on Saturday. Heart disease was the cause. He had spent his whole life in the railroad business, beginning as firemen and for the past 12 years he had been in the employ of the Baltimore and Ohio.

It is a good piece of news, in its way, that the committee which has in charge the Revolutionary monument at Newburg has decided not to erect the obelisk which it was some time ago reported that it had agreed on.
COPENHAGEN, Oct. 7.--The Czar and Prince of Wales will go to Sweden to-day on a hunting excursion.

I was shown the other day a copy of the first edition of the Maryland Journal, a weekly paper, the publication of which was begun in Baltimore on Friday, Aug. 20, 1773, by William Goddard, and has continued its career, though under different names, over since, and is now known as the Baltimore American and Commercial Advertiser.

WHEELING, West Va., Oct. 7.--The excitement in this State regarding the doings of Red men in Harrison and Barbour Counties, in connection with the trial at Clarksburg of Huffman, the mail robber, has scarcely died away when the Red Men of Doddridge County are heard from.
MONTREAL, Oct. 7.--The Rev. Dr. Ewer, of St. Ignatius Church, New-York, was prostrated while delivering a sermon to-day at St. John's Episcopal Church by a stroke of paralysis.
The electric lights on Broadway from Canal to Fourteenth street, on Fifth-avenue from Eighth to Fourteenth street, and in Washington Park went out suddenly about 6:30 o'clock last evening.

The Professor of Arabic who met his death during the Egyprian Campaign which ended in the occupation of Egypt by British troops seems to have had a true genius for languages. His early life was that of twenty other boys.

The concert at the Casino was not up to the usual standard last night. It had a strong and not over-wholesome flavor of the cafe chaniant. Mr. Aronson was possibly of the opinion that because French chansons were to be the leading features of the evening the audience that came to hear them would not care to listen to orchetral music of a high order.

St. Ann's Church, in Eighteenth-street, near Fifth-avenue, celebrated its thirty-first anniversary yesterday. A sermon was preached by the Rev. Mr. Krans and interpreted for deaf-mutes by the Rev. Dr. Galiaudet.
SALT Lake, Utah, Oct. 7.--Col. James Tullis, a special land agent of the Government, who has been investigating the land frauds in the Territories, is in this city.

John Mueller, ex-Department Commander of the Grand Army of the Republic of the Department of New-Jersey, will give the order, "ForWard, march! guide right!" promptly at 10:30 o'clock this morning at Newark, N.J., as Grand Marshal of the procession in celebration of the bi-centennial of the German pioneers in that city.

PORT JERVIS, N.Y., Oct. 7.--At the town election in Forestburg. Sullivan County, last March, Benjamin Case and Andrew Campbell were rival candidates for Supervisor. The strife was very bitter between them. When the Inspectors of Election counted the votes they announced that it was a tie.

The White Star steam-ship Germanic reached the bar Saturday evening at 7 o'clock, and, owing to heavy weather, was unable to cross until midnight, so that the first glimpse which Mme. Marcella Sembrich, the prima donna, obtained of the shores of America, was soon after sunrise yesterday morning, ...

UTICA, N.Y., Oct. 7.--The Republican convention for Herkimer County to nominate candidates for the Assembly and county officers met in Herkimer yesterday, and adjourned at midnight till Oct. 9 without making nominations. The convention balloted 75 times for a candidate for County Judge, the voting varying little at any time from the last ballot, which stood: S.S. Morgan, 19; Charles J. Palmer, 15; Clinton A. Moore, 12; Josiah A. Steele, 11.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7.--Up to 7 o'clock this evening the State Deparment had received no advices that an outbreak had occurred in Canton, or that United States Consul Seymour had been killed. The department telegraphed to China early this morning upon learning of the published rumor of Consul Seymour's death, but no reply to the inquiry has as yet been received.
PARIS, Sept. 24.--It is commonly supposed that at Paris a topic is old after eight days; unfortunately the Tonquin question is an exception.
We raise grain not only for our own people but also for the nations of Europe, and our prosperity depends in a great degree upon the demand for our breadstuffs in foreign markets.

Dr. S. Weir Mitchell, of this city, the eminent specialist in nervous disorders, recently read before the Philadelphia College of Physicians an interesting paper containing the experiences of Capt Robert Catlin, of the United States Army who claims to be able to foretell the approach of storms by pains resulting from the loss of a foot, crushed in battle, in August, 1864.

The alleged conduct of a Massachusetts Postmistress toward her male subordinate will revive the suspicions of those rude cynics who have maintained that no Postmistress could be trusted to preserve the mails inviolate.

ATLANTA, Ga., Oct. 7.--The alliance of the Western and Atlantic and the Georgia Central and roads under its control, which was outlined in a dispatch yesterday, virtually unifies the roads in the State and practically puts them under one management.

Most gratifyingly show a marked decrease of disease in the City for the past few weeks as compared with the same time a year ago. Much may be attributed to the favorable weather, but still more to the wise and more general use of disinfectants.

The Rev. Dr. W.J.R. Taylor delivered a discourse yesterday before the Reformed Pastors' Association, at No. 34 Vesey-street, upon the subject of "Bribery, Past and Present."

CITY OF MEXICO, Mexico, Oct. 8.--The paymaster of the Mexican National Railway was robbed of $11,000 in the station in this city last night by his servant. A reward of $1,000 has been offered for the capture of the robber.

At a meeting of the Constitution Club, held last evening at No. 371 Fulton-street, Brooklyn, A. H. Osborne presiding, resolutions were unanimously adopted favoring the re-election of Mayor Low and pledging him their support. The club resolved not to take action in reference to Senatorial candidates until the regular party nominations have been made.
Typhoid fever, scarlet fever, and diphtheria are on the increase in Boston. Last week there were 60 cases of typhoid fever there.

LONDON, Oct. 8.--Postmaster-General Fawcett announces that it is not intended by the Government after August, 1884, to renew the present contracts for the conveyance of mails between Great Britain and the United States.

The well-known, if not celebrated, Mr. Frederic Gebhard returned from Europe, unheralded, by the steam-ship Arizona, and is now in this City.

LOWELL, Mass., Oct. 8.--This afternoon the locomotive of a gravel train on the Boston and Maine Road was run into near here by a freight train. The engineer and fireman jumped from the engine without shutting off the steam and the engine ...

A meeting of the General Committee of the United Veterans, formerly Hancock Veterans, was held last night at No. 708 Broadway.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 8.--Early this morning burglars operated in Hightstown, but with small success.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Oct. 8.--It is reported to-night that one of Montgomery's quarantine officers, who has just returned from Brewton, states that the malignant fever now raging there is nothing elfe than yellow fever, and is spreading in the village.

Great interest was excited yesterday in railway circles by the report that the Pennsylvania Railroad was to be ordered to-day or to-morrow to "turn to the wall" the tickets by its own roads and the Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul to Omaha.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8, 1883. The Commissioner of Patents has overruled the Board of Examiners-in-Chief and reversed their decision in the case of Sawyer and Mann against Edison, involving priority of invention of the incandescent conductor for an electric lamp formed of carbonized paper. Priority of invention is awarded to Sawyer and Mann, who, it is held, completed their invention at least one year in advance of Edison.
The Boston Club again defeated the Metropolitan nine on the Polo Grounds yesterday. The Boston men batted just when hits were needed, and in consequence none of their players were left on the bases.

BARNESVILLE, Ga., Oct. 8.--Samset McAlister, who lives at Central Point, an out-of-the-way hamlet in the lower part of Pike County, became somewhat unsettled on religious subjects a few weeks ago, but his ailment was not expected to take a violent turn.

NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., Oct. 8.--Henry Geier, age 42, and Wenzel Goske, age 38, Bohemian weavers in the Wamsutta Mills, were drowned this afternoon by the capsizing of their boat while sailing.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Oct. 8.--An Indian Territory dispatch says that the Delaware payment commenced to-day at Chelsea. Several thousand dollars will be paid to such as are entitled to it. An immense crowd of Indians are present, and the scene is one of confusion and grotesque activity. The distribution is made under the supervision of United States Indian Agent Tuffts. There was no disturbance to-day.

Two tramps knocked at the basement door of No. 173 First-street, South Brooklyn, about 10 o'clock yesterday morning. The house is occupied by Mr. John Allen, a widower, and his houskeeper, Annie Stephens, a middle-aged woman, was alone, her employer having gone to business, when the tramps called.

If Newark has within its limits persons who are not of German birth or descent they were net very prominent yesterday, Germans packed the sidewalks and monopolized a great portion of the broad streets and avenues.

The new second mortgage bonds of the Northern Pacific Railroad were objects of much talk in Wall-street yesterday. It was reported early in the day, with a semblance of authority, that the entire $18,000,000 which are to be issued had been subscribed for.

Lilian Holmes, a pretty woman of 18 years, went to the Eighth Precinet Station-house last night and said that she had either lost or had been abandoned by her husband Henry, a machinist, to whom she was married last week in Philadelphia.

A special meeting of the Republican Central Committee was held last evening for the purpose of adopting the call for the primaries and the fixing of the dates and places of holding the conventions. Charles S. Spencer presided.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 8.--The Executive Committee of the Ohio River pool is in secret session here perfecting and ratifying the arrangements made at previous meetings in Cincinnati and Chicago and to fix rates between Chicago and Ohio River points.

About 1:55 o'clock this morning the policemen on duty in Cortlandt-Street discovered flames shooting rapidly up through the elevator shaft of the building at No. 34, a brown-stone-front four-story structure. This was occupied by E. Wells Sackett Rankin, stationers and lithographers. The fire spread so rapidly that second and third alarms were sent out immediately.
NATCHEZ, Miss., Oct. 8.--James Freeman, of Concordia Parish, La., while riding a spirited horse reined him up suddenly. The animal fell over backward on his rider and crushed him to death.

A certain married pair were discussing the propriety of giving a wedding present the other evening, and, as might happen in the best regulated families, failed to agree as to the object and price. The lady desired to send a cut-glass pitcher; the gentleman scoffed at this idea, declaring that nothing but silver would satisfy his taste.
The result of the charter election in Newark to-day will probably give Lang, Republican, 1,000 majority for Mayor, and give the Republicans 10 out of 17 Aldermen, making the Council a tie.

ROCHESTER, Oct. 8.--Workmen are engaged in grading for the West Shore Railway at Macedon, a small village a few miles from this city. On Saturday, by the premature explosion of a blast, two of them were fatally injured.

When the Bureau of Election was closed last night, nearly every one of the 688 election districts had its full Board of Election Inspectors. The vacancies that will be reported this morning will be filled by the Police Board, who will hold continuous session during the day.

MAQUOKETA, Iowa, Oct. 8.--A sensational church row occurred here Sunday night at the Union Prohibition meeting, composed of the Methodist and Congregational denominations. The meeting occurred at the Methodist church, and as it had been announced that the people would be told how to vote the edifice was densely crowded.

MARLBOROUGH, N.Y., Oct. 8.--Reports received to-day from the extensive grape-growing sections along the Hudson Valley tend to show that great damage was done by the severe frosts on Thursday and Friday nights.

A paragraph printed in one of the City papers yesterday said that the suit brought last week by the Wells-Fargo Express Company asking for an injunction against the Northern Pacific Express Company was the beginning of a fight between the Central and Northern Pacific Roads.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8.--The strike of the street-car drivers, which began yesterday on the Belt Line, extended to-day to all the important lines in the city, and since 9 o'clock to-night street-car travel has been suspended on every line except two, which are comparatively unimportant. More than 200 drivers and about 80 conductors have quit work.

The steam-ship Arizona arrived at her pier yesterday morning, and Signor Campanini, the great tenor, who was a passenger, had the pleasure of setting his foot on American soil after an absence of nearly two years.

With the approach of cold weather the Le Boutillier Brothers have placed on exhibition a large and varied stock of Fall and Winter goods, and their large store at Nos. 31 and 33 West Twenty-third-street is crowded daily with ladies seeking to purchase a seasonable outfit.
LAFAYETTE, Ind., Oct. 8.--The firm of Warwick Florer, dry goods, have assigned. Liabilities, $30,000; assets, $45,000.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 8.--The State deaf and dumb institution will be opened in this city to-morrow for the free education of deaf mutes from 5 to 21 years of age whose parents are indigent. Hitherto the indigent deaf mutes of New-Jersey have had to seek education under warrant of the Governor in the asylums of other States. Prof. Weston Jenkins, late of the New-York Deaf and Dumb Asylum, will be in charge of the institution.

ALBANY, Oct. 8.--The celebrated bribery case of the long Senatorial contest of 1881 was moved before Judge Osborn, in the Court of Oyer and Terminer, this afternoon. Although it has been in the courts for about two years and a half, interest in the action has not died out. The basis of the indictment formed the most sensational incident of that political struggle.
NEW-HAMBURG, Ontario, Oct. 8.--Denison Crease, private bankers, failed to-day. It is expected that ther creditors will be paid nearly in full.

Early yesterday morning Peter Langdon and John Kane, both young men who are unfavorably known to the police, were stabbed and cut at Van Brunt and Union streets, Brooklyn, by unknown men who are supposed to be Italians. Kane has suffered so from loss of blood that it is feared he will die. Both men live near the scene of the stabbing.
WILKESBARRE, Penn., Oct. 8.--The convention of the Wyoming Annual Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church began its session in the church at Kingston this evening.

PORT TOWNSEND, Washington Territory, Oct. 8.--Custom Inspector Matheson captured a sloop with 11 Chinamen who were being smuggled across from British Columbia.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 8.--The second annual convention of the Church Temperance Society was held this evening in Holy Trinity Church. The Right Rev. Bishop Williams, D.D., of Connecticut, presided.

Mr. Daniel Frohman, who is always on the alert to secure good players for the Madison-Square Theatre, yesterday signed a contract for three years with Mr. R.B. Mantell, now Miss Daven port's leading support. The agreement included provision for a starring tour in the future. Mr. Mantell will appear early next year at the Madison Square.

The McDonough Telephone Company, which was incorporated at Albany last week, is composed largely of telephone men who have been connected with other companies. The capital stock is $1,000,000, divided into shares of $100 each, and by the articles of incorporation it can be increased to $20,000,000.

LYNCHBURG, Va., Oct. 8.--James E. Bowman, of New-York, and Ellisoa Muller, of Atlanta, were arrested here yesterday, en route to NewJersey, on a telegram from the Chief of Police of Atlanta charging the man with felony.
MONTREAL, Oct. 8.--William Henry Mussen, City Cashier, has absconded, having embezzled a large sum from the Treasury of the corporation. The actual amount of the defalcation is unknown.
BERLIN, Oct. 8.--The Government has prohibited the importation of swine from Russia into Germany.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8.--Judge-Advocate-General Swaim, it is understood, will not approve the finding of the court-martial which tried Lieut. Simpson, of the Third Cavalry, and found him guilty of the charge of conduct unbecoming an officer and a gentleman. Finding him guilty, the court-martial recommended his dismissal from the service.
BALTIMORE, Oct. 8.--Miss Emily McTavish, daughter of Mrs. Charles Carroll McTavish, took her final vows yesterday as a religiouse at Mount De Sales Convent, near Catonsville, Baltimore County.

It would be difficult to find anywhere a set of men of more hale and vigorous appearance than the members of the quoiting clubs who gathered yesterday afternoon at the Ogden Farm, High Bridge, to compete for the amateur championship of America.

Joseph Jefferson and a remarkably good comedy company began a six weeks' engagement at the Union-Square Theatre last evening. The house was crowded to its utmost, and the applause was unstinted.

The New York Presbytery held its first meeting of the season yesterday, at the Scotch Church, in Fourteenth-street, near Sixth-avenue. The Rev. Dr. J.M. Worrall was elected Moderator.

A question at issue in the Supreme Court is as to the liability of Lawyer Francis N. Shepard on a note for $600 which he have a gentleman whom he calls Zachariah Diederick, but who calls himself Robert H. Deaderick. David Lob recently began a suit to recover the amount of the note.

The match race between the sloop yachts Gracie and Fannie will take place to-day. The greatest possible interest has been aroused by this race in yachting circles, and it is expected that considerable money will change hands. About $25,000 has been staked on the contest, one gentleman having four bets of $1,000 each.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8.--The President on the 4th inst. accepted two sections of the Northern Pacific Railroad: one of 75 miles in Montana Territory, the other of 36 3-10 miles, from the Columbia River to Portland, Oregon.

The funeral of Mrs. Elizabeth Stoddard Huntington, wife of Mr. C.P. Huntington, was largely attended yesterday forenoon. Services were conducted at Mr. Huntington's residence, No. 65 Park-avenue, by the Rev. Charles H. Eaton, of the Church of the Divine Paternity.
The American Academy of Medicine will hold its annual meeting to-day and to-morrow in the hall of the New-York Academy of Medicine, No. 12 West Thirty-first-street.

It is very important that as many voters as possible should register to-day, and thus secure the right to vote at the coming election. ST. LOUIS, Oct. 8.--Police Sergeant Jenks, of the Third Police Precinct, was shot and killed this afternoon at 4:30 by Sadie Hill, a negress and one of the most notorious characters in the Third ...

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Oct 8.--Col. Hans Mattson, of Minnesota, Consul to Calcutta, in company with a number of Holland capitalists, has purchased a large stock ranch in New-Mexico known as the Maxwell Ranch. Col. Mattson has been offered and has accepted the position of manager of the new enterprise.

The Treasurer of the Bridge Trustees reported at their meeting yesterday that for the 19 weeks ending Oct. 4 the receipts from foot passengers had been $34,464; from vehicles, $31,563, and the revenue from the cars for the 7 days that they had run $3,936, making a total of $69,983.

MENASHA, Wis., Oct. 8.--This community was somewhat startled this morning by the announcement of the failure of the Menasha Chair Company, an institution which was generally considered to be rock-rooted financially.
ALBANY, Oct. 8.--The Railroad Commission has to-day made public its "decision" in relation to the accident on the Long Island Railroad, at Long Island City, on the evening of Sept. 11.
CINCINNATI, Oct. 8.--There has been intense activity among the workers of both parties to-day, and at the head-quarters it will be continued during the greater part of the night.
At the annual meeting of the Suburban Rapid Transit Company yesterday the old Board of Directors was re-elected. Mr. Samuel R. Filley, the President was absent, owing to severe illness.

BOSTON, Oct. 8.--The Roman Catholic Diocese of Portland, comprising Maine and NewHampshire, is about to be divided in two, because of the increase in the Catholic population within the past five years.

DES MOINES, Oct. 8.--The Iowa prohibition campaign will end to-morrow with the crucial test of the ballot. The Republican leaders admit that there is likely to be a small loss from the usual majority because of the prohibition question, but they think this will be offset by a larger vote than usual.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8.--Gen. Frederick T. Dent, Colonel Third Artillery, has applied to the President to be placed on the retired list on Dec. 1, under the 40 years' service provision. This retirement will promote Lieut. Col. Horatio Gates Gibson to be Colonel, Major L.L. Langdon to be Lieutenant Colonel, Capt.
Official notice is given of the dissolution of the New-York Stock Clearing-house Association, which recently experimented with Mr. Osterberg's system of clearances.

The Railroad Commission has made a report of facts and conclusions regarding the recent accident on the Long Island Railroad near the station at Long Island City, in which it condemns the carelessness and incompetency of the engineer and the negligence of the conductor and rather mildly censures the company.

MILWAUKEE, Oct. 8.--The markets on 'Change to-day were much depressed. Wheat opened cent lower than at the close on Saturday, ruled panicky, and at the close of the noon board was about 2 cents lower than a week ago. This was in the face of a somewhat encouraging Beerbohm.

MONTREAL, Oct. 8.--A confidence operator named G.C. Wheeler, with 10 aliases, was arrested to-day on 30 charges of a serious kind of fraud committed in the Western States. Extradition proceedings will be instituted.
NEWPORT, Oct. 8.--Some six months since Mr. Pierre Lorillard, of New-York, was approached by a New-York real estate broker with a request that he name an amount for his residence on Ochre Point.
DES MOINES, Oct. 8.--William Hart, a wellto-do farmer, who recently sold his farm and moved to Knoxville, committed suicide yesterday evening by shooting himself through the temple.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 8.--There was a fair attendance at the races to-day. The weather was fine and the track was in good condition.

John Lloyd, a private in the Thirteenth Regiment, Brooklyn, fell to the floor last evening in the armory, on Atlantic-avenue, during the ladder drill and was seriously injured. Lloyd, who fell a distance of 10 feet, was taken to his home at No. 202 Fifth-avenue.

NEW-ORLEANS, Oct. 8.--Henry Ward Beecher lectured to-night at the St. Charles Theatre on "The Reign of the Common People." The theatre was about half filled, but the audience was attentive and respectful. Some points made by the speaker received applause, particularly his attacks upon Butler. The people who would vote for Butler were not the class who were present.

TITUSVILLE, Penn., Oct. 8.--An immense well was struck in the Balltown Oil Pool late last night. It is owned by the Howe Oil Company. The production for the first hour was 165 barrels. The well, however, has declined with remarkable rapidity, and is now doing only 12 barrels an hour.
Two fires last night in the dry goods district, one in the storage warehouse of a twine and yarn mill up town, and one in a shirt factory, did damage amounting to between $166,000 and $186,000.
The regular annual "cane rush" between the Sophomores and Freshmen of Columbia College came off, somewhat reluctantly, at the old Manhattan Grounds, in Fifty-sixth-street, yesterday afternoon.

JACKSON, Mo., Oct. 8.--Petitions for a mandamus to compel the Governor, Lieutenant-Governor, and Secretary of State to revoke the appointment of one of the Commissioners of Elections recently appointed in the counties of Madison and Hinds, and to appoint one of a different political party, were filed in the Supreme Court today before Judge Wharter.

SAVANAH, Ga., Oct. 8.--About 11 o'clock last night the cargo of cotton in the forward compartment of the steamer Endymion was discovered to be on fire. Before the flames were extinguished 150 bales had been burned. Five hundred bales were damaged by water.

MATAWAN, N.J., Oct. 8.--The Republican Convention for Monmouth County, held at Freehold to-day, was the largest and most enthusiastic held in the county for many years. Sherman B. Oviatt, of Wall Township, was nominated for County Clerk.

Nothing is said nowadays by Mr. Jay Gould or his friends about his proposed long ocean voyage in the sumptuous Atalanta. Early last Spring it was stated, with much positiveness, that he would start some time in October.

OTTAWA, Oct. 8.--Lieut.-Col. MacPherson, Secretary of the Dominion Rifle Association, has received the English Challenge Shield, which was presented by the auxiliary forces of Great Britain for competition by the Canadian militia. It is a handsome silver shield over two feet high, mounted on ebony.

The registration of voters for the election to be held on Tuesday, Nov. 6, will begin to-day in this City, and the registry-books will be open in each election district from 8 A.M. to 9 P.M., so that all classes of citizens will be able to attend to their duties as electors if they wish to do so.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 8.--The General Convention of the Protestant Episcopal Church in the United States reassembled this morning in the Church of the Holy Trinity.

The recent conference of District Attorney McKeen with Mayor Edson, it appears, was to urge the appointment of Deputy Assistant District Attorney Henry C. Allen to the position of Police Justice, two vacancies occurring this Fall.

Dissatisfaction over the management of the affairs of the Amie Consolidated Mining Company, whose shaft is in Leadville, Col., has aroused a determination on the part of some of the stockholders to oust the present board of officers.
INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Oct. 8.--The fourth murder and suicide combined upon the criminal record of this city within the past three years occurred this afternoon about 5 o'clock.

"Joe" Pendergrast, the heavy-weight hitter of Brooklyn, and Capt. James C. Daly, the athlete, faced each other in the 24-foot ring yesterday, in the ball-room of the Silver Lake Hotel, Staten Island.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 8.--President Arthur arrived in Washington at 10:40 o'clock this evening. He was accompanied by two friends, and was driven to the White House.

PLATTSBURG, Oct. 9.--At the Republican Senatorial Convention for the Nineteenth District, held at Plattsburg to-day, the Hon. S.W. Bowen was renominated by acclamation.

The State Senate which will be elected in New-York this year will take part in the election of the next United States Senator. This fact will show to every voter the importance of the election and the necessity of securing proper nominations for the Legislature.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 9.--The inquest over the victims of the collision at Susquehanna-avenue and American-street last Friday, ended to-day. One of the jurors refused to agree with his fellows on a verdict.

Thomas Doyle and Martin McDonald, two baggage-handlers employed at Castle Garden, indulged in a prize-fight Monday evening in the Battery Park. Four rounds, under the Marquis of Queensberry's rules, were fought, and Doyle succeeded in knocking out his opponent.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Oct. 9.--Samuel Graner, the victim of the dynamite outrage at Pawling, died there at 11:40 o'clock this morning. Coroner Jenks held a post-mortem examination.

OSWEGO, Oct. 9.--Patrick Driscoll, a mason attempted suicide to-night by cutting a fearful gash in his throat. He lost a large quantity of blood, but may recover. Temporary insanity resulting from domestic troubles was the cause of the deed.

The Executive Council of the building trades yesterday ordered a strike of all union men employed on the row of buildings between Eighty sixth and Eighty-seventh streets, now being erected by Contractor Chrystie.

Mrs. Elizabeth Mills, who was stabbed in the left breast by her husband, George Mills, at their residence, No. 148 North-sixth-street, Brooklyn, on Saturday evening, died last night. Mills had been drinking for several days and he stabbed his wife because she refused to give him money to buy beer. He is under arrest.

Mr. Gustav Amberg has sold the right to produce "Der Bettelstudent" in Philadelphia and the South to Mr. E.E. Rice, and the New-England rights in the same work to Mr. Hastings of the Boston Bijou Theatre. This latest and most successful of the German comic operas will be produced in this City at the Casino.

James S. Maxwell, a member of the firm representing the Bald Eagle and Empire Flouring Mills, Millersburg, Ohio, came to this City last Saturday and took rooms at Smith McNell's Hotel, in Greenwich-street. He was assigned to rooms Nos. 79, 83, and 86. He had two sachels as baggage.

BOSTON, Mass., Oct. 9.--The creditors of T. M. Rhodes, the embarrassed commission merchant in boots and shoes, at a meeting to-day appointed the following committee to investigate his affairs: A.L. Coolidge, C.E. Grinnell, and A.M. Stone. The liabilities were stated at $240,060 and the assets at $192,868.

POTTSVILLE, Penn., Oct. 9.--Mrs. Thomas Cooch, who was so terribly burned last Thursday morning while engaged in making apple butter, an account of which appeared in THE TIMES, died this evening after great suffering.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 9.--This was the twelfth day of the Fall meeting of the Louisville Jockey Club. The weather was warm, the attendance fair, and the track in good condition.

ROCHESTER, Oct. 9.--At the Buffalo Convention Peter Doyle, one of the Erie delegates, voted for Maynard and against Purcell. This excited great surprise, and aroused the indignation of Purcell's friends.
HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Oct. 9.--Mrs. O'Connor, a widow, died yesterday from malpractice. Dr. Archibald Lawson, a prominent physician, is implicated, and has left the city to avoid arrest.

The report of the Commissioners of Accounts on the results of their investigation into the frauds in the Controller's office shows up, as clearly perhaps as it could be done with the means at their command, the methods by which the frauds were committed.

PARIS, Oct. 9.--The Figaro states that the agreement entered into by France with the Black Flags in Tonquin grants the latter their arrears of pay and the free possession of the territory between Lao-Kai and Hung-Hoa.
Miss Anne W. Townsend, daughter of Mr. Charles H. Townsend, of Clifton, Staten Island, was married yesterday to Mr. J.H. Scribner, of Stapleton, at St. John's Church, in Clifton.
WILKESBARRE, Penn., Oct. 9.--Two tramps entered the residence of Franklin Monroe at Hunlock's Creek this afternoon and acted in a boisterous manner.
Robert Prior, the proprietor of stables at No. 204 East One Hundred and Twenty-ninthstreet, was the victim of a swindler yesterday.

PARIS, Oct. 9.--The police are making an investigation into the causes of the explosions at Lyons and Bordeaux. It is generally believed that they were the work of revolutionists, with the view of creating public alarm.
OSWEGO, N.Y., Oct. 9.--Asa W. Dagg, age 16, was found crushed to death between the bumpers of two flat cars on the Midland Railroad today. It is not known how he got there.

The Republicans of the Twelfth Senatorial District, comprising the counties of Rockland and Westchester, held a convention at the Vincent House, Tarrytown, yesterday, for the purpose of nominating a candidate for State Senator.

LONDON, Oct. 9.--The Newmarket second October meeting began yesterday. The great event of the meeting, the race for the Cesarewitch Stakes, was run to-day and was won by Mr.G. Lambert's 3-year-old oh. c. Don Juan.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 9.--James W. Williams, an elegantly dressed middle-aged man, pleaded guilty, in the Court of Quarter Sessions to-day, to a charge of aggravated assault and battery upon his wife.

George Johnson, who was conductor of the Far Rockaway train which came into collision with the Long Branch train at Springfield and caused the loss of two lives, was arrested yesterday, he having been indicted by the Grand Jury for manslaughter. He was required to give $1,500 bail to await trial.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 9.--Hoadly has probably carried Hamilton County by 2,500 majority. There was much scratching and the count is proceeding very slowly. Five precincts out of upward of 100 give Republican gains over the vote of one year ago of 160.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 10--1:30 A.M.--The later returns are much more favorable for the Republicans. The vote on the county ticket is likely to be close. The Republicans have perhaps elected their Treasurer and County Commissioner.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 9.--The October meeting of the Narragansett Driving Association opened at Narragansett Park to-day. The track was in good order and the trotting was very good. The favorites in the pools won both races. Following are the summaries:

Aaron Newman, who keeps a shoe store on the first floor of the two-story frame building No. 696 Atlantic-avenue, Brooklyn, discovered about 4 o'clock yesterday morning that the upper part of the house was on fire.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Oct. 9.--A call has been issued for a convention of the river coal miners next Monday to arrange for the appointment of a Board of Arbitration to settle the differences between employer and employe. A number of mines along the river are now idle pending the fixing of a mining rate for the Winter months.

The population of the town rushed panic-stricken into the streets. A church, the military barracks, and one dwelling-house were more or less damaged.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 9.--The Sheriff of Carter County and a posse of nine armed men with double-barreled guns, loaded with buck-shot, arrived here to-day to convey Ellis Craft to Grayson for execution on Friday. ST. LOUIS, Mo., Oct. 9.--The St. Louis Club easily defeated the New-Yorks to-day. The latter were out on a big drunk last night, and several members of the team did not retire until 5 o'clock this morning. This accounts for their exhibition of to-day, which was the poorest ever given by a League team on the St. Louis grounds.

Hall, the absconding Middlesex County Freeholder and Pennsylvania Railroad civil engineer, as Captain of Company D, Third Regiment National Guard, was to-day declared vacated by Gov. Ludlow. COLUMBUS, Oct. 10.--The Democrats have succeeded in capturing everything. It has been more than 40 years since they have held all the avenues to political power, but they have secured them at last, and by an accident. This is the second time the temperance agitators have defeated the Republican Party.

The Jewish fast of Yom Kippur, or Day of Atonement, began at sunset last evening and will end to-night. During its continuance the orthodox Jew permits no food or water to pass his lips, and remains continuously in his place of worship confessing his sins and praying for forgiveness.

PARIS, Oct. 1.--The "bunko" man has made his appearance in the French capital. To a partial extent only has his game been a success as yet. The probabilities are that it will never be so successful a method of swindling as it has been in New-York.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Oct. 10.--There are eight or ten rice mills in New-Orleans, and ever since the first receipts of the new rice crop these mills have been kept running night and day until now the production of clean rice has somewhat burdened the market. CHICAGO, Oct. 10.--Secret Service officials here report the arrest at Grand Forks, Dakota, of three men supposed to have been engaged in printing and circulating spurious ten-dollar silver certificates.

It was expected by railroad men that the decision in the case of the Pennsylvania Railroad, which was accused of cutting the rate on tickets to Omaha, would be issued officially yesterday, but it was not made public.

An employe of Robert Prior, the liveryman, of East One Hundred and Twenty-ninth street, whose cart and horse were driven off on Tuesday by a Miss Smith, but not returned, at 5:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon took two patients to the Bloomingdale Asylum.

Services in honor of the Virgin Mary are held at frequent intervals in all Roman Catholic churches during the present month. Last evening between 800 and 900 persons were gathered in Saint Joseph's Church, at Sixth-avenue and West Washington-place.

NIAGARA FALLS, Ontario, Oct. 10.--The Maid of the Mist ran the rapids of the Niagara River to-day. She was cut loose from her moorings about 2:40 P.M. and passed through the rapids safely, remaining in the whirlpool 10 minutes and then proceeding down the river. Ten thousand spectators were present.

The body of Mrs. Isador French, of East Seventy-third-street, was taken last night to Wash ington. It is the intention to have it cremated there, and the ashes will be returned to the family in this City. Mr. French is a German of Jewish persuasion, and is a dealer in neckties.
BUFFALO, Oct. 10.--The contest of Mrs. Fillmore's will before the Surrogate is again proceeding. Testimony to prove her of unsound mind when her will was made has been taken during the past two days.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 11.--A special meeting of the Council of the New-York and Philadelphia Synod of the Reformed Episcopal Church was held in the chapel of the Second Reformed Episcopal Church this morning. Bishop William R. Nicholson, the Pastor, presiding.

DANVILLE, Va., Oct. 11.--John A. Ferguson, who shot Policeman Parks on Sept. 6 last while the latter was attempting to arrest him, from the effects of which wound Parks died the next day, was on trial yesterday and to-day in the Hastings Court on a charge of murder.

The Brooklyn Republican Campaign Committee engaged head-quarters yesterday in the Garfield Building, at Court and Remsen streets. Daily sessions of the committee will be held until the election. Mr. William H. Loaycraft has been made Chairman, and a sub-committee has been appointed to confer with the organizers of the Citizens' meeting at which Mayor Low was renominated.
LONDON, Oct. 11.--Mr. Henry Irving, the actor, and Miss Ellen Terry, the actress, sailed from Liverpool for New-York today on the steamer Britannic.

Quite a novel and ingenious device is that adopted by the Democrats in some of the southwestern counties of Virginia. A small white flag is nailed upon the house of every Democrat, and the consequence is that these ensigns are displayed upon almost all the houses of well-to-do people. The "object lesson" is said to disturb Mahone very much, as it is ocular proof that his party is opposed by the respectable classes.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Oct. 11.--Dr. W.H. Bartran, of Green Bay, United States Examining Surgeon of the Pension Department, was arrested and brought to Milwaukee this morning by a Deputy United States Marshall, charged with taking fees for the examination of applicants for pension.

John E. McCann, a clerk in the office of Russell Sage, No. 71 Broadway, was arrested yesterday morning by Court Officer Murray on a complaint of assault made by John O. Ball, managing clerk of Francis Speir, Jr., a lawyer, at No. 45 William street.

ALBANY, Oct. 11.--The Railroad Commission has appointed a public hearing at the Chamber of Commerce, in New-York, on Oct. 16, at 10 A.M., relative to the grain elevator case, the New-York Central and Erie having made an application to be heard.

The City recently brought a suit in the United States Circuit Court against Joshua S. Peck to recover $20,000 damages for withholding the land lying on the East River and bounded by First-avenue, Forty-seventh and Forty-eighth streets.
LONDON, Oct. 11.--At the Newmarket second October meeting to-day the race for the Champion Stakes was won by Mr. Lefevre's 5-year-old c.h. Tristan.

The schooner Carrie Hall Lister, of Wilmington, Del., Capt. Pearce, arrived in this harbor last evening in tow of the steam-tug Reliance, her deck a litter of wreckage, and her whole aspect presenting a striking illustration of the power of wind and wave. The vessel was brought into Newport on Friday evening last, having been sighted adriff from Block Island several days before.

Mr. FRANK HATTON, First Assistant Postmaster-General of the United States, is proud to be considered the living embodiment of the old-fashioned and (happily) well-nigh obsolete idea in politics that Government patronage is a means of personal advancement.
The United States steam tug Pinta, which arrived at the Brooklyn Navy-yard from Portsmouth, N.H., on Wednesday, came in collision with a brig during her passage.
The Rev. Thomas Chickering Williams will be installed as Pastor of All Souls' Unitarian Church, of this City, on Wednesday evening, the 17th inst., succeeding the late Rev. Dr. H.W. Bellows.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 11.--The Philadelphia Times to-morrow will tell this story: A purchase was made by Wharton Barker, yesterday, of a colored cravat, in a Chestnut-street haberdasher's.

RUTLAND, Vt., Oct. 11.--The trial of exTreasurer J.M. Haven, of the Rutland Railroad Company, charged with issuing false certificates of stock of that company, ended to-night in a verdict of acquittal on technical grounds. This legalizes the issue of alleged fraudulent stock, amounting to $60,000, issued to Clement, now President of the road.
It is almost hazardous to-day to describe Mr. Murdoch as a great and celebrated actor. He was, in his time, a great and celebrated actor. But that time is now deep in the past.

NEW-ORLEANS, Oct. 11.--Nineteen years ago Eugene Bertrand, a mulatto, was wounded in the left heel by the accidental explosion of a shell, and yesterday his left foot was amputated by Dr. Underhill in the Charity Hospital.
MATAWAN, N.J., Oct. 11.--The Grand Jury of Monmouth County was discharged this afternoon by Judge Scudder, having found about 65 indictments.

CHICAGO, Oct. 11.--Katy J. Gibson to-day filed a bill for divorce against her husband, William H. Gibson, a New-York broker, on the ground of cruelty. She sets out that she was married in June, 1873, but was obliged to leave her husband in 1881.

PRACTICE--ONE MAN FATALLY WOUNDED. BALTIMORE, Md., Oct. 11.--James F. Busey a Democratic ward heeler of the lowest type, but a man who has political influence enough in this city to carry the Seventeenth Ward around in his vest pocket, was shot and mortally wounded in front of the City Hall before noon to-day.
A "Bureau of Information" will be opened at the Grand Central Station on Oct. 15. It will be in charge of Charles Kolle, who has been employed in the station for 11 years.
The report that the Howe Scale Manufacturing Company, of Rutland, Vt., is about to wind up its affairs is untrue.

SCRANTON, Penn., Oct. 11.--A young lady named Jennie Noon died in this city yesterday from the effects of a shock resulting from the announcement, by a friend who called at her house last week, that she had heard of her death. The friend expressed surprise at seeing Miss Noon alive, whereupon the latter fainted and remained unconscious until her death.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 8.--The past week at Harvard has seen settling down to their work both instructors and students, while hardly an evening has passed that several college organizations, classes, or societies have not held meetings for the election of officers. The Freshman Class is the largest that has ever entered the college, numbering 307 men.

S. Decker Brown has been nominated by the Second Assembly District Republican Convention of Passaic County.

PORT AU PRINCE, Sept. 22.--Three rebel bands entered this city recently, pillaging stores, setting fire to houses, and murdering all who resisted them. Among those killed were two Generals. The Government troops finally attacked the invading party and were victorious, putting the rebels to flight.

LIMA, Peru, Oct. 11, via Galveston.--A telegram received from the Jefe Politico of Tacna, and which has been published here, says that the Bolivian Senate has approved by a large majority a motion to treat alone with Chill for peace, on condition that Bolivia secures some territory on the Pacific coast.

By the death of Mr. Lawrence Van Wart, a veteran of the war of 1812, on Wednesday morning, New-York loses one of its oldest citizens.
