The Tammany Hall Committee on Organization met last evening, with John Kelly in the chair. There was no advertisement of the meeting, which took place in the "coal-hole" of the "wigwam" in Fourteenth-street.

GRAYSON, Ky., Oct. 11.--Ellis Craft, the Ashland murderer, whose trial and military protection have cost Kentucky thousands of dollars, arrived here last night from Lexington, where he was kept for safety. He is to be hanged to-morrow. The Sheriff and nine men brought him here, and the jail was strongly guarded last night.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 11.--The Bankers' Association met at 10:30 this morning. George M. Davie, of Louisville, submitted a paper on bankruptcy, which was ordered to be printed.

MADRID, Oct. 11.--The Ministry was unable to agree upon what course should be pursued by the Government in view of the refusal of France to make further reparation for the treatment of King Alfonso in Paris. Gen. Martinez-Campos, Minister of War, also renewed his resolution to resign.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., Oct. 11.--The yacht Dauntless, owned and commanded by Capt. Colt, arrived here yesterday, 28 days from Cowes, Isle of Wight. She met heavy westerly gales during the passage. All are well on board.

Lord Coleridge, on rising, was the recipient of an enthusiastic outburst of handclapping. He protested his unfitness to speak for England or English institutions, holding as he did a somewhat isolated position in the politics of that country.
COLUMBUS, Oct. 11.--At 11 o'clock tonight the hopes that have existed among the Republicans have all departed, and a wholesome silence pervades the city.

ERIE, Penn., Oct. 11.--Mary Vreeland dug under the walls of the insane quarters at the alms house, to-day, and escaped. She ran screaming through the woods, swinging an iron bar. Eugene Wagner, who pursued her, was overcome and would have been brained had the keepers not arrived in time to disarm the desperate madwoman.
TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 11.--A gray-haired old man named Richard Clark, of Hamilton Township, appeared before the Mercer County Court to-day to plead to an indictment against him by the last Grand Jury.

A death as dramatic as it was sudden occurred in Police Justice Davis's office, in Jersey City, yesterday afternoon. Just as the Justice was about to leave his office to go to dinner a man pretty well advanced in years walked in. He had a note from Surrogate McAvoy introducing him.

HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 11.--The intercollegiate lawn-tennis tournament closed to-day. In single contests Throne, of Yale, beat Hill, of Brown, and Taylor, of Harvard, defeated Applegate, of Amherst, and Thorne, of Yale. As in the doubles, Harvard led in the singles, with Brown second and Yale third.

Issac Harby, Moses and Elijah Myers, comprising the firm of I. Harby, Myers Co., produce exporters and commission merchants, at No. 30 SouthWilliam-street, made an assignment yesterday to James J. Thorpe. The present firm was formed Jan. 1, 1881.
HARRISONBURG, Va., Oct. 11.--The Hon. John J. Dezendorf addressed an immense meeting in the Court-house today. His speech was well received, and has caused a panic in the Mahone ranks.

CHICAGO, Oct. 11.--The General Railway Time Convention was opened today with about 60 delegates, representing the principal railways of the United States and Canada, present.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Oct. 11.--The Chautauqua County Medical Society took proceedings today against L.G. Smedley, "magnetic healer," formerly of Avon Springs, for failing to register in the County Clerk's office and otherwise comply with the law's requirements. The doctor was arrested and held for examination on Oct. 18.

The friends of Willard Bartlett and Jesse Johnson, the Democratic and Republican candidates for Supreme Court Judge, are making a very active canvass. There is certainly opposition to Mr. Bartlett among Democratic lawyers, and the other side is taking all possible advantage of it.
Nellie Toumey escaped five weeks ago from the Wetmore Home, in South Washington-square, an institution for destitute girls.

LONDON, Oct. 11.--The prosecution in the case of O'Donnell, the murderer of Carey, have obtained depositions from all their witnesses and have placed their whole case before Mr. Guy, solicitor for O'Donnell.
TORONTO, Ontario, Oct. 11.--Politics in Canada often assume a ridiculous phase. At the general election in June, 1832, Sir John Macdonald ran in two constituencies, Lennox and Carleton.

The Directors of the Denver and Rio Grande Railroad Company met in this City yesterday and authorized an issue of general mortgage bonds up to $5,000,000 in pursuance of the resolution adopted by the stockholders at Colorado Springs last Saturday. President Lovejoy stated that the guaranteeing syndicate had been completed and all of the necessary papers signed.

ANDES, N.Y., Oct. 10.--The Court of Appeals has rendered a decision in the case of David Craig against the town of Andes, Delaware County, in favor of the town, declaring void the bonding and bonds of the town issued in aid of the construction of the Delhi and Middletown Railroad. The Hon. Isaac H. Maynard and Cassius M. Shaw are attorneys for the town.
ST. JOHN, New-Brunswick, Oct. 11.--John McBean, a mill-owner of Nashwook, has absconded. He raised $10,000 before leaving, mostly on forged paper.
DES MOINES, Oct. 11.--The Republican State Committee to-night say that 52 members of the House elected are Republicans beyond dispute, and reserve six other districts as still in doubt.

DOVER., N.H., Oct. 11.--A prize-fight occurred at Farmington this morning between Dennis Delaney, of Biddeford, Me., and "Denny" Cannon, of Dover, both well-known athletes and pedestrians. There were 300 spectators.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 11.--The foot-ball team was selected to-day, and it will play the Rutgers eleven here to-morrow. The team is as follows: Rushers--Belknap, Travers, Wanamaker, T. Harris, Bird, Harlan, and De Camp; quarterback--Kimball; half-back--A. Moffatt and Baker, and full back, Fell.
Nicoli Lecandro and Vincento Tetaro, whose name has been given as Tartusale, two Italian railroad laborers, engaged in a fight in Grandstreet, Hoboken, on the night of Sept. 21.

MILWAUKEE, Oct. 11.--The liquor element of Wisconsin propose to take a pretty active part in politics at the next State election.
BUFFALO, N.Y., Oct. 11.--George Baer, an Alderman of this city, who recently became insane, returned to this city to-day, arriving about noon. He was accompanied by his wife.

INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 11.--Ex-Senator McDonald, as Chairman of the Democratic State Central Committee, telegraphed to Judge Hoadly this morning: "The Democracy of Indiana sends greeting to the Democracy of Ohio, and congratulates you upon your success."
LONDON, Oct. 11.--A dispatch to Reuter's Telegram Company from St. Petersbarg says: "A dispatch from Vladivastock announces that the steamer Kamtschatka arrived there yesterday.

LONDON, Oct. 11.--The Sportsman says there is some dispute between Mr. Walton, the owner of the mare Girofie, and Mr. A. Day, her trainer, concerning her running in the race for the Czarovitch Stakes.

KINGSTON, Oct. 11.--The Republican County Convention met at the Court-house in this city today and nominated William S. Kenyon for County Judge, William Lawton for Surrogate, and renominated A.T. Clearwater for District Attorney. The ticket is regarded as a strong one.
The Rev. Dr. L.T. Chamberlain was last evening installed as Pastor of the Classon-Avenue presbyterian Church, Brooklyn.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 11.--The annual meeting of the stockholders of the Ohio and Mississippi Railroad was held here this morning and the President's annual report was read.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 11.--Forgers are operating on Newport banks and business firms. This morning a check for $100 was received by the Newport National Bank which purported to be drawn by H.C. Cooke, who is unknown there, in favor of Francis W. Sherman, also unknown.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11.--A general order has been issued by the War Department announcing to the army the death of Surgeon-General Charles H. Crane. The officers of the Medical Department will wear the usual badge of mourning for six months.

The sale of Mr. Cooper's imported Jersey cattle yesterday was much more successful than on the previous day. Cows were in good demand, but the bids for bulls were not active. Two good bulls were withdrawn, as little more than what their beef would fetch was offered.

The body of the Rev. Dr. Ewer reached New-York from Montreal yesterday noon and was taken to the Church of St. Ignatius, in West Fortieth-street, and placed in the chancel in its Eucharistic vestments.

OSHKOSH, Wis., Oct. 11.--Mr. Trugert, section boss of the Milwaukee and St. Paul Road, was riding yesterday on a hand-car with his wife and baby, his daughter-in-law, Mrs. Trugert, her husband and child.

Our esteemed contemporary the Herald is quite able to fight its own battles, but the cheap demagogism of the Tribune in encouraging the Aldermen to refuse permission to the Herald to erect news-stands will meet with little approval outside of the longhaired class of men whom it styles "our best citizens."

NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 11.--Freddie Gebhard arrived here this morning. He is at the E.D. Bail cottage, which is occupied by his sister, Mrs. Frederick Neilson, of New-York. He will return to New-York in company with his sister and her family on Saturday.

SANDWICH, Mass., Oct. 11.--Three dredges and pile-drivers, with a large number of workmen, have arrived here, and work will be at once commenced upon the Cape Cod ship canal. Within three weeks 500 men will be laboring upon the line of the canal.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10.--It looks as if there was to be a sort of a social contest in the vicinity of Dupont Circle during the coming season as to whether Mr. Lelter, of Chicago, who is going to do justice to Mr. Blaine's new house, shall be outdone in hospitality by the family of ex-Senator Stewart in their renovated castle over the way.

MILLERSBURG, Ohio, Oct. 11.--Maxwell Brother's mill has been closed by creditors, and the entire property will probably be exhausted to satisfy their claims. The failure was precipitated by the arrest of John T. Maxwell in New-York on a charge of manufacturing counterfeit money.

LANCASTER, Penn., Oct. 11.--George Cromer, a carpenter of West Wilow, this county, was accidentally hanged at that place yesterday. He was working on the upper floor of a building, when he is supposed to have been seized with an apoplectic fit, and, falling between the rafters, he was caught by the neck and strangled to death.

SCOTTDALE, Penn., Oct. 11.--The miners who have been on a strike for several weeks against the "iron-clad" check weighman law waiver, west to work last week, the employers not insisting on their signing the waiver; but this week several union leaders were singled out and dismissed, whereupon the miners quit work again and have refused to resume until their companions are reinstated.

WASHINGTON, Penn., Oct. 11.--This afternoon the Lemoyne Crematory disposed of the twenty-sixth body reduced to ashes in its retort. The corpse was that of Mrs. Isadore French, who died in New-York City a few days ago.
A fire which broke out in the sub-basement of the Brevoort House, at Fifth-avenue and Eighthstreet, at 4 o'clock yesterday morning, gutted the laundry and drying-room and did $4,500 damage.

We have a Herald subscriber in Brookport, N.Y., the sister of the Hon. B.E. Huntley, of that town, who, after 20 years on her bed, (and the doctors had given her up,) has been restored to health. She writes us a beautiful letter in which she ascribes her recovery to prayer. We congratulate her and those who have made special prayer in her behalf.

PORT HOPE, Ontario, Oct. 11.--Jack McCabe, an escaped convict from the Kingston Penitentiary, was traced to this place. Constable Rankin last night attempted to effect his arrest, when McCabe drew a revolver, but the policeman was prepared and fired first, killing McCabe instantly.
ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 11.--At the trial of ex-Senator L.B. Sessions this morning, the crossexamination of ex-Assemblyman Bradley was continued.

A second indictment was made against M. Byrne, the Nassau-street tailor, on Wednesday last on an additional charge of smuggling goods, consisting of vestings, trouser patterns, and the like, and of bribing certain Customs officers.

The large Presbyterian Church at Irvingtonon-the-Hudson, yesterday, was handsomely decorated for the marriage of Mr. C.H. Dodge, of this City, and Miss Grace Parish, daughter of Mr. Henry Parish, of Irvington.

TORONTO, Ontario, Oct. 11.--John Coulter, of Battery B, of Kingston, and Henry Meyers, a Sergeant of United States Artillery, traded uniforms yesterday. Subsequently Meyers was arrested for having in his possession a uniform belonging to the Queen, and was to-day remanded until Saturday.

Ex-Sheriff James O'Brien, accompanied by Jorome Buck, attended meetings in the First and Seventh Assembly Districts last night, arranged for the purpose of promoting Mr. O'Brien's candidacy for the Registership.

BETHLEHEM, Penn., Oct. 11.--This morning the Hon. Eckley B. Coxe delivered the oration before the Faculty and students of Lehigh University and invited guests, the occasion being Founders' Day. To-night a hop was given by the students in the new gymnasium. On Satur day, Oct. 13, the Fall meeting of the Lehigh University Athletic Association will take place on the grounds of the association.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 11.--The General Convention of the Protestant Episcopal Church reassembled this morning in Holy Trinity Church. Messages were received from the House of Bishops stating that they had concurred with the House of ...

FRANKFORT, Ky., Oct. 11--News was received here to-night that three men broke into the house of Elisha Curtis, at Sand Riffle, 15 miles from here, last night, and took Mr. Curtis out in the yard, where one of the men guarded him while the others assaulted his wife and 13-year old daughter. The latter is reported to be dying.

The fine weather yesterday, together with an attractive programme, drew to Jerome Park a large crowd of people, among whom were many ladies. There were five races decided, and the honors at the end were equally divided between field and favorites. The track was in very good condition.
CHICAGO, Oct. 11.--The racing at the Driving Park this afternoon was somewhat tame, as compared with the big events of Tuesday.

NEW-ORLEANS, Oct. 11.--Some days ago the city of Mobile re-established quarantine against Pensacola. The people of the latter city reported that perfect health existed, and no sickness had occurred to justify such action.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11, 1883. Secretary Folger says it is probable that he will soon issue a call for the 3 per cent. bonds. As no estimates have as yet been prepared it cannot be said what the amount of the call will be.

BRIDGEPORT, Oct. 11.--The members of the paid Fire Department of this city had their noses high in the air to-day. They sulked in their houses and acted like a lot of overgrown children who "won't play."

Bowman, was found this evening secreted at the house of reputable people in Amherst County, near this city, having become persuaded of the perfidy of Bowman, who has a wife and three children in Augusta, Ga. DENVER, Col., Oct. 13.--This afternoon William Harrison, residing on Ninth-street, shot his 16-year-old wife and then himself, both dying almost instantly. The case assigned for the act is jealousy and interference with his domestic affairs on the part of his mother-in-law. The couple were married at Shawnee, Kan., last March and had been in Denver for about a month.

LONDON, Oct. 14.--Sir Stafford Northcote closed his campaign in Ireland yesterday with a speech at Larne. LONG BEACH, N.J., Oct. 16. --William Nelson, the old man who was assaulted and robbed while returning home from church at Branchville on Sunday night, died last night at his home near White's Bridge.
BOSTON, Oct. 16.--A party of bicyclists, members of the Citizens' Bicycle Club of New-York. arrived in this city to-day.
The Citizens' Committee of Fifty met yesterday afternoon and made nominations for the two Supreme Court Judgeships and the two City Judgeships. There was a very full meeting.

CHICAGO, Oct. 16.--The Fall meeting of the Chicago Driving Association was brought to a close to-day. The first race was the unfinished 2:26 class, in which Prince had won the first heat and Index the second and third.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 16.--The office of Deputy Coroner Powers was filled to-day by a throng of curious people morbidly attracted to the inquest upon the body of Edward Leonard, the man who, after sacrificing both genius and wealth to late appetite for liquor, died miserably upon the bare floor of his own home.
BOSTON, Oct. 16.--This was the second day of the October meeting at Beacon Park. The attendance was fair, and the track in good condition. Following are summaries of the day's events:

The game of base-ball on the Polo Grounds yesterday between the New-York and Metropolitan Clubs resulted in a tie, each nine scoring 3 runs. The contest up to the last inning was a pretty one, and was enjoyed by the spectators.

NEW-ORLEANS, Oct. 16.--The first train on the North-eastern Railroad came in from Meridian, Miss., across the miles of trestle-work of Lake Ponchartraine, late yesterday.

The Westminster Kennel Club held its annual reception yesterday at Babylon, Long Island. The attendance was not as large as had been expected, but the weather was auspicious, and some excellent shooting was done.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct, 16.--The Rev. M. H. Houghton, the minister who recently denounced from his pulpit William Lewis as the murderer of Rose Clark Ambler, to-day appeared in an even more distinctively characteristic role than that of reverend detective.
Greene County in this State is a perfect network of land patents, many of them granted in the time of the Dutch Governors.

Justice to Mr. CHAUNCEY DEPEW requires us to admit that if he had had any case he could not have made so very lame a defense as he did yesterday before the Railroad Commission of the policy pursued toward suburban residents upon the lines of the Hudson River and Harlem Roads.
The New-York Classis of the Dutch Reformed Church met yesterday morning in the leeture-room of the Collegiate Church, at Fifth-avenue and Twenty-ninth-street.

BRADFORD, Penn., Oct. 16.--With very few exceptions the old miners returned to work at the Beech Tree mines to-day at the company's terms. At Reynoldsville and Punxautawney many strikers have gone in. Pinkerton's men are still guarding the mines, but no violence has been offered. All is quiet and promises to remain so for the present.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16.--The Fall meeting of the National Jockey Club was inauguratod today with a splendid track and bright, cool weather. About 3,000 persons were present. The grand stand was well filled with ladies.

LONDON, Oct. 16.--R. Edward Earll and William V. Cox, United States delegates to the International Fisheries Exhibition, announce the following awards: The jury has awarded 48 gold, 47 silver, and 29 bronze medals, 24 diplomas, and 7 special prizes to United States exhibitors.

BOSTON, Oct. l6.--The Supreme Court has sustained the decision of the Superior Court at Pittsfield that a common victualer at Great Barrington, who was licensed to sell liquor, was guilty of keeping a public bar. Under this decision and understanding of the law, it is alleged that the public bar of nearly every hotel in Massachusetts can be closed.
Through tickets between New-York and Chicago by the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western and the Grand Trunk Railroads are offered by brokers at $17.50.
The attendance at Brighton Beach yesterday was moderate. One of the six races, the fifth on the programme, was declared off through errors in entering the horses.

Gen. BUTLER has accepted the Greenbackers' nomination for Governor of Massachusetts in a letter less impudent than usual, and which shows that his mind is not so easy as it has apparently been recently.
UTICA, N.Y., Oct. 16.--Mgr. Capel is the guest of ex-Senator Kernan.
The Long Island Historical Society held a special meeting last evening to listen to an address by Protop Chunder Mozoomdar, of Calcutta on the "Aspects of Civilization in India."

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Oct. 16.--The jury in the United States Circuit Court gave Thomas L. Mackay $4,500 damages for iujuries received in colliston on the Missouri Pacific Railroad about a year and a half ago.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Oct. 16.--M. C. Harris, editor of the Hot Springs Horseshoe, was arrested to-day, by order of Judge Woods, of the Circuit Court, for contempt, in having published an editorial reflecting on the court for the manner of selecting a jury in the Rugg murder case.

A well-known lawyer of this City, Gabriel Winter, died in 1862, leaving an estate valued at $250,000. As no will could be found letters of administration were granted to his son, William Winter, and his son-in-law, John Livingston.
ST. PAUL, Minn., Oct. 16.--The new operahouse was opened here last evening in the presence of a very large and brilliant andience.

Four criminals stood in a group in front of the bar in Tom, alias "Shang," Draper's saloon at No. 466 Sixth-avenue a few minutes before 2 o'clock yesterday morning. After gulping down some liquor they began to converse.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 16.--John G. Thompson was in the city to-day on a mission which he did not explain. When asked about his fight for Ser geant-at-Arms of the House of Representattiveshe smiled and said he felt confident, very confident, of getting the appointment.
LOCKPORT, N. Y., Oct. 16.--At Orangeport, a few miles east of this city, Miss Mary Alden committed suicide this morning by shooting herself with a pistol.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Oct. 16.--The stockholders of the National Stock Yards, situated at East St. Louis, have re-elected the old Board of Directors, who will meet in New-York next Monday to elect officers.
The second annual anglers' tournament of the National Rod and Reel Association was begun at Harlem Mere, Central Park, yesterday morning.

The Democratic Conference Committees assembled at the Metropolitan Hotel in the interest of peace and harmony last evening. The Tammany committee of 24 was the first on the ground. It immediately occupied the front parlor at the head of the stairs on the first floor.

MADISON COURT-HOUSE, Va., Oct. 16.--The murder of Philip Page, which occurred here Sunday, still occasions intense excitement. John H. Hall, who murdered Page, is in jail.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., Oct. 16.--A large crowd gathered at Statesville, 40 miles north-west of here, on Monday to witness a circus performance.
NEW-HAVEN Oct. 16.--The will of the late Henry Farnan was filed in the Probate Office this afternoon.
The commission to select sites for parks in the annexed district met in the Mayor's office yesterday.

Three religious bodies convened in Brooklyn yesterday. The Long Island Baptist Association entered on its seventeenth annual meeting in the Central Baptist Church, at South Fifth and Eighth streets.

LAREDO, Texas, Oct. 16.--A great sensation has been caused here by the announcement of the suspension, at Monterey, of the great firm of Zembroma Co., one of the oldest and wealthiest houses in Northern Mexico.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16, 1883. The Cabinet to-day considered the question of attending the centennial celebration at Newburg, and the conclusion was reached that owing to the pressure of public business it would not be advisable for the President or any of his Cabinet officers to leave the city at present.
PITTSBURG, Penn., Oct, 16.--The International Socialist Workingmen's Association held a final session to-day.
Mayor Edson yesterday appointed Andrew B. Martin as one of the Commissioners of Accounts to fill the vacancy caused by the removal of William Pitt Shearman.
ALBANY, Oct. 16.--The proceedings of the Republican County Convention held at Sloan's this afternoon were harmonious, and the ticket nominated will receive the support of all shades of Republicans.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotis, Oct. 16.--The schooner Florence F. arrived hero to-day from Boston.

Mayor Low opened the campaign last night in the Eastern District, Brooklyn, in the Masonic Hall, at Grand and Seventh streets, by giving an account of his administration. The hall was crowded, and many were unable to get within hearing distance of the speakers.

A majority of the active Republican politicians, as represented in the Republican Central Committee and the committee of conference, were not at all pleased last evening with the action of the Citizens' Committee in making nominations without cousulting them.
More than half of the panel of 100 jurors drawn for duty in Supreme Court, Circuit, Part I, failed to appear on Monday morning.

The primaries held last evening in Brooklyn to elect delegates to the various local nominating conventions to be called by the Republicans during the present week were hotly contested in most of the wards.

Messrs. Theodore Roosevelt and Theodore Kane Gibbs, members of the Board of Managers of the New-York Infant Asylum, have sent to the Commissioners of the State Board of Charities for the County of New-York; a series of charges against Mr. Clark Bell, the President of the board.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., Oct. 16.--The body of a richly dressed woman was found in the Seekonk River, off Swan Point Cemetery, this evening. The body, which is supposed to be that of a suicide, has not yet been identified.
WASHINGTON, Penn., Oct. 16.--The reunion of the One hundred and Fortieth Pennsylvania Volunteers here to-day was a grand affair.

NEW-ORLEANS, La. Oct. 16.--At Happy Jack, in Plaquemine, died yesterday Francis Barthelemy, aged 94 years. He was a veteran of the battle of New-Orleans under Jackson, and is the third survivor of that fight borne on the pension rolls who has died within 30 days.

The Citizens' Committee found a difficult task upon its hands yesterday in so framing a ticket as to attract to its support the largest force of voters that could be mustered against whatever combination the Democratic factions might effect.

WASHINGTON, Penn., Oct. 16.--The remains of Dr. Charles E. Blumenthal, of New-York, arrived here this afternoon and were at once taken to Le Movne's furnace and cremated. The body was accompanied by a Knight Templar escort from Mary Commandery of Philadelphia of which the dead man was Past Commander. The ashes will be sent to Carlisle, Penn., for burial.
About 150 of the leading butter merchants of this City met yesterday at the Mercantile Exchange to consider the question of the illegal sale of imitation butter as the genuine article.
When the American bark Richard Parsons, which arrived from Havre yesterday morning, anchored off the Battery she hoisted a signal of distress.
INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Oct. 16--The search for the murderer of Ada Atkinson, near Oxford, Benton County, three weeks ago, narrowed down to Jacob M. Nelling and Jacob Ladd.

President Arnold called the attention of the members of the Coffee Exchange yesterday to the recent irregularities in the transmission of telegraphic coffee quotations from Rio de Janeiro to New-York.

WORCESTER, Mass., Oct. 16.--The anti-Butler Greenbackers, who call themselves the regulars, and are under the leadership of E. Moody Boynton, of Essex County, held their convention here to-day, and put John N. Arnold, of North Adams, in nomination for Governor, in place of Gen. Butler, nominated by the Boston convention. Mr. Boynton was first nominated, but he declined.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Oct. 17.--The twentieth annual convention of the International Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers of the United States and Canadas was opened in this city to-day with a large attendance.

NORTH ADAMS, Mass., Oct. 17.--There was a large attendance at the Williams College athletic sports at the Fair Grounds this afternoon.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 17.--President Porter, of Yale College, denies the telegraphed reports that typhoid fever is prevalent in the college. One death has occurred from typhoid fever superinduced by exposure in a foreign hotel, and there are two mild cases of intermittent feuer. The health of the college is as good as usual, and no extraordinary amount of typhoid fever is prevalent in the city.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Oct. 18.--Hiram Extein, a prominent wholesale dealer in men's furnishing goods, yesterday made a general assignment to exMayor Philip Brecker. He had been established 15 years, did a business of something like $700,000 a year, and was considered very prosperous.

OLYMPIA, Washington Territory, Oct. 18.-- The bill granting women the right of suffrage passed the House of the Washington Territory Legislature last night. The vote stood 14 to 7. The result of the vote has caused much excitement among the friends of women's suffrage.

The two men were traveling together between this city and Bennington Bridge when, without any warning whatever, Burns whipped out a rovoiver and shot his companion through the mouth, and then robbed him of $250 in cash. The would-be murderer has so far eluded arrest.

NORTH TROY, Vt., Oct. 20.--The store of Royce Goff was entered by a burglar last night and several hundred dollars' worth of merchandise was taken. A convict recently released from jail is suspected, but from the large amount of goods taken it is thought others are implicated.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Oct. 23.--An elevator platform at Benjamin Ray's wood-working establishment fell 14 feet at 5 o'clock to-night, instantly killing Frederick J. Viner, a workman who had just stepped on it. It was fitted with safety clutches, and how it could fall is a mystery which will be investigated. Viner leaves a wife and two children.

OSWEGO, N.Y., Oct. 23.--All the Canadian 'longshoremen employed by Rathbun Co., except 15 men, returned home last night and all is now quiet. ST. THOMAS, Oct. 17.--A report has reached here that the Haytian Government recently captured a vessel, supposed to be an American craft, which was trying to force the blockade. NASHVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 24.--Miss Annie Craft this morning unintentionally took an overdose of morphine, from the effects of which she died in a short time. CRAWFORDSVILLE, Ind., Oct. 24.--John Murphy was found dead, with three bullet wounds in his body, this morning, at Wallace, a small village 20 miles west of this place. The horse returned to-day. There is no clue to the murderer.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 24.--The nineteenth day's session of the General Convention of the Protestant Episcopal Church was opened to-day with prayer by the Rev. William S. Langford, D. D., of New-Jersey, and the Rev. Daniel C. Roberts, of New-Hampshire.

That peace and harmony which existed between the Democratic factions when they agreed upon a Register and four Judges appears to have been utterly destroyed by the proceedings of the last few days.

The foot-ball team of Stevens Institute played a game yesterday with Princeton's eleven, on the grounds of the St. George's Cricket Club, and scored a goose-egg for themselves against 14 points made by their opponents.
ATLANTA, Ga., Oct. 24.--Controller-General Wright has signed an order revoking the licenses issued to several insurance companies who have been doing business in this State.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Oct. 24.--J.D. Weeks Secretary of the Western Iron Association returned home to-day from an extended tour through Europe. During his absence he acquired a large fund of information concerning labor and wages abroad, which he will embody in his report to the Census Bureau. Between 300 and 400 working men responded to the call of the Central Labor Union for a massmeeting last evening at the Germania Assembly Rooms, Nos. 291 and 293 Bowery, to discuss the system of convict labor.
BUFFALO, N.Y., Oct. 24.--The Republican City Convention was held to-day. After a stormy session the following ticket was nominated.

NEW-ORLEANS, Oct. 24.--The Directors of the Cotton Exposition have determined that the main building for the exhibits for the hall shall contain 1,000,000 square feet floor space.

Mrs. Stetson has been digging rather deep of late in the graveyard of melodrama. After having unearthed those lively masterpieces of ghastly mimicry, "The Corsican Brothers" and "Monte Cristo," he has new brought to light "The Duke's Motto."
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 24.--The firm of Stern, Trautman Co., wholesale clothiers, of No. 336 Market-street, failed to-day for $150,000, with assets which they claim will amount to $30,000.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., Oct. 24.--Yesterday a party of distinguished State officers arrived in Lockport and registered at the Judson House. They were the Hon. H.L. Northrop, of Washington County; the Hon. George M. Beebe, of Sullivan County, and the Hon. Henry F. Allen, of ...

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 24.--Elmer F. Culver, the wealthy young farmer of East Haven, who was charged with having maltreated and failed to support his young wife, was to-day found guilty in the Superior Court.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24.--The Secretary of War received today, through the Acting Chief Sig nal Officer, Lieut. Garlington's answers to the questions asked him by General Hazen after the receipt of his (Garlington's) official report of the expedition to Smith Sound. The questions and the most important part of the answers are as follows:

PLYMOUTH, Mass., Oct. 24.--James Gilmore, who set fire to the Bridgewater Work-house some month ago, causing its destruction, was sentenced this afternoon to 20 years in the State prison. Gilmore addressed the court, saying that he set fire to the work-house because he was treated badly while living there. The testimony of the officers showed him to be a very refractory inmate, whom it was necessary to frequently punish.
Snow fell in Berlin a fortnight ago for the first time this season. Potsdam was visited with a slight snow--fall some days earlier.
The Governing Committee of the Stock Exchange listed a large number of new stocks and bonds yesterday.
Congressman Cox's buoyant hopefulness does not desert him. CARLISLE, he thinks, is stronger than RANDALL in the Speakership contest, and he is stronger than both.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 25.--The following are the results of the handicap games held here to-day under the auspices of the Athletic Association: Hundred yards--Griffith, scratch, first; second, G. Reynolds.

Mr. Charles G. Francklyn, late of the Cunard Steam-ship Line, has become a large cattle and ranch owner in the South-west. To improve the breed of his cattle, Mr. Francklyn recently imported from Scotland two buffalo bulls, which are...

Mr. Patrick Clancy, of Boston, who last week secured an injunction restraining his partners in the purchase of several vessels recently sold by the Government at auction from again disposing of the vessels by an auction among themselves, returned Wednesday night to his home.

What brought the Democratic factions of this City together this Fall is just now attracting some attention in view of the established fact that the rank and file of each are just as much opposed to one another as they ever were.

The Colored Republican Central Committee, at its meeting, at No. 121 West Twenty-fifth-street last evening Col. John J. Freeman in the chair, warmly indorsed the Republican State and County tickets and pledged the support of the colored voters.

The National Board of Steam Navigation met again yesterday at the Metropolitan Hotel. The poor attendance was the subject of much discussion, and Mr. D.M. Munger made a vigorous onslaught upon the Secretary of the board, who, he alleged, had failed to supply proper notices.

WILKESBARRE, Oct. 25.--The funerals of the three little girls, Mattie James, Hattie Moss, and May Morris, who died from injuries received by the explosion at the squib factory in Kingston on Tuesday, took place this afternoon.
The semi-annual meeting of the American Association for the Cure of Inebriates was held yesterday at the Fort Hamilton Home.

A third attempt of the sloop yachts Gracie and Fanny to make a race proved successful yesterday, although the winning boat had little over eight minutes to spare, and her opponent crossed the line at 1:21 after the prescribed time of the race had expired.
Register to-day. Duncan D. Parmly, of Maquand, Parmly Foster, stock brokers, has been admitted to membership in the Stock Exchange.
The Republican Convention of the Seventh Senatorial District met again last evening at the Concordia Assembly Rooms, in Avenue A, with Andrew Coates in the chair.

Miss Elsie Maria Withers, daughter of Frederick C. Withers, the architect, was married yesterday in St. John's Episcopal Church, Yonkers, to Mr. J. Foster Jenkins, son of the late Dr. J. Foster Jenkins, of Yonkers.

The Eighth Ward Mission, at No. 9 Ludlowplace, (West Houston-street,) began yesterday the seventh year of its existence as a charitable institution under the management of Mrs. M. Laidlaw, who organized and has since managed it. The object of the mission is to aid the needy of ...

BOSTON, Mass., Oct. 25.--Joseph E. Hurd, the St. Louis sewing-machine agent, whose arrest here on the charge of having abducted a St. Louis girl was made yesterday, and who agreed to return to Missouri in the custody of the girl's father, ...

ITHACA, N.Y,, Oct. 25.--The annual regatta between the classes of Cornell University, which had been postponed from time to time on account of unfavorable weather, came off his afternoon on Cayuga Lake, and was witnessed by a large number of people in steam-boats, yachts, and sailboats.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Oct. 25.--At the business meeting of the Society of the Army of the Cumberland this morning Gen. Barnett, Chairman of the Committee on the Garfield Monument, reported that a place had been selected in Washington as the site of the monument, but it would require the action of Congress in the matter to make it final.

Controller Grant has served a formal notice on Auditor of Accounts Daniel Jackson to show cause on Oct. 29 why he should not be removed from his office, he having failed to resign when requested to do so by the Controller. Accompanying the notice are specifications of "some of the facts and circumstances" upon which Mr. Grant proposes to remove the Auditor.

Capt. Weightman, of the steam-ship Monkseaton, which arrival yesterday from Havana, reports that at 10 A.M. on Oct. 24, when 80 miles south-east of Absecorn, he sighted the threemasted schooner Norena.

A number of prominent German Catholic gentlemen residing in and around the City, formed, at a meeting at the Grand Central Hotel, a branch of St. Raphael's Society of Germany, of which the Prince of Isenburg Bernstein is President.
BALTIMORE, Md., Oct. 25.--The Fall meeting of the Maryland Jockey Club, at Pimlico, began today. The weather was fair, but the track was heavy. The attendance was good.

ATLANTA, Oct. 25.--During the past few days pieces of spurious coin have floated to the surface in Atlanta trade circles. The counterfeits are of quarters and halves, and are most admirable executed, except so far as the letters are concerned; these are badly formed, and through them detection is made easy.

Those Democrats who, counting on Democratic harmony in this City, had already elected a President in '84 and begun to parcel out the spoils, will be sadly disappointed over the attempts of yesterday at patching up a truce.

LONG BEACH, N.J., Oct. 25.--During the severe storm on Tuesday night the schooner Eliza Jane, from Hampton Roads, with a cargo of oysters, came ashore off Cedar Ridge Creek. The crew were safely taken off by the life-saving station. The schooner struck upon an old wreck and broke up before she could be dismantled. Both cargo and vessel are a total loss.

At a meeting of the Seventeenth Assembly District Republican Association last evening William Winterbottom read a letter from Robert Gordon declining the nomination for the Assembly tendered to him by the Republican Convention.

The seventh annual Commencement of the Training School for Nurses of the Charity and Maternity Hospitals, on Blackwell's Island, was celebrated yesterday, and 17 trained nurses were graduated. Several hundred ladies and gentlemen were present at the ceremonies, which ...

RICHMOND, Oct. 25.--The negroes in this city and other portions of Virginia are very much incenced at the recent decision of the United States Supreme Court in declaring the Civil Rights bill unconstitutional except in its application to the District of Columbia.
ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 25.--In the Court of Appeals to-day the following cases were argued:

CHICAGO, Oct. 25.--Much astonishment was caused to-day by the voluntary assignment of the firm of Eddy, Harvey Co., dealers in hats, caps, and furs, to John G. Shortall, for the benefit of their creditors. No schedules were filed, and it will be several days before any trustworthy statement can be furnished.

The International and northern Telegraph Company was organized in this City, yesterday, with a capital stock of $5,000,000. The object is to run telegraph lines through the Northern and Eastern States and into Canada. The Directors for the first year are Joseph Owen, ...

Yesterday's exhibition at the MadisonSquare Garden was the tamest and most unsatisfactory of the week. There was a very large atendance of Americans, and from them complaints were heard on all sides because the day was given over to the English imitators, and because even with these the programme dragged wearily.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 25.--Capt. Evans and 10 members of the Salvation Army, who were arrested for parading the streets and singing, were tried in the Police Court to-day. Some time since the Common Council, by resolution, prohibited the parading of the streets by the army.

The racing at Brighton Beach yesterday was not of a brilliant nature, but a large crowd was present. The track was heavy and sticky, which was the cause of the small list of entries. As there are over 300 horses in the vicinity of the track the ...

The annual report of the New-York Eye and Ear Infirmary was read yesterday at a meeting of its Board of Directors, and showed that during the past year 50,115 patients were treated at the infirmary--an average for every work day of more than 160.

Caroline B. Furlong was placed on trial inthe Kings County Court of Sessions, yesterday, before Judge Moore and a jury, on a charge of having, by means of an unlawful operation, caused, in August last, the death of Charity Von Gildar, alias Lewis. Dr. Samuel B. Childs testified that he was ...

Herzog Brothers, manufacturers of cloaks at No. 29 White-street, made an assignment yesterday to Jacob F. Cullman, giving a preference for $2,863 to the Market National Bank on an accommodation note made by F. Cullman.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 25.--Gov. Crittenden's reply to the Citizens' Committee's request that he remove Police Commissioners Lutz, Caruth, and Cleveland and appoint non-gambling ring men in their stead was received to-day.

PERTH AMBOY, N.J., Oct. 25.--It is believed now that the young woman whose body was found in a much decomposed state in the woods between the Pennsylvania and New-Jersey Central Railroads one week ago to-day was murdered, although there has been no inquest.

We are glad to hear that some of the swindlers who have been robbing veteran soldiers and the poor widows of brave men who fell in the late war have been forbidden to do business with the Pension Office, and that others are to be punished more severely.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25.--The attention of Mr. Justice Harlan was directed to the brief editorial in to-day's TIMES, in which he is reported as saying that he did not wish to be embarrassed by politics.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25, 1883. James F. Rusling, a pension attorney of Trenton, N.J., who was suspended by Secretary Teller at the request of Commissioner Dudley on the 23d inst. has been restored to practice. His offense consisted in the use of the words "United States Pension Agency" as descriptive of his business.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25.--An evening paper of this city prints to-night what it says is a true copy of a letter written by Mr. W.H. Smyth, While United States Marshal for Georgia, to one of his deputies, with regard to making out accounts for fees, Mr. Smyth was recently appointed Postmaster at Atlanta, and the letter, which is said to be in the possession of Gen. Longstreet, is as follows:
Yesterday evening, at the City Hall station of the elavated railroad, a gentleman paid 20 cents for two tickets, the hour being 5:30 P.M. and the train he took starting at 5:35.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Oct. 25.--It is understood that Lord Lansdowne, acting upon the suggestions contained in Lord Lorne's answer to the last address presented to him, has decided that it will be the better plan not to receive any addresses from national societies.

The printers belonging to Typographical Union, No. 6, who met last night in the rooms of the Union, No. 19 Centre-street, were all in a state of perfect good humor, as the strike which had been commenced the day before had been very successful.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Oct. 25.--There was a lively scene at the County Jail for a few minutes to-day. As two Deputy Sheriffs sat at their dinner the cry of fire was heard, and smoke was seen coming out of the prison doors.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Oct. 25.--Mary Rose Berleur, formerly associated under the name of Sister Mary Joseph with the order of the Sisters of St. Francis, in this city, has brought suit through Lawyer John W. Gerdmann, an ex-priest, in Common Pleas Court No. 1, against the order. She declares she is 43 years of age, and was a member of the sisterhood for 17 years.

The corner-stone of the new Alumni Hall, connected with Seton Hall College at South Orange, was laid yesterday afternoon. The services began in the chapel with Bishop Wigger as celebrant and the Rev. Father Messner as master of ceremonies.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Oct. 25.--The formation of a new base-ball association, the managers of which intend to cut into the American Association and League for players, is the topic of the day in local sporting circles.

Lord Coleridge was the guest of the Union League Club last night. The swelling notes of "God Save the Queen" greeted him as he passed through the Railway and up the grand stair-case, and President Evarts walked by his side, looking serenely happy in his dignified way.

The long threatened suit of the stock and bondholders of the Bruff Elevated Railroad of Brooklyn against W.F. Bruff, R.B.F. Jones, C.N. Jordan, J.L. Nostrand, Adolph Ladenbergh, Ernest Thalmann, and the Central Trust Company was commenced this week by Sylvester H. Gray representing the stockholders.
LONDON, Oct. 25.--The Allen Line steam-ship Buenos Ayrean, Capt. Scott, from Montreal Oct. 11, for Glasgow, has arr. at Moville.

NEW-HAVEN, Oct. 25.--Prof. H.A. Newton, of Yale College, is enthusiastic over the adoption of the new standard of time in the Eastern States, which will go into effect on the 18th of November next. Speaking to THE TIMES'S correspondent yesterday, he said: "There has been much inconvenience ...
Mayor Low was cheered to the echo last evening as he mounted the platform of the Brooklyn Rink, at the Republican mass-meeting there, to the music of "Hail to the Chief" by Conterno's Band.

The Board of Estimate and Apportionment appropriated yesterday $20,000 to be expended under the direction of the Mayor for expenses of the celebration of the centennial anniversary of Evacuation Day. Clerk Twomey, of the Common Council, said the Common Council would require $84,500 next year.

UTICA, Oct. 25--At a conference of Jefferson and Oswego County Republicans, held to-day at Sandy Creek, an agreement was reached by which Worts, the bolting candidate, agrees to withdraw. It is probable this will insure the reelection of Senator Lansing.
F.C. Burrhus, a man of about 55 years of age and a native of Washington, D.C., was found dead in his bed yesterday afternoon at Everett's Hotel, No. 98 Barclay-street, suffocated by gas.
FULTONVILLE, N.Y., Oct. 25.--Capt. M. De Puy, a canal-boat owner, has publishad the following letter:
Pierre van Cortenberg, a Belgian artisan, went on board the Red Star steam-ship Belgenland at Antwerp on Oct. 4 to take leave of his friend, M. Verlac, who was about to sail on that vessel.

Unless Dr. JEFFERIES, who lectured in this City the other night on color-blindness, was incorrectly reported, he made a grave mistake in asserting that to people who are color-blind red and green appear as gray.
MILWAUKEE, Wis., Oct. 25.--The news leaked out to-day that Fay Templeton, the pretty opera singer, who was romantically married to Billy West, the negro minstrel, last Spring, had seperated from him.
MEMPHIS, Tenn., Oct. 25.--This was the third day of the Fall meeting of the new Memphis Jockey Club. The weather was cold, the attendance fair, the betting moderate, and the track slow.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25.--The proceedings of the United States Supreme Court today were as follows: No. 77--The Town of Berlin, plaintiff in error, vs. John G. McCullough, Administrator, argument concluded.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Oct. 25.--To-day's session of the Protestant Episcopal Church Convention was opened with morning prayer by the Rev. Archibald Beatty, D.D., of Kansas, and the Rev. William H. Moffett, of Northern New-Jersey.
CINCINNATI, Ohio, Oct. 25.--The General Home Society Missionary Convention of the Disciples of Christ began its session here to-day, the Rev. D.R. Dungan, of Iowa, in the chair.

LANCASTER, Penn., Oct. 25.--Jacob Gangaway, the boy who placed the obstruction on the Reading and Columbia Railroad, near Ephrata, is now on trial on the charge of manslaughter in causing the death of George M. Hain, the master mechanic of the Reading and Columbia Railroad.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 25.--The all-absorbing topic of conversation about the college for the past few days has been the disaster at the boathouse. It is highly probable now that the injuries of no one who was hurt will prove fatal, but the thought of the results that might have followed from the fall of the balconies cause a shudder, and the negligence that allowed the structures to become so weak is severely commented upon.

OLEAN, N.Y., Oct. 25.--The Western NewYork Agricultural Association met here to-day for their third semi-annual session. Ex-Gov. Fenton, of Jamestown, delivered an address on agriculture East and West.

The Prohibitionists in Brooklyn have nominated a candidate for Mayor, not to elect him, but to defeat Mr. Low. "If the Republicans," says this candidate, Mr. C. C. LEIGH, "are defeated by our efforts in the next election, they will see the wisdom of coming to us and asking us what we want."

CHICAGO, Oct. 25.--George F. Slosson won the cushion carom championship of America last evening from William Sexton, after a long and tiresome contest lasting over four hours. The announcement that the two experts were to play last evening at Central Music Hall resulted in filling the house.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 25.--A murder has just come to light near New-Britain. Yesterday afternoon a young man approached the conductor of the up train on the Consolidated Road, as it was nearing Hartford, ...

A set-to between Mr. Franklin B. Gowen, counsel for the Reading Road, and the Hon. Roscoe Conkling lent unusual interested to the proceedings yesterday in the matter of the suit of William B. Dinsmore to set aside the lease of the Jersey Central to the Reading Road.

CHICAGO, Oct. 25.--It is not often that the conditions of the cattle market are so decidedly adverse to the selling interest as was the case to-day. Not only were the receipts among the largest ever reported, but they consisted for the most part of a class of stock so poor that Eastern buyers could not safely handle it.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25.--Pension Commissioner Dudley is pursuing the swindling pension claim agents with commendable vigor. He is putting the axe deep into a tree that had become too strong by half, and he should not drop the weapon until the tree is extirpated, root and branch.
CHICAGO, Oct. 25.--A well-attended meeting of colored citizens was held last night for the purpose of protesting against the recent decision of the Supreme Court on the Civil Rights bill.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., Oct. 25.--THE TIMES of Oct. 20 contained a dispatch from this city stating the unfortunate condition of a respectably dressed old gentleman, who, on stepping from the train at Suspension Bridge, fell and stunned himself so as to lose all memory of his name, home, destination, or relatives.

George Goehling, a German, residing in Williamsburg, while suffering from delirium caused by intemperance, attempted to commit suicide yesterday by taking arsenic while at the City Button-works at No. 233 Canal-street, where he was employed.
Officer Main, of the Fourth Precinct, arraigned at the Tombs yesterday Lewis B. Stem, of No. 392 Pearl-street, and charged him with selling liquor on anothor man's license.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Oct. 25.--The congregation of the Second Presbyterian Church to-night, by a unanimous vote at a very large meeting, extended a call to the Rev. Dr. James McLeod, of Buffalo, to become their Pastor.

Mr. John Rooney, a leading Democrat of Brooklyn, nominated for Alderman at Large by the Republicans, in accepting the nomination has written a letter denouncing the sham reorganization of the Democracy, asserting that the Boss rules as absolutely as he ever did, ...

PARIS, Oct. 25.--The Radical Left in the Chamber of Deputies has decided to postpone its interpellation concerning the Tonquin question, as it does not wish to embarrass the Government while the negotiations with China are proceeding.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Oct. 25.--The Patriarchal Cirole is now an independent and self sustaining order. At the session of the Suprome Temple in this city this morning a resolution was unanimously adopted receiving the Odd-fellow qualification, and declaring the Patriarchal Circle henceforth to be an independent organization.
ALEXANDRIA, Oct. 25.--Nine additional deaths from cholera, most of the victims being Europeans, have occurred here.

POINT PLEASANT, N.J., Oct. 25.--A spirited pigeon-shooting match took place near this place to-day between William Nelson, of New-York, and Dr. Edwin Kale, of Philadelphia. The terms of the match were 75 birds each, 30 yards' rise, five traps, use of both barrels.
The complications in the Jefferson-Oswego District, by which two Republican candidates for Senator were placed in the field, have been the cause of much uneasiness to the Republican State Committee.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 25.--Orders have been issued from the War Department instructing Col. Carlin, in command of the Newport Barracks, to disregard for the present the previous orders regarding the preparations for the removal of the greater portion of the command to the East.

WARRENTON, Mo., Oct. 25.--A wildly insane man named Henry Keeny was placed in a large room adjoining the jail under the Courthouse by the authorities for shelter. While the jailer was at supper screams attracted people to the window, and they saw Keeny hugging the redhot stove. He was taken away, but death soon relieved him of his sufferings.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Oct. 25.--The Iowa Railway Commissioners are preparing their annual report, Mr. Coffin favors a recommendation that the Legislature pass a law forbidding the sale of immoral pictorial papers in Iowa passenger trains.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 25.--A murder has been committed on the line of the Erie Canal, the waters of which are daily giving up mangled fragments of a woman's body.

BOSTON, Oct. 25.--J.S. Grinnell has been nominated by the Democratic State Committee for Lieutenant-Governor, Grinnell is State Senator from Greenfield, Mass. The Democratic State Committee denies that it has received a letter from S.A.B. Abbott declining to be a candidate ...
CHICAGO, Oct. 25.--Three important meetings were held here to-day in connection with the Ohio River lines, which recently engaged in a disastrous rate war.

A young man who gave his name as Stephen James was employed in July last by Gaskell, Greenlie Co., machinists, of No. 499 Waterstreet, as an assistant to their book-keeper. James soon gained the confidence of the firm.

MONCTON, New-Brunswick, Oct. 25.--A tramp went into the residence of George McCann, at Petitcodiac, yesterday, and with a long knife cut Mrs. McCann's throat. He then fled and has not yet been captured. It is thought that the victim will recover, although her present condition is very critical.

CHICAGO, Oct. 25.--A bill was filed in the Superior Court to-day by F.M. Bradshaw against the Standard Oil Company to compel that corporation specifically to perform a contract. Bradshaw alleges that he made a contract with the Standard ...

BUFFALO, N.Y., Oct. 25.--In the Fillmore will case to-day O.H. Marshall testified that by request of Mrs. Fillmore he took charge of her affairs shortly after the death of the ex-President. He considered her perfectly rational.

PANAMA, Oct. 13.--Capt. D. Seymour, of the American whaling bark Hope On, which anchored in the bay on the 7th, from a four months' cruise, with 400 barrels of hump-back on board, reports having encountered a strange marine monster off St. Elmo.
NEW-ORLEANS, Oct. 25.--The managers of the Cotton Centennial Exposition have advertised for plans of the ground floor and elevator of the main exposition building, to be received up to Nov. 24.
Jesse Conklin, with a number of assistants, yesterday commenced to draw off the gas from a tank at the hotel at Woodsburg, belonging to the estate of the late Samuel Wood.
ALBANY, Oct. 25.--The prosecution in the Carroll divorce case closed to-day with the testimony of George L. Stevens, an old and intelligent man, who admitted that he had been supported ...

The Roman Catholics and Protestants of Lakeville, Conn., are still engaged in upholding their respective religious by endeavoring to exasperate one another. The crucifix which was erected to aid the devotions ...

Coroner Tice continued his inquiry last evening, at Mount Vernon, in the case of the death of Rudolph Sigmond, who died recently in the Mount Vernon Home of the New-York Infant Asylum from diphtheria and measles.

CHICAGO, Ill., Oct. 25--The South Park Retreat Hotel, in the suburb of Hyde Park, was to-day destroyed by fire. This morning about 4 o'clock the cook discovered the fire in a vacant room on the second floor, and at once ran to the room occupied by Mr. Chandler, the proprietor, and gave the alarm.

READING, Penn., Oct. 25.--The bicycle meet on the Fair Grounds in this city to-day was well attended, there being nearly 3,000 spectators on the grounds. Wheelmen were present from different parts of the State and a street procession was given at noon, the entire body being preceded by a mounted bugler.
TOMBSTONE, Arizona, Oct. 25.--W.H. Stuart, who has returned here from the Swissheim Mountains, says the Apaches have been routed by Mexican troops with great slaughter.
One of the female passengers of the steamship St. Germain, from Havre, weighed 198 pounds just after she stepped ashore.

BRIDGEPORT, Oct. 25.--On Monday night last a barn belonging to Mrs. J. Fitch Raymond, of Westport, was burned to the ground. Suspicion rested on a man who had been in the employ of Mrs. Raymond, but who had been discharged that day.
The problem of heating street cars has long puzzled the brains of engineers, and rendered the public uncomfortable. The difficulties to be met with in the invention of a cheap system of isolated ...

Romeyn Mulligan, an agent of the NewYork Life Insurance Company, living at No. 789 Willoughby avenue, Brooklyn, met a man named Thomas Flynn in a saloon on Canal-street yesterday morning, and was induced to go with him to No. 68 Varick-street, where they played faro, ...

The track of the Coney Island Jockey Club at Sheepshead Bay was laid out three years ago. Soon afterward many defects in its proportions were discovered, and this season means have been taken to remedy them.

The dinner which was tendered to Congress man Perry Belmont at the Argyle Hotel, Babylon, Long Island, in June last, and which was not given to him because he suddenly discovered that he had business in Philadelphia, is making a great deal of trouble for the committee of Democrats which made the arrangements for it.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 25.--At the semiannual meeting of the New-Haven County Medical Association to-day the case of Dr. E.L.R. Thompson, a physician of large practice, who was recently indicted for illegal practice, was brought up. A motion that he be expelled was unanimously carried, subject to the consent of the State Medical Association.

The session of the annual convention of the Congregational Association of this State closed last evening. The morning was given to the reports of the Ministerial Fund Society, and the Committee on Systematic Giving, which were followed by an essay on the "Causes and Remedies of ...

GLOUCESTER, Mass, Oct. 25.--The schooner Alaska, of this port, sailed on a bank trip on Aug. 18. On Aug. 24 she touched at Canso and subsequently started for the fishing grounds, since which time she has not been heard from, and it is feared she was lost in the gale of Aug 29. She had 12 men on board.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25.--Lieut.-Gen. Sheridan will arrive in Washington next Wednesday evening, and will formally relieve Gen. Sherman of command of the army the following day.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Oct. 25.--Dr. Thomas D. Warden, of Saratoga Springs, N.Y., and Miss Annie Scott Paine, eldest daughter of S.C. Paine, Esq., were married this morning at St. Stephen's Episcopal Church.

WALNUT RIDGE, Ark., Oct. 25.--An attempt was made to rob the north-bound express train on the Iron Mountain Road last night, about 10 o'clock, between O'Kean and De la Plaine, 15 miles north of this place.

PATERSON, N.J., Oct. 25.--A great Republican meeting was held to-night at the Opera-house, which was filled to overflowing. There were many of the better class of Democrats present. T. Frank Hoxie was Chairman.

The old suit of John A. Walsh against Thomas J. Brady, of star route notoriety, to recover about $42,000 which Mr. Walsh claims is owing to him by Brady, was before Judge Barrett in Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday, and Mr. Walsh received a bad set-back through the negligence of his counsel.

WAUSEON, Ohio, Oct. 26.--A terrible tragedy was enacted five miles from this place on Tuesday night. A farmer named George W. Williams drove into Wauseon on Tuesday afternoon with a load of clover-seed, which he sold for a considerable sum.
ST. LOUIS, Mo., Oct. 26.--Fifty operators in the coal mines of St. Clair County, Ill., have been indicted for violating the law requiring seales for weighing coal to be placed in each mine.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 26.--Lively scenes were witnessed in the United States Court here to-day during the arguments and the taking of testimony in the case of Dinsmore against the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad, which involves the validity of the lease of the New-Jersey Central to that corporation.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26.--Commissioner Hiram Price, of the Indian Bureau, has submitted to Secretary Teller his annual report for the fiscal year ended June 30, 1883.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Oct. 26.--Dispatches from Walnut Ridge and other places late last night say that the men who stopped the Iron Mountain train between O'Kean and De la Plaine on Wednesday night were wood-choppers who expected a lot of supplies, and who, when they found the goods were not aboard the train, retired without any demonstration.

ALBANY, Oct. 26.--In the Court of Appeals today the following business was transacted: No. 219-- Kersey Coats, Assignee, C., appellant, vs. Robert W. Donnell et al., respondents; argument resumed and concluded.

BUFFALO, Oct. 26.--The injunction which Mrs. Hamilton, Administratrix of the Ensign estate, obtained restraining the operation of the Commercial Line steamers has resulted in a salt blockade at Saginaw, Mich. The Commercial Line steamers were the only regular transporters of selt, and since they have been tied up several hundred tons of salt have accumulated at that point.
The Eleventh Senatorial Republican Convention met last evening at No. 341 West Fortyseventh-street, George W. Cregier presiding. Steven McClaye nominated Stephen N. Simonson for State Senator.
SALT LAKE CITY, Utah, Oct. 26.--Yesterday David Rich, son of Apostle Rich, was sentenced to the penitentiary for robbing the Zion's Savings Bank.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26. The President to-day signed the commission of Benjemin Butterworth as Commissioner of Patents vice Edgar M. Marble, resigned.
SHELTON, Conn., Oct. 26.--The Baldwin family, of Milford, dates back over 200 years, and an old account-book, once in possession of Noah Baldwin, of that town, is very interesting.
ST. JOHN, New-Brunswick, Oct. 26.--A threemile sculling-race to-day between Hugh McCormack and Edward Ross, for $50, was won easily by the former.

BUFFALO, Oct. 26.--The will of the late Rev. Willaim Shelton, D.D., was admitted to probate to-day. It is dated Dec. 9, 1881, and covers 17 pages of foolscap. There are large number of private bequests, including a liberal one to Bishop A. Cleveland Coxe.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Oct. 26.--The Pennsylvania and New-York Canal and Railroad Company put 50 Hungarian laborers to work this morning to fence in a swampy lot of land in the northern part of this city, which it claims as its property, which claim is disputed by the city.
ATLANTA, Ga., Oct. 26.--C.E. Kuhn, a painter and paper-hanger, and a native of Virginia, came to Atlanta 15 months ago. He was a young man of good address.

In spite of a drizzling rain-fall, there was at noon yesterday a small gathering of people in front of No. 99 Sixth-avenue, which soon swelled into a crowd, as a score or more colored men dressed in long black frock coats and wearing military fatigue caps entered the building and ascended the stairs.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26.--The Army Surgeon on duty at Whipple Barracks, Arizona, has reported to the War Department that Lieut. John F. Simpson, Third Cavalry, is in the hospital at that post, and is considered to be insane.
ALBANY, Oct. 25.--The control of the next State Senate figures more largely in the calculations of politicians than the election of the State ticket.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Oct. 26.--A beautiful and accomplished young woman, the daughter of Benjamin Schoolfield, of Rhea County, aged 17, while delirious this morning escaped from her bed and threw herself in front of the south-bound Cincinnati Southern train. She was huried from the track by the pilot of the engine, terribly bruised, and her death is hourly expected.

KENT, Ohio, Oct. 26.--Samuel Biehl, a young tramp, committed suicide yesterday by jumping head first into a retort at the glass works of Day, Williams Co. The furnace was heated to a high degree in order to melt sand, soda. ash, and other substances used in the composition of window glass. Death must have been instantaneous, as a single breath drawn in the fiery furnace would shrivel the lungs.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Oct. 26.--The Dominion Government has disallowed two railway acts passed by the Legislature of British Columbia-- one incorporating the Frazer Valley Railway Company and the other incorporating the new Westminster Southern Railway Company.

BIDDEFORD, Me., Oct. 26.--Frank Simpson, about 30 years old, has been arrested here charged with assault upon, with intent to kill, his mother, aged 65 years.

BUFFALO, Oct. 26.--The Carriage and Wagon Axle Manufacturers' Association of the United States met in session yesterday in this city with the independent manufacturers of the country to take action in regard to the dullness of the trade, which has been so evident for the past six or seven months.

McCullough, both of whom are interested in the horse Quebec, and are supposed to be also interested in F. Robinson's stable.

ALBANY, Oct. 26.--The Governor to-day issued an order of removal upon Benjamin W. Downing, District Attorney of Queens County, for malfeasance in office in receiving two checks for $100 each, to stimulate his zeal in the prosecution of an indictment against James Riley, who was indicted in Queens County for manslaughter in the killing with a knife of Robert E. Desmond, on Aug. 28, 1882.

BOWIE, Arizona, Oct. 26.--A courier from Lieut. Hunter's camp on Silver Creek brings advices that 75 hostile Apaches surrendered to Lieut. Hunter last night, and that 11 more were coming in. They will all be brought here.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Oct. 26.--There were no important developments to-day in the war between the Pittsburg, Youngstown and Chicago and the Pennsylvania Railroad Companies. Nothing has been done by either since Monday.

LANCASTER, Penn., Oct. 26.--Jacob Gangaway, the boy who placed an obstruction on the the Reading and Columbia Railroad near Ephrata last may, causing a wreck which resulted in the death of Master Mechanic George M. Hain, was today convicted of involuntary manslaughter with a recommendation to mercy. Sentence was deferred and a motion made for a new trial.
OSWEGO, N.Y., Oct. 26.--The Republicans opened their campaign here to-night with a large and enthusiastic meeting, in which all factions united.

CHICAGO, Oct. 26.--The People's Railway Company of America to-day commenced a suit in the Circuit Court against Wilbur F. Story, proprietor of the Chicago Times, for libel, placing the damages at $500,000.

MEMPHIS, Oct. 26.--This was the fourth day of the Fall meeting of the Memphis Jockey Club. A cold rain prevailed all day. The attendance was up to the average, but the betting was limited. The track was heavy.

LONDON, Oct. 26.--The Cabinet Council was engaged yesterday in discussing the affair of Missionary Shaw. It was stated that France would grant an indemnity to Mr. Shaw of 1,000, besides officially expressing suitable regrets at the occurrence. This closes the incident.

LONDON, Oct. 36.--The Manchester Guardian, in its commercial article, says there is no improvement in the market. Prices tend in favor of producers. Business is lessened by the strength of the cotton market.
The Executive Committee of the anti-machine Republican General Committee met last evening at No. 173 East Thirty-third-street, Christopher Pullman in the chair.

PERTH AMBOY, N.J., Oct. 26.--Last Saturday, as one of the Lehigh Valley boats passed the Narrows between this place and Staten Island, a yawl boat, without oars, was picked up with a woman fast asleep in it. The boat was drifting with the outgoing tide.

VINITA, Indian Territory, Oct. 26.--During a dispute over a game of cards in a store at Catoosa Station, on the St. Louis and San Francisco Railroad, west of here, yesterday, A. Cleveland, a Texas cattle man, shot and killed John James, a resident of Cherokee City, Ark. Cleveland escaped.
Bellini's opera "Norma" was presented at the Academy of Music last night by Col. Mapleson's company in the presence of a large and remarkably enthusiastic audience.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., Oct. 26.--A social event of unusual attraction in Lockport was the wedding of Miss Frances M. Daniels, daughter of the Hon. F.R. Daniels, ex-Mayor of Lockport, to Mr. Henry A. Martin, an oil broker, of Bradford.
New-Yorkers claim to live in a whirl and to have time for nothing, but there is no city in the land where a crowd has more time to stop and investigate a dog fight or a row between bootblacks.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., Oct. 26.--A report received late last night from Argentine states that 12 of the 32 men in the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe yards there left their work last evening.

PARIS, Oct. 10.--After several days' negotiations M. Jules Ferry has succeeded in finding an officer who is willing to accept the position of Minister of War, made vacant by the forced retirement of Gen. Thibaudin.
A somewhat amusing story is told of an alleged discovery of oil on Conanicut. It appears that a man owning property there engaged a Providenne mechanic named D.L. Barker to bore an artesian well.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 26.--Many tears were shed over one small child in Judge Allison's court to-day. "I want my child--I want him--I want him because he is mine!" cried Mrs. Bessie Feaster during a hearing on a proceeding to obtain possession of her 4-year-old son, who had been taken away by her husband.

Mr. A.P. Bethell, in a letter to the Standard, explains a system of scale color, or as he prefers to call it color music, which he invented more than 16 years ago for his own use, and he hopes soon to publish in some magazine such a sketch of the system as will enable artists to form some opinion upon it.

BALTIMORE, Md., Oct. 26.--This was the second day of the Fall meeting of the Maryland Jockey Club. The track was in a much-improved condition and the attendance was large. QUEENSTOWN, Oct. 27.--The Cunard Line steam-ship Bothnia, Capt. McKay, from New-York Oct. 17, for Liverpool, arr. here at 2:30 A.M. to-day. The Inman Line steam-ship City of Chicago, Capt. Leitch, from Liverpool, sld. hence yesterday for NewYork.

The first attempt at a National Horse Show was brought to a close last evening. For five days Madison-Square Garden has been crowded to its utmost capacity, afternoon and evening, with ladies and gentleman representing the wealth, culture, and refinement of the City.

RALEIGH, N.C., Oct. 26.--The Republicans Convention at Edenton yesterday nominated Judge Charles C. Pool, of Pasquetank, to fill the vacancy in the First District caused by the death of Congresman Walter F. Pool. Judge Pool is a brother of the deceased Congressman. He is a lawyer, and is Collector of the port of Elizabeth.

PORTLAND, Oregon, Oct. 26.--Ben Holladay, of railroad fame, has commenced a suit against his brother joseph for the possession of $2,000,000 worth of property, held in trust by the latter for the former.

ALBANY, Oct. 26.--Judge Osborn, after the summing up of Messrs. Peckham, Moak, and Carroll in the Nolan divorce case, charged the jury today and then directed them to bring in a sealed verdict by 10 o'clock to-morrow. Should they agree in the meantime they can disperse.

BOSTON, Oct. 26.--Insurance Commissioner Tarbox has sent a letter to the United States Plate Glass Company, in which he refuses to reinstate the company in Massachusetts. The Commissioner gives in detail the results of his recent investigation of the affairs of the company in Philadelphia, criticisng the character of its investments, many of which he regards as of a speculative character.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 26.--Judge Noonan, of the Court of Criminal Correction, decided to-day that the game of draw poker, while requiring a great deal of skill on the part of the players, is yet so thoroughly imbued with the element of chance that it comes under the gambling law.

Secretary Vrooman opened a bushel of letters directed to the Republican State Committee, yesterday, in nearly every one of which was some mention of the growing interest of Republicans in their State ticket.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 26.--A freight train on the Philadelphia. Wilmington and Baltimore Railroad collided with a construction train at Seventieth-street, West Philadelphia, this morning. The bridge over the railroad at that place was demolished, both engines badly damaged and several cars wrecked.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 26.--The Republicans State and Executive Committee met here this afternoon, 15 of the members being present. There was a long consultation on the result of the last campaign and the causes which led to Republican overthrow.
BUFFALO, Oct. 26.--Proceedings in the contest of Mrs. Fillmore's will after taking the testimony of the Hon. James O. Putnam and one or two others as to her sanity have been adjourned until Nov. 8.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Oct. 26.--The legislative committee appointed to investigate the charges that the Standard Oil Company paid money to have suppressed certain testimony obtained by the State in its suit against the company held another session-to-day.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26.--At the session of the Universalist General Convention to-day the Committee on the Commemoration of Luther's Birthday reported a resolution expressing the gratitude of the Universalist Church for the movement which he had inaugurated.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 26.--President Porter, of Yale College, received Lord Coleridge and party at the railroad station this morning on the arrival of the 10:15 train from New-York.

John S. Higgins, a flagman on an Erie freight train, while attempting to board his train last night at Penborn, N.J., fell into the creek there and was drowned. The boy has not yet been recovered. He was about 45 years of age, and resided at Port Jervis, N.Y., where he leaves a wife, but no children.

A decision of much importance to the City of New-York was rendered by the Supreme Court, General Term, yesterday. By it the judgment for $1,126,148 13 entered against the City by John Baird, on the report of a Referee, is reversed, and a result has been achieved for which the law officers of the corporation have been laboring since 1874. The suit grows out of the famous "watermeter job."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26.--Secretary Chandler has received from the Naval Advisory Board the report and recommendations with regard to the type and number of vessels which should be begun at once in order to carry forward the work of reconstruction of the unmanned fleet.

The Marquis of Lorne and her Royal Highness the Princess will leave for England by the steam-ship Sardinian on Saturday, Capt. Barolay, Superintendent of the Allan Line, has fitted up a beautiful suite of state-rooms for the party in the vessel.

ALBANY, Oct. 26.--The Governor has granted a pardon to William Rabson, who was sentenced in Rensselaer County on Jan. 17, 1877, to 15 years' imprisonment for alleged rape. He was 17 years old when sentenced.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 28.--The new theological seminary of the German Evangelists, seven miles west of this city, was dedicated today with imposing ceremonies. Notwithstanding the stormy weather 2,000 persons were present, also delegates from many parts of the country. The building is a four-story brick and is beautifully situated. It cost of $100,000. The seminary will open next week with 68 students.

BALTIMORE, Md., Oct. 25.--James S. Bartol, Chief Judge of the Maryland Court of Appeals, will publish a card to the people of Baltimore tomorrow resigning his position on account of continued ill-health.

CAMBRIDGE CITY, Ind., Oct. 28.--The body of an unknown man, apparently an Italian, was found on the road near here on Saturday. The man was evidently murdered, as the skull was mashed in. A passport from Italy to New-York was found in his pocket. There was nothing on his person that would assist in his recognition. Two suspicious persons have been arrested in connection with the case.

LAFAYETTE, Ind., Oct. 28.--A special freight train was in collision with the regular freight train near Stookwell, on the Cincinnati, Indianapolis, St. Louis and Chicago Railway, this morning, Joseph Bowers, a fireman, was killed, and both locomotives were demolished.
