HAVANA, Oct. 28.--The town of Guantanamo, near Santiago de Cuba, was visited by a cyclone yesterday. The direction of the wind was from north to south-west.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 28.--The little hamlet of Ledyard Centre, in this State, has lost its most important factor in the death of John Newton. The township embraced many of his broad acres, but from them the hamlet itself derived little benefit, as John was a miser.

News has reached this city of the death in Paris, on the 30th of last September, of Pietro Mezzara, the well-known San Francisco sculptor. Soon after the death of his friend, F.L.A. Ploohe, Mezzara went to France, where he has resided ever since.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 29.--A meeting of underwriters was held to-day to organize a tariff association, to be composed of all the companies in the city. About 90 per cent. of the companies were represented. It is claimed that the business is very unsatisfactory on account of the lack of a discriminative tariff. The new association, which was organized, but has not yet elected officers, will be outside of the Board of Underwriters.

Phyfe and Campbell, the builders of the Gramercy Apartment-house, his 12 lots on the west side of the Fifth-avenue Plaza for the sum of $850,000, and the purchasers intend to improve the premises at once by the erection of an edifice suitable to so grand a location.

CHICAGO, Ill., Oct. 29.--Detectives to-day arrested W.H. McClenningham, agent of the Northern Pacific Express Company, stationed at Dawson, Dakota, for the embazzlement of $2,000. He belongs to a good family of Woodstock, Canada, and was on his way from that place to Winnipeg when arrested.

WAUPUN, Wis., Oct. 29.--S.J. Hudson, of Belvidere, Ill., who came here recently with two children in search of his runaway wife, found her masquerading in male attire under the name of Frank Dubois.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Oct. 29.--The steamship Wanderer, from Livingston via Port Cortez and Belize, arrived this evening, bringing as part of her cargo nine bales of cotton raised by Mr. Coleman, of San Pedro, Spanish Honduras, and shipped to John Phelps Co., of this city.

MONTREAL, Oct. 29.--The chief topics of interest in the financial world to-day are the action of the Government in guaranteeing the Canadian Pacific Railway dividend and the allotment of a portion of the Dominion new 4 per cent. loan.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 29.--Following upon the sensation caused by the accident at the boat-house, the attention of the students has been called from the melancholy outcome of the Fall aquatic sports to the Fall field meetings of the athletic association.

The Veteran Battalion of the Twenty-second Regiment met last evening at the armory and decided to appear in the parade on Evacuation Day. Col. G.W. Laird presided, and there were present about 30 of the battalion.

MADRID, Oct. 29.--The appointment of Senor Camacho, lately Minister of Finance, to the Governorship of the Bank of Spain, signifies the union of the two political groups in the new Ministry, and is intended to prepare the way for the formation of a great Liberal party.

ST. PETERSBURG, Oct. 29.--The second number of a Socialist journal issued by the students of Chestvo has been published here. It declares that despite the miserable condition of the peasantry the Socialist propaganda has not made the progress it expected.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Oct. 29.--The Grand Jury to-day found a true bill for murder against young John Coffey, who shot and killed the prioner Albert Gossett on Saturday last. Gossett was the murderer of Coffey's father.
JACKSONVILLE, Ill., Oct. 29.--A resolution was passed by the City Council to-night enjoining the "Jesse James troupe" from performing in this city to-morrow night.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 29.--J.H. Haverly opened his new theatre in this city this evening. The house is what was known as the Lyceum, and is situated on South Broad-street. It has been thoroughly refitted, and the opera given this evening was "Prince Methusalem." Notwithstanding the disagreeable weather the house was well filled.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Oct. 29.--The police last night and this morning raided nearly 100 public poker-rooms. Donnelly, who was convicted on Saturday of keeping a poker-room, will appeal his case until the last court decides against him or until he secures a decision that poker is a game of science and not of chance.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Oct. 29.--The HuberMagoon scandal, which has created a great sensation in religious circles here, has been further complicated by the sudden death yesterday of Jacob J. Plucker, Mrs. Huber's father.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29.--Secretary Teller has informed the Secretary of the Navy that he would be glad to adopt for Washington local time the seventy-fifth meridian time, which is understood to be eight minutes eight seconds faster than the present local time, and the change will go into effect on Nov. 18.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 29.--Two letter-carriers, Charles Gehring and John Isaacs, were arrested to-day on warrants issued by United States Commissioner, Rogers, charged with embezzling and destroying mail matter. The particular charge is opening envelopes containing election tickets, sent through the Post Office addressed to various parties, and destroying, the tickets by burning them. They were held in $1,500 bail for a hearing on Wednesday.

DUBLIN, Oct. 29.--There were no public meetings of members of the National League in Ireland yesterday, those appointed for the day having been abandoned in consequence of the proclamation of the Government forbidding them.

ST. JOHN, New-Brunswick, Oct. 29.--While section men were engaged in repairing the track on the bridge over Mile Stream to-day an Intercolonial Railway freight train going north failed to notice the signals. The engine passed over safely, but a dozen laden cars went through to the stream beneath. The damage to rolling stock and other property is heavy. No one was injured.

CHICAGO, Ill., Oct. 29.--At the close here last night of the bicycle-race of 72 hours, or 12 hours per day, the score stood as follows: Prince, 889 miles: Morgan, 883; Woodside, 865; Shock, 855, and Dawse, 750.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Oct. 29.--The Schenectady Union, the only paper in the entire Congressional district having the Associated Press franchise, was sold to-day to John A. Stelcher, formerly of the Troy Times. The price paid was $18,000.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29.--The Chilian Minister has received an official dispatch from Lima, dated to-day, announcing that Arequipa has surrendered without a battle being fought and that Montero has fled. The dispatch also says that Iglesias has been proclaimed President in that city.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Oct. 29.--News reached the city this afternoon of a fatal accident yesterday at Brooks Tunnel, near Confluence, Penn., on the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad, 85 miles from Pittsburg. Over 1,200 pounds of dynamite exploded, instantly killing five persons.

VIENNA, Oct. 29.--The Budget Committee of the Austrian delegation to-day discussed the foreign estimates. Count Kalnoky, Minister of Foreign Affairs, in answer to questions, reviewed the political situation in Europe.

POMEROY, Washington Territory, Oct. 29.-- An organization entitled the Washington Territory Wool-growers' Association has been formed here, and has passed resolutions calling on Delegate Brents and Oregon's Representatives in Congress to use their efforts to fix the tariff on wool as it was before the last Congress met.

May, of No. 161 West Thirtysixth-street, who was arrested charged with malpractice upon Frances Seates, who was living with a female friend at No. 847 Third-avenue, has been discharged by Justice Herrman, at the Yorkville Police Court, the evidence showing that he had been unjustly accused.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 29.--The stockholders of the Keely Motor Company are up in arms again, and are preparing for another suit against the inventor.

MANCHESTER, N.H., Oct. 29.--Samuel Brown, a veteran of the war of 1812, died to-day. He was 87 years old.

ALBANY, Oct. 29.--John McCall, Jr., the Superintendent of Insurance, has issued a circular to insurance companies in this State relieving them from fees, taxes, and rates to the amount of $11,165 per annum, the action to take effect from the close of the fiscal year Sept. 30. Three Indian elephants arrived at Hoboken Saturday on the steam-ship Oder from Bremen. The smallest is a female about 2 years old, and stands 4 feet 6 inches high. She is valued at $2,000, and can flap her ears in five different styles.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 29.--The Coroner today began an inquiry in regard to the death of Maggie Conway, aged 21, who died on Friday in the house of Mrs. Ann McIlhenny, on Kinggoldstreet. Evidence was offered to the effect that death was due to malpractice, and as other testimony is to be produced the inquest was adjourned until Friday, Mrs. McIlhenny was committed.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29.--The United States Coast Survey Office has been informed that the Eagere arrived at New-London, Conn., this morning after a very rough voyage. It had been suggested that the wreck seen off Metinic Island might have been the Eagere.

TORONTO, Ontario, Oct. 29.--Hanlan, the oarsman, says he has not yet received an answer to his dispatch to Laycock, and is consequently not sure of the date of his departure for Australia, if indeed he goes at all.

BERLIN, Oct. 29.--The disorders at Oldenburg arising from the unpopularity of the commanding officer, Gen. Steinmann, who is said to have insulted the soldiers and people of Oldenburg, have excited much attention here.
MONTREAL, Quebec, Oct. 29.--The steamer Sardinian, with the Marquis of Lorne and the Princess Louise on board, passed the south-west point of Anticosti Island at 9 P.M. yesterday.
PITTSBURG, Penn., Oct. 29.--H. Herzog Brother, wholesale notion-dealers of this city, failed to-day for $12,100.

JOLIET, Ill., Oct. 29.--In the case of the convict Mooney, who killed a fellow-prisoner in the penitentiary a few months ago, the defense have tried to throw a cloud over the testimony that was given by the medical experts.

The Prohibitionists held a mass-meeting last night in Choral Hall, Lexington-avenue and One Hundred and Twenty-fifth-street. About 300 persons were present when James Shipman called the meeting to order.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 29.--The fifty-fourth annual exhibition of the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts was opened this evening. The galleries were well filled with guests, and the Germania orchestra played at the head of the staircase.

Margaret Nash and John D. O'Reilly, indicted for larceny in the first degree, pleaded not guilty yesterday, before Judge Gildersleeve, to a charge of swindling Bridget Reilly, an aged servant, out of $4,300, which she had saved in the last 50 years.

J.H. Delevan, who lives at No. 66 Carltonavenue, Jersey City Heights, and claims to be an insurance broker, was a prisoner at Police Headquarters yesterday, having been brought back to this City from Chicago on a charge of fraud.

The last week of the campaign opens most auspiciously for the Republican State ticket. Letters of encouragement were received by every mail in the State Committee rooms from every quarter of the State.

BATAVIA, N.Y., Oct. 29.--Charles Porter Pardee, the Batavia farmer who was arrested in the Continental Hotel, New-York, on Friday night on a charge of bigamy, arrived here yesterday morning in charge of Sheriff Southworth.

John H. Strahan and Thomas Allison appeared before Controller Grant yesterday as counsel for Auditor of Accounts Daniel Jackson, who was required by the Controller to show cause why he should not be removed from office for gross carelessness and negligence.
Mr. Billy McGlory, of Armory Hall, Hesterstreet, after putting one of his horses through an afternoon on the road last week, walked pensively down Broadway about 5 o'clock in the evening.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Oct. 29.--The wife of ex-Secretary of the Interior James Harlan is reported dangerously ill at the family residence at Mount Pleasant, and the immediate relatives have been appraised.

A man, who by dint of sheer courage and energy overcame almost insuperable difficulties and showed that life, even when it seems almost a curse, may be well worth living, died last week at Arare, in the canton of Geneva.

Mrs. Margaret Finnegan and her daughter were complainants at Police Head-quarters yesterday against Frank Finnegan, their son and brother. He is but 22 years of age, but he has been for some time a source of trouble and sorrow to his relatives.

CHICAGO, Ill., Oct. 29.--Lieut.-Gen. P.H. Sheridan took his departure this evening for Washington. The party consisted of the General and wife, Lieut.-Col. J.F. Gregory and Lieut.-Col. W. C. Volknar, Aides-de-Camp, and Lieut.-Col. M.V. ...

SHERMAN, Texas, Oct. 29.--It is reported that the town of Gordonville has been totally destroyed by a fire that started in a drug store which had been set fire to after being robbed. The insurance is unknown.
LONDON, Oct. 30.--The Allan Line steam-ship Hanoverian, Capt. Stephens, from Montreal ...
PERTH AMBOY, N.J., Oct. 29.--It is rumored here to-day that the body found near Boynton Beach, in the wood, by two hunters, is that of a young woman who came here from New-York in July last.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29.--Pere Hyacinthe Loyson arrived here to-day from New-York, and is stopping at the house of Ralph Merriman, the son of Mme. Loyson by her first marriage.

"Chinese" GORDON is generally known to be a deeply religious man of the old Puritan type. It is this fact that will enable people to understand the extraordinary letter that he has written concerning the Palestine Canal project.

Mr. F.B. Sidney, a young Englishman of pleasing address and insinuating manners, who for the past year has been engaged in the lumber business, has disappeared, leaving creditors behind him who mourn the loss of over $7,000 in the aggregate.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 29.--The Committee of One Hundred has made discoveries in the Assessors' lists which may lead to the exposure of false registration and political colonization on a scale eclipsing the developments made in some of the down-town wards within the last few years.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Oct. 29.--The Hon. C.M. Woolsey having declined the nomination for member of Assembly in the Second Ulster District, the Republicans have nominated G.D.B. Hasbrouck, a prominent young lawyer of Esopus, who has for some time past acted as the assistant of District Attorney Clearwater.
The impetus given to trade in the Russian Empire by the recent Moscow Exhibition has given rise to considerable activity and an apparent desire to push Russian trade in every direction.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 29.--William Shepard Bryan was nominated to-night by the Executive Committee of the Democratic City Convention as a candidate for Judge of the Court of Appeals of this State, to fill the vacancy caused by the resignation of Judge James L. Bartol. The election will take place at the general election next week.

LONDON, Oct. 29.--A gentleman was attaked yesterday by a lunatic in a compartment of a car on a suburban railway, and beaten until he was insensible.

LONDON, Oct. 18.--By persons likely to be well informed considerable doubt is felt as to whether there is any foundation for the programme of impending changes in the Cabinet which is somewhat ostentatiously set forth ...

On Monday morning of last week C.S. Starr and C.S. Thornton, of Monticello, and D.S. Avery of Wurtsboro, started for Blank Lake, in the town of Bethel, on a deer-hunt.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Oct. 29.--The body of exAlderman John Geiger, who was drowned last June, was found this morning in a pile of drift in a mill creek. The body was identified by a watch, a badge, and pocket-books.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 29.--The Grand Jury returned true bills of indictment to-day against Frank Finn, Lawrence Plunkett, and Charles Henry for defacing statuary in Fairmount Park. The cases will, it is said, be pressed to trial vigorously.

The Independent Citizens' Sub-Committee on Nominations decided last night to add to the ticket which James O'Brien heads for Register the names of four candidates for Supreme and City Court Judgeships.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 29.--The American Iron and Steel Association has received statistics showing a considerable falling off in the imports of iron and steel from Great Britain. The imports of these products last month footed up 55,144 tons, against 66,633 tons for the previous month. The total imports for the nine months of this year were 540,079 tons, while for the corresponding period last year they were 950,905 tons.

The rainy weather last evening supplied plenty of jokes to Thatcher, Primrose and West's Minstrels, who began the last week of their engagement in the New Park Theatre. "Which would you rather be, a doctor or lawyer?" Interlocutor Morse inquired of Mr. Thatcher.
RALEIGH, N.C., Oct. 29.--Guilford Loon, who was convicted of rape in the Lenoir County Superior Court, has been sentenced to be hanged on Thursday, Dec. 20, at Kingston.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 29.--The lawyers concluded their argument this evening in the trial of George Brown and Mrs. Hestor Ann Lomack, colored, who are charged with the murder of Forward Lomack, husband of the woman. The jury brought in a verdict of not guilty. About 1,000 persons, mostly colored, surrounded the court building all day.

CHICAGO, Ill., Oct. 29.--The stationery and printing house of Culver, Page, Hoyne Co., one of the oldest in this city, closed its doors this morning. In answer to inquiries it was stated that the business had been closed out to John Morris.

DES MOINES, Oct. 29.--Certain visionary Democrats are trying to effect a coalition of the Republican members of the Legislature who are lukewarm toward Allison with the opposition members in favor of Judge J.M. Dav for United ...

BOSTON, Mass., Oct. 29.--The joint special committee of the City Council appointed to consider the propriety of changing the standard of time to be shown by the public clocks and apparatus in Boston, gave a public hearing this afternoon.
Those who have been traveling on the Continent lately cannot but notice the difference in appearance between the German and Austrian soldiers.

Bellini's chief aim in composing "I Puritani," his last opera, was to furnish suitable parts for that mighty quartet of Italian singers, Pasba, and Rubini, Lablache and Tamburini, who at that time were entrancing all Europe with their marvelous art.

LONDON, Oct. 29.--The Mark Lane Express, in its weekly review of the British grain trade, says: "The weather has generally been fine and mild, and the land is in excellent condition for sowing. Prices are weaker. All qualities of wheat except fine are cheaper.
The Sinking Fund Commissioners met in Mayor Edson's office yesterday and resolved to pay off $950,000 of the principal of the City debt and to cancel $711,000 bonds now held by the sinking fund.

The first annual horse show auction sale began at the American Horse Exchange yesterday, a large number of persons being in attendance. Most of the horses sold yesterday were disposed of at low prices, ranging from $100 to $400.
The American Society of Mechanical Engineers will hold its annual sessions at No. 127 East Twenty-third-street, beginning to-morrow evening at 8 o'clock and finished on Friday.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 29.--The clerks in the office of Grand Secretary Turner, of the Knights of Labor, at No. 202 Spruce-street, are busily engaged in mailing circulars to district and local assemblies, containing a resolution adopted by the General Assembly, repudiating the organization styled the "Improved Order of the Knights of Labor."

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Oct. 29.--The notorious Sam Pine, who is wanted at North Salem, N.Y., for an assault on Miss Stocum, and is held here for burglary and horse-theft, was brought before the Superior Court this afternoon. By the advice of counsel he pleaded guilty, and was sentenced to 14 years in State prison--10 years for burglary and 4 years for horse-stealing.

PARIS, Oct. 17.--The visit of M. Jules Ferry and some of the members of his Cabinet to Rouen and Havre is the important event of the moment. Not only has this Ministerial visit a political signification, but it has also a commercial importance in ...

MONTGOMERY, N.Y., Oct. 29.--John Sammons, an inoffensive old man, lives a few miles from this place, owns a fine farm, and has attained notoriety as the purchaser of his own coffin and as predicting the exact day of his own death.

ROCKLAND, Me., Oct. 29.--A dispatch was received to-day by the owners of the schooner America, of this port, lime laden, for New-York, which states that she was burned and sank off Cape Cod on the night of the 24th inst. The crew took to the boats, and was picked up by the schooner Addie M. Bird and landed at Newport News, Va.

The thirty-seventh annual convention of the American Missionary Society was called to order at 8 o'clock yesterday afternoon in the Central Congregational Church. In the absence of William B. Washburn, LL.D., President of the society, the Rev. J.E. Rankin presided...

WHEELING, West Va., Oct. 30.--A large meteor was visible here at 9:14 o'clock this evening. It was seen first in Aries and passed eastward into Taurus, where it exploded, fragments being visible as they flew in every direction. The meteor was about one-third the diameter of the moon, and cast a strong shadow on the lighted streets.

Controller Grant yesterday appointed William J. Lyon, his private secretary, as Auditor of Accounts, in place of Daniel Jackson, removed. Mr. Lyon was for several years a cashier in the office of the Associated Press.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 30.--Articles of incorporation of the United States Central Railroad Company, with a capital of $75,000,000, were filed to-day at Denver, Col., with head business offices in this city. "The opening of this road," said Chief...

PARIS, Oct. 30.--Figaro publishes a report that the Governor of the Chinese Province of Yunnan, with 14,000 troops, has received orders to enter Tonquin and occupy Cao-Baug, about 130 miles north of Hanoi, the French head-quarters.

LIVERPOOL, Oct. 30.--Morris Ranger, a cotton broker, formally announced to the President of the Liverpool Cotton Association to-day that he was unable to meet demands that had matured, and that he had suspended payment.

LONDON, Oct. 30.--While the Inman line steamer City of Berlin was entering the Mersey today she came in collision with her Majesty's ship Hawk, damaging the latter's starboard bows and carrying away some of her boats. The steamer received no damage.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30.--There will be no ceremony attending the transfer of the army from Gen. Sherman to Lieut-Gen. Sheridan Thursday morning. Two short orders will be issued--one by Gen. Sherman upon relinquishing command, and one by Gen. Sheridan upon assuming it.

To offset the impression created at the meeting of Tammany's Committee on Organization that the Democratic State ticket is likely to suffer in this City, the County Democracy's Executive Committee held a meeting last evening and its members expressed the cheerist views in regard to both the State ticket and the union County ticket.

Congress has no right to punish an inhabitant of a Territory for holding a specified religious opinion or belief, but it has an undoubted right to punish him for violating laws that are constitutional and that are enforced in every State in the Union.
George Stephen, of Montreal, is at the Windsor Hotel. Col. E. McK. Hudson, United States Army, is at the Albemarie Hotel.
There was an exceptionally large attendance at the annual horse show sale at the American Horse Exchange yesterday. William Easton occupying the auctioneer's desk.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 30.--The stockholders of the Pemberton and Sea Shore Railroad Company and the Philadelphia and Long Branch Railway Company met in Camden to-day and adopted an agreement of consolidation and merger, the new company to be called the Philadelphia and Long Branch Railroad Company.
ELMIRA, N.Y., Oct. 30.--There is a lively competition between the New-York, Lake Erie and Western and the Delaware. Lackawanna and Western Railroads relating to excursion matters.
Assignments for the benefit of creditors were filed in the County Clerk's office yesterday by John F. Lovejoy and H. Ingalls Drake to James L. Fling, and by Abraham Wallach to Frederick Lewis.

DORRITY--SPARKS--FETTEROLF--MANGAM. Miss Eugenie Stephanie C. Sparks was mar ried to Mr. John Henry Dorrity, a young lawyer of this City, in the Church of St. Francis Xavier, at 8 o'clock last evening. Father Ducey, of St. Leo's, and Father Coltan, of St. Stephen's, officiated. The bride wore a dress of white satin and brocaded silk, trimmed with point lace and orange blossoms.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 30.--The case of the State against James P. Briley, who recently shot and killed Robert P. Bates, during a circus performance in this city, was called in the Criminal Court this morning. The court-room was crowded...

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30.--In this trial of the suit of Hallet Kilbourn against John G. Thompson, ex-Sergeant-at-Arms of the House of Representatives, Mr. Kilbourn was called as a witness. He gave an account of his arrest and imprisonment, reading passages from the report of the investigation committee and of the proceedings of the House.

The art loan exhibition in aid of the fund to defray the cost of the pedestal for the Bartholdi statue will be opened at the National Academy of Design, in this City, on Monday, Dec. 3, and will continue for four weeks.

MATAWAN, N.J., Oct. 30.--The First Presbyterian Church of this place has been without a Pastor for six months past owing to the resignation of the Rev. William Ford, now in Brooklyn. At a meeting of the congregation held to-night it was voted to extend a call to the Rev. Robert Kent, of Ringoes, N.J.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 30.--The fourth day of the Fall meeting of the Maryland Jockey Club at Pimlico was much better attended than was anticipated. The weather was bright and clear, with a sharp north-west wind, but the track was in wretched condition, having been thoroughly saturated by the heavy rain which prevailed throughout...

TRENTON, Oct. 30--Charles G. McCann, the youthful Camden mail agent recently convicted of stealing two sheets of three-cent postage stamps and some small change from the Bridgeton (Cumberland County) Post Office, was arraigned for sentence in the Unites States District Court here ...

CITY OF MEXICO, Oct. 30.--The opening of the Fall races of the Mexican Jockey Club was a great success. The principal race was won by the French horse Mayomet. The trotting race was won by the American horse Black Prince. The time made in both races was fair.

MONTREAL, Oct. 30.--The guardian of William Murray, a minor, entered an action to-day against the South-eastern Railway Company for $50,840 damages for injuries received in an accident near North Troy some time ago, which rendered the boy a cripple for life.
ST. LOUIS, Mo., Oct. 30.--Tom Allen, at one time the champion pugilist of the world, was arraigned in the Police Court here to-day upon a charge of keeping a disorderly house.

The Executive Committee of the National Rifle Association met yesterday afternoon in No. 102 William-street to investigate charges against Lieut. B.A. Skinnell, of Company H, Ninth Regiment, who was accused of bribing scorers at Creedmoor during the competition for the State marksmanship medal. There were present Gen. George...

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 30.--The trial of Collector Crumbaugh, of the Second Internal Revenue District, on the charge of violating the postal laws by sending private letters in official envelopes, resulted in his acquital. It was evident that the motive of the persecution was to get the letters before the public and make Crumbaugh ridiculous.

MONTREAL, Oct. 30.--The Earl of Cork has lodged a complaint with the police here that he was robbed on Saturday of a pocket-book contain ing a circular note for 1,000 $150 in Canadian money, and some valuable papers. There is no clue to the thieves.

BOSTON, Oct. 30.--C.A. Holt, a lawyer, was arrested to-day by a Deputy United States Marshal for violation of the pension laws. He furnished bail in the sum of $5,000 to await examination, to take place on Friday.

Messrs. Fairchild and Matthews, the United States Local Inspectors of Steam-boats, rendered their report yesterday in regard to the collision between the ferry-boats Weehawken and Pavonia on the 15th inst.

A mass-meeting under the auspices of Branch No. 155 of the Irish National League was held last evening at the Hall of the Holy Innocents, Broadway and Thirty-seventh-street, about 600 persons being present. On the stage were seated the Rev. Fathers Larkin and Downs, ...

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Oct. 30.--The stockholders of the Cincinnati, Indianapolis, St. Louis and Chicago Railroad held their annual meeting yesterday in this city and elected as Directors for the ensuing year...

The Republicans of the Twenty-fourth District have placed in the field for their Assembly nominee Mr. Henry W. Hayden, a young lawyer, who has lived in the district nearly all his life and is tolerably familiar with the needs of this outlying section of the City. Mr. Hayden was born in West Fourteenth-street 30 years ago.

ST. JOHN, N.B., Oct. 30.--An inch of snow fell at Memramcook and Dorchester last night. A heavy storm of rain and wind prevailed here to-day. The wind at noon reached a velocity of 40 miles an hour. No damage has been reported.

WAUPUN, Wis., Oct. 30.--A strange case has come to light in this town around which there still hangs an air of impenetrable mystery. Every woman is gossiping about it. Last Spring a young woman named Gertrude Fuller became the bride of a young man--or a person supposed to be a ...
BOSTON, Oct. 30.--Wendell Phillips makes another contribution to the literature of the present heated campaign in this State, which closes with the election next Tuesday.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Oct. 30.--Kiefer Stiefel's tannery, in the upper part of Allegheny City, was this morning the scene of a terrible affair, two men sacrificing their lives in an unsuccessful attempt to save that of a fellow-workman.

ALBANY, Oct. 30.--The Governor has commuted the sentence of William Boorne, convicted in Cattaraugus County of murder in the second degree on June 2, 1874, and sentenced to imprisonment in Auburn Prison for life, to 16 years, which, with allowances for good behavior, will entitle him to a discharge on June 8, 1884.

VINEYARD HAVEN, Mass., Oct. 30.--The schooners Kben Fisher, Capt. Reynolds, from Rondout, for Boston, with coal, and the Quoddy, Capt. Mashoney, from New-York, for Beverly, with coal ran ashore on Hedge Fence Shoal, Vineyard Sound yesterday morning. They floated during the day without apparent damage.
Mr. Benjamin Fitch, whose gift of the Fitch Creche to Buffalo has made him prominent, is confined to his bed at his residence, No. 61 Fifthavenue, with a cold which he caught about a week ago.

BUFFALO, Oct. 30.--There has been a lively buzzing in political circles all day over the action of Timothy J. Mahoney, the present City Controller and the Democratic nominee for re-election, in withdrawing from the ticket.

Mr. Bernard Mulholland was renominated for Assembly in the Second District of Kings County last evening by a meeting of citizens at Columbia Hall, in Main-street. The Young Republican Association of the Fourth Ward met at Jay and Tillary streets and indorsed the nomination.

Chickering Hall was crowded to its wells last evening by a brilliant audience, assembled to hear Mr. Matthew Arnold's first lecture in this country on "Numbers." A few minutes after 8 o'clock Mr. Arnold was escorted to the centre of the platform by Mr. Parke Godwin, Mr. Wayne MacVeagh following.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 30.--The firm of Smith, Stoughton Payne, shoe manufacturers, has determined to remove its factory from this city to South Abington, Mass. The reason for doing so is that the trades-unionists here have become so troublesome.

CHICAGO, Oct. 30.--The peculiar condition in which the affairs of the large stationery and printing firm of Culver, Page, Hoyne Co. are at present continues to excite general comment. That the firm suddenly sold out to John Morris, a lawyer, who presumably knows nothing of the ...

Just after the South ferry boat Pacific had left her slip on the New-York side on her 7:45 trip to Brooklyn, last evening, a young man about 5 feet 6 inches in height, dressed in dark clothes, and apparently under 30 years of age, jumped into the water from the after part of the boat.

The races which were to have taken place at Brighton Beach on Monday took place yesterday, on a heavy track, but they were closely contested, and afforded excellent sport to a large crowd of spectators. Although the fields in each race were small, the Mutual pool dividends were large, as only two favorites were successful.

Mr. L. COE, photographer, is just at present anxious to know who is to pay him for his broken camera. Last Monday it occurred to certain policemen that the photograph of Mr. THOMAS DAVIS--a man said to be a professional criminal--would be a desirable addition to the Rogues' Gallery.

NEWARK, Oct. 30.--The second mass-meeting of the Democracy of Essex County was held tonight in Orange. A large crowd was present, and speeches were made by Senator Bayard, of Delaware, Leon Abbett, Ex-Gov. McClellan, and others.

SALIDA, Col., Oct. 30.--Baxter Stingley, a City Marshal, has been fatally shot while attempting to arrest Frank Reed, a cowboy, for stealing cattle. Stingley covered Reed with a revolver. Reed was, however, too quick for him. He shot the Marshal three times and then escaped.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30.--The proceedings of the United States Supreme Court to-day were as follows: No. 71--The Dubuque and Sioux City Railroad Company et al., plaintiffs in error, vs. The Des Moines Valley Railroad Company; ...

PITTSBURG, Oct. 30.--Hundreds of people visited the scene of the dynamite explosion at Brook's tunnel to-day. A piece of a human foot was picked up half a mile from the shed where the explosive was stored.

There is a great deal of enthusiasm in the Twenty-first Assembly District, which includes the wealthiest residence portion of the City, over the nomination by a number of brokers and business men of Mr. J.R. Andrews for Alderman.

The funeral of the late James Y. Watkins, who died last Saturday, took place yesterday. Services were held over the remains early in the afternoon at the Church of the Divine Paternity, Forty-fifth-street and Fifth-avenue, which were conducted by the Rev. Charles H. Eaton.

A certain prominent Democrat, after visiting the Republican State Committee's head-quarters yesterday and noting the activity which there prevails, contrasted the busy scene with the graveyard solemnity attending the proceedings at the Democratic State Committee's rooms in Albany.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., Oct. 30.--For a week past the prospective visit to Lockport of Robert A. Maxwell, of Batavia, Democratic candidate for State Treasurer, has been heralded through the local Democratic press and talked of in the Democratic County Committee rooms in this city.

BATAVIA, N.Y., Oct. 30.--As a passenger train on the Rochester and Pittsburg Railroad approached the station at Leroy, in this county, last evening, it was flagged to enable a freight train that was on the track ahead to pull out of the way.
Ludwig Maue, a German laborer, who formerly lived at No. 438 West Thirty-eighth-street, committed suicide yesterday afternoon by hanging himself in the cellar of the Glerman Hospital.

ALBANY, Oct. 30.--The Bryant Building Company, of New-York, to acquire and hold real estate and rent the same, capital, $300,000, was incorporated to-day. The Trustees of the company are Parke Godwin, Fannie Bryant Godwin, Frederick N. Goddard, Alfred Ludlow White, Fannie Godwin White, Harold Godwin, Annie Godwin, and Nora Godwin.
MONTREAL, Oct. 30.--Vennor announces that the first cold snap will occur on Nov. 3, 4, and 5.

LONDON, Oct. 31.--A terrible explosion occurred at about 8 o'clock last evening near the Praed-street underground station on the Metropolitan Railway. On the first alarm a strong cordon of police was summoned to preserve order, and to keep the way clear, and to convey wounded people to the hospitals.
Mr. Irving's plays for next week at the Star Theatre are "Louis XI." and "The Merchant of Venice."

DES MOINES, Oct. 30.--Mifflin E. Bell, the new Supervising Architect of the Treasury, is a native of Chester County, Penn., and is 36 years old. He studied his profession under some rural builders, and was a member of the force of A.H. ...

RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 30.--C. Baker and William Burnett, colored men, and professional resurrectionists, were arrested this morning while moving the body of a dead pauper through the streets on a wheelbarrow.

AUBURN, Oct. 30.--A sensation has been caused here, where Marshal McDougall resides, by the dispatch stating that a NewYork paper had published an announcement of irregularities in the Marshal's office. It was promptly denied by the Marshal's ...

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30.--As a result, it is announced, of the exposure by the press of the operations of swindling pension claim agents in this city the house of N.W. Fitzgerald Co., of this city, was to-day formally closed and all the employes of the establishment dismissed by the ...
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30.--The Commissioners appointed by President Arthur under the antipolygamy act to-day submitted their second annual report to the Secratary of the Interior.

The services of the Forty Hours' Adoration of the Blessed Sacrament, at St. Stephen's Roman Catholic Church, in East Twenty-ninth-street, be gan at 11 o'clock last Sunday morning and were ended at 10 o'clock yesterday morning.

A fortnight since, when the ultra temperance men had given Ohio to the Democrats and the revenue reformers had cut down the Republican majority in Iowa till the election was hardly more than a drawn battle, the Democrats were highly elated.

CHICAGO, Oct. 30.--Major-Gen. John M. Schofield, who succeeds Gen. Sheridan in command of the Division of the Missouri, arrived from San Francisco this morning, accompanied by his family and two members of his personal staff-- Col. William M. Wherry and Lieut. C.B. Schofield. Gen. Schofield will publish an order assuming formal command to-morrow.

LONDON, Oct. 30.--The Brighton meeting began to-day. The Brighton Autumn Handicap race resulted in a dead heat between Mr. T. Cannon's (formerly Mr. P. Lorillard's) 4-year-old ch. c. Sachem and Mr. W.G. Stevens's 4-year-old br. g. Ironclad.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30, 1883. Secretary Folger to-day appointed Mifflin Emlen Bell, of Des Moines, Iowa, to be Supervising Architect of the Treasury, vice J.G. Hill resigned. Mr. Bell was architect of the Capitols at Springfield, Ill., and Des Moines' Iowa.

CHICAGO, Oct. 30.--The incorporation of the Chicago Hansom Cab Company was announced one week ago, and the statement is now made that 50 vehicles, patterned very closely after those in use in London, will be placed on the streets of this city by Jan. 1, and 50 additional ones soon after.
ST. JOHN, New-Brunswick, Oct. 30.--William A. Finley, the sole survivor of the schooner W.H. Rourke, wrecked in Vineyard Sound, returned here this morning.
CITY OF MEXICO, Oct. 30.--Immense clouds of locust have appeared in the State of Puebla.

The Republican Committee of Queens County, which met in Long Island City yesterday, named Thomas A. Smith as the candidate for the Aesembly from the Second District, in place of Robert A. Davison, declined.
MEMPHIS, Tenn., Oct. 30.--The attendance at the race, here to-day was fair. The weather was superb and the track was hard, although not fast. The betting was limited.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Oct. 30.--The Prohibitionists of the Second Assembly District of Monmouth County, held their convention here today and indorsed Dr. Thomas G. Chattle, the Democratic candidate for the Assembly.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Oct. 30.--Early on Monday morning three strangers entered the store of Abram Gray, at Homowack, Elster County, and asked small bills for three one-dundred-dollar notes, saying that they were cattle buyers. Mr. Gray proceeded to count out the change, when they threw some poisonous liquid in his face, nearly blinding him, and ran off with all the money. They have not been arrested.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 30.--For a long time Eugene Lynch, a Philadelphia artisan, former ly of New-Haven, and Miss Katherine T. Mulcahey, of this city, have been betrothed.

For the past two years Joseph M. McEnerney, a young man, has been employed as bookkeeper in the New-York agency of the Jersey City steel-works, at Nos. 99 and 101 John-street.

ATLANTA, Oct. 30.--Several days ago a stranger registered at the National Hotel as L.F. McKinney. He was a genteel-looking man, about 28 years old. Soon after his arrival he made the acquaintance of C.W. Wells at the hotel bar.

The Luther festivals, which are being celebrated in Germany and all over the world, will begin in this City to-night. Today is the festival of the Reformation, which dates from the nailing up by Luther of his 95 theses against papal indulgences on the church door of Wittenberg, Oct. 31, 1517.
MILFORD, Penn., Oct. 29.--Particulars have just been received here of one or the most, coldblooded murders ever committed in Pike County.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 30.--H. Clay Sexton, Chief of the St. Louis Fire Department, arrived home today from the New-Orleans Convention. He was questioned as to what reason the fire Chiefs had for declaring war on the Fire Patrol and Salvage Corps Companies. In reply he said: "No war has...

BATAVIA, N.Y., Oct. 30.--This village is full of excitement to-night over the murder of Johnson L. Lynch, a lawyer, of Utica. N.Y., by E. Newton Rowell, a paper-box manufacturer, who came to Batavia from Utica about two years ago and engaged in business here with a partner named William T. Palmer.
VIENNA, Oct. 30.--The Archduke Rudolph, Prince Imperial of Austria, and his wife, the Archduchess Stephanie, have left here on a visit to the Prussian Court.
Henry Ward Beecher spoke in favor of Mayor Low's re-election before as many people as were able to crowd themselves into the Brooklyn Academy of Music last night.

CHICAGO, Oct. 30.--The United States Grand Jury, after a week's deliberation, brought into court this morning a batch of 25 or 30 indictments. The most important presentments were against the swindling commission firms whose frauds were exposed last Spring.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 30.--In many respects this has been one of the most peculiar campaigns within the recollection of New-Jersey politicians. Perhaps its most peculiar feature has been the fact that from the beginning the Republicans have been more confident of Democratic success than the Democrats themselves.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Oct. 30.--The first bale of cotton ever picked from the field by machinery was exhibited of the Charleston Cotton Exchange to-day and attracted general attention. The condition of the cotton was pronounced by cotton men as good as hand-picked cotton of the same grade. The bale will be sent to the convention of the National Cotton Planters' Association at Vicksburg next month.
PITTSBURG, Penn., Oct. 30.--Wallace Ross and John Teemer, the oarsmen, have formed a double team, and will soon issue a challenge to row any two men in the country.
The case of Mr. Charles Briggs, a gentleman of Boston, who is now at the Massachusetts General Hospital, is said by the physicians to be one of the most remarkable on record.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 30.--The Board of Directors of the Keely Motor Company held a meeting to-night. Mr. Keely made a statement explaining his progress, and stated that he was constructing a street chamber to contain the vapor, and that when this was completed an exhibition would be given. The Directors voted Mr. Keely's explanation very satisfactory.
Probably if it had been generally known at the Buffalo Convention that Boss MANNING'S candidate for Secretary of State had a temperance record he would not have received the nomination.
WORCESTER, Mass., Oct. 30.--Dennis McNamara, Michael McNamara, Patrick Fitzgerald, Thomas Wiseman, and Edward J. Fay are under arrest here for perjury in naturalization cases.

A man about 45 years of age, tall and bearded, registered Monday afternoon at the Manhattan Hotel, Broadway and Canal-street, as A. W. Perrott, from Philadelphia. He was assigned a room on the fourth floor, and retired at once, saying that he was tired and wanted to rest.

"D.R.S." is informed that his friend is an American citizen.

COLORADO, Texas, Oct. 30.--Intelligence was received yesterday from Snyder's store, 25 miles north of here, that Mr. Rumels had been fatally poisoned with arsenic, which was placed in his coffee by a Mexican shepherd named Holderman.
The Rev. Dr. O.H. Tiffany will begin a course of seven lectures in the Forsyth-Street Methodist Episcopal Church, between Grand and Division streets, to-morrow evening.

The annual meeting of the French Benevolent Society will be held at 8 o'clock this evening, in Steck Ball, No. 11 East Fourteenth-street, when the report of President Charles Renauld will be read and officers for the ensuing year will be elected.

ROCHESTER, Oct. 30.--A prominent Republican politician from Wayne County, in conversation with THE TIMES'S correspondent to-night, said that the Republicans of his county were working very hard. Thousands of excellent campaign documents are being sent out to every part of the ...

Henry Alford, of Nyack, was attacked in West-street late last night by three footpads and beaten. His cries for help brought Officer Parley, of the Fifth Precinct, to the rescue, and the intended robbery was prevented, though Alford was badly cut about the head.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 30.--Horace Hogan, alias "Little Horace," who was serving a three years' sentence in the Eastern Penitentiary for burglary, has been pardoned by Gov. Pattison, and upon a warrant issued by United States Commissioner...

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Oct. 30.--At Knoxville, Tenn., yesterday a two-horse team ran away, killing a pedestrian, Solomon Nipper, who was crossing the street. Nipper's skull was crushed and both jaws were broken. He was a farmer aged about 70 years.
DUBUQUE, Iowa, Oct. 30.--Edward Allen and Charles Van Meter, carpenters, fell from a building a distance of 25 feet yesterday. Allen was killed and Van Meter fatally injured.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Oct. 30.--In November, 1879, a young woman named Ella Steele died at the house of W.J. McKee, a farmer, living six miles from Wentsboro, Sullivan County, in the Shawangunk Mountains. She was 25 years old, and had been an invalid since a child.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Oct. 30.--The octagon building of Amherst College, in which are the Lawrence Observatory and Wood's Cabinet, narrowly escaped being destroyed by fire this morning. The students by energetic work quenched the flames, and the damage to the building is trifling. The mineral collection was considerably damaged by careless handling.
The profane people of the Blue Grass region are being amused by what are called the revelations in the Crumbaugh case. The busy and hurrying world may have forgotten CRUMBAUGH.

Mr. William R. Martin was once a very prominent lawyer and real estate operator in this City. In recent years he has come before the public very seldom, and chiefly in connection with the estate of the late Nathan C. Platt, who was at one time City Chamberlain.

LONDON, Oct. 31.--Gen. Don Fernando Fernandez de Cordova, formerly Captain-General of Cuba, is dead in his ninety-first year.
It is said that the Democrats will make no nomination for the Assembly in the Second District of Rensselaer County, now that Isaac L. Van Voast, their candidate, has declined because of Ill-health.

PARIS, Oct. 30.--The International Labor Conference continued its session to-day. Great diversity of opinion prevails among the delegates. The subject of international legislation was resumed, but the discussion degenerated into generalities.

"Have you a letter addressed to Alice Daly?" said a well-dressed female immigrant, who had just landed from the steam-ship Maasdam to one of the Castle Garden clerks yesterday. A letter with that address was handed her, and she was requested to sign a receipt.
Zimri Pratt, proprietor of a carriage lamp manufactory, at No. 54 Cliff-street, asked MyerElsas, a clerk in the Sheriff's office, in May last, to help him in obtaining sureties on a bond for $3,000.

The practical effect of the Civil Rights bill decision upon the progress and comfort of the negro race has been over-estimated. Mayor Edson attended a meeting of the General Committee in charge of the Evacuation Day celebration, in the rooms of the Chamber of Commerce, yesterday. Gen. Cochrane presided and the following members of the committee were present: John Austin Stevens, George W. Lane, Col. Varnum, C.N. Bliss, Royal Phelps, Charles S. Smith, and Alderman O'Connor.

RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 31.--At a political discussion at South Boston, Halifax County, in this State, last night, a serious disturbance occurred. Two white Democrats were knocked down by negroes. The whites used pistols. One negro was shot in the neck and painfully wounded and another was seriously cut.

It will be 12 years in this month of November since Christine Nilsson was first heard here in Ambroise Thomas's "Mignon." The fair Swedish singer had only a month before made her first appearance in opera in America, and the marvelous charm of her voice and her impassioned and graceful acting formed the chief sensation of the hour.

Although the track at Brighton Beach still remained heavy, the racing yesterday was an improvement over the preceding day, the entries in each of the five events being more numerous, and close finishes were the order in most of them. The last was run in the dark, and it will very soon become necessary to begin the races at 2 o'clock. Three of the favorites were successful.

In the United States Circuit Court yesterday, before Judge Shipman and a jury, was begun the libel suit of Gaston L. Feuardent against Louis P. Di Cesnola, Secretary and Director of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. We have the evidence of Gov. CLEVELAND himself that he could not have achieved the victory of last year without Republican votes. His party cannot succeed this year without the aid, directly or indirectly, of Republicans.

An attempt on the part of editors, professional politicians, and lay citizens to re-establish harmony among the savage Democratic factions of the City was discovered yesterday. The politicians, when their attention was called to it, laughed immoderately, and said that harmony might possibly be secured after election, but certainly not before.

There seems to be an exorbitant value attached to small-boys in Brooklyn. At least such will be the universal opinion if the Brooklyn man who has sued a school teacher for spanking his small-boy, and laid his damages at $3,000, should be successful.

NEWPORT, Oct. 31.--It is generally believed that several well-known New-York ladies are residing here for the purpose of securing divorces from their husbands under the very lenient laws of this State, which simply require parties to be residents of the State before securing a legal separation.

LONDON, Oct. 31.--The excitement over the explosions on the underground railway line last evening is very great. A large number of policemen under special Inspectors were on duty all night at the various railway stations and guarding the line. A heavy force was also employed watching the houses of Parliament and other public buildings. The explosion at Charing Cross occurred a distance ...

In nearly all the districts the Republicans have completed their nominations. In the Tenth District they finished their list at a meeting held last evening at the Concordia Assembly Rooms, in Avenue A, and nominated Charles A. Binder as candidate for Assemblyman.

SAVANNAH, Ga., Oct. 31.--A fire which had its origin this noon in the large cotton warehouse of Garnett, Stubbs Co., in this city, destroyed the warehouse, containing 3,000 bales of cotton, 1,300 houses, covering an area half a mile square, causing a loss of at least five lives, and probably eight or ten.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 31.--The property of the late ex-Gov. Padelford at Newport was sold to-day to John H. Glovar, of New-York, for $35,000.

BOONTON, N.J., Oct. 31.--The inside history of the Morris County Democratic Convention on Monday has just come to light, and is already exerting a damaging influence on the prospects of Mr. Abbett, the Democratic nominee for Governor. The Democracy of this county some time ago nominated Dr. Jackson, ex-Director of the Board of Chosen Freeholders, for State Senator, but he declined, ...

GLASGOW, Oct. 31.--Sir Charles Dilke, President of the Local Government Board, delivered an address here last evening. He reviewed the proceedings of the last session of Parliament, and said that in the future the great measure for the consideration of Parliament would be the assimilation of county and borough franchise.

LACKAWAXEN, Penn., Oct. 31.--Thirty-six years ago this month two young Irishmen emigrated to this country together. Their names were Andrew Callinghan and Hugh Gilfillan. In 1848 they were both members of a gang of laborers employed in the construction of the New-York and Erie Railroad, and were working at this place.

PARIS, Oct. 31.--In the Chamber of Deputies to-day, M. Clemenceau, Radical, resumed the debate upon the interpellation of the Government on its Tonquin policy. Thompson, for $350,000 damages for false imprisonment, was begun this morning in the Circuit Court by Jere Wilson, of counsel for defense. Superintendent Cady, of the Water Register's Bureau, gave testimony yesterday before the Grand Jury in relation to the water rent frauds.

WAUPUN, Wis., Oct. 31.--Much excitement prevails in this usually quiet little town over the developments in the extraordinary case of the two women who married each other and lived, apparently, as husband and wife, the outlines of which were telegraphed to THE TIMES yesterday.

An Associated Press dispatch from Albany stated that Thomas Hoag, of this City, passed through the capital an his way home yesterday morning. On the same authority it was stated that Mr. Hoag had been to London, and had returned to this country by way of Halifax, passing through Canada and Northern New-York.

Garlington and the latter's reply to the questions regarding the loss of the Proteus. In his letter Secretary Lincoln says:

LONDON, Oct. 31.--The steamer Holyhead, belonging to the London and North-western Railway Company, came in collision last night with the German ship Alhambra, when 25 miles off Holyhead, and both vessels sank.

LIVERPOOL, Oct. 31.--The suspension of Messrs. Mellor Fenton, cotton brokers, was announced this morning, and Messrs. Henry Pearce Co. and Messrs. Joseph Taylor Co., both cotton brokerage firms, have suspended payment.

The question for the voters and tax-payers of Brooklyn to decide next Tuesday is whether the interests of Brooklyn are worth more to them than the interests of party. The contest there is not between the Republican and Democratic Parties, but between the city and the Democratic political machine.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 31.--W.E. Hughes, of Bowling Green, a prominent Republican editor, who was a witness in the trial of Collector Crumbaugh, makes a statement of a sensational character regarding Commissioner Evans's connection with Crumbaugh's case. He says: Mrs. Burbridge was Postmistress at Hopkinsville some time ago.
To-day Gen. SHERMAN closes a continuous and illustrious service of more than twentytwo years in the army of the United States, for the past fourteen years as its Generalin-Chief.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31.--The news of the death by suicide of A.M. Perrottet, which was heard by his friends here this morning, caused much surprise among them.

Charles M. Sams, assistant purser of the steam-ship Nacoochee, of the Savannah Line, was shot in the head early yesterday morning by Jennie Mitchell, of No. 106 West Thirty-first-street, in T. H. Moffatt's shooting gallery, No. 484 Sixth-avenue, and he died in the New-York Hospital at 8 o'clock A.M.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 31.--Ten years ago one of the prettiest, most accomplished, and most popular young ladies of South Norwalk was Miss Lulu Morehouse, the daughter of Mr. Morehouse, proprietor of the Norwalk Hotel. This morning this same young woman was found dead in one of the cheapest rooms of a cheap hotel in this city.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Oct. 31.--This was the sixth day of the Fall meeting of the new Memphis Jockey Club. The weather was delightful, the attendance the largest during the meeting, the betting active, and the track in good condition.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31.--Secretary Teller has to-day issued an order which changes the custom of the Interior Department in its treatment of pension claim agents who have been accused of irregular practices before the Pension Bureau. The custom has been to suspend them when charges were made until the truth or falsity of the charges was disproved or established.

BALTIMORE, Md., Oct. 31.--The first day of the extra meeting at Pimlico was as much of a success as was expected, but the fields were too small to be interesting, and the attendance was very fair. There was some activity at the auction poolstand, but none of the bookmen opened for work.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Oct. 31.--The Times to-morrow will print an interview with the wife of O'Donnell, who killed Carey, the informer. Mrs. O'Donnell is living in this city, and with the aid of a Catholic clergyman and other friends, is getting up affidavits which, it is thought, may aid her husband in his coming trial.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Nov. 1.--Late last night the schooner Sophia Minch, loaded with ore from Marquette to this port, dropped anchor 300 feet from the east pier. A tug went out and endeavored to take her inside the break-water, but the cable parted and the schooner began to drift to the north-west.

Tammany held her annual ante-election mass-meeting last evening. The seats in the large hall were removed from the floor, and the braves were required to stand during the tedious harangues of the evening.

BATAVIA, N.Y., Nov. 1.--Nothing has so excited this locality in many years as the tragedy of Tuesday night, which resulted in the death of Johnson Lynch, the Utica lawyer, who was found in the act of adultery with the wife of Edward Newton Rowell, who shot him.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 1.--D. Banks Morehouse,the broken and aged father of Lulu Thompson, the Norwalk woman who died in King's Hotel yesterday morning, said of her to a TIMES reporter this evening: "My Lulu was a beautiful girl; she was great hearted when she was a child.

By direction of the President a military court of inquiry has been appointed to investigate the organization, fitting out, and general conduct of the Greely relief expedition. The court's first duty will be to make a thorough examination of the orders and instructions issued for the guidance of the expedition.

As SOLOMON would undoubtedly have remarked had it occurred to him, "Of the building of air ships there is no end." The trout family appear to have pre-eminence in the waters of British Columbia. They are very plenty and are the chief foon of a great many Indians. There appear to be several varieties here. One of them inhabits Arrow Lakes, is two feet long when full grown, is silver-sided, and very rich in flavor.

One would hardly imagine the existence of spirit in a man addicted to playing croquet, but from the recent tragedy in Woodbury, N.J., we may fairly infer that a spirited male croquet player is possible, or that, at all events, the male croquet player is capable of turning when too severely trodden upon.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1.--Capt. George B. Russell, Ninth Infantry, has been relieved from special duty in the Department of Texas and detailed as Acting Assistant Inspector-General for the Department of the Missouri, to take effect to-day.

About 10 o'clock yesterday morning a stoutly built gentleman, about 50 years of age, dressed in a gray suit, and with a round face and small grayish whiskers, tried to open the door of the jewelry store at No. 1,336 Broadway, which has been closed since Sept. 4.

The Clinton-Avenue Congregational Church in Brooklyn was crowded last evening on the occasion of the marriage of Miss Mamie Boardman, daughter of George Boardman, an old resident of Brooklyn, to Mr. Charles C. Lima, Jr. The groom is a son of Capt. C.C. Lima, of this City.

By the falling of a shed on the south-west corner of First-avenue and Thirty-ninth-street, soon after noon yesterday, an aged laborer and a little girl were killed and a boy seriously injured. The shed was a one-story wooden structure, of about 75 feet on the avenue and about 120 feet on Thirty-ninth-street.

BOSTON, Nov. 1.--F. Shaw Brothers, the suspended leather concern, to-day formally offered the creditors the sum of 33 1/3 per cent. on their respective claims, to be paid in cash or its equivalent within 30 days of acceptance.

Mrs. Maud Howe, of Boston, is to be a guest of Mr. and Mrs. George Bancroft in Washington this Winter.

INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 1.--On the train arriving here at 6 o'clock to-night a gang of "shovers" of counterfeit money who have been operating in the southern counties of the State were brought here under the custody of United States Marshal Foster and Chief Abbett, of the Secret Service.

PARIS, Nov. 1.--The Voltaire expresses the belief that M. Challemel-Lacour, Minister of Foreign Affairs, will soon resign on the ground of illhealth. Prime Minister Ferry will take charge of the foreign portfolio when M. Challemel-Lacour resigns.

BRANDON, Wis., Nov. 1.--The mystery regarding the sex of Frank Dutois, the female husband of the Waupun young lady, has at last been cleared up and all doubt set at rest by a statement made to THE TIMES'S correspondent by the person in question.

President Watrous, of the New-York, NewHaven and Hartford Railraod, has issued an order to the effect that on and afternoon of Sunday, Nov. 18, the time used upon that road will be of the seventy-fifth meridian of west longitude, which is about four minutes slower than New-York City time.
VIENNA, Nov. 1.--A desperate fight has taken place at Kocani, in Herzegovina, between Austrian gendarmes and robbers. The latter were driven off and several of them killed.

The greatest and most important sale of thorough-breds over held in this City was that of yesterday, at the American Horse Exchange, which was attended by turfmen and breeders from all parts of the country and Canada.

The Republicans of the Eighteenth Assembly District have nominated William L. Brockway for Alderman. Mr. Brockway is a well-known business man and a member of the Stock Exchange. He is the manager of a large manufacturing company in this City. This is the district in which ex-Coroner Richard Croker is running for the same office.

LONDONDERRY, Nov. 1.--A large number of Orangemen took possession of and occupied the City Hall to-day, in order to prevent the Lord Mayor of Dublin, for whom the hall had been engaged, from delivering a lecture upon the franchise. The seizure of the hall created intense excitement.
Aloes in the Botanical Gardens at Oxford are in full bloom, and the sight is a rare one at Oxford, although the plants are said to have been there nearly a hundred years. They are about 20 feet high.

JACKSON, Miss., Nov. 6.--The election today in Mississippi for Senate. Legislature, and county officers has passed off, except in counties where Democrats and Republicans have agreed upon a joint ticket, notably Hinds, Madison, and Monroe, Copiah, Panola, and a few others, and in which they were opposed by what is called the Independent or People's Party, representing what is known as Chalmers's element.

PARIS, Nov. 6.--The Gaulois publishes a report of an interview with the Marquis Tseng, the Chinese Ambassador, at his residence in Folkestone, England. The Marquis said if war occurred between France and China, which he believed to be probable, the Kingdom of Annam would become the ally of China. The French, he said, would require 40,000 troops to overcome their united forces. Meantime, England's commercial interests would compel her to intervene.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., NOV. 6.--Reports from 14 of the 25 election districts of Niagara County, embracing two-thirds of the entire vote, give Carr for Secretary of State 730 over Maynard. The majority for Carr in the county, actual and estimated, is 1,000, and will not fall short of that figure.

PHILADELPHIA, NOV. 6.--Enough return have been received at this hour (1 o'clock A.M.) to indicate very clearly that the Republicans have carried Pennsylvania by from 10,000 to 15,000 majority. The total vote in the State in 1880 was 875,000. In 1882 it fell off to 743,000.

RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 6.--The interest in the election which took place to-day has been unprecedented. In nearly every section all business has been to some extent partially suspended. Men talk of nothing but the result, and how the State has gone. Last night men here and in other portions of the State were armed in case of trouble.

BOSTON, Mass., Nov. 7--1:30 A.M.--The returns now received indicate that a heavy vote was polled. Gov. Butler received a large vote, due in great measure to the increased registration all over the State. The vote of this registration overcame his losses.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 6.--The election in this State to-day was for Governor, State Controller, Attorney-General, and Legislature, excepting onehalf the Senate, who hold over, all county officers, and in Baltimore city a Judge of the Court of Appeals, Clerk of the Supreme Court, Sheriff, State Attorney, three Judges of the Orphans' Court, and City Surveyor.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 6.--The Southern rate war is growing hotter. The Cairo Short Line has dropped its prices to Cairo $1, to Memphis $4, and to Vicksburg, Natchez, and New-Orleans $6.50. The Iron Mountain Road meets this with a further cut to points below Cairo.

TROY, N.Y., Nov. 6.--On the 10th day of October there escaped from the penitentiary at Lancaster, Penn., 12 prisoners, burglars and incendiaries, whose terms of sentence ranged from four to nineteen years. Among them was John Frankford, the notorious horse-thief, and Alexander Lemen, who has just been caught.

The popularity of horse-racing was made evident yesterday at Jerome Park, for, although the programme was somewhat meagre, there was a great crowd present. The club-house bluff was largely occupied by society people, and the coaching club was represented by three drags.

There was a grand circus on the Polo Grounds yesterday afternoon. They called it a foot-ball match, but it looked more like a general wrestling match. The contestants were 11 young men from the College of New-Jersey, commonly known as Princeton College, and 11 from Wesleyan.

PETERSBURG, Va., Nov. 6.--Gen. The games of the Manhattan Athletic Club on its grounds in West Eighty-sixth-street yesterday afternoon were of more than ordinary interest. Among the many contestants were some of the best known amateur athletes in this vicinity.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Nov. 6.--The State election in Minnesota has been made interesting and the Republican majority has been badly cut down by the same cause, a large defection by the Scandinavian Republicans.

The first race for the cross-country championship of America was run yesterday over the hills and farms lying in the vicinity of the King's Bridge road, in Inwood. Spuyten Duyvel, Bronson's, and Fordham, under the auspices of the New-York Athletic Club.

The day generally was a quiet one in this City. Business was suspended in the down-town wholesale houses, but the retailers kept wide-open doors and transacted a large amount of business during the morning. In the afternoon large numbers of the retailers closed their stores also and gave their clerks a half-holiday.
The lawn in front of the Peabody House, Yonkers, was well filled with bicycles and tricycles yesterday afternoon, the occasion being the arrival of the Ixion and New-York Bicycle Clubs of this City.

Elections were held yesterday in ten States. In the State of New-York the Republican candidate for Secretary of State is elected by a majority of from 14,000 to 17,000. The rest of the Democratic State ticket is probably successful.

LONDON, Nov.7.--A special dispatch from Hong Kong says Admiral Courbet has postponed his attack on Bac-Ninh, where the Chinese are preparing for a desperate defense. He will wait until the roads are sufficiently dried to transport heavy cannon over them, and will begin the march early in December, by which time China will have decided whether she will assist the garrison at Bac Ninh.

One of the drivers failed to make his returns, and the lady went to the hack stand to see about it. One of the hackmen made an uncomplimentary remark which she overheard, and, wrenching a whip from his hand, she chased him off the ground.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., Nov. 15.--The efforts of the defunct American Transportation Company to collect an assessment of 25 per cent from stock holders scattered throughout Southern States has created a sensation in a small way among the parties liable. As men went into this enterprise .......

OTTAWA, Ontario, Nov. 15.--The Toronto Globe to-day calls attention to the necessity of Government intervention in the case of the capture of a band of Canadian half-breeds near Fort Buford by United States cavalry.

It is announced that Mr. CHAPLIN, member of Parliament for Lincolnshire, will renew his efforts to prevent the importation of cattle from the United States. As we have pointed out before, the sanitary pretext which Mr. CHAPLIN and other landlords put forward for their opposition to importation is a mere pretext and a very flimsy pretext.

The Special United States Treasury Agents in this City received warning from Chicago a feew weeks ago to look out for the arrival from France of 100,000f. worth of diamonds which, it was believed, were to be smuggled into this port.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Nov. 15.--A breach of promise case in Judge Bernard's Court, in this city, in which the plaintiff to-day recovered $5,000, presents a feature that is very peculiar, the parties having proved what is believed to be a marriage under the law. The plaintiff in the case was a ......

Since the late election in this State persons living at a distance are more than ever puzzled to know what manner of man JOHN KELLY really is. It is complained that people outside of New-York can have no information concerning the Tammany chief but that which they glean from the New-York newspapers.
MATAWAN, N.J., Nov. 25.--Yesterday as several gentlemen were out rabbit-hunting they came upon a camp near Hazlet Station where meat had been recently cooked.
