WATERTOWN, N.Y., Nov. 15.--The body of T. Barrows arrived at his parent's home in Chaumont, near here, to-day. Barrows was Second Engineer of the propeller John Otis, and was fatally stabbed on Nov. 7 by a Kentuckian named kemble, at Charlevoix, on Lake Michigan Kemble has not been arrested, and a reward is offered for his capture. The murder occurred during a row in a saloon at Charlevoix.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Nov. 15.--Matrimonial eccentricities have been developing within a day or two. In Taylor County, to-day, William Hogg was married to Miss Georgia Garrett, a girl between 12 and 13 years old, by W.P. Caldwell, a Justice of the ...

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Nov. 15.--A sensational dispatch from this city in relation to Abraham Lincoln's body appears in a Chicago paper of this date. Its statements are some of them positively untrue and many of them unauthorized by any one having knowledge of the facts.
Capt. B.L. Crouch, an unmarried Texan stockman, has an insurance of $60,000 on his life.

Argument on the application of Mrs. Sarah M. Funk to secure letters of administration on the estate of the late Gen. Augustus Funk was had before Surrogate Rollins yesterday. Gen. Funk died on Oct. 18. He left no will. Before the application of Mrs. Sophia, M. Funk had been granted, Mrs. Helen I. Funk, who also claims to be ...

CINCINNATI, Nov. 15.--After several meetings, the committees of the Academy and the Pharmaceutical Society of this city have come to an understanding as to the province of the two professions, and a set of rules for the guidance of each have been adopted.

CHICAGO, Ill., Nov. 15.--The National Convention called for by Dr. Loring, Commissioner of Agriculture for the purpose of considering the ssubject of contagious diseases among animals, began its work at the Grand Pacific Hotel this morning.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 15.--The address of the National League for the Suppression of Polygamy, adopted last night, says: "Now is the time for action. The honor of the Nation is in danger. The total disregard of the law of the land is bringing us into disgrace among the peoples.
BATAVIA, N.Y., Nov. 15.--Edward Newton Rowell was to-day indicted for manslaughter in the first degree for killing Johnson L. Lynch on Oct. 30. The Grand Jury had the case under con- .....

Some time ago Rosa Schiebner, wife of a Springfield-avenue (Newark) restaurant-keeper disappeared from home, and she was found living with Herbert Schlichter, who had been a patron of the restaurant, and Schlichter's mother.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15.--Now that reports are finding circulation that the effort to make President Arthur a candidate for the Presidency in 1884 are to be pushed openly and vigorously in a short time the apperance here of Republican politicans from New-York, let them ...

After the announcement of the death of Dr. J. Marton Sims was made to the Academy of Medicine last evening the President, Dr. Fordyce Barker, made a short addrees, in which he said that by Dr. Sims's death the academy and the profession not only of this city but of this country had ...
The body of the man found some days ago hanging to a tree in the woods at Maspeth, Long Island, not having been identified it was buried in a pauper's grave.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 15.--Constable Glasse, of Reading, arrived in this city to-day with a warrant issued by the authorities of Berks County for the arrest of Mr. Alexander K. McClure, editor of the Times, on a charge of libel preferred by George Smith, Jr., of Union Township, Berks County.

Mrs. Henrietta Tracy, on Monday, rented her front parlor, at No. 22 West Fifteenth-street, to a man named James Lummy, who told her that he liked to play cards, and in all probability he would have some gentlemen friends drop in on him to assist him in gratifying his desires.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 15.--The Cleveland Rolling Mill Company's works have been going some what lightly in work for some time past, but the managers now say that there is a prospect for steady work the rest of the year. The rail mill started up again to-day, and the hammer department of the plate mill was set going yesterday.

Mr. Max Heinrich's concert at Steinway Hall last evening was not as well attended as it deserved to be. Taken as a whole, it was a concert of a class which is painfully infrequent in our long list of minor musical entertainments, though it suffers some what in being judged by the standard which its programme set.
OTTAWA, Ontario, Nov.15.--George Stephen, President, and W.C. Vanhorne, General Manager, of the Canadian Pacific Railway, were here to-day, and had an interview with members of the Government.

The trial of the first of the suits against the Trustees of the East River bridge for damages sustained in the crush which occurred on the bridge last Decoration Day was begun in the City Court, before Judge McAdam yesterday.
The sixth annual convention of the Sundayschools of Kings County was called to order at 10 o'clock yesterday morning in the Strong-Place Baptist Church by Mr. E.W. Hawley.

The suit of Francis A. Fogg to recover $63,000 damages from Gen. Clinton B. Fisk for alleged fraud and deceit in a mining stock transaction was removed yesterday from the Supreme Court to the United States Circuit Court.
CHICAGO, Nov. 15.--The trouble in the Kansas City pool has been settled. A meeting of passenger agents of the roads interested was held here to-day, at which all differences were adjusted.

The four remaining members of the Corean Embassy are to return to their native Tah Chosun to-morrow on board the United States flag-ship Trenton, by way of the Suez Canal. The ViceMinister and four of the legation sailed in the City of Rio from San Francisco.

A citizen came to the Prince-street police station yesterday afternoon and informed Capt. McDonnell that there was a drunken policeman in full uniform in the lager beer saloon No. 413 Greenwich-street.

RIVERHEAD, Long Island, Nov. 15.--The bicentennial anniversary of the formation of Suffolk County has been celebrated in this village to-day with as much spirit as it was possible to arouse in the face of the fact that the Supervisors of the County refused to make any appropriation for the celebration and the expenses had to be borne entirely by private citizens.

Policeman Patrick McCurley was talking with another officer at Broadway and Chambersstreet, at 1:15 o'clock this morning , about the Ann-street fire, when the former, looking down Chambers-street, discovered flames bursting forth from a high building below West Broadway.

The State Civil Service Commissioners held a conference with Mayor Edson yesterday with reference to making improvements in the civil service here. Commissioner Augustus Schoonmaker and Chief Examiner Silas W. Burt appeared.

NEW-ORLEANS, Nov. 15.--At noon to-day there were sold in front of the Custom-house the four barges and steam-boat hull which were a portion of the fleet turned over by the late National Board of Health to the Marine Hospital Service.
The Hon. E.F.C. Young, President of the First National Bank of Jersey City, last evening gave a dinner party at his residence in Glenwoodavenue in honor of Governor-elect Leon Abbett.

The Tenth Assembly District Republican Association, at its meeting last evening at Concordia Hall, Henry H. Haight presiding, resolved, on motion of Judge Jacob M. Patterson, Jr., to keep up its organization, and adjourned to meet on the third Thursday in December to take action as to its future course.

A train of two cars was sent from the Brooklyn terminus of the bridge at 6:40 o'clock last evening, but after traversing half the distance toward the tower the grip gave way and the cars glided rapidly back down the incline.

About 15 detectives--professional, amateur, New-York City, and Pinkerton's--visited Long Island yesterday looking for clues that might lead to the discovery of Mr. Robert Fellows, the missing Wall-street broker.
David Salzman, a little Russian Hebrew lad who earns a living by blacking boots in Castle Garden, found a check for $1,250 Wednesday afternoon on Broadway near Bowling Green.
Another large crowd assembled at Brighton Beach yesterday to witness the races. The entries were large and the contests interesting.

A small decanter of good rye whisky was placed on the long white table in the dining-room of Washington's Head-quarters, at Broad and Pearl streets, and glasses were set within the reach of five venerable men yesterday afternoon. Gen. Abraham Dally called for a glass of beer, but his associate veterans of the war of 1812 helped themselves out of the decanter.

The recent changes made in the rules of the Civil Service Commission by the President are in the right direction and are important, especially that relating to the choice of an appointee from those presented by the examiners as standing highest on the list of competitors.

NEW-ORLEANS, Nov. 15.--Major Amos Stickney, of the United States Army, in charge of the Government works, reports that at the mouth of Red River a rise in the stage of water has given needed relief to navigation.

PENN YAN, N. Y., Nov. 15.--The Keuka Lake steam-boat Yates was burned at her pier at this village early this morning. The fire is supposed to have been accidental. The insurance is not sufficient to cover the loss.

The certificate of incorporation of the Southern Electric Light Company, whose main purpose is to supply cities and towns in the Southern States with electric lights, was filed in the Country Clerk's office yesterday.
SUNCOOK, N. H., Nov. 15.--The funeral of ex-Gov. Natt Head occurred from his late residence at Hookset to-day at noon. Among those present were ex-Govs. Smyth, Weston, Cheney, and ...
VICKSBURG, Miss., Nov. 15.--A theatre here last night was the scene of the unprovoked and cowardly murder of D.R. Allen by Frank E. Starke.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 15.--This morning a train on the Tennessee and Pacific Railroad struck a carriage containing Mrs. C.W. Peden and Miss Mamie Tenison at a crossing near the city. Miss Tenison was thrown from the vehicle and was considerably bruised while Mrs. Peden, who remained in the carriage, was dragged 150 yards. Three of her ribs were broken, an ear was cut, and an eye was severely hurt.
It is expected that the principal office of the Hannibal and St. Joseph Railroad Company will be removed to Boston within a few days.

The solicitors sent out to raise funds for the Evacuation Day celebration got over $1,500 yesterday. Many of the banking firms and insurance companies were not prepared to give a definite answering as they can only appropriate money by vote of the Board of Directors.

LONDON, Nov. 15.--The summons in the libel suit of the Central News against the Sportsman, because the latter charged the association with issuing bogus news, was dismissed to-day after a further hearing before Alderman Knight. The suit of the Central News was based upon an article printed in the Sportsman of Sept. 29. The following is the article referred to:
The Young Ladies' Christian Temperance Union and the Boys' Loyal Legion held their first reception last night in the Free Reading-room for Boys at No. 16 East Fourteeth-street.
KITTERY, Me., Nov. 15.--The mysterious shooting last night of Thomas Burrows, a farmer, is creating great excitement here.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15.--By direction of the Secretary of War, the following changes in the stations and duties of officers of the Corps of Engineers have ... been ordered: Capt. Edward Maguire, now on leave of absence, will relieve Major Milton B. Adams of his duties in connection with the works of river and ...

Alexander Taylor, Jr., of Alexander Tay lor's Sons, No. 56 Broadway, has been suspended as a member of the Stock Exchange for five days by the Governing Committee for using indecorous language on the floor of the Exchange on Aug. 31.

The war veterans of the Seventh Regiment met in the rooms of the Veterans' Association in the regimental armory, last evening, and made arrangements for a reunion on the evening of Nov. 24. Gen. E. L. Molineux presided.

On Sunday next the new railway time is to be adopted. In this City at noon the clocks are to be turned back three minutes and fifty-eight seconds, and, in consequence, the day is to be lengthened by precisely that amount.
NEWBURG, N.Y., Nov. 15.--In the Orange County Circuit Court to-day James J. Hallihan sued the Erie Railroad Company for damages for injuries sustained on the railroad.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 15.--John B. Isaacsen has been arrested on the charge of obtaining goods under false pretenses from Herman Streicher, of Chicago. Isaacson was formerly in ....
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15. 1883. Secretary Teller has decided that, under sec tion 4,707 of the Revised Statutes, dependent mothers who lost their sons in the war of the rebellion are entitled to pensions.

It was manifest to spectators that Mr. Di Cesnola did not like the revelations made by Mr. A. D. Savage, formerly Assistant Director of the Museum, relative to his methods and his acts at about the time of Mr. Savage's resignation, as testified to on Wednesday and yesterday.
DETROIT, Nov. 15.--Dr. Frank B. Smith, of this city, has begun a suit for $50,000 in the United States District Court against Dr. John H. Rauch, Secretary of the Illinois Board of Health, whose ...

POUGHKEEPSIE, Nov. 15.--The Evening Enterprise, edited by a Democrat, states that a meeting of the Democratic County Committee of Dutchess has been called to investigate rumors and charges of crooked work within the party outside of the city. It adds: "If .....

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 15.--Before the National Academy of Sciences, to-day, Prof. William H. Brower, of Yale College, read a paper upon. "The Subsidence of Particles in Liquids." The results of years of investigation were shown by means of bottles filled with water.

LEWISTON, Me., Nov. 15.--Special dispatches to the Evening Journal say that the recent gale took the form of a cyclone in Oxford and Franklin Counties. In Bethel a house and several barns were destroyed. J.H. Carter was blown 30 yards and picked up insensible.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15.--At the Proteus court of inquiry to-day, Gen. Hazen's examination was resumed. A series of written question were read by Gen. Poe and answered by Gen. Hazen, bringing out in more succinct form the important points covered by the evidence of yesterday.

BUFFALO, Nov. 15.--The Rev. James McLeod, D.D., who has been Pastor of the Central Presbyterian Church in this city for a few year, has resigned his pastorate and will preach his farewell sermon next Sunday.

The Pinkertons made a clever catch on Wednesday night, as the result of four months' work, in the arrest of two professional safe-burglars who are the last of the more dangerous of two gangs that have been robbing jewelers in small towns for more than a year, to combat which the Jewlers' Security Alliance was formed in this City last June. These burglaries began in New-Orleans .....
The compositors employed on the World, Star, Truth, and Morning Journal struck last night for an advance to a uniform scale of 46 cents per thousand ems.

Mr. Edison's contradiction of the London dispatch announcing that the Edison Electric Light Company had purchased the right to the FaureSellon-Volckmar accumulator for Germany, led Mr. J.I. Courtenary to telegraph to London for information.

PARIS, Nov. 15.--Semi-official journals in this city say that the French squadron in Chinese waters will be reinforced, owing to the fact that the Chinese Viceroy of Canton is assisting the Black Flags.

On the application of Alderman William P. Kirk, Judge Donohue, holding Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday issued a writ of mandamus commanding Maurice O'Connell, John J. Meagher Thomas F. Bernett, and Samuel Alexander ....
MACON, Ga., Nov. 15.--A case was to-day called in the Superior Court which has a romantic interest. Several years ago Senator Thomas J. Perry was passing through this city on his way ......

CLEVELAND, Nov. 15.--John Waffen, a German, 44 years of age, who had been in this country only a year and had not learned what American whisky is last night made a bet that he could swallow 15 drinks in 15 minutes.
A large congregation of gentlemen and ladies attended the first public meeting of the Huguenet Society of America, in the French Church of St. Esprit, in West Twenty-second-street last night.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 15.--The General Committee of the Church Extension of the Methodist Episcopal Church assembled here today, Bishop Simpson presiding. The committee consists of the Bishop of the church, officers of the Board of Representatives from the General Conference districts, and laymen.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 15.--The largest ore contract ever made in the South was closed to-day by Mr. Shook, General Manager of the Tennessee Coal, Iron, and Railroad Company, with Messrs. G.P. Curting Co. The contract runs ......

NORWICH, N.Y., Nov. 15.--Nearly the whole day in the Dwight trial was spent in reading the depositions taken in Pennsylvania in August last, and in reading and placing in evidence the bankruptcy proceedings relating to Walton Dwight and his wife, Anna M. Dwight.

BUFFALO, Nov. 15.--In the contest of Mrs. Fillmore's will to-day, the testimony of George Gorham, attorney for Mrs. Fillmore, who had renounced a bequest in order to testify, was concluded, and he submitted to a long crossexamination. He was not familiar with her ......

Frederick Hurlburt, a produce broker, of No. 7 Fifth-avenue, boarded a Sixth-avenue elevated train at Battery-place on the evening of July 31, and in pushing through the crowd had his pocket picked, and his gold watch, valued at $280, stolen ...

Felix J. Rosenberg and Emanuel Stern, composing the firm of Rosenberg Co., who also do business under the style of the Rosenberg Manufacturing Company, manufacturers of trowsers, at No. 496 Broadway, made an assignment yesterday to Henry Brash.

HANOVER, N.H., Nov. 15.--Among the Class Day speakers elected by the Dartmouth College Seniors are: Introductory address, George A. Nottleson, of St. Paul, Minn., orator, Ernest Howard, of Adrian, Mich,; poet, Benjamin P. George, of Concord N. H., chronicler Alfred E. Nutt, of Glenooo, Ill,; address at "Old Pine" Charles Eldredge, of Fond du Lae, Mich., and Marshal, H.C. Bullard, of New-York.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Nov. 15.--This was another day of great excitement in oil. Before the opening this morning the feeling was very strong and every indication pointed to a realization of the expectation of a $1.25 market.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 15.Congressman Follett, of the First Cincinnati District, said to-day that he expected to introduce a bill soon after Congress assembled extending the bonded period of whisky two or three years.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 15.--The jury in the Bronson-Brand ministerial libel case of Oberlin disagreed here Wednesday night and were discharged after being out 18 hours.

A new hotel, called the Hotel Warwick, a brick structure, with accommodations for 300 guests, has just been completed and opened to the public at the popular Summer and Winter resort, Newport News, Va.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 15.--A ship-load of imported Jersey cattle, mainly cows and bullcalves, arrived in this city on the steamer Otranto on Aug. 10 and to-day they were offered for sale by auction.

The leading topic in railroad circles yesterday was the threatened war in passenger rates, which, it is claimed by some of the Western roads and the ticket brokers and speculators here, will be precipitated by the action of Commissioner Pierson in ordering the stoppage of the sale of tickets here for points west of Chicago and St. Louis.

OMAHA, Nov. 15. --Trinity Cathedral, one of the most imposing Episcopal church buildings in this country, was consecrated to-day by the founder. Bishop Clarkson, assisted by Lord Bishop Sweetman, of Toronto, Bishop Garrett, of Texas, and a number of clergymen from this diocese.

Mayor EDSON has again demonstrated his unfitness for the responsible position which he holds. He has done this so many times that there is no further reliance to be placed on his professions of independence or of high regard for the public interests.

TRENTON, N. J., Nov. 15.--The names of the four students in the State Normal and Model Schools who have been afflicted with scarlet fever are Butler, Jardine, Ogden and Dalrymple. They belong to New-Jersey. Two are mild cases, but ....

The public is cautioned against Mary M. St. Clair, who is soliciting in aid of St. Frances hospital, in One Hundred and Ninth-street. She exhibits forged letters of recommendation, purporting to be signed by the Mother Superior in charge of the hospital. She is about 24 years of age, 5 feet 4 inches in height, of stout build, with light brown hair and blue eyes, and wears a maroon-colored dress.

DETROIT, Mich., Nov. 15.--The subject of State aid for the purpose of stimulating scientific work occupied nearly all the morning session of the American Public health Association. While Germany, France, and Great Britain are spending large sums for the purpose indicated.

MOBILE, Ala., Nov. 15.--Yellow fever, which appeared in Brewton, Ala., first on Sept. 18, and which carried off 25 victims out of a population of 200 or 300, is declared at an end. There are no more sick. Mobile raised the quarantine against all places to-day.

CHARLESTON, S. C., Nov. 15.--Without much show of fanaticism, prohibition is becoming a very formidable issue in the local politics of this State. An election for member of the Legislature has just been held in Barnwell County. In the pri mary election to select a candidate, for the first time in this State, the line was distinctly drawn upon the temperance issue.

The trial of a noteworthy dispute respecting the ownership of land was ended in the Superior Court yesterday with a verdict for the defendant. The premises in controversy are two lots at Fifth-avenue and East Eighty-seventhstreet. They were bought in 1846 by John McCall for $270.
LIMA, Nov. 15. via Galveston.--It is stated that a project for the purchase of new iron-clads will be presented to the next Chilian Congress.

Wendel's Assembly Rooms, between Eighth and Ninth avenues, on Forty-fourth-street, were crowded yesterday afternoon by the striking operatives of E. S. Higgins Co., carpet manufacturers. They had met to form a plan of conduct to be observed during the strike.

LONDON, Nov. 15.--A dispatch to the Times from Berlin says the tone of the French press in commenting upon the projected visit of the Crown Prince Frederick William to King Alfonso has made a very bad impression in Berlin.

The ship St. Clair, of Thomaston, Me., sailed from New-York on Dec. 18, 1882. She was commanded by Capt. Rives and had a company of 20 souls, including her first and second officers and the crew of 16 men. She carried an assorted cargo and was bound for Nagasaki, Japan.

The trial of a noteworthy dispute respecting the ownership of land was ended in the Superior Court yesterday with a verdict for the defendant. The premises in controversy are two lots at Fifth-avenue and East Eighty-seventhstreet. They were bought in 1846 by John McCall for $270.

NORWICH, N.Y., Nov. 16.--Most of the day in the Dwight trial was spent in reading documentary evidence. Twenty-five applications for insurance in various companies were put in evidence by the defense. Mr. Larocque read part of the applications.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, Nov. 16.--Two large clothing firms, banked by heavy capital, recently started here. In their efforts to build up business they adopted various gift schemes.

NEW-HAVEN, Nov. 16.--In June last the wife of J. Pierce, of Derby, died and was buried in the village cemetery. The widower was grief-stricken; he refused to be comforted, and bemoaned his loss with tearful eyes.

The latest of the proceedings arising from the murders in "Shang" Draper's saloon, in Sixthavenue, on the morning of Oct. 16, is the trial of "Billy" Porter for the murder of Walch, which was begun yesterday morning in the Court of Oyer and Terminer before Chief-Justice Noah Davis.
PARIS, Nov. 2.--The Chamber of Deputies has not followed the advice of one of the waggish members of the Opposition and buried the Ministry on the eve of the Day of the Dead.

DALLAS, Texas, Nov. 16.--The south bound passenger train on the Houston and Texas Central Railroad jumped the track during the night just north of Choctaw, throwing the engine and baggage and express cars through a trestle.

John McArthur, mate of the brig Peter and John 14 years ago, now a respectable farmer in Antigonish, Nova Scotia, has made the following statement to the Antigonish (Nova Scotia) Aurora: "I was the first mate of the brig Peter and John ...

CINCINNATI, Nov. 16.--The Railway Arbitration Committee, sitting in the case of the roads forming the Chicago and Ohio River pool, held three sessions yesterday and two to-day, when the representatives of the several roads were dismissed.
Frank Sulte, a hatter, and Vincent Metecke, a tailor, occupy rooms on the ground floor of the five-story building No. 700 East Fourteenth-street.
In spite of the high wind, which was blowing at the rate of 60 miles an hour at Fort Hamilton yesterday, at 1 P. M., three siege guns discharged 20 admirable shots.

Among the prisoners arraigned before Justice Walsh, sitting for Justice Bergen, in Brooklyn, yesterday, were Charles Nichols, aged 22, of Eighthstreet, near Sixth-avenue, New-York, and Alfred Willis, aged 20, who said he lived in Jersey City.

LONDON, Nov. 16.--Inquiries have been made from America as to whether it was true, as reported in trade circles there, that the French Government has removed the embargo against American hog products. Neither the local papers nor the news agencies can find any ground for the statement that this has been done, and inquiries directed to Paris fail to confirm it.
COLUMBUS, Nov. 16.--The Democratic editors of the State began arriving last night and by noon to-day a majority of the Democratic press of the State were on hand.

At the meeting of the German Republican Central Committee last night, at No. 385 Bowery, George Reininger called attention to the recent appointment of the two Police Justices, who, he said, were closely related to the Green Isle, and he was grieved to see that both Republicans and Democrats had ignored the German element.

Mr. Gerald Massey, who has been advertised as the English orator who can be heard, thought it necessary, before beginning his lecture in Chickering Hall last evening, to relieve the embarrassment of the situation by informing the very small audience that he had come here to sow the seed and not to reap the harvest.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 16.--A strong effort will be made to secure the holding of the Republican Presidential Convention in Cincinnati. Subscription papers are being quietly circulated and those who have them in charge say there will be no trouble at all in commanding all the funds that will be needed.

Edwin Bibby, a well-known wrestler of Providence, and a Frenchman who calls himself "Mamou," and is called the champion wrestler of his native country, ware announced to wrestle last night in Irving Hall at 8 o'clock.

BALTIMORE, Md., Nov. 16.--John Smith, a colored man, was hanged at Oakland, Garrett County, to-day for the murder of Josiah Harden, May 16. Sheriff Jamison made the execution as quietly as possible, allowing but a few to enter the jailyard.

Alice has recently begun to go to school, and has for several days come home proudly with a "gold mark," which, in the particular temple of learning that she patronizes, signifies that the recipient has been very good during the session.

READING, Penn., Nov. 16.--Thomas Baltzer, employed as a laborer on the Pennsylvania and Schuylkill Valley Railroad, at Gibraltar, while hauling a load of dirt to-day, stumbled and fell, the car passing over his body. When picked up blood gushed from his mouth, and he was found to be dead.
OTTAWA, Ill., Nov. 16.--The passenger train on the Fox River Branch of the Chicago, Burlington and Quincy Railroad which leaves Chicago at 8:45 A.M., due in Streator at 12:30, when two miles ...

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Nov. 16.--Miles Orton's circus was attached upon its arrival here at 2 o'clock this morning by Miss Eda Sutton, known as Mlle. Mille Lavely, who since April 4, has been with the show as a tight-rope performer, also appearing as a woman with an iron jaw. She claimed a balance of $500 due on salary.
Inspector Byrnes and his detectives made another raid upon policy-dealers yesterday afternoon, and secured 17 prisoners.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Nov. 16.--The House to-day called up and reconsidered the resolution to adjourn Dec. 5. and then defeated it by a vote of 108 to 36. In the Senate a resolution to receive pay only to Sept. 10 was committed. The Appropriation bill from the House was referred to a committee.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16.--The partisans of the three leading Democratic candidates for Speaker of the House are making the most of their opportunities to arouse interest in behalf of their respective favorites, but the slow arrivals of members makes the contest drag.

ALBANY, Nov. 16.--The Governor has commuted the sentence of John Shine, who was convicted in the County of Niagara in December, 1880, of robbery in the first degree, and sentenced to imprisonment at Auburn Prison for the term of 10 years. The Governor files the following reasons for this action:
Brethren--and especially Free Masonic brethren--ought to dwell together in unity, but just at present a Masonic quarrel of the most complicated nature appears to be in progress.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., Nov. 16.--A corn-shucking, given by Robert T. Love on the farm of John L. Parks, in Long Creek Township, was attended with considerable bloodshed, growing out of a difficulty between a party of whites and blacks.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16--A young man calling himself Francis Christy, and claiming to be from New-York, is under arrest at the Police Head-quarters charged with obtaining money on false pretenses.

CHATTANOOGA, Nov. 16.--Last night a young man named James and an unknown man entered the house of Jeff Redmond, near Carpenter's, Ala., and without saying a word shot him. Redmond's wife leaped from the bed, seized a hatchet, and cut several gashes in James's head, injuring him fatally. Redmond is badly hurt. A feud had existed between the families for 20 years.
Bradstreet's reports 205 failures in the United States during the past week, 14 less than the proceding week, 38 more than the corresponding week of 1882, and 89 more than the same week ...
PARIS, Nov. 16.--This afternoon while Prime Minister Ferry was in the Senate Chamber a young man, 18 years of age, went to the Ministry of Public Instruction and asked to see M. Ferry.
LONG BRANCH, N.J., Nov. 16.--Daniel Huestis, who is accused in Putnam County, N.Y., of firing the town of Brewsters on the night of Nov. 4, is well known in this vicinity.
MILWAUKEE, Nov. 16.--Particulars have been received of a terrible experience in the Northern woods by a man named Ole Nelson.

About 3:30 o'clock yesterday morning the palatial residence of Charles H. Housman, in Valatie, was discovered to be on fire.
One good effect of the late election is to submerge and put out of sight the whole batch of tidal-wave Governors, each of whom had aspirations to the Presidency.

ST. PETERSBURG Nov. 16.--The Will of the People, (the Nihilist organ,) of Nov. 7, states that the sentence of death which was passed by the Nihilist Central Committee on an informer was carried out in October. It says their party has lost many valuable members recently, but that the gaps are being rapidly filled.

BRADFORD, Penn., Nov. 16.--A party consisting of Gen. U.S. Grant, Mayor Franklin Edson, James D. Fish, President of the Marine National Bank; J. Nelson Tappan, Ferdinand Ward, Gen. Grant's business partner; Col. F.D. Grant, Gen. B.W. Spencer, Treasurer, of the New-York, Lake ...
TORONTO, Nov 16.--The inquest upon the body of Rose Tait, of Eugenia, (the young wife of Cook Tait, an aged blind man,) who died suddenly, was resumed yesterday.

CHICAGO, Nov. 16.--With a view to securing an unbiased view of the probable result of the contest for the Speakership of the next House of Representatives the Tribune sent out circulars to its correspondents in each section.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16.--The proceedings of the United States Supreme Court to-day were as follows: No. 127--W.J. Smith et al., plaintiff's in error, vs. Malcolm McNeal et al.: argument. No. 128--Oakley Randall, plaintiff in error, vs. The Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Company; argued. No. 129--Virginia Young, appellant, vs. A.B. Duvall and William F. Holtzman; argument commenced. Adjourned.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 16.--The coal tonnage of all the anthracite carrying companies for October is officially reported at 3,426,270 tons, an increase of 481,235 tons, as compared with the corresponding month of last year.
TROY, N.Y., Nov. 16.--Edward S. Wheeler, a prominent radical and spiritualist, who died at Boston, wss buried from the Unitarian Church in this city to-day.

Louisa Frazer, an emaciated colored woman, 86 years old, was recently found living in a corncrib on the farm of Mr. Mersereau, near Gifford's Station, Staten Island. She said she was born a slave near New-Dorp, Staten Island.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Oct. 16.--As the 3:40 P.M. Cape May train on the West Jersey Railroad was between Woodbury and Westville yesterday afternoon, the engineer shut off the steam, causing the back draught to force the flames from the furnace.

HAMILTON, Ontario, Nov. 16.--Mrs. Langtry, who was too ill to perform here as announced last night, was no better to-day, but notwithstanding she went to London, where she is to perform. She is suffering from a nervous fever.

There is a young lady in Cincinnati who is conditionally engaged to be married. That is to say, if on the day appointed for her wedding she is found to weigh 125 pounds, she is to be married, but in case she weighs less or more than 125 pounds, her engagement is to be broken.
The circumstances of a somewhat romantic marriage in Yonkers got noised about yesterday, the details of which show that a little perseverance can accomplish a great deal.
READING, Penn., Nov. 16.--A number of Philadelphia merchants have been victimized by a party operating under the name of Adam Johnston Sons.

Last night's performance at the Metropolitan Opera-house afforded the New-York public an opportunity to listen to one of Mr. Abbey's barltones for the first time, and to hear Mme. Sembrich and Signor Stagno in fresh roles.
John D. Archbold, of this City, a member of the Executive Board of the Standard Oil Company, spent a few hours with the Pennsylvania Legislative Committee in Leland's Hotel, yesterday.

A broad and bright blaze was visible in the direction of Communipaw at 2 o'clock this morning. It attracted much attention from those persons who were on the streets at that hour. It was stated that the freight-house of the Central Railroad of New-Jersey was on fire.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16.--Major-Gen. W.S. Hancock, in his annual report of the operations of the Military Division of the Atlantic, states that the total number of enlisted men in that division on Sept. 30, 1883, was 2,591, and of commissioned officers 351.
Teams representing Yale and Columbia Colleges will play a match game of football for the championship at the Polo Grounds to-day at 2:30 P. M.

MOBILE, Ala., Nov. 16.--The Register is receiving the plant for lighting its newly remodelled building throughout with electric light. This is the first newspaper office in this section to adopt this system of illumination.
The naval parade, which will be the feature of the celebration on Evacuation Day, will surpass anything of the kind ever attempted in this country.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 16.--Prior to the adjournment of the last hearing of the Dinsmore suit to annul the lease of the Central Railroad of New-Jersey to the Philadelphia and Reading Railway, ex-Senator Roscoe Conkling and Clarence A. Seward, of NewYork, declared that they would not come back to Philadelphia on any account.

PARIS, Nov. 16.--The Gaulois estimates the French forces now in Tonquin at 18,000 men, including both soldiers and sailors, which is 4,000 above the figures given by Admiral Peyron, the Minister of Marine.
A jury in Newburg has been performing one of those feats of interpretation which are possible only under the marriage laws of New-York.

About 300 people, who stamped their feet and rubbed their ears to keep warm, gathered on the lee side of the Prospect Park Fair Grounds yesterterday to see the finish of the race between Johnny Murphy's Frank and James Golden's Winship.

An important action has been instituted by a prominent law firm of this city against Mary Caroline Fries, the Superior of the School Sisters of Notre Dame, this city. The plaintiffs are William, Magdalena, Edward, August, Albert, Walter, Ella, and Nettle Schraudenbach, Caroline Staps, Otillie J. Rice, and Henry Lowe.

Garlington, and described the changes which had subsequently been made. From this it appeared that the original was prepared by Capt. Clapp, and the amendments were made up on suggestions of Prof. Abbe, ...

BUFFALO, N.Y., Nov. 16.--The propeller Avon, Capt. E. Marion, of the Union Steam-boat Company's Line, which left here yesterday morning with a mixed cargo of merchandise valued at $10,000 and insured, was caught in a terrible gale of wind and snow in the afternoon, and was driven back.

The 2,000 operatives of E.S. Higgins Co. ended their day on strike yesterday more determined than ever to resist the 10 per cent. reduction. A meeting was held in the morning in Wendel's Assembly Rooms, and the situation was discussed.

The lighter Echo, belonging to the National Steam-ship Company, was lying alongside the bulkhead between Piers Nos. 49 and 50 North River, yesterday morning, with a deck-load of 181 bales of cotton intended for shipment to Europe.
DUBLIN, Ga., Nov. 16.--Miss, Pennie Wimberly, the 18-year-old daughter of Col. Robert Wimberly, was burned to death to-day, her dress igniting while preparing dinner.
This city, which has enjoyed an enviable reputation as one of the healthiest places within 20 miles of the great Metropolis, seems likely to suffer from the prevalence of typhoid fever.
CHICAGO, Nov. 16.--The Iowa pool is broken at last. As related in these dispatches, there has been trouble growing out of the equalization of the live stock rates in the Iowa pool.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 16.--The trial of the libel suit of ex-Judge Briggs against Phillip C. Garrett, Chairman of the Committee of One Hundred, drew a great crowd of people to the Common Pleas Court No. 1 to-day.

The compositors who day before yesterday were busying themselves with several of the morning papers in demanding higher prices, yesterday morning transferred the fight to the evening papers by asking an increase of from 35 to 40 cents per thousand ems.

The familiar music of Violetta in Verdi's opera, "La Traviata," took a fresh hold on life last night when Adelina Patti, at the Academy of Music, inspired it with the vitality of her impassioned and exquisite performance.
DETROIT, Nov. 16.--The Michigan crop report for Nov. 1 is received. It includes returns from 605 townships.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Nov. 16.--The deposition of John W. Rumohr, who ran away from this city last April, after embezzling a considerable sum from Smith Weber, grocers, in whose employ he had been, was filed in the County Clerk's office to-day.
PANAMA, Nov. 7.--The American bark Azor, Capt. Haines, of and from Roston for Aspinwall, with a cargo of dressed lumber, was wrecked a few weeks ago on the island of New-Providence.
PITTSBURG, Penn., Nov. 16.--The conference of glass manufacturers and work men, which has been in progress here for the past two days, adjourned this evening without reaching any settlement.
The Chicago Inter Ocean prints the following letter written by Abraham Lincoln when a member of Congress to Judge A. Williams, of Quincy, Ill., a personal and political friend:
BANGOR, Me., Nov. 16.--The steam boiler of Kimball De Laite's mills, at Easton, blew up on Wednesday. Four men were scalded, three of them so severely that their recovery is doubtful.
The Harlem Commons Syndicate, a company with a capital stock of $300,000, filed its papers of incorporation with the Secretary of State one day early this week.

CHIHUAHUA, Mexico, Nov. 16.--Frank O. Jaynes, clerk of the Superintendent of ore-sorting at the Jesus Maria Silver Mine at Parral, Mexico, of which N.A. Cowdrey is half-owner and Robert E. Leer, of Leadville, is President, is said to have gone to the United States with $600,000 of the company's money. It is alleged that he went North on a freight train disguised.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16.--The President has mitigated the sentence of dismissal in the case of Lieut.Col. A.P. Morrow, Sixth Cavalry, tried by court-martial for drunkenness, to a suspension from rank and command, with forfeiture of one-half pay for the period of one year and a reduction in linear rank to the foot of list of Lieutenant-Colonels.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 16.--The facts of a singular seizure have been made public. Commander Russell, under orders from the Navy Department, seized the monitor Monadnock, which was being constructed at Vallejo, and removed it to the navy-yard.

LONDON, Nov. 16.--The Paris correspondent of the Times says there is reason to believe that the basis upon which an agreement is likely to be arrived at between the Suez Canal Company and the English ship-owners is that the administration of the company shall be 44 per cent. English and 56 per cent. ...

ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 16.--Walton County has made a beginning in the punishment of illegal voters. A number of indictments have been found against persons who have voted in violation of the law, and two of them, white Democrats, named Richard Robertson and John Jarrel, were convicted in the County Court and fined $15 and costs. The other cases have been continued to the December term.
When Larry Jerome, accompanied by his friend Aleck Taylor, entered the down-town Hoffman restaurant Wednesday he was visibly affected by the gorgeousness of his surroundings.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 16.--William F. Airey, elected Sheriff of this city at the recent election, having received his commission from the Governor of the State, qualified to-day and assumed the duties of the office. Mr. Airey was elected on the fusion ticket and is the first Republican elected Sheriff of Baltimore since 1867. It is probable there will be a wholesale removal of Deputies in the office in a few days.

The body of the oil broker, Mr. Robert Fellows, who lived in Stamford, Conn., and who disappeared in this City on Oct. 29, was found yesterday afternoon under Pier No. 19 North River lying on the rocks, where it had been left at high tide.
The funeral of Dr. J. Marion Sims took place yesterday morning at 10 o'clock in the Madison-Square Presbyterian Church. There were no services at the residence of the dead man.

The managing Committee of the American School of Classical Studies at Athens met in this City yesterday. There were present Profs. John William White and William W. Goodwin, of Harvard College; William M. Sloane, of Princeton College; W.S. Tyler, of Amherst College, and J.C. Van Benschoten, of Wesleyan University.

An insane woman set fire to a bed in a cell on the ground floor in the female work-house, on Blackwell's Island, at 9:45 o'clock last night, and for a few moments there was great excitement among the other inmates. A fire alarm was sent out, but the bed was dragged out in the corridor and the fire put out without any damage except the destruction of the bed.
The tug Samuel J. Christian, Capt. George Mitchell, took fire at 4 o'clock yesterday morning while steaming up the North River.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Nov, 16.--Great interest was aroused in commercial circles shortly after noon to-day by the announcement that Daniel Wells had brought suit against Peter McGeoch to call the latter to an acounting for all the transactions in which the two were concerned at the time of the collapse of McGeoch's lard corner last July.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 16.--The change in the weather has caused a more lively demand for coal, and small stove is now so scarce that no orders for delivery this month are taken. The fire at Shenandoah will restrict supplies from that section.

In obedience to the order issued by the Supreme Court the Inspectors of Election of the Eighth Election District of the Second Assembly District produced before the County Canvassers yesterday the returns from that district and the board proceeded to canvass the Assembly District.

DES MOINES, Nov. 16.--It is broadly intimated that considerable change will be made in the Faculty of the Iowa Agricultural College this week, and it is probable there will be a change in either the Presidency or the next in rank. President Welch and wife will spend the Winter in Europe. Two of the Professors will tender their resignations, having secured other engagements.

Mitchell, of Staunton, Va., who has in press a volume on ancient sculpture. The celebration of the Feast of Saint Cecilia by the New-York branch of the American St. Cecilia Society will occur next Thursday at the Church of St. Francis Xavier, in West Sixteenthstreet.

LONDON, Nov. 16.--The Manchester Guardian, in its commercial article, says: "Business is unimproved. Reports from Liverpool of a strong market there make sellers less easy, but buyers are not eager and the business transacted has been small. Prices are fairly steady.

TROUT RUN, Penn., Nov 16.--A portable boiler in Marlette Maxwell's steam saw mill, in Jackson Township, near Trout Run, exploded at 7 o'clock this morning.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Nov. 16.--The body of Thomas L. Kidney, a well-known manufacturer, was found last evening in the wheel-pit of his mill, at Deer River, Lewis Couty. He went into the pit to repair the machinery, missed his footing and fell to the bottom--about seven feet. A large cogwheel which he was supporting also fell, striking him on the head, crushing his skull. Kidney was 45 years of age.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 16.--John O'Neill, a former employe of the Pennsylvania Railroad, who was recently arrested in Hartford, was brought to this city to-day by Detective Donaghy.

NORWICH, Conn., Nov. 16.--Judge Stoddard, in the Superior Court, has disposed of Emanuel Montairo so effectually that one of the worst terrors to the police and to the lovers of law and order in North-eastern Connecticut will spend the next 20 years of his life in the State prison.

When the vessel which brought Father Hyacinthe to this country arrived here it was boarded by an employe of the New-York Tribune. This parson, who bears the name of Dr. Oswald Keatinge, expressed his eagerness to help the French clergyman by giving him a pleasant notice in the columns of the Tribune, and added that he was anxious to be of service to him in any other manner.

ELLENVILLE, N.Y., Nov. 16.--This village was thrown into a state of great excitement on Thursday evening by the arrival of four Deputy Sheriffs with Charles Mayhon and John Moore ...
GALVESTON, Texas, Nov. 16.--Two farmers, D.R. Neal and William Lynn, while disputing about picking cotton, shot each other. Lynn was killed, and Neal is dying.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Nov. 16.--The jury in the case of Edward Rickert, on trial for the murder of Selina Wilson, to-night rendered a verdict of acquittal. Rickert was a reporter on the Glove-Democrat until three years ago.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 16.--Gen. Cook telegraphed to head-quarters to-day that Capt. Rafferty had arrived at San Carlos with 90 Chiricahuas. The total number of Indians on the reservation is 83 bucks and 343 women and children. Only 40 are now out and they will be in soon.
CITY OF MEXICO, Noc. 16.--A letter has been received here which states that a new gold field has been discovered in Lower California. It is much richer than those already explored.

BATAVIA, N.Y., Nov. 16.--Edward Newton Rowell was arraigned before Judge Haight at the opening of court this morning, and pleaded not guilty to manslaughter in the first degree, as charged in the indictment. His father, sister, and brother were in the court-room, and it is said the first named and Holden T. Miller, Cashier of the bank of Batavia, will become Rowell's bondsmen if he is admitted to bail next week, as expected.
BUFFALO, Nov. 16.--In the contest of Mrs. Fillmore's will to-day a cloud of women witnesses appeared to testify to her sanity.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Nov. 16.--Henry Stiever, an itinerant peddler, was murdered near Johnston's station, in Edgefield County, on Wednesday night. He was struck on the head with a wagon standard while asleep, and when found he had been dead for several hours. Jim Green, a colored boy, who had been driving Stiever's wagon, is missing, and is suspected of having committed the murder.
CHICAGO, Nov. 16.--John L. Sullivan late to-night agreed to fight Paddy Ryan. The fight is to come off in San Francisco in one, two, or three months, four rounds, Marquis of Queensberry ...

OTTAWA, Nov. 16.--It is understood that Postmaster-General Carling will submit to Parliament at the coming session such an amendment to the postal laws as will prevent the circulation of lottery circulars and tickets through the mails.
The commander of the Yantic showed conclusively in a report recently made that his vessel sailed to the arctic seas in very bad condition.
A cold westerly wind blow through the streets of this City yesterday, and at 11:12 A. M. attained a velocity of 30 miles an hour.

An eccentric old woman named Mary Woodbridge died at Shirley, near Birmingham, yesterday morning. The deceased, who is 83 years of age, had occupied the same miserable tenement for over 20 years, and from her appearance and penurious mode of life was generally believed to be in extreme poverty.

PARIS, Nov. 17.--The physicians who have examined young Currieu, who endeavored to shoot Prime Minister Ferry yesterday, state that he is suffering from the effects of a recent attack of typhus fever. He does not belong to any anarchist society.
GALT, Ontario, Nov. 17.--James Trotter's jewelry store here was entered by burglars last night and $7,000 worth of watches, jewelry, and cash was taken.

MILWAUKEE, Nov. 17.--President Rhinelander, Treasurer Norrie, Manager Reid, Attorney Corry, and seven Directors of the Milwaukee, Lake Shore and Western Railway, all of New-York, are making a careful trip of inspection of the Lake Shore's main and branch lines by special train.
A divorce contract between Martin Reeg and Salome, his wife, both of Allegheny, was placed on record in the Recorder's office yesterday.

READING, Penn., Nov. 17.--Owing to the continued decline in iron the Pottstown Iron Company, of Pottstown, employing several hundred hands, announces a reduction of wages of about 10 per cent., beginning on Dec. 1. Some other mills in the Schuylkill Valley contemplate similar action.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Nov. 17.--Intelligence has been received here of two homicides in Orangeburg County, in this State. At Fort Motte, Andrew Reese, while under the influence of liquor, had a fight with his father.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 17.--One of Mayor King's colored policemen cane into the Central Station this afternoon clutching a Chinaman by the nape of the neck. The pair were followed by a young man whose face showed that he was of Milesian extraction.

BOSTON, Nov. 17.--Col. Huguley, of Gov. Butler's staff, has commenced a suit in the courts against the Hon. Alanson W. Beard for alleged libel, uttered in his speech first made at Lawrence and repeated at other places.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 17.--At a meeting of the Board of Police Commissioners this evening the case of ex-Capt. Sheridan, of the police force, who resigned last Monday night because of alleged peculations from prisoners brought to his station-house, was considered.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 17.--In a game of foot-ball between teams from Rutgers College and the University of Pennsylvania, respectively, the following score was made: Pennsylvania, 2 goals, 1 touch-down; Rutgers, 5 safeties, or 18 to 0 in favor of the Pennsylvanias.
OTTAWA, Ontario, Nov. 17.--An order in Council is published placing imported recovered rubber and rubber substitute on the free list.

Much interest is being taken in the preparations for the festival to be held by the united choir of Trinity Parish in Trinity Church on next Thursday evening. This will be the eleventh annual meeting of the choir, the first having been held in Trinity Chapel in 1873.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Nov. 17.--A German peddler named Henry Steifer has been murdered near Trenton, S.C. Wilson Stephens, a young colored man, who drove Steifer's wagon, has been arrested. The shoes, clothing, and money of the murdered man were found in his possession, and Stephens has confessed the crime. It is feared that the murderer will be lynched.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 17.--The young lady students of the State Normal and Model Schools were sent to their homes to-day by Prof. Hasbrouck, the principal, in order to prevent any possibility of contagion from the scarlet fever which has broken out in the young men's boarding halls.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 17.--The swindler, some account of whose operations in this city was given in a Reading dispatch to THE TIMES this morning, is a young man of fine appearance and good address, who called himself Benjamin A. Johnston.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Nov. 17.--The Rochester Lincoln Club, one of the most prominent associations of the young Republicans of Western NewYork, to-day sent a letter to Mayor Low, of Brooklyn, congratulating him on his re-election.

CHICAGO, Nov. 17.--An order was made by Judge Moran in the Scoville divorce case to-day granting the custody of her child, Bertha, to Mrs. Francis Maria Horne, formerly Mrs. Scoville, sister to Charles J. Guiteau, the murderer of President Garfield.

There is living on Clerkenwell Green an aged woman, one Sarah Wybrow, who entered her one hundred and second year on the 29th of last April. Although physically weak, she is in possession of all her faculties. Her last surviving child, a daughter, died last week at near 80. Her grandchildren are elderly people, and her great-grandchildren are too poor to help her.
The main hall of the Cooper Institute was filled last night with a large and intelligent audience, attracted by the lecture on "Rural Russia" given by Miss L.M. von Finkelstein.
Last evening Mr. John H. Meech, of the Academy of Music, received a dispatch from Chicago announcing the death of Mr. James C. McCollom, an actor well known in Buffalo. No particulars were given.

It is quite a mistake to suppose, as some of the daily papers have persistently asserted, that Cardinal Manning's visit to Rome has anything whatever to do with the establishment of a Catholic college in Oxford.

Mr. Morris Ranger, the Napoleon of Liverpool finance, the huge operator, the gigantic speculator, the dealer in "futures," the man who thought as little of millions as another one might of pence, has come to the ground at last and brought a great many of his friends with him.

The New-York Free Trade Club has arranged for a meeting at the Cooper Union next Thursday evening, to consider the necessity of a prompt revision of the present system of national taxation.

To undertake to furnish scientific proof of the existence of Deity appears somewhat premature,if not presumptuous, when, according to the general admission of philosophers, man has made little, if any, progress in demonstrating his own existence.
The upper part of the five-story brick building, No. 257 west Twenty-seventh-street, which is occupied by wood-workers, and turners was burned out early last evening.

PARIS, Nov. 17.--Official advices have been received from Tonquin which state that the military situation there is unchanged. Admiral Courbet will remain within his lines if the result of an attack upon Sontay and Bac-Ninh appears to be doubtful.

The three surviving members of the Pasteur mission have just returned from Egypt, and are preparing an elaborate report which will be presented to the Minister of Agriculture, whose department includes questions of public health.

Henry Fuhr, a German compounder and vendor of medicine for rheumatic ailments, disappeared from his home, No. 309 West Forty-fourth-street, last Wednesday morning, and was found dead yesterday in a lodging-house at No. 226 Thompson-street, having evidently committed suicide.

Local self-government survives in Georgia, although it is said to have almost disappeared in several Southern States.
Company I, Forty-seventh Regiment, Brooklyn, will give an exhibition drill and reception in the Greenpoint armory to-morrow evening.

Fire broke out in the battery-room of the Western Union Telegraph Company, in the west end of the New-Jersey Central Railroad Freighthouse, at Jersey City, about 1 o'clock yesterday morning, and the building, together with 16 cars and a quantity of freight, was destroyed.

NORWICH, N.Y., Nov. 17.--The first witness called to-day in the Dwight case was L.E. Bowe, ex-Register in Bankruptcy for the Northern District of New York. He swore as to the proceedings in the bankruptcy case of both Walton Dwight and Anna N. Dwight at great length.

It has been estimated by those best able to judge of such matters that there are over 1,000,000 cigars smoked daily in New-York City, requiring at the least calculation 15,000 boxes, which when once empty are rendered useless by law for the further storage of tobacco.

NEW-HAVEN, Nov. 17.--The University Club held an important meeting this week, the result of which will be to make the club an assured success, and one of the college institutions.
CHICAGO, Ill., Nov. 17.--Sullivan and Ryan to-night signed articles for a four-round contest with soft gloves between Jan. 19 and Feb. 1 at San Francisco, the data receipts to be divided equally.

We may protest with all the righteous indignation of which we are capable against the degradation of yachting by the introduction of steam yachts; but the century is too strong for us. The beautiful, whitewinged yacht is doomed.
It is unfortunate that Mr. GERALD MASSEY has arrived in this country at a time when the Concord School of Philosophy is not in session. There can be no doubt that Concord is his true sphere.
A Roman memorial arch has just been completed in the town of Tilton, N.H., through the munificence of the Hon. Charles E. Tilton.

A marriage ceremony in East St. Louis was very abruptly cut short on Monday evening. A young man named Moses Casey wood and won the heart of Lydia Parker, and the marriage was set for the evening mentioned at the residence of Justice Draggon.
NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 17.--Sedonia P. Wagner, widow of Peter K. Wagner, and sister of Gen. John L. Lewis, died last night at the age of 85 years. She was a remarkable woman and had a remarkable career.
A proposition to enlarge the scope of the Brooklyn Young Republican Club is at present exciting a good deal of discussion among the members of that vigorous organization.

For more than a year Mrs. Emma Winters has been the happy wife of Isaac Newton Winters, a well-to-do Brooklyn builder. Winters is about 80 years of age, and until yesterday was much respected as a citizen and churchman.

It is the last day of July; a thousand versts wide around is Russia--home. The whole heaven is a shadowless azure; only one solitary, tiny cloud floats therein, and melts away. Perfect calm, heat. An atmosphere like lukewarm milk.

Everything was quiet yesterday among the ticket-sellers. There was little business doing, and what was done was principally over the road's running out of St. Louis, the order of Commissioner Pierson applying only to those roads having Chicago as their eastern terminus.
Mr. Caleb Eber, the turtle fisher, who was in this village a few weeks since, is still engaged exploring the small streams in the eastern part of this town, and for the most part with great success.

Several changes have occurred among the members-elect of the House of Representatives. Mr. George D. Robinson has been elected Governor of Massachusetts. Mr. John E. Kenna, of the Third District of West Virginia, is to take his seat in the Senate as the successor of Mr. Henry G. Davis.

PRINCETON, N. J., Nov. 17.--To-day was a day of rejoicing for Princeton. The town was filled with visitors to witness the first game in the foot-ball championship series played between the Harvard and Princeton teams.
OTTAWA, Ontario, Nov. 17.--Although the demand for lumber has been somewhat duller this year than last, larger quantities have been shipped, but at lower prices.

It was too cold weather to expect a large attendance at the Yale-Columbia foot-ball game, on the Polo Grounds, yesterday afternoon; but between 200 and 300 people, three-fourths of them students with canes, passed in a half-dollar to the man at the ticket-office.

In a vault of the largest safe deposit company in the country, situated in lower Broadway, is a great safe that is entirely filled with articles left in the vaults and private business apartments of the company by depositors who consider themselves the most careful people alive, and who pay largely for the very security they do not avail themselves of.
The question of Government control of the telegraph in this country has been the subject of discussion in two successive numbers of the North American Review.

On a Columbus-avenue car, filled to repletion, the other day, there entered a well-dressed young woman carrying a pug dog in her arms. Several gentlemen started to vacate their seats, but, getting a sight of the pug dog, settled back complacently in their seats again.
Bernard McDonald, who was shot in the head during a quarrel with Richard O'Keefe on the night of Nov. 5, at Forty-sixth-street and Tenthavenue, died yesterday at Roosevelt Hospital.

The brakemen on the passenger trains of the Consolidated Road seldom have occasion to jump from the train while it is in motion. Most of those who jump live at way stations where express trains do not stop. Some regular passengers are well up in the jumping act.

Mrs. Tartufe is very comfortably off, and spends a considerable portion of her income on dress, preferring, however, a sort of chastened splendor is her attire, as agreeing with her retiring disposition and her state of widowhood.

BOSTON, Nov. 17.--The meeting of the Presidents of New-England colleges, which has been in session in this city for two days, has adjourned. The conference was strictly private and was devoted entirely to informal discussions on educational subjects. Among other topics that of the study of modern languages in colleges was considered, every participant freely expressing his views. President Porter, of Yale, was not present at any of the conferences.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17.--Two more candidates for the Speakership arrived to-day, and there are now four candidates in the field, with about 30 Congressmen among whom the work of canvassing can be prosecuted.

Turgenieff's old friend Annenkoff tells the following story of the poet's youth: Turgenieff frequented the St. Petersburg University. At the beginning he had plenty of money, but all at once his supply stopped, the student having had a quarrel with his mother.

Senator James G. Fair, of Nevada, is in the city on his way to his Western home after an extended Eastern trip, which directly followed a European tour. BUFFALO, N.Y., Nov. 17.--Several local bankers were interviewed to-day on the question of the national bank currency contraction which must result from the paying off of the national bonds.

When the Queens County Insane Asylum was instituted, in 1876, "Dr." W.A. Rogers, who had conducted a private asylum at Glen Cove, Long Island, was appointed Keeper. He has held the office ever since up to Nov. 1, when the Board of Supervisors appointed Charles G. Clements, of Hempstead, Keeper in his stead.

The Milwaukee (Wis.) Sentinel prints the report of a committee of the Robert Chivas Post of the Grand Army of the Republic, giving the results of its investigation of the charges made respecting the treatment of the inmates of the National Soldiers' Home, near that city.

It is proposed to make a collection of old steel pens for the benefit of the homes for destitute and neglected boys, Deansgate, Manchester. Patrick Hayes, a Bowery gambler, has accused George Norton, another gambler, of betraying his wife and alienating her affections, and has begun a suit against him, claiming $10,000 damages.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 17.--A fire broke out this evening in the south-east corner of the American Steam-ship Company's freight shed, at the foot of Christian-street.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 17.--The members of the Congregational church of Hebron are anxiously waiting for to-morrow's service.

BOSTON, Mass., Nov. 17.--A box at the Salem National Bank, which should have contained $6,000, the personal effects of the estate of the late T.B. Perkins, of which Ira H. Bigelow was Trustee, was opened yesterday by the counsel for the estate and found to contain only two rubber bands. Bigelow absconded some months ago. The loss will be made good by his bondsmen.

TROY, N.Y., Nov. 17.--There is a water famine in Ticonderoga, and the supply for manufacturing and domestic purposes is exhausted. The pipes are being extended 500 feet into the lake. The manufacturers of the district began to blast the rapids below Lake George, but the Lake Champlain and Lake George Transportation Company obtained an injunction restrainining them. A mass-meeting of citizens has been called, and legislative aid will be asked.
RACINE, Wis., Nov. 17.--J.I. Case, of this city, to-day purchased from Mr. Easton, of Kentucky, the 4-year-old stallion Endymion, a halfbrother of Jay-Eye-See, the consideration being $10,000.

I have several times denounced the practice of rating great country houses at scandalously small sums, but I certainly cannot approve of the proceedings of the local authorities at Raglan, who have increased the rating of the castle ruins from 20 to 300.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17.--The United States Treasurer now holds in United States bonds to secure national bank circulation, $353,178,300; bonds to secure public moneys in national bank depositories, $16,856,000; bonds deposited to secure circulation during the week, $814,500; bonds to secure circulation withdrawn during the week, $697,000.

HAVANA, Nov. 17.--There were 18 deaths from yellow fever here during the past week. There has been a larger proportion of cases of yellow fever among shipping than is usual at this season. This is probably owing to the continuance of hot, damp weather.

The will of the late Thomas Whitridge, filed in the Baltimore County Circuit Court, shows disposition of property valued at about $3,000,000. The American Unitarian Society, of Boston, receives $100,000 cash, and the Home of the Friendess, this city, $15,000 cash.
A number of German and foreign officers have been invited to Buckau, near Magdoburg, to witness a series of interesting experiments with German artillery against German armor-plating.

The Republican State Convention in 1856 was the first State assembly of delegates held by this party in Maine. It was composed of 1,186 members, representing every section.

In a little school-house, nestled under the shadow of a mighty boulder in the Adirondacks, we found three children in session; one of them a harmless little idlot, sent there for safe-keeping, and a bright light woman as busy as she could be in the teacher's work.

Much interest is at present felt in Catholic circles in the project to start a Catholic university in New-York. Among the many Catholics who seem to favor the project strongly is Mr. Thomas B. Connery, whose views were obtained yesterday by our reporter.

Each day determines some new point in the arrangements being made by the Victoria Hotel committee for the celebration of Evacuation Day. The extent of the celebration will be limited only by the funds subscribed for the purpose by the City and by private citizens.

LAFAYETTE, Ind., Nov. 17.--Early on Friday morning a body of masked men visited the drug and notion store of C.C. Sutton, at Romney, this county, burst in the door, carried out the drugs and entire stock of goods, and destroyed them.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Nov. 17.--A summons has been filed in the Sheriff's office by Daniel Wells, Jr., in a suit to compel Peter McGeoch to account for money involved in the settlement of the celebrated McGeoch lard failure a few months since.

READING, Penn., Nov. 17.--The Luther festival was celebrated in this city to-day with the ringing of bells and services on the Fair Grounds. There were upward of 7,000 Sunday-school children and two bands of music in the line of the parade. The great feature was the singing of Luther's hymns by this immense concourse of people.

George Gardner, formerly of Groton, but later of Providence, R.I., was fatally injured Tuesday night. He was employed as brakeman of the midnight freight train on the New-York, Providence and Boston Railroad, and his head came in contact with a bridge near Providence.

Dr. Valentine Browne, the City Health Officer of Yonkers, told a TIMES reporter yesterday that no new cases of typhoid fever had been reported in two days and those first taken down with the disease were now convalescing.

CAIRO, Ill., Nov. 17.--South-bound passenger train No. 3 on the Illinois Central Railway collided with train No. 4, bound north, near Bradford Station, Penn., at 2 o'clock this afternoon.

Mrs. John W. Garrett died at Montebello yesterday morning at 8:10 o'clock, unconscious and without suffering. The injuries she received while out riding on Oct. 11 resulted in accute inflammation of the brain, which was the immediate cause of death.

The pre-emption feature in our public land code was enacted for the specific purpose of enabling actual settlers to secure farms on the public domain, and to protect the domain from speculators. But it seems that in the North-west the pre-emption law has been seized by the speculators and employed to defeat the very purpose it was intended to serve.

The farmers in Alabama are recorded as making a fortune raising roses, and have orders for 50,000 plants more than they can fill. Two farmers in Georgia, we hope, will fill that aching void and rake in the shekels.

LIVERPOOL, Nov. 17.--In an address delivered in the Town Hall yesterday M. de Lesseps said that a second canal across the Isthmus of Suez could only be constructed alongside the present one, with a liberal margin intervening for the strength of each.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17.--The members of the naval court-martial, of which Commodore McCauley was President, appointed last month to try Medical Inspector S.D. Kennedy on charges of drunkenness have returned to New-York from Panama, where the court was held.
A young woman applied at the box-office of the theatre in Augusta, Ga., the other day for "two circular dress seats."

CHICAGO, Nov. 17.--The Western Electric Company, which furnishes the time to all the leading jewelers, has decided to conform to the new standard. The Board of Trade Committee to-day decided to adopt the new time on Monday morning, and the Post Office will make the change at noon to-morrow.

DEPOSIT, N.Y., Nov. 14.--Mr. M.B. Hulse, an old resident of this place, who attended the celebration of the opening of the New-York and Erie Railroad, at Dunkirk, N.Y., on May 15, 1851, an account of which was published in THE TIMES of Nov. 12, kept an elaborate diary on the occasion.

INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 17.--This week Purdu University, at Lafayette, the State Agricultural College, was provided for by an agreement to advance one year's interest on bonds of the State held by the university, and this leaves only the Bureau of Statistics yet unprovided for.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Nov. 17.--John Green, the negro boy suspected of the murder of Stiefer, a peddler, in Edgefield County, Wednesday night, was captured yesterday at his father's house.

Yesterday, while hunting on the Norris grant, near Dry Creek, Louis Melcher shot a fine specimen of the golden eagle. It measured almost 8 feet from tip to tip, had immense talons, and weighed 15 pounds. It is the first of this species that ever was killed in this section.

CHICAGO, Nov. 17.--The leading produce markets were rather slow to-day and generally weak, though they did not decline so badly as on some other days when weakness has prevailed. The fine weather was in large part the reason for the weakness, as it favors a liberal movement of produce from first hands without increasing the consumptive demand.

Thomas B. Rand, one of the proprietors of the St. Cloud Hotel, who has been acting as Receiver of the Rossmore for two and a half years, appeared before Judge Donohue, of the Supreme Court, on Friday, and asked to be relieved of his duties as Receiver.

An interesting discovery has just been made in Calcutta by Mr. Bayne, an engineer in the employment of the East India Railway Company. He has succeeded in identifying the exact site of the historical Black Hole, and has laid bare a portion of its walls.
Charles F. Billings, an agent of the Society for the Prevention of Crime, was brought to the Tombs Police Court, yesterday, charged with compounding a misdemeanor.

Gov. Ludlow yesterday sent a message to Counselor Kalisch in answer to the request for a respite for John H. Chisholm, the Newark wife murderer, who is to be hanged on Thursday, stating that there was "nothing in the case to warrant any interference by the Executive by reprieve or otherwise."

The fifteenth anniversary of the Presbyterian Hospital will be celebrated at a meeting to be held in the Collegiate Dutch Church, Forty-eighthstreet and Fifth-avenue, to-morrow evening at 8 o'clock, when addresses will be made by the Rev. Dr. John Hall and Dr. Arthur Mitchell, of Cleveland, Ohio.

STAMFORD, Nov. 17.--John Rogers, the sculptor who has become famous for his celebrated Rogers Groups, which may be found in nearly every city, erected a little over a year ago, near the railroad station in this town, a strange-looking building.

CHICAGO, Nov. 17.--A south-west wind and a bit of a blaze came near cleaning out "the Strand" at South Chicago early this morning. As it was, seven buildings, most of them boardinghouses, were burned to the ground, and one man, a rolling mill hand, was charred to a crisp.

A widowed ox at the Brooklyn Navy-yard is quietly awaiting his fate while heartless men, known to the world as butchers, are bidding for the possession of his fair proportions. The bereaved animal is to be sold.

The house of Cecil is figuring in prominent relief at the present moment, and the marriage at St. Adrew's, Wells-street, on Saturday last is the appropriate sequel and culmination of the two magazine articles by the head of the family.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 17.--The Elks club-rooms were thronged to-night by members and several hundred guests, invited to the club's full-dress reception of Miss Clara Morris, who plays an engagement here next week.

MATAWAN, N.J., Nov. 17.--John Drum, one of the band of outlaws surprised near Hazlet Station, escaped while in the hands of a constable. Each day Thomas Drum gives some new account of the depredations of the gang.

LONDON, Nov. 17.--The Daily News says it has reason to believe that Speaker Brand is desirous of retiring from the office at the beginning of the next session of Parliament, and that Sir Henry James, member of Parliament for Taunton, is spoken of as his successor.

In the conclusion of his Thanksgiving proclamation the Governor says: "Given at our Council Chamber in Boston." This is after the manner of royal proclamations. The usual form is "The Council Chamber." Does the Governor mean "We, the people, or us, the Jupiter Tonans of the gilded dome?" The phrase needs explanation.

James Scott, aged 99 years, a native of Ireland, came down from Camptonville yesterday to take out naturalization papers. He was unable to secure them, Judge Keyser being absent.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Nov. 17.--This afternoon a pistol-shot was fired on the second floor of No. 22 North Second-street, where Herman H. Liempke's glass painting shop is situated. Among his employes was the proprietor's brother, J.H. Liempke, a single man 30 years old, who was addicted to excessive drinking.

Pratt, of No. 26 East Twenty-seventh-street, New-York, who is insane, and who escaped from his friends here last Wednesday, was captured to-day in Brookline, Mass., and brought here to-night. CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Nov. 18.--At the convention yesterday of the Congregational Association, after considerable discussion, resolutions were passed advocating equality among Christians of all races in religious communion, and strongly condemning the present system of separate churches for white and black Christians. LONDON, Nov. 18.--The British steamer Condor, from Liverpool, sank off Minden, Holland, today during a violent storm. Eighteen of the persons on board were lost, including the engineers, who were killed by the bursting of the boiler. Eight were saved.

CHICAGO, Nov. 18.--Anna Dickinson has decided to again go on the lecture platform under the auspices of the Kinghts of Labor. She declares her intention of making speeches in all the principal cities of the country in the interest of that organization until the close of the next Presidential election.

WHEELING, West Va., Nov. 18.--For the past 24 hours this city and immediate vicinity has been greatly excited over the mysterious disappearance of Major Samuel B. McColloch, clerk of the Circuit Court, an influential Republican politician and probably the most popular and widely known citizen of Ohio County.

ST. GEORGE, Ontario, Nov. 18.--Two freight trains came into collision near this station last night, wrecking both engines and several cars. Forty hogs were killed. The trainmen saved themselves by jumping. The loss is estimated at $30,000.

The little village of Chappaqua, Westchester County, was greatly excited yesterday over the arrest of a man who confesses to having committed a number of burglaries in that vicinity re cently, and the discovery and recovery of a lot of the plunder.

PETERSBURG, Va., Nov. 18.--Senator William Mahone has issued a long address to the Readjuster Party of Virginia, in which he tries to explain the defeat of his party at the election of Nov. 6, and declares that the fight in Virginia shall still go on.

LIMA, Nov. 18, via Galveston, Texas.--The National says that a Ministerial crisis is approaching. Ministers Lavalle and Osma have sent in their resignations, and it is expected they will be followed by the resignations of Ministers Barinaga, Dalanto, and Malpartida. It is believed the resignations of Ministers Lavalle and Osma will not be accepted. Gen. Osma's departure for the South has been postponed.
