NEW-ORLEAIS, Nov. 18.--The first through train to Cincinnati, without change, over the NewOrleans and North-eastern Road across Lake Ponchartrain left the Cotton-Press-street station at 11 o'clock this morning.
WILKESBARRE, Nov. 18.--The bad blood existing between the two Irish Democratic factions of this county, engendered by the late county convention, still continues.

Mr. John T. Agnew, one of the managers of the Presbyterian Hospital, presided at the fifteenth anniversary of that institution, which was observed in the Collegiate Reformed Church, at Fifth-avenue and Forty-eighth-street, last evening, and introduced the Rev. Dr. John Hall as the first speaker.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 18.--Caleb R. Brown, an inmate of the State Asylum for Insane Paupers at the State Farm, died in June and was buried in the cemetery on the farm. Last week friends sent for the body, when it was discovered that the grave had been violated and the head of the corpse removed.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18.--The report published some time ago that the President had forbidden the publication of department reports in advance of their submission to him is again going the rounds of the newspapers.

RIDGEWOOD, N.J., Nov. 10.--The elegant residence of I.W. England, publisher of the NewYork Sun, at Paramus, was destroyed by fire about 11 o'olock this morning with all its contents, excepting a few oil-paintings.

"Gus" Heitner, ex-champion of Long Island City, and "Billy" Mulhall, middle light-weight champion of Queens County, were to have met in the pugilistic arena on Saturday night at a wellknown sporting resort in this City.

The most elaborate religious ceremony ever witnessed in Paterson took place there yesterday in St. John Baptist's Roman Catholic Church, on the occasion of the semi-centennial anniversary of the dedication of the first substantial Roman Catholic church in Paterson, in 1833.

MATAWAN, N.J., Nov. 18.--The institution known as the First National Bank of Manasquan will open its doors to-morrow. It is a newly organized company, with Charles Allen, of Manasquan, President, and John Terhune, of Matawan, Cashier. The capital of the institution is $50,000. A new brick building has been erected for its use, and time locks have been placed in the vaults.

BROOKVILLE, Long Island, Nov. 18.--All last night and to-day Mr. Garrett Maybee, old, blind, and crippled, sat in a little upper room in his house moaning and bewailing the loss of his wife and daughter, whose bodies lay in the parlor underneath, while hundreds of persons from all over the county swarmed to the homestead to view the scene of the murder of the two women.

BOSTON, Nov. 18.--The new time standard went into effect successfully in this section to-day. Prof. Pickering at the Harvard University watched through a telescope for the falling of the time-ball in this city.

The class which graduated from Yale last year mourns its first loss by the death of Yung Few Tan, who died after a short illness at Colebrook, Conn., last Wednesday morning. Yung Few Tan was the only one of the Chinese students in the Class of '83 who completed his course in college.

CARMEL, N.Y., Nov. 18.--James Byrnes, the prisoner who was shot in the jail here on Nov. 7 by Jailor Merrick, died this afternoon. Merrick is still in confinement. Dr. Bryant, of New-York, who visited Byrnes twice, has been asked to attend the post-mortem examination.

The Church of Disciples of Christ, in West Fifty-sixth-street, between Eighth and Ninth avenues, was formally dedicated yesterday morning, the sermon being delivered by the Rev. Frederick D. Power, of Washington, the Pastor of the late President Garfield.

The concert at the Metropolitan Opera-house last evening, in spite of the attractive array of singers, was not attended by a very large audience. The orchestra chairs ware nearly all filled, but there were unsightly gaps in the rows of boxes.

Barton Allen, a respectable looking young man, presented himself at the boarding-house No. 31 West Thirty-second-street on Sept. 27 and applied for a situation as waiter. He came well recommended, and was engaged by the mistress of the house on a small salary.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Nov. 18.--The trial of James Nutt for the murder of N.L. Dukes will come up at Uniontown, Penn., the first week in December. The services of the Hon. Daniel Voorhees, of Indiana; the Hon. Marshall Swartzwelder, and Major A.M. Brown, of this city, have been secured by the defense.

LANCASTER, Penn., Nov. 18.--George, alias "Tid," Brimmer, the fugitive incendiary, was captured in Harrisburg this afternoon and returned to the Lancaster jail this evening.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Nov. 18.--Louis Elbinger, who came here from a Northern Ohio town last Spring and went into the clothing trade, has assigned. His preferences are as follows: Marks Co., Cincinnati, $4,866; K. Hirschman, Cincinnati, $520; J. Lowman Brother, Cincinnati, $1,234; J. Elbinger, Des Moines, $1,500. The stock is large and the goods would seem to be ample for a large dividend.

BOSTON, Mass., Nov. 18.--F.N. Westervelt and O.N. and C.E. Whipple, members of the Springfield Bicycle Club, arrived here to-night, having made 101 miles in 12 hours, the fastest time on record.
PETERSBURG, Va., Nov. 18.--This morning Albert Slade dropped dead in the Ettrick Mathodist Church while about to engage in prayer.

Pattison's place he would veto the bill appropriating money to pay the members of the Legislature. When asked to state his reason he replied, "For the public good." He considered the extra session a farce.

It is evident that the visit of the German Crown Prince to King ALFONSO is in danger of proving a failure. The visit was planned by Prince BISMARCK, and there is no doubt that had the management of it been left to him it would have been brilliantly successful. Perhaps even at this late hour BISMARCK may manage to make it useful, but the prospect is certainly dark.

UTICA, N.Y., Nov. 19.--Saturday night the houses of Henry Beckwith and William Wright, merchant and banker respectively, were entered by burglars and several articles of small value taken. This morning Ward Hunt, Jr., found that his house had been ransacked during the night. Watches, silver ware, and clothing to the value of several hundred dollars were stolen. Mr. Hunt's wardrobe was so depleted that he had to telephone for a suit of clothes.

The trial of "Billy" Porter for the murder of John Walch was continued yesterday before Chief-Justice Davis in the Court of Oyer and Terminer. Capt. Selden Alien Day, of the United States Army, who is at present detailed by the Ordnance Department as inspector of small arms, was called to give expert testimony.

LEADVILLE, Col., Nov. 19.--S.H. White, a civil engineer on the Denver and South Park Railway, was murdered to-day by T. Cutter, at Robinson. White has a brother in Chicago named Randall White, who is a Justice of the Peace.
LONDON, Nov. 19.--A slight shock of earthquake was felt at Malaga, Spain, on Friday last. A slight shock was felt in the province of Palermo, Sicily, to-day.
The Dominion Department of Marine has decided to present Michael Troy, of Wolfe Island, a silver watch in recognition of his humane and praiseworthy exertions in saving life in Lake Ontario.

Gen. Butler does not care to have the credit of being the father of the Civil Rights bill, lately declared null and void by the Supreme Court. He says that while he reported the bill from the Judiciary Committee, it was not drafted by him, but by Mr. Shellabarger.
Our town has been considerably excited over the imprisonment of a drummer by the name of Smylie a few days ago.
An amusing incident that occurred to the RevFrederick Baylis Allin, Assistsat Rector of Trinity Church, is called to mind by the number of weddings that have occurred during the past week.
Mr. J.F. Robinson sues the city of San Antonia, Texas, for $55,150, and his petition is based on the following facts: The city of San Antonio each year destroys all unlicensed dogs by poison.

NORWICH, N.Y., Nov. 19.--The proceedings in the Dwight trial this afternoon consisted mostly of documentary evidence. Norman W. Batchelder was cross-examined. He testified that in 1876 he was the agent of the Mutual Benefit Insurance Company of Newark, N.J., at Albany.

An elegant monument of beautiful Hallowell granite has just been placed in Forest Grove cemetery in honor of the late Hon. Lot M. Morrill, The monument rises gracefully to the height of about 25 feet, tapering symetrically to the apex.

It is extremely probable that the young straneer, P.J. Gebhard, who claimed to be a cousin of Freddie Langtry Gebhard will not be sent to the penitentiary on account of the faulty manner in which the prosecution was conducted.

M. LOYSON evidently has an unlimited capacity for religions. Like the King of Siam, who made a collection of religions, embracing them all, with the view of securing the right one, M. LOYSON is at once a Roman Catholic, an Old Catholic, an Anglo-Catholic, a Gallican, a Puritan, a Huguenot, and a Calvinist. With the Old Catholics, he refuses to accept papal infallibility.

Fissures aggregating 2,000 feet in length were discovered in the Croton aqueduct in the section south of Yonkers last Thursday and Friday. The aqueduct was shut off until 4 P.M. on Saturday and the necessary repairs were made.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 19.--The culpability of Frank Vaneman, a conductor on the Fourth and Eighth streets line, for forcibly ejecting Daniel J. Murphy from his car was so plain to Magistrate Clarke this morning that he held Vaneman in $800 bail to answer for assault.

Isaac Walker, a fashionably attired and good-looking young man, aged 23 years, was arrested yesterday at a boarding-house in Second-avenue, near Twenty-third-street, on a warrant issued by a Philadelphia magistrate.

The new building of the Ovington Brothers, importers of fine chinaware and glass at No. 250 Fulton-street, Brooklyn, was opened for inspection yesterday from noon until 6 o'clock, and a large number of ladies and gentlemen holding special invitations visited the store.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Nov. 19.--The NewsJournal has a dispatch from its Columbus correspondent which charges that John R. McLean is being assisted in his efforts to prevent the re-election of Senator Pendleton by Gov. Foster.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Nov. 19.--A dispatch to the Journal from Sugar Grove, Penn., to-day says that the Rev. Marc Emory, a Congregational minister, has disappeared, and it is feared that he is either mentally unsettled or a defaulter, as there are accounts aggregating a considerable sum against him. He was unmarried and came to Sugar Grove from near Cincinnati a few months ago.

During Monday night a remarkable fire occurred in Hensell's stationery establishment of Camp-street. The fire was remarkable because the room in which it occurred was filled with the most combustible material and a conflagration did not follow.
CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Nov. 19.--This morning James Brown fell between two cars in the Cincinnati Southern yards in this city. Both legs were out off and he died is a few hours.
Mr. W. Gilbert writes to us as follows: "A statement has recently appeared in your columns to the effect that my houes in Harrington Gardens was designed by myself.

The town of Liege, writes to us a correspondent in Belgium, had the privilege of a visit from M. Francisque Sarcey, the eminent French critic, on Wednesday last, who delivered a most interesting lecture on Corneille's tragedy of "Polyeucte."

BOSTON, Nov. 19.--George L. Ruffin, a leading colored lawyer nominated just after election by Gov. Butler for Jndge of the Municipal Court in the Charlestown District, was today confirmed by the Executive Council, and immediately qualified. He is the first colored man to hold a judicial position in the State.

Every pleasant afternoon, particularly at this season of the year, the broad pavements of Broadway between Madison and Union squares are thronged with an ever-varying stream of pedestrians which moves slowly along the thoroughfare.

"If a storekeeper wants to starve in business, let him tell the truth." This sentence, overheard as it dropped from the lips of a man apparently well versed is business methods, led to an attempt to discover to what extent the business code of honesty has been deliberately adopted among shopkeepers.

DFF REDANG BEZAR, Sept. 10.--If first impressions are the most enduring, those of an adventurous tourist on first landing in Malacca must be peculiarly unfortunate.
There is a mystery about the retention of Mr. FRANK HATTON in the Post Office Department, which the Postmaster-General, since he suffers most from it, would do well to explain.

The proceedings in the suit of William B. Dinsmore against the Philadelphia and Reading and New Jersey Central Railroads, to have the lease of the latter to the former declared void, were concluded in the office of the Central road, in this City, yesterday.

TROY, N.Y., Nov. 19.--At the County Clerk's office to-day was filed the notice of the commencement of an action of foreclosure of a mortgage of $2,000,000 by the Lebanon Springs Railroad Company to the Union Trust Company of New-York.

Many of the older residents of Pittsburg will remember Miss Louisa Simpson, who was known for her peculiarities and her wealth. She owned the old Drury Theatre besidos many other valuable pieces of property about the city.

ROSLYN, Long Island, Nov. 19.--Theodore Valentine's lamp-black factory was burned to the ground to-night at 12 o'clock. The origin of the fire is said to have been the explosion of a distilling pipe. The building was a large wooden structure, in the centre of the villarge. The loss is estimated at about $5,000, and there was no insurance.

Prof. Maassen, of the Vienna University, who was hissed by the students last Spring for his anti-German speech in the Diet, met with the same fate to-day in the splendid building on the Ringstrasse, which the University has just taken possession of.
ST. LOUIS, Nov. 19.--The Union Depot Street Railway Company have discharged a number of their conductors for stealing, and some of the discharged men are to be prosecuted.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Nov. 19.--Howard R. Deacon, a well-known merchant of this city, accidentally shot Charles Martin, of Burlington, N.J., at Fifth and Market streets, about 4:30 o'clock this afternoon. The wounded man, who, with his brother, W.H. Martin, keeps a hotel at Barnegat, was standing with the latter on Fifth ...
The brain of Turgenieff is said to have weighed 2,012 grammes. The avearge weight of the human brain is 1,390 grammes. Turgenieff's is said to be the heaviest which has yet been weighed.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Nov. 19.--Theodore Roosevelt, of New-York, was in this city to-day. He says he is a candidate for Speaker of the Assembly, but that it is too early to form any opinion about the probable result.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19.--The Speakership contest has not thickened to any appreciable extent to-day. Mr. Randall has deferred opening his head-quarters at the National until tomorrow and was only seen down town for a short time soon after noon.
Mr. Georgs V. Hecker, head of the firm of Hecker Co., of the Croton Flour Mills at No. 205 Cherry-street, lost his handsome Summer residence in Orange Mountain, N.J., by fire early on Sunday morning.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Nov. 19.--John Clair, who was fatally shot by Dennis Keller on Saturday night because he would not move faster when he was requested to do so, died at the hospital this morning from his injuries.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Nov. 19.--Jamestown is much perturbed over a proposal to abolish the village charter and adopt a city charter. Previous attempts to get a city government have been frowned down, but a strong effort will be made again this Winter. The worst result feared by the obstructionists if a city charter is secured are increased taxes and opportunlties for political job bery.
WHEELING, West Va., Nov. 19.--Four days have now elapsed since the disappearance of Major S.B. McColloch, and not the slightest trace of his whereabouts has been, discovered.

Mr. E.D. Bassett, Consul-General for Hayti, asked Collector Robertson yesterday to have the schooner Azelda and Laura preveated from leaving this port. "I have reason to believe," he said, "that she has a lot of arms and ammunition on board designed to give aid to the rebels in Hayti." The schooner was cleared last Friday for Bluefield, Nicaragua.

There appears to be a possibility, if not a probability, of an outbreak of war between Nepaul and Thibet. The quarrel arose thus: A custom prevails at Lhassa that for the first two months of the year a kind of carnival is held, during which the Ministers retire from the cares of State and make over their duties to the monks of the three great monasteries.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 19.--Col. Solidor Milon to-day celebrated the ninety-sixth anniversary of his birth, and in the evening was the guest of the Philadelphia Musical Association, of which he is a member, at a banquet.

Of all the many beauties of the Thames, none surpass those which he around that great bend of the river which passes from Henley to Bray, Skirting the wooded cliffs of Cileveden, rich at this season of the year with antumnal tinting, it passes picturesque Maidenhead, and thence runs through the broad alluvial flats which extend toward Windsor.

The statement that the Hon. Neil Gilmour is a candidate for the clerkship of the Assembly was without foundation. Some of his many friends confused their earnest wish with his possible inclination in making the premature announcement, and beginning a canvass which was certainly promising. Mr. Gilmour desires not to be considered in connection with the office in question.

In the recent election in this City every voter was called upon to choose between two candidates for Secretary of State, Controller, Treasurer, Attorney-General, State Engineer and Surveyor, two candidates for each of two Judgeships of the Supreme Court, two candidates for each of two Judgeships of the City ...

ATLANTA, Nov. 19.--A fight for $1,000,000 is under way between different factories of the old Southern Mutual Insurance Company of Athens. The company was organ ized in 1847, first as a Life and Fire Insurance Company, but subseqnently the life feature was abandoned.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Nov. 19.--A dispatch from Iron Mountain says: "The 1,500 men from the Chapin and Ludington mines, who struck on Saturday, are holding out, but threaton to destroy the works if the Menomines Mining Company, ...

LONDON, Nov. 6.--The old fable of the mouse helping the lion has once more been illustrated in the persons of Lord Randolph Churchill and Sir Stafford Northcote. The Conservative leader was nominated by the students of Edinburgh University for the Lord Rectorship of their college, having two opponents in Mr. G.O. Trevelyan, the Liberal ...

OTTAWA, Ontario, Nov. 19.--The City Council to-night adopted the report of the Medical Board appointed to investigate the cause of the alarming mortality in the foundling hospital kept by the Grey Nuns in this city, known as the Bethlehem for the Friendless.

VICKSBURG, Miss., Nov. 19.--President Morehead and several delegates to the convention of the National Cotton Planters' Association, which meets in this city on Wednesday, have arrived here. Telegrams received from distant States announce that many delegates are en route to the convention.

Before the Alumni Association of the Philadelphia College of Pharmacy recently a promineant physician related a rather unusual circumstance in which a case of corrosive poisoning was treated and cured.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 19.--County Auditor Brewster, who succeeded W.S. Cappellar, a few days ago, states that he has discovered extensive frauds in tax duplicates. He charges that ex-Auditor Cappellar's clerks systematically raised the valuation of property returned by the Board of Equalization, and computed the taxes upon this fraudulent valuation.

Arabi's influence among Mohammedans all over the world has greatly increased since his arrival in Ceylon. Thousands of his Indian co-religionists have visited him at Colombo, which is now regarded as a sort of half-way house to Mecca.

Every now and thon a movement is made by the State authorities to compel the theatres of this city to pay a license fee of $500 under the provisions of the act of May 15, 1850. The cases in the past have always dropped out of sight for some reason.

M. Henlein Co., wholesale dealers in nosiery at No. 189 Church-street, made an assignment yesterday to Leopold Bleier, giving preferences for $50,726.05, all for borrowed money or discounted notes. The liabilities are about $160,000.
BOSTON, Nov. 19.--It is stated that as the consent of the Controller of the Currency to the withdrawal of the suit against the stockholders of the Pacific Bank must be obtained, ...

M. Gaston Tissandier and his brother Albert have constructed a balloon with an electrical propeller, consisting of the balloon proper, the gas generator, and the electromotive apparatus driven by a battery of 24 bichromate cells.

PARIS, Nov. 19.--M. Challemel-Lacour, who recently obtained leave of absence from the Foreign Office, has written a letter to President Grevy from Cannes finally resigning the office of Minister of Foreign Affairs on account of ill-health.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Nov. 19.--There is no truth in the report sent out yesterday that Daniel Wells, Jr., had attempted to shoot Peter McGeoch, but there have been spicy developments to-day in the great row in progress between the millionaires, growing out of the lard corner collapse of last July. Wells first sued McGeoch for an accounting of the transactions ...

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Nov. 19.--In a conversation with THE TIMES's correspondent concerning the recent controversy between Gen. Joseph Holt and himself Mr. Jacob Thompson, who, besides Gen. Holt, is the only living member of President Buchanan's Cabinet, stated that he contemplated writing a history of his visit to Canada as the agent of the Southern Confederacy.

At the time of the failure of Cecil, Ward Co. it was found that the Wall-street National Bank had certified checks for the firm to the amount of nearly $200,000. The indorsement was written by the Paying Teller, George P. Graff.

PORTLAND, Oregon, Nov. 19.--Justice Field, of the Supreme Court, indorses Judge Deady's decision granting a temporary injunction in favor of Wells, Fargo Co. in their suit against the Northern Pacific and Oregon Railway and Navigation Companies for equal express carrying facilities over those lines.

When Gov. and Mrs. Pattison left the city Tuesday to attend the marriage of Senator Gordon, at Alexandria, Va., they left their bright and interesting young son Robert, aged about 5 years, in the best of health, but when they returned yesterday afternoon they found the little fellow seriously ill with membraneous croup, and his recovery in the gravest doubt.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 19.--The second trial of Dr. Albert G.F. Goerson, who was convicted in 1881 or poisoning Elizabeth G. Goerson, his wife, but was granted a new trial by the Supreme Court, was begun to-day.

W.B. Johnston, whose home is in Webster Mass., left California eight months ago with as old horse and buggy, behind which was fastened an Ayrshire cow that had accompanied him across the plains and furnished him with most of his living en route. He passed through this village on his long journey and reached his destination on Tuesday.

"Chill November," and the partridge shooting season is in its zenith! Eager sportsmen, with dog and gun, are on every outgoing train, and huge bunches of the plump little perdrix hang in front of every provision store.

CHAPPAQUA, N.Y., Nov. 19.--The burglar Phyle, who was captured here on Saturday, was committed to-day by Justice Lane for further examination. He admits having committed four burglaries in Tarrytown last Summer, and having stolen two watches, a clock, two silk dresses, and some men's clothing. He says he had confederates, and that there are other goods hidden. He promised Constable A.C. Lawrence that he would make further revelations.

The tug-boat Jenny, which has been used in conveying supplies to Bedloe's Island since work was begun on the foundations for the Bartholdi statue, was run into on Saturday evening off the Battery by an unknown tug.
Mayor Edson returned to the City yesterday from his trip to the western part of the State. He was at his office in the City Hall only for a few minutes.

From a given point in this city the signs indicate the offices of some 16 physicians. The infereuce would be the place is unhealthy, when the contrary is the case. The writer is reminded of the visit of an English lord to Sacramento during a session of the Legislature many years ago.

Gustave Dore's statue of Alexandre Dumas was unveiled this afternoon in the presence of a host of literary and artistic notabilities, some thousands of persons collecting also outside the inclosure. It is erected in the Place Malesherbes, only a stone's throw from the house of Dumas the younger, who was on the platform, and was overwhelmed with congratulations on the homage paid to his father's memory.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., NOV. 19.--On the 24th of September last Ada Atkinson, a beautiful girl of 15, was found murdered in her room in her father's house. She was the daughter of Cephas Atkinson, a man of wealth, living near Oxford, Benton County, 20 miles west of Lafayette.

Alexander H. Falconer, a photographer's assistant, became infatuated with the daughter of Henry Hale, of Brooklyn, six years ago. Miss Hale was then but 12 years of age Falconer was arrested about 18 months ago on a charge of writing annoying letters to her.

We a are informed that Mr. John O'Day, Chairman of the State Democratic Committee, is taking an active interest in the election of Mr. Randall as Speaker of the next national Honse of Representatives, and is undertaking to bring influences to bear upon Missouri members in that direction.
"France's Readiness for War" is the title of a pamphlet which appeared here toward the end of September, is already in its fourth edition, and is being translated into French and Italian.

For the last week or 10 days a dispatch form Bloomington, III., has been going the rounds of the press representing Alexander D. Hamilton, the ab soonding and defauiting City Treasurer of Jersey City, to be in a very repentant mood, and bespeaking for him the generous sympathy of the people.

CHICAGO, Nov. 19.--The Illinois Central Railroad will adopt the new standard time of the Central Section, or the ninetieth meridian, next Sunday, the difficulties at first anticipated having been overcome.

Mr. Harris's "Uncle Remus, His Songs and His Sayings," published in 1880, gave us a foretaste of that pleasant subject of folk-lore on the plantation, and in the present volume, having found new stories, derived from the same sources, the author has presented a delightful work.

RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 19.--The address published by Mahone, purporting to give an account of how the recent election in this State was conducted by the Democrats, meets with the severest criticisms on all sides here. Even some Readjusters regard it as a bitter partisan account, in which the people of this State are grossly misrepresented.
The Baltimore Day calls Butler the Mahone of Massachusetts and Mahone the Butler of Virginia, and has not yet satisfied itself with rejoicings that they were both defeated in the late elections.

Ten years have passed since the enactment of the Revised Statutes of the United States; a measure which, while it but very slightly changed the substance of the law and practice of the national courts, entirely rearranged and phrased anew all the statutes on the subject, and cast doubt on the applicability of former decisions.

TORONTO, Ontario, Nov. 19.--Willing Williamson, books and stationery, Kins-street, have failed. They bought out the old firm of Adam Stevenson Co. some years ago. They appear to have been crippled by a lack of ...

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Nov. 19.--A prisoner named Rosegrant made a daring escape from the custody of Oliver Easton, the Sheriff of Wyoming County, this morning, between 1 and 2 o'clock. The pair, accompanied by a third man, left Tunkbannock on the 1:30 o'clock train.

LONDON, Nov. 19.--Later accounts from Jeddah relative to the defeat of the Egyptian force at Toka state that the Egyptian soldiers fled before the enemy despite the efforts of their commander to rally them.
LONG BRANCH, N.J., Nov. 19.--Chief of Police Frank Patterson, of Red Bank, has succeeded in recapturing John Drumm, the brother of Tom Drumm the negro leader of the robber band.
The Russian Government is still engaged in its war against the phylloxera. It has already spent $150,000 in the enterprise, and further large sums will be needed to complete the work.
An affidavit over the signatura of Benjamin F. Butler, of Massachusetts, was presented as evidence yesterday by the plaintiff in the Gilman against Noyes hearing now in progress at the Courthouse.

Last April William W. Gillis left Clifton Springs, New-York, where he edited a religious paper, leaving behind him large defalcations. He is charged to have forged the name of Mark A. Johnson to a promissory note.

Prof. Norris, the ethnologist, who has been examining the mounds in this section of West Virginia for several months, the other day opened the big mound on Col. B.H. Smith's farm, six or eight miles below here. This is the largest mound in the valley and proved a rich store-house.

"The women, bless their little hearts," said Mr. Drew, of the Van Ness Horse, "the women can be just as sharp at a trade as the men. One Winter I went up to Richford to buy a horse. I found it all right, but all the time I was making a trade with the man who owned it his wife kept raising ...

ITHACA, N.Y., Nov. 19.--The testimony introduced at the recent trial of the Fiske will case goes far to prove one of the leading points of the contestant, that at the time of the death of Mrs. Fiske, Sept. 30, 1881, the university already held property exceeding $3,000,000, the limit fixed by its charter.

The corruption of the empire has reappeared in the heart of Paris. Theresa, the Patti de la chope, the Rigolbocne de la chanson; Theresa, who, with Jacques Offenbach, used to be considered the chief artisan of the decadence that led to the disaster of Sedan, has returned to the stage of the Alcazar, the scene of her old triumphs.
A novel wager was decided at the Fair Grounds in Sherman yesterday. The bet was that a mule could not move a sack of salt 10 feet, the mule being at one end of a 200-foot rope, 2 inches ...

DROGHEDA, Nov. 19.--Mr. Healy, Member of Parliament for Monaghan, delivered an address here yesterday before a large public meeting, in which he adverted to the report that the Government intended, at the next session of Parliament, to introduce a bill extending the franchise, from the benefits of which Ireland was to be excluded.

The death watch has been set on John H. Chisholm, the wife-murderer, who is to be hanged at Newark on Thursday. When he was told that the Governor would not interfere to save him, he expressed a wish to see his children, who are with his dead wife's parents, the McCembers.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Nov. 19.--The Bessemer Steel Works at Homestead, Penn., closed down their rail department on Saturday night for an indefinite period. The remainder of the establishment will continue in operation until the present orders are worked off, when there will be a general suspension unless there is an improvement in trade.
LOCKPORT, N.Y., Nov. 19.--Mrs. Patrick Kane, 60 years old, was found dead at her residence on Adam-street, in this city, at 6 o'clock this morning.

The career of Alexander Jonin is one which, so far as success is concerned, any man in any service might be proud of, because every step of it has been earned by work done and recognized at ite value by a Government which dose not always know its best servants.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 19.--For some time past the business men of St. Louis have been urging that the rates charged by the St. Louis, Bride and Tunnel Company were excessive, and a new bridge has been talked of. It has been known that Jas Gould has been contemplating the building of a bridge across the river at Arsenal Island.

Our party rein up to a fine, modern-built two-storg farm-house, with a commodious barn, stable, and outbuildings, says a correspondent in Caribou, Me. Mr. John Eddy lives here. He was a pioneer and a fair sample in some respects of the average Aroostook farmer.
The Reformed Church Classis of Long Island, at its meeting yesterday, received from Mr. E.S. Porter a letter withdrawing his application for ordination at the hands of the classis.

The little hillside farm in Brookville, Long island, where Mrs. Lydla R. Maybee and her daughter, Annie Eliza, were strangled to death and the husband and father, Gerrit M. Maybee, was beaten almost insensible late Saturday afternoon, was thronged with people from all the country round yesterday.

DENVER, Col., Nov. 19.--Last night several men who were playing poker in a barber's shop here became involved in a personal fight, in the course of which half a dozen shots were fired. Jack Weidermen, a faro dealer, was instantly killed. It is said that the shooting was done by Tom Yeager, another faro dealer. Weiderman was well known in Chicago and Cleveland.

UTICA, N.Y., Nov. 19.--The canal-boat A. P. Downer, loaded with corn sank crosswise in the canal five miles west of Utica this morning. The boat is broken across the middle and is a total wreck. The canal is completely blocked and it will probably take a couple of days to clear away the wreck.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19.--Another means of raking in money by circulars through the Post Office and a lock-box has just come to light. Circulars have been sent to those Postmasters of the country who come within the law for readjusting salaries, offering for the sum of $5 in advance to collect the amount due.

Norton's Union Intelligencer, at Dallas, announces improvement in its daily and weekly editions, and proposes to hold the fart as a "firstclass Republican paper." The Gazette will be very glad to see the Intelligencer realize its aspirations, journalistically speaking.

Some German papers having urged Gorman ladies not to get their dresses from Paris, the Vottaire indulges in the following elegant raillery:
KINGSTON, Outario, Nov. 19.--A disturbance occurred last night in the Victoria Music Hall, which was occupied by the Salvation Army.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17.--In the Protons court of incuiry Commander Frank Wildes, commanding the United States steamer Yantic, was called to the witness stand. Before taking the oath he handed to the court two papers, stating that they were the orders of the Secretary of the Navy, under which he reported to the court.
RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 20.--The State Democratic Committee will meet here on Thursday next. One of the most important matters to be considered by this body is the recent address issued by Mahone.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20.--The annual report of David D. Porter, Admiral of the navy to Secretary Chandler is an exhaustive document of 110 pages of legal cap. Admiral Porter devotes a chapter of his report to new steel armored vessels designed for the navy by the Advisory Board.
AUGUSTA, Ga., Nov. 20.--The Southern Telegraph Company's line has been completed to this city, and is working with Richmond, Baltimore, and intermediate places.
BOSTON, Nov. 20.--The cargo of naphtha on the schooner Nellie Clark, from Bayonne, N.J., owned by the Clark Brothers, of New-York, took fire this afternoon, and 300 barrels were destroyed.
"Constant Reader" is informed that Baton Rouge is the capital of Louisiana.

EASTON, Pa., Nov. 20.--John Price, who with Carling and Smull, the alleged faster, escaped from the Belvidere, N.J., Jail last Thursday night was captured at the residence of his grandfather the Phillipsburg N.J., this morning and returned to prison.
The New York Trio Club gave a pleasing concert of Russian music at Horticultural Hall, in West Twenty-eighth-street, last evening.

BOSTON, Nov. 20.--William C. Phelan, well known in Montreal, who was brought from there several weeks ago to answer a charge of passing counterfeit money, has been sentenced to five years' imprisonment.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, Nov. 20.--The announcement was made this evening that the Herald, which lately reduced the price of its evening edition to 2 cents, will reduce its morning issue to 3.

TROY, N.Y., Nov. 20.--The Coroner to-day ordered an investigation into the death of Mamie Ryan, aged 6 years, who is reported to have died from the effects of an outrageous assault committed upon her in July lask. The alleged culprit was indicted, but discharged on his trial, the child's testimony not being admitted. The girl suffered terribly for four weeks before she died.

A diminutive Skye terrier of the female gender skipped about the desk in front of Justice Duffy, at the Jefferson Market Police Court, during an examination before that magistrate to decide her ownership.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 20.--Miss Ober, proprietor of the Ideal Opera Company, a middle-aged lady of firm manner, occupied the stand all day to-day in the breach of contract case against her ex-manager, Martin.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 20.--Through grief and despair at the suicide of her mother, Miss Lizzie Burmiester, residing in the eastern section of this city, made an attempt to commit suicide this morning by hanging herself to a grape arbor in the rear of her residence.

A meeting of the stockholders of the Postal Telegraph Company has been called for Saturday, Dec. 1. "to consent by a formal vote to the sale of their property, rights, and interests" to the Postal Telegraph and Cable Company.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., Nov. 20.--In a letter to the Post-Express Mr. Robert B. Roosevelt relates an interview which he had with ex-Mayor Ely, who referred to the letters of Hewitt and Cleveland,...

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Nov. 20.--Joseph E. Parsons was dismissed from the letter-carrying force of this city for throwing into a waste-hasket at the Post Office, pamphlets addressed to parties on his route. He was arrested to-day and taken to Boston to answer for violating the postal laws.
The second verdict in the Kilbourn case shows once more that the national Government, when acting either as plaintiff or defendant, is at a disadvantage before a Washington jury.

BANGOR., Me., Nov. 20.--The City Government by the votes of three Democrats have sustained the vote by Mayor Cummings of the order adopting the new time standard. The standard time has, however, been quite generally adopted in in the city. Two of the public clocks have been changed by a vote of the parish committee, and the Unitarian clock will to-day adopt the new time.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 20.--About 10 o'clock last night an attempt was made to rob the house of J.J. Garrett, in New-Providence, a mile and a half from Clarksville.

But little was done in the way of searching the city or surrounding country as the ground bas been gone over so often and so carefully that it was felt by all that any further effort in that direction would be futile.

No more applications will be received for places in the line of the Evacuation Day parade. The committee in charge have made arrangements for all they can conveniently handle. They estimate that between 25,000 and 40,000 men will participate.

LONDON, Nov. 20.--At the Central Criminal Court yesterday, the Central News applied to have certain alleged libels, which have appeared in the London Sportsman since the dismissal of the summons for libel last week, added to the indictment. The Recorder ordered the matter postponed until counsel for the Sportsman could be heard.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 20.--Just before sun down this afternoon one the officers of the steamboat Twilight, which has Chestnutstreet wharf as a landing saw a well dressed woman running at full speed toward the end of the pier. Suspecting that she contemplated suicide, he followed her and caught her just as she was about to leap into the river.
The new standards of coffee have reached the Coffee Exchange in this city from Rio de Janeiro, They embrace six different kinds, and each conforms to certain recognizad American standards.

Judge McAdam, in the City Court yesterday, dismissed the complaint of Lizzie Hannon against the Trustees of the East River bridge. Miss Hannon was hurt in the disaster last Decoration Day. She sought to hold the Trustees of the bridge personally responsible far damages on the ground that they had neglected to take proper precautions against disaster.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20.--Commander Wildes's examination before the Proteus court of inquiry was resumed to-day. Gen, Hazen was present and asked leave to put some questions to the witness.

ALBANY, N.Y., Nov. 20.--John Hurley, an eccentric old miser, a resident of Fultonville, committed suicide yesterday afternoon by hanging himself in a dilapidated house a short distance from the village.

The longest water-supply pipe ever laid on the bed of any river in this country was sunk in the East River yesterday. It was 2,200 feet in length, reaching from One hundred and Thirtyeighth-street diagonally across the Government channel to North Brother Island.

The second day of the Republican enrollment was marked chiefly by the much larger number of names received than on the first day. There were added to the lists yesterday 8,787 names; the number registered the first day was 5,784, making a total of 14,571. Of those about one-third, probably, were not members of the previous district organizations.

Miss Katie T. Cotting, daughter of Mr. Amos Cotting, was married yesterday afternoon to Mrs. J. Egmont Schermerhorn, at the residence of her parents, No. 13 East Forty-second-street. The parlors were decorated with smilax and roses. The ushers were Robert McLean, E.C. Cotting, cousin of the bride; Elliot Roosevelt, and William Parkin.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 20.--The second trial of Dr. Albert G.F. Goerson for the alleged poisoning of Elizabeth Goerson, his wife, was fairly started in Judge Ludlow's court to-day, a twelfth juror having been chosen from the special venire of 15 issued on Monday.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Nov. 20.--John Nazro, of Chicago, one of the best posted iron dealers in the country, was on 'Change at noon to-day, and THE TIMES'S correspondent took occasion to ask him what he thought of the situation and outlook in the iron trade.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Nov.--Mrs. E.N. Rowell, of Batavia, whose paramour was recently shot by her husband, passed through this city this morning with her two little children on her way to her father's home, near Utica.

A hencoop rested over a deeply indented track in a little circle of sand in the barnyard on the Maybee farm at Brookville yesterday. The print was believed, to have been made by the foot of the murderer of Mrs. Maybee and her daughter.

BRIDGEPORT, Nov. 21.--The Home Machine Company's works in this city were burned on the night of July 26, and occasioned a loss of $500,000. To-day a force of men began the rebuilding of the main factory and an adjoining foundry. A part of the old foundation will be used, it being uninjured. The main building will be three stories in height and of brick. Forty men are now engaged in the work.
