DANBURY, Nov. 21.--P.T. Barnum, the proprietor of the Greatest Show on Earth, was, in 1832, editor of then village newspaper here, the Herald of Freedom and Truth.

The marriage of Miss Florence Cecil Moss, daughter of Theodore Moss, to Maurice B. Flynn, was solemnized last evening in St. Patrick's Cathe dral, which was well filled with the many friends of the bride and groom.

The fighting Fifteenth District Republican Association held a meeting at its head-quarters, No. 472 Eighth-avenue, last evening, and indorsed the action of its Executive Committee in removing the Chairman of that committee, E.C. Lee, and substituting in his stead Dr. J.J. Goodman.
HARTFORD, Conn., Nov. 21.--At a meeting of the Conneclicut Central Railroad Company today the old Board of Directors was re-elected.

ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 21.--A decision has been rendered in the Supreme Court which has created general interest among railroad men, as it settles the liability of roads for accidents where employes have signed the so-called "death warrants."
ROME, Nov. 21.--It is reported that Prime Minister Depretis is seriously ill.
CINCINNATI, Nov. 21.--There has been an unexpected halt in the work of the Board of Arbitration in fixing the bill of prices for the employes in the boot and shoe factories for the coming year.
The Board of Education yesterday heard Superintendent Jasper's report for the month ending Nov. 3. During that time 23 schools and 210 classes were examined.
DES MOINES, Iowa, Nov. 21.--A decision has been rendered in the United States Circuit Court here against the stockholders of the Lamar Insurance Company of Chicago.

TROY, N.Y., Nov. 21.--The quarrymen's strike in the vicinity of Poultney, Vt., has ended, and the men have returned to work. The strike was against a change of pay from day to hour, the men claiming that at the rate of wages allowed per hour they could not make as much as on the per diem plan. They were obliged to accept the terms of the employers.
MARSHALL, Mich., Nov. 21.--Byron Sibley, a telegraph operator here, was found yesterday morning in a back street with a bullet through his brain.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., Nov. 21.--The Canadian Pacific Railroad Company has had built on the Clyde, Scotland, a number of iron steam-ships to ply between Collingwood and Prince Arthur's Island.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Nov. 21.--Benjamin Russell is in jail charged with assaulting his wife at a hotel here. Men heard Mrs. Russell fall and found her husband choking her on the floor and about to stab her with a knife. Three men were required to take him from her. Mrs. Russell is a daughter of a wealthy farmer near Ithaca. She married Russell against the will of her parents and left him because of ill treatment.
"Constant Reader" is informed that 75 years of married life entitles a couple to celebrate its diamond wedding.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 21.--Franklin B. Gowen has issued a circular, dated to-day, in which he announces his intention of resigning the Presidency of the Reading Railroad at the expiration of his present term.
BOSTON, Nov. 21.--The Rev. Father Fulton, Provincial of the Jesuits in the United States, and the Rev. Father Brady, arrived here from Rome to-day in the steamer Samaria.

OTTAWA, Ont., Nov. 21.--Attorney-General Miller left Winnipeg for Rat Portage on Monday last, it having been reported to the Government that fresh trouble was likely to take place in connection with the provincial boundary dispute.

MADISON, Wis., Nov. 21.--The verdict of the Coroner's jury in the case of the recent Capitol disaster holds the contractor, A.F. Nowlen, guilty of gross negligence in causing certain piers to be improperly repaired, and the supervising architect. Jones, and the consulting architect, H.C. Koch, for designing the internal construction without due regard to its safety during its erection thus contributing to its falling on Nov. 8.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21.--The following business was transacted in the United States Supreme Court to-day: No. 1,207--Joseph Hurtado, plaintiff in error ...

GIRARDVILLE, Penn., Nov. 21.--Small-pox in a malignant form has broken out here. Two girls named Higgins died to-day and another girl is in a precarious condition. Despite every precaution the disease is spreading.

Gov. Bate, of Tennessee, issued his Thanks giving proclamation on Saturday. An evening paper in Detroit, Mich., now issues its first edition at 14 o'clock, and follows it up with a 15 o'clock edition.
HIGH POINT, N.C., Nov. 21.--Eleven heats in the first series in the All Ages Stakes were run to-day.
RUSHVILLE, Ind., Nov. 21.--About 4 o'clock this morning Edward Payne, Cashier of the Rushville National Bank, was awakened by a noise in the kitchen.
Capt. Cox, of the schooner Annie E. Safford, which arrived from Pawtucket on Tuesday evening, reported that on Nov. 16, when off Cape May ...

A decision interesting and important to hotel-keepers and persons living in hotels was made yesterday by the Court of Appeals in Albany. During the Winter of 1876, when Gen. Hancock weighed less than he does now, and was therefore not so great a man, he lived in the St. Cloud Hotel.
The report of the Committee on Streets, recommending that the application of George F. Williams for permission to erect Herald ...

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21.--Lieut-Gen. Sheridan has gone to Chicago for a few days on private business. The Superintendent of the General Recruiting Service has been ordered to cause 40 recruits to be prepared and forwarded under proper charge to Fort Snelling, Minn., for assignment to the Third Infantry, and 80 to such points as shall be designated by ...

OTTAWA, Ontario, Nov. 21.--On inquiry at the Agricultural Department it was ascertained that there is little probability of the Government undertaking to assist the destitute immigrants reported at Toronto and other places.
The visitation of the families connected with the Germrn Roman Catholic Church of the Assumption, West Forty-ninth-street, is now taking place.

President Villard begins his fourth annual report to the stockholders of the Oregon Railway and Navigation Company by saying: "The fourth year of our corporate existence brought some disappointments, but taken as a whole it is marked by decided general progress."

There was atleast one sensation and a number of interesting incidents in the Feuardent-Di Cesnola case in the United States District Court yesterday. Mr. Feuardent, the plaintiff, occupied the witness stand throughout the day, more than two-thirds of the session being taken up by the continuance of his direct testimony.
OTTAWA, Nov. 21.--The Minister of Agriculture of Manitoba is in the city and in conversation with your correspondent denied that there was any dissatisfaction in his Province.
SCHENECTADY, Nov. 21.--The report in a New-York paper that Senator Arkell would lead Cornell's forces in the Senate next Winter in the fight for the United States Senatorship is denied.
The Board of County Canvassers yesterday made its official declaration of the count of the votes cast in the recent election in this City. The official return shows that the result was as follows:

Mary Higgins, a pretty girl of 21 years, reached her father's home, No. 635 Water-street, last Friday morning, after an adventure which has furnished her with an experience in "theatrical" life that will doubtless be sufficient to last her to the end of her days.
John Jannsens, a Flemish immigrant, who arrived on the Red Star steam-ship Belgenland early in October, told Inspector Gruelle, of Castle Garden, a strange story yesterday.
READING, Penn., Nov. 21.--The disappearance of Stephen M. Meredith, a well-known lawyer and prominent Democratic politician, has created a great sensation in this city.

PETERSBURG, Va., Nov. 21.--Robert Pratt has been convicted in the Superior Court at Goldsboro, N.C., of murder in the first degree, and sentenced to be hanged on Dec. 20. This is the third murderer who has been convicted at this session of that court.

The Oratorio Society gave its first public rehearsal yesterday afternoon in the Academy of Music, before a large and generous audience. The chorus, though not out in full force, was unusually numerous for a rehearsal and generally good work was done.

LANCASTER, Penn., Nov. 21.--Two freight trains on the Pennsylvania Railroad ran into each other while in rapid motion in the company's yards at Columbia this morning. A caboose and two cars of one train were demolished, and the engine and six cars of the other were thrown from the track and badly dismantled. David Mower, of Columbia, a brakeman, was sleeping in the caboose at that time and was fatally injured.
The following sales of securities were made at auction yesterday by Adrian H. Muller Son, in the Exchange Sales-room, No. 111 Broadway:
ALBANY, Nov. 21.--The official returns from all the counties show the following results of the late election ...

A 12-year-old girl, living at No. 376 Firststreet, Jersey City, is a natural curiosity. She has a foot where one of her hands ought to be, and a hand in the place of one of her feet. She can walk without effort, but uses the misplaced foot as a hand only clumsily, and has to call her misplaced hand into requisition in delicate manual operations.

BOSTON, Nov. 21.--The Venezuelan Consul at Boston, Mr. Arthur W. Roudier, has forwarded his resignation to his Government. Mr. Roudier resigns because the New-York Consul of Venezuela has been appointed Commissioner to the foreign exhibition without any notification to the Boston Consul or Vice-Consul.

The next session of the State Legislature will afford an opportunity to the Republican Party to do a great deal of good work, and the way in which it is done will go a long way in determining the action of the independent voters who will decide the fate of parties next year in this State, and, therefore, to a marked degree, in the Nation.

RALEIGH, N.C., Nov. 21.--Returns to the News and Observer from the Counties of Pasquotank, Perquimaus, Chowan, Martin, Washington, Camden, Pitt, Beanfort, Pamlico, Carteret, and Currituck, assure the election of Thomas T. Skinner, Democrat to Congress from the First North Carolina District, by 1,000 majority. Judge Pool, the Republican candidate, concedes the election of Mr. Skinner by 800 majority.

At the opening of the proceedings yesterday, before Judge Van Brunt, in Common Pleas, Equity Term, in the trial of the elevated railroad suit to set aside the merger agreement, Francis C. Barlow, of counsel for the plaintiff, the Metropolitan Company, stated that several important witnesses for ...
WILKESBARRE, Penn., Nov. 21.--No tidings of the missing girl, Annie Milligan, have yet been received, although searching parties were out all last night and all this forenoon.

CHICAGO, Nov. 21.--Another terrible marine disaster has probably resulted from the great gale of last week, which surpasses in horror any wreck which has occurred on the lakes since the Alpena foundered.

At a meeting of the Park Commissioners yesterday John Taylor Johnston, on behalf of the Trustees of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, requested permission to use the accumulated interest now in the hands of the institution in completing the Museum.

BOSTON, Nov. 21.--The standard time question has promptly got into court. Application was made by a creditor to Edward J. Jenkins, Commissioner in Insolvency, for a certificate authorizing an arrest of a poor debtor.
The Hon. Thomas H. Dudley lectured last night to the Association for the Protection of American Industry on "The American System of Protection."
The fog of Tuesday evening continued until late yesterday afternoon and was at times very dense. During the early part of the day ferry travel was greatly delayed.
ALBANY, N.Y., Nov. 21.--At the meeting of the State Board of Health to-day, Health Officer Smith reported a diminuation in the cases of small-pox arriving at the port of ...

CHICAGO, Nov. 21.--Cleveland, Cummings, Woodruff, the suspended dry goods firm, are settling with their creditors at the rate of 60 cents on the dollar, having been advised to do so by some of the non-resident creditors.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21.--The Pension Office to-day struck a new branch of the work of cleaning out the swindling pension attorneys, who have grown fat with the money filched from their many dupes.

BATESVILLE, Ark., Nov. 21.--A cyclone struck Melbourne, the County seat of Izard County, at 3 o'clock this morning. Ex-Sheriff John Hinkle and his wife and two children were killed and Mrs. Henry S. Hinkle was crippled. The Court-house, two churches, and several stores and houses were blown down.
STRATFORD, Nov. 21.--For nearly two years the Congregational Church of this town has been dependent upon borrowed ministers. The town now has one that may be called its own, the...

BATAVIA, N.Y, Nov. 21.--Albert Phillips, aged 72 years, a prominent farmer of Byron, in this county, arose this morning in his usual health, ate a hearty breakfast, and went to work in his yard. He soon sat down on a wheelbarrow to rest, and almost instantly expired. The cause of death is supposed to have been heart disease.

LONDON, Nov. 21.--The American ship Thomas Dana, Capt. Sisson, from Liverpool, Oct. 22, from New-York, landed at Fayal on the 8th inst. Twenty-one men, being a part of the crew and passengers of the French brig Rocaberg, from St. Pierre, Miquelon, for St. Malo, which was sunk by collision on Oct. 30. The remainder of the crew and passengers, numbering 88, perished.
Patrick Brady, an ex-convict, was shot and killed yesterday by Officer Charles J. Ryan, of the Twenty-second Precinct, who had for some time endeavored to arrest him upon an indictment for burglary.

BOSTON, Mass., Nov. 21.--Ellen Thorne, the first wife of the late Charles R. Thorne, Jr., the actor, who obtained a divorco from him in 1882, and was awarded $150 per month as alimony, has brought suit against Mrs. Mary S. Thorne, the daughter of Dr. Swift, of Philadelphia, and Mr. Thorne's ....

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 21.--Post Office Inspectors Brown and Herrick, of Cleveland, to-day arrested George D. Bauer, of Portsmouth, a clerk on the line between Columbus, Ohio, and Ashland, Ky., charged with embezzling and rifling letters.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 21.--Matthew Arnold arrived in this city this afternoon, as the guest of President Porter, of Yale. Mr. Arnold lectured this evening on "Science and Literature." He will leave here for New-York to-morrow.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21.--During an intermission in the proceedings of the Proteus court of inquiry to-day, photographs showing the position of the Proteus after she was "nipped" and had begun to sink, and of the place where she went down, the ice having closed over her, leaving only a few broken planks visible, were examined by the members of the court.

BALTIMORE, Md., Nov. 21.--The sloop Willie F. Thomas, which capsized and sunk off James's Point in the Chesapeake in the late gale, when Captain Webster and his crew of eight men were lost, was raised yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21, 1883. The Secretary of the Interior has affirmed the decision of the Commissioner of the General Land Office denying the right of appeal to William ....
BUFFALO, N.Y., Nov. 21.--Dr. A.E. McDonald, Superintendent of the New-York City Asylum, was called by the contestants in the Fillmore will case to-day.

Michael McCarthy, a waiter at the NewYork Hotel, appeared before Justice Duffy, at the Jefferson Market Police Court, yesterday, to answer a complaint of abandonment, preferred by his wife Ellen, a young Irish domestic.
PITTSBURG, Penn., Nov. 21.--Commodore Kountze, who is well known in railroad and steamboat circles in all parts of the country, was to-day convicted to criminal libel.
The completion of the Buffalo, New-York and West Shore Railroad has given fresh impetus to the various reports concerning its future policy.
Justus Schwab, the Socialist, was on trial yesterday in the Court of General Sessions, before Judge Cowing, for a violation of the excise law at No. 50 First-street.

In the suit brought by Durant de Pont in the United States Circuit Court to restrain the Northern Pacific Railroad Company from issuing second mortgage bonds to the amount of $20,000,000 Judge Wallace rendered a decision yesterday denying a motion for a preliminary injunction.

At the meeting last evening of the sub-committee having in charge the celebration of Evacuation Day, Secretary Stevens reported that he had called personally at a number of the leading hotels, and had received the following additional subscriptions: Windsor, $100; ...

NORWICH, N.Y., Nov. 21.--Mayor Swinburne, of Albany, was recalled to-day in the Dwight trial. A paper was handed him, which it was claimed was made at the first autopsy and signed by all the doctors present.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Nov. 21.--The Common Pleas Court to-day referred to Lawyer Jerome V. Masterson for audit an account in the estate of Mrs. Henrietta R. Daniels, colored, in which several extraordinary legal questions have arisen.
BALTIMORE, Md., Nov. 21.--In the Criminal Court this afternoon, in the case of Edward J. Curry, on trial for the murder of his wife in August last, the jury brought in a verdict of manslaughter.

Mayor Low yesterday rendered his decision in the matter of the application of the South Ferry and Sea-side Direct Transit Company for permission to construct a tunnel road under Atlantic-avenue from the ferry to a point between Third and Fourth avenues, and a depressed or "cut" road, thence in a south-westerly direction to the city line.
J.W. Converse, of Boston, and F.H. May and G.S. Mott, of this City, were yesterday elected Directors of the American Rapid Telegraph Company.

For some time past gas has escaped from a leaky pipe into the basement of the residence of William Foster, at No. 340 Jersey-avenue, Jersey City. On Tuesday evening, Mr. Foster took a lighted lamp in his hand, and descended into the basement to find out where the leak was.

AUSTIN, Nev., Nov. 21.--Ex-Senator George E. Spencer, of Alabama, was arrested here to-day, on an order of Attorney-General Brewster, for contempt of Court in not appearing in the Star Route cases. Mr. Spencer denies eluding the officers. He left here to-day with two Deputy Marshalls for Washington.

PARIS, Nov. 21.--The Temps states that the Marquis Tseng, the Chinese Ambassador, has received from the Chinese Government a reply to the last French communication relative to the Tonquin question, in which China has made fresh proposals to France, which, the Temps says, are not in any way acceptable.
CHICAGO, Nov. 21.--Special telegrams to the Tribune, received to-night from Illinois, Indiana, and Iowa show an alarming amount of soft corn on hand.

ALLENTOWN, Penn., Nov. 21.--William P. Snyder, of this city, has forwarded his resignation to Attorney-General Brewster as special Assistant Attorney-General in prosecuting election cases in South Carolina. He says the Government does not give its officers proper assistance and encouragement.

Legislative acts, and resolutions of the Board of Aldermen, passed years ago, gave to the NinthAvenue Railroad Company the right to run horse cars between the Battery and the Harlem River, by way of Greenwich-street, Ninth-avenue, the Bloomingdale-road, and Tenth-avenue.

The Society for Instruction in First Aid to the Injured held its annual meeting in its rooms, in East Fourteenth-street, last evening, and the old board of officers was elected, with the Hon. John Jay as President, and Dr. Henry B. Sands as ...
BOSTON, Nov. 21.--Insurance Commissioner Tarbox some days ago dispatched Mr. Plympton and Mr. Milton, the latter formerly actuary of the Union Mutual Insurance Company of Maine, to ...

William Ruboskie, aged 8, and John Kirchshafer, aged 4, were playing together in a butcher's shop at their residence, No. 315 Avenue A, when William told John that if he would put his finger on the chopping block he would chop it off for him. Johnny obligingly complied, and William amputated the finger with a cleaver. He was arrested yesterday. In the Yorkville Police Court, Justice Power naroled him for examination.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 21.--The civil suits brought by the United States against Joseph Funk, defaulting star route mail contractor and his sureties, Henry Arbuckle and William R. Cosen, were discontinued to-day by United States District Attorney Valentine.

NEWBURG, Nov. 21.--A verdict for $1,750 was rendered in a civil damage case in this city to-day against William O'Sullivan, keeper of a small beer saloon at Central Valley, on the Newburg and New-York Railroad.

The appointment by the United States Circuit Court of Thomas R. Sharpe as Receiver of the Ohio Central Railroad. It was stated yesterday, was only for the West Virginia portion of the River Division of the road.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Nov. 21.--George Darrell and Godfrey Brand were to-day arrested for attempting to wreck a passenger train on the Pittsburg and Lake Erie Railroad last week. They were had a dispute with Conductor Davidson about their fare, and since then three attempts have been made to wreck his train by placing obstructions in a frog. Darrell and Brand are young men, and live at Beaver Falls, 30 miles west of this city.

Reports were current in this City yesterday that L.M. Michels Co., wholesale dealers in notions and fancy goods, at No. 69 Greene-street, who do business in San Francisco as Michels, Friedlander Co., were embarrassed, principally ...

CLEVELAND, Nov. 21.--The body of the suicide, Henry Moore, which was taken to the Western Reserve Medical College before his daughter could make arrangements for his funeral, was discovered to-day in a pickling vat in the college. The body was restored to his daughter.
A decision of the Court of Appeals reached Brooklyn yesterday, which finally determines a law suit which has had much interest during its progress for many wealthy residents of that city.

MONTREAL, Nov. 21.--Alderman Roy stated at a meeting of the Investigating Committee of the Civic Council to-day that the amount lost by the city through the bad management at the Sheriff's sales and the defalcation of McNeill, a clerk in the Treasurer's office, who absconded, is $20,000.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Nov. 21.--About 7 o'clock this morning, while Richmond Simmons, a worthy citizen of Talladega, Ala., was eating breakfast with his family, an unknown assassin fired through the window and the ball entered Mr. Simmons's temple, killing him instantly. He was a prominent citizen, and much excitement prevails.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 21.--The Naval Commission appointed by Congress to invastigate the matter of the navy yards, of which Commodore Luce is President, has completed ...
MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Nov. 21.--At the recent election many of the villages along the Con necticut River voted in favor of "no license," and the tempernance men were jubiliant.

Two or three close-mouthed stone-cutters have, during the past few days, been chipping out the top of the broad platform stone upon the back of which rests the pedestal prepared for J.Q.A. Ward's statue of Washington, in front of the SubTreasury.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21.--For lack of new material to work upon, the various Congressmen who would be glad to preside over the deliberations of the next House of Represen tatives have passed rather a quiet day. Arrivals have been very few, and while Messrs. Carlisle, Randall, Cox, and ....

Secretary TELLER has concluded that he will not grant the application of the Southern Pacific Railroad Company for a transfer to itself of the unearned land grant of the Texas Pacific, but in so doing he puts on record no formal decision against the claim.

SYRACUSE, Nov. 21.--A State Convention of representatives of the various Irish organizations of the State, was held at Empire Hall, in this city to-day. Among the delegates were some of the leading Irishmen of the State, including Thomas F. Meehan, editor of the Irish-American;

Mrs. Lydia R. Maybee and her daughter Ann Eliza, the victims of the Brookville murder were buried in the village cemetery yesterday afternoon. It had been announced that the funeral would be private, but a large crowd gathered around the house.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Nov. 21.--A man about 30 years of age, who came to this city last Thursday and registered the St. John's House as "W.C. Coussins, N.J." was found dead in his bed this morning with a bullet hole in his breast and a pistol by his side. His effects contained articles of value, $240 in cash, and an American Express badge No. 964 It is thought that Coussins was not his right name.
BRIDGEPORT, Nov. 21.--The annual meeting of the stockholders of the Naugatuck Railroad was held this morning.

BALTIMORE, Md., Nov. 21.--Frederick Albright, of Cincinnati, aged 18, is lying here at the point of death. His illness is said to have been caused by the extreme treatment of a quack doctor, a member of the Thompsonian school.
Charles Meighen, who was found dead in his room at the Gleason House, in Washington, on Tuesday, lived at No. 407 East One-Hundred-andTwenty-second-street.
BATAVIA, Nov. 21.--Mrs. Jennie Rowell, wife of the man who killed Johnson Lynch, with her two little girls, accompanied her mother to ...

John H. Chisholm, the wife murderer, who is to be hanged at Newark, N.J., this morning, begged so piteously to see his children that Warden Johnson went on Tuesday evening to the residence of the McCombers, his dead wife's parents, in ...
ALBANY, Nov. 21.--Judge Isaac H. Maynard, the defeated candidate for Secretary of State, argued a case before the Court of Appeals today. He was apparently in the best of spirits.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Nov. 21.--The Government attaches no importance to the report that Chinamen have been arrested in Victoria, British Columbia, for endeavoring to smuggle a quantity of dynamite ashore under suspicious circumstances, and regard the affair as a hoax. If there was any truth in the rumor they would have been communicated with at once.
UTICA, Nov. 21.--Senator Warner Miller says there is no truth whatever in the reports that he is seeking to control or influence, directly or by combinations, the organization of the Legislature.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 21.--In the Ideal Opera suit, ex-Manager Martin testified to-day. He was nervous and talked so loud that the Court was obliged to check him.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 21.--The Yale College foot-ball team easily defeated the Michigan University eleven at Hamilton Park this afternoon.
ALBANY, N.Y., Nov. 21.--In the Court of Appeals to-day, present the Hon. William B. Ruger, ChiefJustice, and associates, the following business was transacted:
NEWBURG, N.Y., Nov. 21.--A judgment was rendered in the court here this week against Adam Forepaugh, the circus proprietor.

In the face of the unreasonable crowds which clamor to cross the bridge when the fog lies on the river, Col. PAINE preserves an attitude of philosophic calm. Philosophy and calmness seem indeed to be, intellectually speaking, the "strong points" of Col. PAINE.

WILKESBARRE, Pa., Nov. 21.--Wilbur H. Fry, a well-known druggist of this city, failed today. His store was closed this evening by the Sheriff upon executions issued at the instance of Herman C. Fry, to whom he is heavily indebted.
It was the purpose of the Board of Aldermen, yesterday, to consider the provisional estimates for 1884, but after the board had done into ...

The office of the National Rifle Association, on the second floor of the building at No. 102 William-street, was entered by burglars on Tuesday afternoon, some time between 5 and 6:15 o'clock, and ten rifles and one revolver were carried off.

"Ah!" said Mr. Leonard W. Jerome yesterday as a TIMES reporter accosted him on the steps of the Union Club. "I suppose you have heard that I have rented the old Union League Club rooms, on Twenty-sixth-street and Fifth-avenue, to the University Club.
James Smith, who was recognized as the best umpire for a cricket match in this country, died at his residence, No. 426 East Eighty-sixthstreet, on Tuesday, after a brief illness.

SARATOGA, Nov. 21.--Leo Dafts's electric railway motor is here and will be tested on the Mount McGregor Railroad next Saturday afternoon. It was tried on a level grade last night after midnight and worked perfectly, making 20 miles an hour easily.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 21.--Robert Cunningham, who this morning completed a term of 18 months' imprisonment for using the United States mails to carry on a scheme to defraud, was re-arrested upon leaving the prison on a charge of connection with an alleged conspiracy of John O'Grady and others to defraud the American Legion of Honor of $5,000. He was committed in default of $3,500 bail for a hearing next Monday.

"Ah!" said Mr. Leonard W. Jerome yesterday as a TIMES reporter accosted him on the steps of the Union Club. "I suppose you have heard that I have rented the old Union League Club rooms, on Twenty-sixth-street and Fifth-avenue, to the University Club.

BOSTON, Nov. 21.--Obed Huey, Captain of the bark Florence, was held to-day in the sum of $1,500 on a charge of so beating and ill-treating the steward, John Dibold, that he died from the effects of his injuries.

A "boom" is usually a useful thing in a newspaper office. It gives a newspaper an object, and it enables it to display consistency, which by many competent judges is thought to add to the dignity of a paper.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 21.--J.J. Garrett, of New-Providence, who was dangerously wounded in a fight with burglars, is doing well, and it is thought will recover.
VICKSBURG, Miss., Nov. 21.--The notice "Bank closed; in the hands of an Assignee," was posted on the door of the Mississippi Valley Bank this morning.
WHEELING, West Va., Nov. 21.--Nothing has occurred during the past 24 hours to throw light on the disappearance of Major McColloch, and the affair remains shrouded in mystery.
CARTERSVILLE, Ga., Nov. 22.--Carl Y. Penley, a citizen of this place, has been arrested for a peculiar offense. Several days ago a strange woman, who refused to give her name, with a babe in...
BOSTON, Nov. 22.--By a decision of the Athletic Committee of the Harvard College Faculty the Harvard foot-ball eleven will not be allowed to play any more games this fall.

James Doyle, the tramp, who is suspected of being the murderer of Mrs. and Miss Maybee, was taken from Roslyn to Oyster Bay yesterday to be present at the inquest. Doyle smoked his pipe and moved about undisturbed.
CLEVELAND, O., Nov. 22.--Arguments in the Martin-Ober case were concluded to-day. The decision will be rendered on Monday. John Sherma's nephew, Martin's attorney, scared Ober's, agent, Foster.
PITTSBURGH, Penn., Nov. 22.--There are no indications of nearly adjustment of the differences between the window-glass manufacturers and the blowers.
TORONTO, Ont., Nov. 22.--Great excitement has been caused in financial circles here by the suspension from the Stock Exchange of R.H. Temple, of Temple Co., and William Hope, of...
CHARLESTON, S.C., Nov. 22.3--The two hundreth anniversary of the organization of the First Baptist Church of Charleston was celebrated to-day.

LONDON, Nov. 22.--This was the first day of the Manchester November Meeting. The plate race for 2 year olds and upward was won by Mr. C. Perkins 82-year-old b.f. Decisive Mr: R. Peck's aged ch.h. Friar Rush came in second and Mr. F. Archer's (formerly Mr. Lorillard's) 5-year--old b.g. Passaic third.

HELENA, Montana, Nov. 22.--Gov. Crosby, in his annual report to the Secretary of the Interior, urges that polygamous Mormons be not only disfranchised, but that they be debarrad from entering Government lands, thereby preventing the spread of Mormonism in this Territory.

BOSTON, Mass., Nov. 22.--A game of football between the Harvard eleven and the University of Michigan eleven was attempted this afternoon on Jarvis'e field, but darkness closed upon the contestants so rapidly that the game was virtually over at the end of the first three-quarters.

NEW-ORLEANS, Nov. 22.--The fight between the Ogden and McEnery factions of the Demooratic Party to carried on with great bitterness. Personal difficulties are not unfrequent, and yesterday Gen. Ogden and Col. Fairfax, proprietor of the City Item, indulged in fisticuffs, and there is now talk of a duel.
Charles M. Cooper, a colored man, brought a suit in the United States District Court against the New-Haven Steamboat Company to recover $500 damages under the Civil Rights act for being

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22.--Among the distinguished citizens of the Empire State who have graced the capital with their presence to-day are Mr. Robert G. McCord, Mr. Michael Dady and the Hon. Albert Daggett. Whether their visit is one purely of pleasure, or whether certain gave affairs of State have brought them here, has not yet transpired.

PARIS, Nov. 22.--The action of M. Clemenceau against the Paris Morning News, for publishing what, purported to be an interview with a reporter, whom M. Clemenceau alleges he refused to see, and for not publishing a satisfactory retraction came up for trial today.

BOSTON, Nov .22--R.H. Holbrook, of Springfield, Vt., left New-York on Thursday, Nov. 15, for Springfield. Mass., since which time nothing has been heard from him. He was a man of temperate habits, and had $1,000 on his person.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22.--The headquarters of the candidates for the Speakership of the next House of Representatives have been little, if any, more animated to-day than yesterday, and for the same reason. The Congressmen come in very slowly, and the candidates have few opportunities to buttonhole the men who are to decide the present contest.
District Attorney John McKeon died at his residence, No. 44 West Thirty-seventh-street, at 11 o'clock yesterday morning, after an illness which had confined him to his house only two days.

MILWAUKEE, Nov. 22.--Gen. Charles B. Hamilton is lying at the point of death at his residence, No. 649 Marshall-street. He caught a very bad cold last Monday, and has been confined to his bed ever since.

The proceedings in the Court of Common Pleas, Equity Term, in the elevated railroad suit to set aside the merger agreement, were very brief yesterday, being interrupted at noon by the adjournment of the court on receiving news of the death of District Attorney McKeon.
MILWAUKEE, Wis., Nov. 22.--For a few weeks past negotiations have been going on between the Government authorities of the Indian..

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Nov. 22.--The House of John Campbell, No. 49 Teresa-street, was partially consumed to-night. The servant girl, Mary Parker, was badly, perhaps fatally burned. A few minutes later M. Nisiu's house. No. 66 Whitman-street, took fire. Nisin's daughter, a young woman, vaulted on the roof to help the firemen, but in reaching over to get the nose, lost balance and fell from the roof to the ground, fracturing her skull.

Mr. THOMAS H. DUDLEY is the latest of the orators whom the New-York Association for the Protection of American Industry (Limited) has engaged to illuminate the public mind on the tariff. Mr. DUDLEY'S address was delivered before the body in question on Wednesday evening.

NORWICH, N.Y., Nov. 22.--At last an end to the Dwight case may be seen in the distance. Judge Follett announced today that the expert witnesses on each point would be limited to six The defendants have had four already.

Counsel for the South Ferry and Seaside Direct Rapid Transit Company called on Corporation Counsel Taylor in Brooklyn, yesterday, to consult as to the proof that the company would be required to furnish of the fact that it had the consent of a majority of the property owners alone the proposed route.
LYNCHBURG, Va., Nov. 22.--Richard Spooler, age 16, last night killed Richard Newcomer, a companion, age 17, for asking him for a chew of tobacco.

The bright glare of colored lights, the bursting of bombs, and the hissing of brilliant rockets attracted thousands of people to the vicinity of Cooper Union last night. On the bill-boards at the front entrance were announcements that a massmeeting "in favor of an immediate reform in the tariff" was to be held in the large hail under the auspices of the New-York Free Trade Club.

A short man, carrying a large live eagle across his breast, staggered into Police Head-quarters yesterday and entered the room occupied by the Evacuation Day Committee. Gen. John Cochrane spied the bird and said to the man, "What's that for?"

MADRID, Nov. 22.--The German Crown Prince landed at Valencia at noon to-day. Ten thousand people gathered to witness the landing, and greeted the Prince with loud cheers, while the men-of-war in the harbor and the batteries on shore fired salutes.
"Constant Reader" is informed that Henry J.Raymond died on June 18, 1869. Thomas Reed, Jr., and C.C. Brown were yesterday elected members of the New-York Stock Exchange.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22.--The proceeding's of the United States Supreme Court today were as follows: No. 969--Thomas Poindexter, plaintiff in error,
READING, Penn., Nov. 22.--The mangled remains of a Hungarian were found at an early hour this morning lying between the rails of the Reading track at Morocacy Station.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, Nov. 22.--One of the handsomest and most imposing stone edifices in this city is the First Methodist Church, at Euclid and Erie streets. Two years ago its debt was $22,000.

Among the mang proposals which have, from time to time, been made for the utilization of vacant lands on the Victoria Embankment is one for the establishment of a fruit and flower market, which should practically supersede the present market at Covent Garden.
CHARLESTON, S.C., Nov. 22.--Considerable excitement prevails in Washington, S.C., on account of several burglaries which were committed in that town last night.
CHICAGO, Nov 22.--A telegram from Sand Beach, Mich., announces that the propeller H.J. Jewett and the schooner Hazard, which she had in tow, Have gone on the rocks during a fog.
WASHINGTAM, Penn., Nov. 22,--At Wyland's Station, on the Pittsburg Southern road, there is a camp of colored men in the employ of the Baltimore and Ohio Company.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Nov. 22.--Miss Clara Louise Kellogg sang in a concert at the Academy of Music this evening. The house was crowded in every part, fully 2,000 persons being present. So great was the desire to hear Miss Kellogg that 300 seats were provided on the stage, all of which were filled.

In a good many quarters of New-York theatrical life there seems to he a very well-defined tendency in the direction of managerial weakening. Mr. Stetson has intimated his desire to dispose of his lease of the Fifth-Avenue Theatre, and has bluntly declared that after his tenancy of that house runs out he will have nothing more to do with theatricals in New-York.
NEWBURG, N.Y., Nov. 23.--Alonzo C. Pugsley, age 30, a clerk, commited suicide last night by shooting himself through the heart. The cause of his act was domestic trouble.
The Hon. David A. Wells, of Connecticut, was introduced by Mr. Beacher as "a man whose name is known in every land where the subject of the tariff is discussed."
CHICAGO, Nov. 22.--Five hundred Norwegians and Swedes, from Illinois and Wisconsin, who came to this country as immigrants .
OTTAWA, Ontario, Nov. 22.--The Hudson Bay Company is pressing its claim against the Dominion Government for $50,000 to indemnify it

A second hearing of Mr. Frederick H. Cowen's cantata, "St. Ursula." at the concert of the Oratorio Society last night resulted in a confirmation of the opinion produced by its first performance on Wednesday afternoon.
SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Nov. 22.--Surgeon Van Zandt, of the United States Marine Hospital, reports two cases of yellow fever in that institution.

LIMA, Nov. 22, via Galveston, Texas.--There has been a crisis and a change in the Ministry. Don Eugenio Larraburey Unannue, Manual Galup. and Ca-tro Zalaivar have taken the oaths as Minister of Foreign Affairs, Chancellor of the Exchequer, and Minister of Government, respectively. The appointments have given much satisfaction.
The Elks' benefit entertainment was given yesterday at the Academy of Music.

BOSTON, Nov. 22.--A reception was tendered to-night to Governor-elect Robinson by the Harvard class of '58 of which he was a member. Subsequently Gov. Robinson and James G. Blaine attended the regular meeating of Post No. 113 of the Grand Army of the Republic and made brief speeches. Mr. Blaine and his Family will spend the Winter in Washington.
Miss A. May Titus was married last evening in Brooklyn to George W. Bostwick, at the residence of her mother, Mrs. A.L. Titus, No. 282 Carlton-avenue.

WARSAW, N.Y., Nov. 22.--Cyrus Jefferson, aged 78, whose estimated wealth is between $2,000,000 and $3,000,000, and who was known as the richest citizen in Wyoming County, died this morning at Franklinville, Cattaraugus County. He leaves a widow and two children.
FORT VALLEY, Ga., Nov. 22.--The members of Cool Spring Colored Church are in a state of great excitement over a schism in their body.

CITY OF MEXICO, Nov. 22.--All doubt concerning the suspension of negotiations with the British holders of Mexican bonds is removed by the declaration of the official organ of the Mexican Government, which is the voice of the Executive.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 22.--In the Congdon murder case at East Greenwich this morning, after 43 hours' deliberation, the jury returned a verdict of manslaughter with a recommendation...

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Nov. 22.--Scott Moseley, late a mail messenger, was arrested yesterday by Post Office Inspectors Lucy and Williams on a charge of embezzling registered packages of the value of $800. Four years aao Moseley was a mail messenger, at Hemando. Miss., where he was arrested for a simllar crime and convicted.
VICKSBURG, Nov. 22.--The condition of the affairs of the Mississippi Valley Bank, which failed yesterday, is hourly getting worse. Mr. Klein says the liabilities will probably reach $800,000.

BATESVILLE, Ark., Nov. 22.--Melbourne, the town struck by a cyclone yesterday morning, is so far from a telegraph station that it is not possible to obtain other than meagre particulars of the destructive work done by the storm.

INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 22.--It is the custom in the County Jail, a stone building situated in one corner of the public square, one block from the Government building, and not more than one hundred yards from the court-house, to lock the prisoners in their cells at 7:30 o'clock.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Nov. 22.--The Hon. W. A. Courtenay was renominated for, Mayor of Charleston by the City Democratic Convention to-day without opposition. The ticket for aldermen was also nominated and the ticket as a whole is considered strong. The total registration of voters for the city election is over 7,000, and as the white registered vote is double the colored vote, the result of the election is a foregone conclugion.
Proud as Toledo is of the services of the gallant Fourteenth Ohio Veteran Volunteers, that regiment has one claim to honor that has hitherto been unrecognized.
CINCINNATI Nov. 22.--A dispatch from Urbana, Ohio, states that Rev. Nathen Prince, a Methodist preacher on trial there for extreme cruelty to his wife, has been found guilty.
The sidewalk in front of Trinity Church was crowded early last evening by an eager throng, who wished to enjoy the eleventh annual choral festival of the choirs of Trinity Parish.

The death of Garth Wilkinson James, which had been expected by his friends for some time past, occurred last evening shortly after 5 o'olock, at his residence, 473 Jefferson-street. Notwithstanding their preparation for the melancholy event, it has occasioned heartfelt sorrow throughout the wide circle of his acquaintances, and his loss will be mourned With a sincerity that is not usual.
LONDON, Nov. 22,--A dispatch to Reuter's Telegram Company, dated Cairo, 8:25 o'clock this morning, says the army of Hicks Pasha has been destroyed by the forces of El Mahdi, the False Prophet.
An informal meeting of the New York Association of Lafayette College Alumni was held in the lecture-room of the Young Men's Christian Association building last evening.

The Rahway (N.J.) National Bank suspended payment yesterday. Groups of people congregated in the streets of the little town discussing and commenting upon the occurrence. Beyond that there was little excitement, and the confidence of the people was not severely shaken.

Clarks and Mr. Blackburn, of the Pacific Garden Mission, entered the car in which the two were seen to take seats, and took the girl frem her companion just as the train moved out of the station.

WOONSOCKET, R.I, Nov. 22.--John W. Benway, who attempted to blow up the House of A.B. Wentworth, in Dedham, Mass., with powder on last SundaY night, was arrested here last night. He will be returned to Dedham for trial.

The recently organized Importers and Grocers' Exchange was formally opened yesterday noon. Fully 400 persons assembled in the rooms, at Wall and Pearl streets, and the down-town mercantile trade was well represented.
While the revenue cutter Grant was cruising in the Lower Bay, yesterday morning, she was bafled by the ship Northern Light, which had just arrived from South Africa.

WASHINGTON, NOV. 22, 1883. James R. Davies, United States Examiner of Teas, came here from New-York to-day, by direction of Secretary Foiger. It is understood that his business is in relation to proposed amendments to be made to the adulterates tea act, with a view to a better carrying out of the intent of that act.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22.--At the meeting of the Base-ball League here to-day the morning session was spent in amending the playing rules.

SHELBYVILLE, Ind., Nov. 22--The little city of Rushville, in the adjoining County of Rush, 20 miles north of this city, on the Jeffersonville, Madison and Indianapolis Railroad, was thrown into a great state of excitement about 3 o'clock yesterday morning by screams of "Murder" and " Help." which proceeded from the residence of Edward Payne, the Cashier of the Rushville National Bank.

Thomas H. Pratt, junior member of the firm of Winslow, Post Pratt, insurance agents, at No. 34 Pine-street, has done West with $5,000 belonging to the firm, and about as much more which was intrusted to him by outside persons.

FALL RIVER, Mass., Nov. 22.--John Cummings, of New York, a steward on the Fall River Line steamer Bristol, seriously stabbed John MoNamara in a quarrel on the boat this morning. Cummings is held for trial.
KEY WEST,Fla., Nov. 22.--The British schooner Mary Jane arrived here this morning with 26 bales of cotton; which she had picked up in the vicinity of the Sombrero Light-house.
ERIE, Penn., Nov. 22.--Acting upon instructions from United States District Attorney Stone. Collector of internal Revenue Walther...

RICHMOND, Nov. 22.--The Democratic State Committee met here to-day with a full representation. The principal object of the meeting was to consider the recent address of Senator Mahone to the Readjusters of Virginia,and to decide if any formal notice of it should be taken.
The Commissioners of the State Reservation at Niagara held a meeting at the office of exGov. Dorsheimer, No. 115 Broadway, yesterday.
PITTSBURG, Penn., Nov. 22.--This was wild day at the Oil Exchange. Excitement ran higher than at any previous time during the year.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Nov. 22.--Andy Taylor, the last living of the three Taylor brothers who murdered two Sheriffs and captured a railroad train with 100 passengers aboard, compelling the engineer to carry them 20 miles at a dangerously high speed, about a year ago, is to be hanged tomorrow at 2 P.M. at London, Tenn. Today.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Nov. 22.--Frank James, the noted outlaw, is in very low health, and Charles P. Johnson, one of his attorneys, to-day said that in all probability before the courts settled the case the distinguished defendant would be called before a higher tribunal.
CHICAGO, Nov. 22.--The suspension is announced of Horatio G. Billings one of the oldest and heaviest lumber men in the city.

NEWPORT, Nov. 22.--It has become known that Katie Judd, the female incendiary who is serving a 25 years' sentence, made another attempt to escape from prison a few days ago. She slipped from the ranks while marching to dinner and hid in a woodpile until she had an opportunity to seek a better hiding place. She was subsequently found and placed in solitary confinement.

MONTREAL, Nov. 22.--A further installment of operatives in the Grand Trunk Railway shops has been temporarily discharged. One foundry has given notice of 25 per cent reduction in the wages of molders, and the men have accepted the terms.

A large assemblage of ladies and gentlemen celebrated yesterday the twenty-ninth anniversary of the Woman's Hospital in the endowed ward of that institution, which was tastefully decorated with flowers and evergreens.

Patrick J. Hickey is a Republican politician in the Tenth Ward, and his income is by no means small, being derived from three liquor saloons-- one is Second-avenue, and two in Canal-street. He lives at No. 31 Forsyth-street.

J.C. Farr, a wholesale dealer in lumber and masons' materials, of Fifth-street, Hoboken, made an assignment yesterday. His liabilities are over $100,000, two-thirds of that amount being due in Albany. B.W. Arnold, of Albany, is a preferred creditor. Farr is also interested in the firm of Sullivan Co., sash and door manufacturers of Asbury Park. Sixty hands are thrown out of employment.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Nov. 22.--N.B. Freeman, a liquor-dealer in Greenville, S.C., who was convicted of selling whisky behind a screen several days ago, has been refused a new trial by Judge Kershaw, and was sentenced to pay a fine of $200 or six months imprisonment.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 22.--Col. William Preston Johnston, President of the Tulane University, telegraphed to Judge Fenner, of the Board of Trustees in this city from New York, that Mr. Paul Tullane had completed the donation to his administrators or bonds yielding 10,000 yearly. This last gift of Mr, Tulaue to the university fund makes it foot up $1,000,000, with very much more in prospect.
A neatly dressed middle-aged couple, who registered late on Wednesday night as Patrick Dodd and wife, of Utica, N.Y., were given a room at the Pennsylvania Hotel, at West and Desbrosses streets.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22.--A general court-martial has been ordered to meet at Fort Snelling, Minnesota, on Dec.6 , for the trial of Capt. Chambers McKibben, Fifteenth infantry, on charges of duplicating his pay accounts.

While party leaders are constantly striving to rally their forces by partisan appeals, and relying on "getting out" the full vote to effect their purposes, every election in this State demonstrates anew that the result is determined by the votes of those upon whom party ties hang loosely.

The Postal Telegraph Company has just completed a sale of all its property, franchises, patents, , to the Postal Telegraph and Cable Company, of which H.C. Cardiner is President, for the sum of $10,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22.--Lieut.-Commander McCalla being reached by the Proteus court of inquiry, testified today that he had seen "Inclosure No. 4" at the Navy Department on June 4 or 5, 1883. It was handed to him by Capt. Walker, Chief of the Bureau of Navigation, and was headed. "Instructions or Memoranda for Naval Tender." He did not know what became of it.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Nov. 22.--A new process in the manufacture of low carbon Bessemer steel was put into operation to-day at the Bessmer Steel Works at Homestead, which, if sucessful, will completely do away with the work of puddling. A number of puddlers from various mills were present during the experiments and watches the result with great interest.
BRIDGEPORT, Nov. 22.--The Second and Fourth Regiments of the Connecticut National Guard will go to New-York Evacuation Day.

NORWICH, Nov. 23.--One of the best-known Long Island Sound pilots is Gilbert Horton, aged 65 years. With his clinker-boat he is quick to detect a signal and from East River he often secures a first-class run the length of the Sound.
YOUNGSTOWN Ohio, Nov. 23.--Thirty-three creditors of the corporation of Brown, Bonnell Co., iron manufacturers, have had judgment confessed on their petitions for $570,000 in the Common Pleas Court.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 23.--The jury in the suit of Mary O'Connor against Samuel G. Keely, a Manayunk manufacturer, to recover damages for personal injuries, to-day rendered a verdict in favor of the plaintiff for $10,000.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Nov. 23.--Paul Bechtner, Secretary of the National Vinegar Manufactures' Association, returned to-day from Washington, where he had been as one of a committee of five to confer on behalf of the association with the Secretary of the Treasury and the Commissioner of Internal Revenue.
HUNTINGDON, Penn., Nov. 23.--A disastrous forest fire is now raging on Jocks Mountain, in the vicinity of Mill Creek, and extends almost to Allenville, a distance of nine miles.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Nov. 23.--The Rev. George Alexander, of this city, has decided to leave the question of his acceptance of the call to the pastorate of the University-place Church, NewYork, to the Schnectady Presbytery. It is understood they will advise his acceptance. Mr. Alexander's salary in New-York will be $6,000; here he receives $1,000. He has declined many calls heretofore.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 23.--News has reached Charleston, Mo., to the effect that the tornado at Bertram tore Eli Brown's house to splinters, killing him outright, fatally injuring a lady, and wounding several others. None in the house escaped but a small boy. The barns, stables, cow sheds, and fences were swept away.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov, 23.--An express train on the Pennsylvania Railroad ran into a wagon at the Seventeenth-street crossing to-night, killing a man supposed to be W. Fray and a woman whose name is unknown. A third party was removed to the hospital.

CAIRO, Nov. 23.--Col. Coetlogan, who was with Hicks Pasha, has sent a telegram from Khartoum to Gen. Sir Evelyn Wood, the commander of the British troops, confirming the previous re ports of the disaster to Hicks Pasha's army.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Nov. 23.--The Monmouth County Teachers' Institute closed its three days' session this afternoon. There were over 200 teachers present. Lectures were delivered by Prof. E.A. Apgar, the New-Jersey State Superintendent of Public Instruction, and Prof. Doolittle of Rutgers College.
LONDON, Nov. 23.--Sir John Hawley Glover, lately Governor of Antigua and the Leeward Islands, has been appointed Governor of Newfoundland.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Nov. 23.--A dispatch from Florence says that 250 of the striking miners from the Chapin and Ludington Mines armed themselves with Winchester rifles to-day and practised at a target in the woods.

The Directors of the suspended National Bank of Rahway, N.J., yesterday morning telegraphed to the Controller of the Currency the fact that the bank had closed its doors. They expected that an examiner would arrive and take possession of the institution late last evening or this morning.

MADRID, Nov, 23.--The Crown Prince Frederick William of Germany arrived here at noon today on a special train. The streets were crowded with people of all ranks, and many houses were gayly decorated. The weather was pleasant.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 23.--The steamer Arizona, owned by Stephens, Jones Co., of NewYork, which has been libeled by many creditors, was sold at Newport at noon to-day under the first libel of Jeremiah Holland and others of the crew.

PHILADELPHIA Nov. 28.--A special dispatch to the Times from Bridgeton, N.J., says: "John Cheeseman, editor and proprietor of the Patriot, the leading Democratic weekly newspaper of Cumberland County, N.J., was shot to-day by J.N. Van Syckle, a prominent Democratic politician.

Three months ago Mrs. Henrietta Ehret came to this country from Germany. She was poor and found her way to the Lutheran Hospital in the town of New Lots, Long Island, where, on the 8th of October last, she gave birth to a child.

Austin Corbin, President of the Long Island Railroad Company, yesterday sent Detective J.S. Wood, one of Pinkerton's force who worked on the Rose Ambler case in Connecticut, to the scene of the Brookville murders.

Thomas Enos, alias "A.C. Bennett," the man who sold the City coupon bonds which W.B. Carroll stole, is a prisoner at Police Head-quartets. Inspector Byrnes was asked to a conference with Mayor Edson and Controller Grant two or three days after the latter had been appointed.
The second public rehearsal of the Brooklyn Philharmonic Society took place at the Brooklyn Academy of Music yesterday afternoon before a large audience.

HARRISBURG, Nov. 23.--In the Senate today, the House Appropriation bill providing for the payment of Senators and Representatives and other expenses of the extra session of the Legislature was defeated on third reading by a vote of --yeas, 21; nays, 9, not the requisite constitutional majority.

BOSTON, Mass., Nov. 23.--Edwin A. Durgin, of Boston, and James Portor, of Portland, Me., have finished 10 checker games of a series of 20, the result being a credit of 2 games for each man and 6 drawn games. The series is for the amateur championship of the world. The other 10 games will be played in Portland.

HICKMAN, Ky., Nov. 23.--Hillsman King and his wife, an old and respectable couple, were murdered here last night. Their son Arthur this morning visited their house and found his mother lying dead in a pool of blood. He gave the alarm, and the neighbors found his father's body in the barn covered with husks and party eaten by rats. A German peddler is suspected of the crime. The house was robbed of $2,000?

ALBANY, Nov. 23.--It is reported that exAssemblyman Thomas E. Benedict, of Ulster County, will be Deputy Controller under Controller Alfred C. Chapin. He will succeed Mr. Henry Gallen, who has been connected with the department for about 15 years.
John W. Candler, of Boston, is at the Windsor Hotel. Senator D.M. Sabin, of Minnesota, is at the Gilsey House.
Sad was the fate of Mr. CLAY, of Hardenburg, in this State. Mr. CLAY was a man in the prime of life, but his hair was gray, and the Widow TRUMANN, whom he desired to marry, disliked gray hair.

LONDON, Nov. 23.--The police at midnight arrested a man named Wolff, who is a member of the advanced Socialists' Club of London. Upon searching his house at Vincent-square. Westminster, the police discovered two infernal machines, which are considered to be of sufficient ...

LONDON, Nov. 23.--A Paris dispatch to the Exchange Telegraph Company says the Marquis Tseng, the Chinese Ambassador, has informed Earl Granville, the British Foreign Secretary, that war between China and France is certain to occur.

Capt. Joshua Siocumb, of the ship Northern Light, obtained a warrant from United States Commissioner Shields Thursday afternoon for the arrest of Henry Arthur Slater, one of his crew, who, he said, was mutinous. Deputy United States Marshal Charles Bible served the warrant.

BOSTON, NOV. 23.--The question of the legality of the new standard time was argued before Judge O.W. Holmes in the Superior Court to-day. There was no controversy as to the facts, the question being one purely of law as to the legality of standard time in judicial proceedings.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23.--The President today appointed Surgeon Robert Murray, now on duty in New-York, as the chief medical officer at Major-Gen. Hancock's head-quarters, to be Surgeon-General of the Army, vice General Charles H. Crane, deceased.

In June, 1882, Surrogate Rollins admitted to probate the will of Alexander P. McCue against the protest of his nephew, Thomas H. Riley, and his nieces, Catharine Bentine and Mary Rolston. Mr. McCue left an estate of about $30,000, principally consisting of real estate on the east side.
Three games of billiards are to be played in Philadelphia by Randolph Heiser, of this City, and Edward McLaughlin, of Philadelphia, at $250 a side, beginning Dec. 12.

The Yale Alumni Association held its first social meeting for the present season at Dolmonico's last evening. Mr. Chauncey M. Depew, who presided, read an address describing the humorous episodes of a European tour.
Mr. Henry D. Mildeberger, of Harlem, has lost his dog, and he feels worse over the affliction than he of whom the poet sings:

A banquet was given last night at Martinelli's by the members of the Theta Delta Chi fra ternity to conclude the proceedings of its thirtyseventh annual convention, which has been holding its sessions during the last two days.
BOSTON, Nov. 23.--It is stated that Naval Constructor Webb, who has been investigating the charges of Charles Osborne against A.A. Woodward, foreman of the brass foundry in the Charlestown ...
LIMA, Nov. 23, via Galveston.--News from Bolivia states that Senior Montero has left the capital for the Argentine States, doubtless en route to Europe.

The exercises at Cooper Union last evening under the auspices of the Clan-na-Gael, commemmorative of the sixteenth anniversary of the death of the Manchester martyrs. Allen, Larkin, and O'Brien, were attended by an audience of about 3,000 persons. Gen. T.F. Bourke presided.
Dr. Zukertort the chess champion gave a public exhibition, playing simultaneously eight games of chess blindfold, at Steinway Hall last evening. The number of spectators was comparatively small.

BOSTON, Nov. 23.--Major McIlrath, of the Secret Service, to-day arrested J. Henry Meyers, age 19, at Woburn, for horse-stealing in Jamaica, Vt. Meyers is also charged with being the leader of the organization known as the "United Band ...

READING, Penn., Nov. 23.--Morris Brown, an ex-Postmaster of Hamlin, Lebanon County, was arraigned before United States Commissioner Young in this city to-day, charged with detaining and opening letters.

CHARLESTON, West Va., Nov. 23.--Further explorations of the Great prehistoric mound in the eastern part of this county reveal some interesting facts. The mound is 540 feet in circumference and 85 feet high, covering about one acre.

NEW-ORLEANS Nov. 23.--Some excitement was caused here to-day by the summary dismissal of the Grand Jury by Judge Luzenburg, on motion of District Attorney Finney.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 23.--Five years ago this month, the Superior Court appointed Profs. Johnson T. Platt and John E. Clark, of the Yale Law School, a committee to hear and report upon the claims of policy-holders against the defunct American National Life and Trust Company of New-Haven.
ODESSA, Nov. 23.--The mercantile firm of Fichtenholz has failed with liabilities at $1,500,000.

Applause was frequent and hearty at the meeting of the Young Republican Club in Music Hall, Brooklyn, last night. Reports of election day work and addresses on the lessons of the recent local campaign were heard.
BOSTON, Nov. 23.--In the Municipal Court to-day Rust Brothers Bird, wholesale druggists, were charged with selling adulterated drugs by the State Board of Health, Lunacy, and Charity.

Cyrus W. Field appeared on the witness stand again in the Court of Common Pleas, Equity Term, yesterday morning and submitted to further examination in the elevated railroad suit to set aside the merger argreement.

NEW-HAVEN, Nov. 23.--The announcement that the Harvard Faculty had forbidden the University foot-ball team to play any more games on account of the brutality of the rules was received with great astonishment at Yale College.

The funeral services of the late District Attorney John McKeon will be held in St. Patrick's Cathedral at 11 o'clock this morning. Solemn requiem high mass will be celebrated by the Rev. Dr. William E. Degnan, of St. Agnes's Church, who was formerly a student in Mr. McKeon's law office.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23.--The proceedings of the United States Supreme Court to-day were as follows: No. 85--Jacob Esty et al, appellants, vs. Riley Burdett. Argument concluded. Adjourned.

The Aldermen yesterday, with Mr. Fitzpatrick in the chair, considered the provisional estimates of City expenditures for 1884. DES MOINES, Iowa, Nov. 23.--J.W. Flower, a dentist, 25 years old, from Kittaning, Penn., committed suicide at State Centre, Iowa, yesterday. He wrote a short letter saying his rother. J.A. Flower resided at Kittaning. J.A. Henderson, his brother-in-law, who resided at Blairville. Iowa, gives as a cause of the suicide that Flower's wife dead and he could not live without her.
CINCINNATI, Nov. 23.--The Evening Post exposes an arrangement by which the bucket shops in this city have been betting the market reports in spite of the action of the Chicago Board of Trade.

BOSTON, Nov. 23.--The Supreme Court has decided that Mrs. Clara Leonard is legally a member of the State Board of Health and Charities. Gov. Butler endeavored to have her removed, on the ground that she was not legally a member.

The funeral of the late Hannah Louise Van Alen, daughter of W.K. Van Alen, of San Francisco, took place yesterday morning at 10 o'clock from the residence of the deceased girl's uncle, C.C. Ruypen, No. 201 Academy-street, Jersey City.

A meeting of capitalists identified with the New-York and New-England Railroad was held in this City yesterday morning to nominate Directors to be elected at the stockholders' meeting in December. H.L. Higginson and Saltonstall, of Boston, and Jay Gould, E.E. Chase, and Le Grand B. Cannon, of New-York, were present.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 23.--The W.W. Walker syndicate, which owns the St. Louis, Hannibal and Keokuk Road, has gained control of the Forest Park and Central Road, which it will use as an entrance to this city.

The public will be deeply interested, without doubt, in the approaching engagement of Mr. Edwin Booth at the Star Theatre, chiefly because this engagement is to come so soon after Mr. Irving's engagement at the same theatre.

One stage-driver out of Augusta, Me., gets 50 cents for his round trip of 60 miles. The Virginia State Canvassing Board will meet in Richmond on Monday. The next Legislature assembles on the first Wednesday in December.
CHICAGO, Ill., Nov. 23.--M.H. Cochrane, of Compton, Quebec, sold 19 head of Hereford and 24 head of Aberdeen Angus cattle at the Fat Stock Show here this afternoon.
John Minnock, a boy, of Vernon-a venue and Fourth-street, Hunter's Point, came to this City with John Killeen, another boy, last Thursday night, and bought a pair of shoes at No. 394 Seventh-avenue.

VICKSBURG, Miss., Nov. 23.--The Conven tion of the National Cotton Planters' Association to-day adopted a resolution memorializing Congress to make a prompt appropriation for the improvement of the Mississippi River, and urging Congressmen to advocate the erection of levees.
UTICA, N.Y., Nov. 23.--Mackie Lousell, alias Yankee Mitchell, was arrested here to-day for participating in recent burglaries committed in this city. He says his residence is in Oswego Falls.

It is safe to assume that the reason why the last Legislature of this State referred the question of abolishing contract labor in the prisons to a vote of the people was because it was incompetent to deal with the subject.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 23.--The arguments in the Dinsmore suit against the Central New-Jersey and Philadelphia and Reading Railroad Companies were continued before Judge Nixon in the United States Circuit Court to-day.

Patrick O'Hara, a laborer, age 27, living on Clay-street, Peterson, N.J. was arrested last night for shooting Mrs. Nellie Fullalove, at No. 14 Slaterstreet, and he is now in the police station awaiting the result of her injuries.
SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Nov. 23.--Mrs. J. Dyer, of Glenville, died in great agony of lock-jaw to-day. A cancer was recently removed from her breast which resulted in erysipelas and lock-jaw.

Novelties in girls are naturally looked upon with suspicion. The present style of girl has been thoroughly tested and found to be perfectly satisfactory, and when any one claims to have devised a new and improved style of girl, the claim usually proves, upon examination, to be a ridiculous failure.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23.--The experiments of the Commissioner of Agriculture in the manufacture of sorghum sugar have come to an end for the season, for the very good reason that the appropriation has given out.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Nov. 23.--The announcement by cable that Capt. F.W. Dawson, editor of the News and Courier, had been created a Knight of the Order of St. George by the Pope was naturally the subject of general conversation in Charleston to-day, and a good many facts have been elicited which have never before been published.
Verdi's opera, "Ernani," was given at the Academy of Music last evening in the presence of the largest audience that has been in the house since the opening night.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Nov. 23.--The Arbitration Board of coal operators and miners of the fourth pool appointed to settle the wage dispute met to-day and elected an umpire. The board then adjourned until Tuesday, Dec. 4. Meanwhile the miners will use every effort to have all the mines of the fourth pool agree to accept the board's decision, regardless of the failure of the operators and miners to arbitrate in the other pools.

"Reader of THE TIMES" is informed that he can be enrolled next Tuesday. Assistant Bishop Henry C. Potter will preach a sermon in the floating church, Pike-street and East River, to-morrow at 3 o'clock P.M.

ROCHESTER, N.Y , Nov. 23.--In the Monroe County Surrogate's Court this morning the will of James McDonnell, late of this city, was admitted to probate. It was signed by ex-Deputy AttorneyGeneral Charles J. Everett of Utica and C.M. Dennison, ex-Canal Appraiser, of Whitestown, as witnesses, and disposes of $600,000 worth of property, about half of which is real estate.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23.--Sergt. W.H. Lamar, the man who took photographs of the Proteus as she was going down, was called of the witness stand by the Court of Inquiry to-day, and identified five photographs as being from the negatives he took on that occasion.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23.--The two newly appointed Lieutenants in the army have been assigned to regiments as follows: Wilson Y. Stamper to the Twentyfirst Infantry; Maury Nichols to the Sixteenth Infantry.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Nov. 23.--An attempt was made at an early hour this morning to burn the house of Silas S. Derby. This is the third attempt within a year to burn the house, each resulting in a small loss. Over a year ago Mr. Derby received a letter from an unknown spiritualist, in which it was stated that his house would be burned.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Nov. 23.--The fires on Storm King Mountain are still burning. Hundreds of acres of timber have been destroyed. Christopher Chaplain and Warren Delano, together, lose 300 acres of standing timber. J.B. Brundswayde, of New-York, loses 500 acres, and several other persons lose small quantities, ranging in value from $40 upward.

NEWTOWN, Conn., Nov. 23.--An agreement which was made about a year ago, when the Housatonic Railroad Company, or its chief officers, tookthe management of the creamery here, bids fair to create a disturbance.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23.--Most of the Democratic Congressmen seem determined to step away from Washington as long as possible. Only five or six were added to the list of those present to-day.

ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 23.--Pinckney Garnet, a deaf-mute, beat his wife so badly last night that she died from the effects of her injuries to-day. Garnet, when he saw that his wife was dying, left town and has not been arrested.

Grammar School No. 63, which is situated at One Hundred and Seventy-second-street and Third-avenue, will be closed all next week on account of the prevalence of diphtheria in the neighborhood, and the fact that three children of the janitor, Henry Muller, have died of the disease within a few weeks. Diphtheria prevails very extensively in Morrisania.

JACKSON, Mich., Nov. 23.--The Crouch murder is still a profound mystery. The officers are busy investigating but have absolutely nothing to work on. The greatest excitement still prevails and should the murderers be detected within the next ...
UNIONVILLE, Mo., Nov. 23.--The house of T.W. Huston, a farmer, two miles from here, was destroyed by fire yesterday. Mrs. Huston and two children perished in the flames.
Ten Governors will dine with the Chamber of Commerce on the night of Evacuation Day. Many distinguished gentlemen will be among the guests. New-York's favored son will not be one of the number.

READING Penn., Nov. 23.--A brakeman named George W. Kennedy, while standing on front of the pusher engine at Pottstown this morning, holding on to a pusher pole used to shove a car, was struck by the pole, which was lifted out of its socket. He was thrown across the track, and the engine passed over him right below the hips, cutting him in two. He expired in great agony in a few minutes.

A brutal assault, which may terminate fatally, and for which no sufficient reason is assigned was committed early yesterday morning by a farm-hand known as Carl on a lad named Nicholas Kohler in Conover's-lane, in New-Utrecht, Long Island.

CHICAGO, Nov. 23.--A bill for divorce was filed today in the Superior Court by Ellen Beardsley Reed against her husband, Charles H. Reed, the well-known lawyer, formerly of this city, for 12 years State Attorney of Cook County, and connected with the Guiteau trial.

NEW-HAVEN, Nov 23.--Judge Beardely, in the Superior Court to-day, decided the assault and slander cases brought by one wealthy citizen, Edmund B. Richardson, against two neighbors, also wealthy citizens, named Daniel H. Wilcox and George Wilcox.

TROY, N.Y., Nov. 23.--Shortly after 7 o'clock this evening a fire was discovered in the building on River-street owned by Charles Cleminshaw and occupied by Cleminshaw on the principal floor and basement for manufacturing and bottling soda-water.

BOSTON, Nov. 23.--The Republican convention to-night indorsed Gen. A.P. Martin and Isaac S. Burrill, previously nominated by the Citizens' convention for Mayor and Street Commismissioner, respectively. A committee was appointed to nominate candidates for the School Committee and Alderman, to report next Monday evening.
At a meeting last evening of the Cornell Univerversity Alumni Association at No. 8 Union-square, it was decided to hold the annual dinner on Dec. 7, the place to be selected later.

NORWICH, N.Y., Nov. 23.--The defense in the Dwight trial rested their case to-day, after calling one witness, and the plaintiff commenced the rebuttal. The defendants called Albert H. Hitchcock. He was the city editor of the Binghamton Leader at the time of Dwight's death.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Nov. 24.--It is reported that the damages to bridges and farm property, buildings, , in Randolph County, Ill., by the late storm will reach $100,000. PORTSMOUTH, N.H., Nov. 24.--Mrs. Barrows and Oscar E. Blaney, her son-in-law, were arrested this morning for the murder of Thomas Barrows, who was found shot dead 10 days ago.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24.--The week closes with less than 70 Democratic Congressmen in town, and not many more than 80 members all told. So few of the Democrats are new arrivals that this has been another off day in the Speakership contest, and none of the candidates have been overworked.
PHILADELPHIA, NOV. 24.--The Times tomorrow will print an account of one of the most remarkable lunacy cases that ever came before the courts of Philadelphia.

Joseph House, of Berlin, the wagon was struck by the Chicago express train. Mrs. McIntosh was instantly killed, Miss House died three hours later, and Mr. McIntosh is fatally injured.

SCHENECTADY, Nov. 24.--George Lawrence, in Niskayuna, was yesterday blown 15 feet by a premature explosion of powder with which he was blasting a stump. He was found unconscious and blinded. WASHINGTON, Nov. 24.--The last work of the season on the Washington Monument was done to-day, and for the rest of the Winter the structure will remain at its present height of 410 feet. UTICA, N.Y., Nov. 24.--Charles Loiselle, brother of the burglar arrested yesterday, was arrested to-day in connection with the Union burglaries. He was engaged last night in robbing the house of Frederick C. Hitter, of Alder Creck. The booty, amounting to about $700, was found on him, and also Mrs. Hunt's watch. The operations of these robbers have been very bold and skillful and disturbed the community greatly.

NEW-ORLEANS, Nov. 25.--The Gore Combination, which is composed of leading League players, played a game of base-ball here to-day with the Cincinnati Club. The latter played in good form, only allowing the Gore men to score a single run, while the Cincinnati players placed 12 runs to their credit. Five innings were played, when rain interfered with the contest.

BERLIN, Nov. 26.--The lower house of the Prussian Diet has begun the debate upon the annual estimates. Herr Scholz, Minister of Finance.

TORONTO, Ontario, Nov. 26--Port Perry, on Lake Seugog, was visited by fire this morning, and the entire business portion of the thriving and populous town was destroyed. The flames broke out in Ruddy's Hotel, in Queen street, shortly after midnight. The appliances for fighting fire being limited and primitive, the flames spread rapidly and were soon beyond control.

PARIS, Nov. 26.--The departure of the Marcuis Tseng, the Chinese Ambassador, from this city is believed to be imminent.

NORWICH, N.Y., Nov. 26.--The whole day in the Dwight trial was occupied in examining one witness, Henry C. Hermans. He testified that in 1878 he was agent for the Phoenix Mutual Life Insurance Company at Binghamton.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov 26.-Mrs. Hyles, an old lady, aged 86 years, and widow of the late Sheriff John Hyles, of Gloucester County, N.J., attempted suicide yesterday by taking laudanum. The overdose acted as an emetic, add Mrs. Hyles only suffered from prostration...

BRIDGETON, N.J., Nov. 26.--J.L. Van Syckle, who made an assault on editor Cheeseman, of the Patriot, with a revolver, on Friday last, waived a hearing to-day and was admitted to bail in the sum of $1,500 by Mayor Smalley for his appearance at the January term of court. Jacob Dailey, Jacob Heinsel, and William T. Bowen became his security. Van Syckle's face is still in a terrible condition.

MUNCIE, Ind., Nov. 26.--Last Saturday R. Scott, after a two years' separation from his wife, returned to her house near Easton, twelve miles north of here, and insisted that she should live with him again. She refused, and he then stabbed her to death, killed their child, and took a dose of morphine, from the effects of which he died.

Sojourner Truth, the well-known colored lecturer, died at Battle Creek, Mich., yesterday, aged 108 years. For almost three-quarters of a century she delivered lectures from the East to the West upon temperance, politics, and the woman's rights question.

ALBANY, N.Y., Nov. 26.--Sergt. Mason was released from the penitentiary this afternoon and left for New-York on the 4:40 train, hoping to reach Virginia in time to spend Thanksgiving Day with his family. His pardon only arrived from Washington in the afternoon mail and he was not informed of his good fortune until then.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Nov. 26.-The ownership of the Murraysville Gas well is this county has been in dispute for some time. The claimants are the Westons, of Chicago, and others and the Haymakers and others of Allegheny County.
