BALTIMORE, Nov. 26,-- The annual meeting of the stockholders of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Company was held to-day.

SCRANTON, Penn., Nov. 26.-Kirsts's Hotel, in this city, was entered by burglars early this morning and the safe carried out of the building and blown open. Carpet was wrapped around the safe to deaden the noise of the explosion. The exact amount obtained is unknown, but it is supposed to be between $200 and $300.

Police Justices Gorman and O'Reilly met their colleagues at a meeting of the board for the first time last evening. There were no formalities. Justice Power offered resolutions upon the death of District Attorney McKeon and spoke of his career.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 26.-The dead-lock which has prevented the organization of the first branch of the City Council of this city since Nov. 5 was broken to-night. The members erected stand 10 regular Democrats and 10 Republicans and Fusion Democrats, the latter opposing the regulars. Tonight Dr. Robert F. Burton, Fusion Democrat, was elected President, and regular Democrats were elected to all the minor positions, the President voting with the regular Domocrats.

PARKERSBURG, West Va., Nov. 28.--Ex-Gov. William E. Stevenson, whose serious illness for the past few weeks has been the cause of much solicitude throughout the State, is very low to-night, and his death before daybreak to-morrow is extremely probable.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Nov. 26.--An application was made in court this morning by George H. Anderson, Assignee of Tinsmau Tate, for the sale of the Mount Braddock Company's works, situated near Uniontown. The plant is valued at $3,500,000, and it is undersood that the property will be transferred to the coke syndicate, thus making the centralization of the great coke interest almost complete.

NORTH ADAMS, Mass., Nov. 26.--The property of Briggs Brothers, woolen manufacturers at Briggsville, was attached this morning for $15,000 by Mrs. O.B. Titus for borrowed money. The business will be continued till the present stock is worked up.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Nov. 26.--Fayette Brown was appointed Receiver of the large iron firm of Brown, Brownell Co. Feb. 20 last. He has collected $118,000 out of the business since then, but not withstanding this, a strenuous effort has been made by creditors in the United States court to oust him. Part of the original claim of $1,000,000 has been paid, and the unpaid creditors want the Receiver retained till all claims are liquidated.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Nov. 26.--The Holmes Mining Company has obtained a judgment of $260,000 against the Northern Belle Mining Company for trespass. The stock of the latter company dropped 50 per cent to-day.

PLYMOUTH, N.H., Nov. 26,--A wealthy young lady of New-York will build, at the cost of $10,000 a church in this place. It will be a gift to the Holderness school for Boys, and she will furnish and pay for the care of the edifice.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Nov. 27.--The Dominion Artillery Association, instead of sending a team to England next year, to compete at Shoeburyness, propose establishing a competition of garrison artillery at Quebec, and one for field artillery at Toronto. The enrollment of the Republicans in this City was completed yesterday with a total of 23,494. The registration of the first day was 5,785; second, 8,787; third. 8,922--the enrollment yesterday being larger than on either of the previous days. The proceedings yesterday were generally without incident.

The New-York Historical Society celebrated the seventy-ninth anniversary of its founding by a reception at the Academy of Music last evening, supplementing it with an address by the Hon. John Jay on "The Peace Negotiations of 1783." The Academy was fairly well filled.

FONDA, N.Y., Nov. 27.--This morning the body of George Coombs, a wealthy resident of Cranesville, was found in a creek near his residence, close to where it is crossed by the Central Railroad bridge. His neck was broken. As he was well acquainted with the vicinity, no explanation can be given as to the cause of his death.
Justice Gardner had issued warrants for the arrest of three women who were charged with keeping disorderly houses, and they were arraigned at the Essex Market Police Court yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27.--The Secretary of War has issued a general order providing, in the event of the retirement or death of an officer of the army, that his personal effects may be transported from his last station to his home at the expense of the Quartermaster's Department.
The Aqueduct Commission met yesterday and listened to arguments relative to the construc tion of the new aqueduct and dams.

PITTSBURG, Pa., Nov. 27.--All is quiet at Murraysville to-night. There has been no further disturbance, and the leaders of the aggressive party being in jail, no trouble is apprehended for the present.

BOSTON, Nov. 27.--William D. Howells gave a reception at his residence this evening to George W. Cable, the poet and author. Among the 70 or 80 guests present were Oliver Wendell Holmes, John Boyle O'Reilly, T.B. Aldrich, Edwin Booth, Lawrence Barrett, Ernest Longfellow, Francis Parkman, E.P. Whipple, and T.W. Higginson.

MARSHFIELD, Wis., Nov. 27.--While John Dent and his son were hunting is this vicinity today, the boy stumbled and fell, discharging his gun. The charge of buckshot entered the elder Dent's right leg. The wounded man lay four hours on the frozen ground before assistance arrived. Amputation was decided upon by a surgeon, but the patient did not rally sufficiently from the shock to warrant the operation being performed. He died in great agony.
ST. LOUIS, Nov. 27.--There was a dramatic scene in the City Jail here to-day when Lena Kleinschmidt was led up to cell No. 5, which contained her lover, Frederick Spilker.

The owners of the Sturtevant House were ordered by Inspector Esterbrook, on Jan. 25, to have outside fire-escapes put up, but they failed to do so.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Nov. 27.--The Senate to-day reconsidered the Appropriation bill which was defeated on Friday and passed it finally by a vote of 27 to 6, after a long debate. The resignations of Senators Arnbolt and Upperman said to have been tendered to the President pro tem. were not read. The former was present to-day.
The New-York Hare and Hounds Club wil celebrate Thanksgiving Day with its usual 'cross country paper chase.
Twenty first mortgage bondholders of the Texas and St. Louis Railroad Company met in the Astor House yesterday to protest against the proposed readjustment scheme.
NEW-LONDON, Conn., Nov. 27.--The Wequetquock religious war is the topic of interest here just now. It appears that in that ancient hamlet there are many ladies who were converted at recent revivals.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27.--A number of reputable attorneys at law, practicing their profession in part before the Pension Office, have endeavored to induce the Secretary of the Interior to adopt some regulations regarding admission to that practice.

Sporting men from New-York, New-Jersey, Long Island, and Connecticut met at a saloon at Stapleton, Staten Island, late Monday night, to witness a cooking main between Staten Island and Connecticut birds. Several county officials graced the basement in which the main was fought with their presence, and lent an air of judicial dignity to the scene.
MADRID, Nov. 27.--The Cabinet has approved the decree of the Minister of the Colonies abolishing the right of Cuban slaveholders to punish slaves with stocks and fetters.

The License Committee of the Paterson Board of Aldermen has resolved to recommend to the board that hereafter all licenses for the sale of liquor shall be acted upon by the full board; that the fee shall be raised from $35 and $50 to $75 and ...
Autograph-hunters besieged the Sub-Treasury Building immediately after the unveiling of the statue of Washington on Monday.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Nov. 27.--Four hundred miners in Gamble Risher's mines, third pool, struck last evening against a reduction of cent per bushel on the mining rate. The men also object to the free coal they are expected to dig, which passes through 1 -inch screen.
CAIRO, Nov. 27.--Baker Pasha will start for Suakim in 10 days to take command of the Soudan expedition.
GLASGOW, Nov. 27.--Messrs. Dobie Co., ship-builders at Govan, a suburb of this city, have failed. Twelve hundred workmen are thrown out of employment by the failure.

One of the grandest features of Monday's celebration was the parade of the Irish "sappers and miners." This corps consists of men trained in the use of dynamite and subject to the orders of O'DONOVAN ROSSA.
The Tamaulipas, a steam-ship which has been built for the new company known as the Compania Mexicana Transatlantica, recently arrived at Liverpool from the Clyde, and will soon sail for Vera Cruz.

Edward Kennedy, the left fielder of the Metropolitan Club, was approached some time ago by the manager of the new St. Louis Club and offered a large amount to break his contract with the "Mets." This he refused to do, and in consequence will again play here next season. The St. Louis Club has been very anxious to secure the services of New-York players.

"Hen" Rice, arrested on Monday on a Charge of larceny made by Robert Solomon, a diamond miner, and a fellow-passenger on the steamship Servia, was arraigned before Justice Patterson, at the Jefferson Market Police Court, yesterday. When the case was presented by Capt. McDonnell the magistrate said he did not think he had any jurisdiction, as the offense alleged was committed on the high seas.

FONDA, N.Y., Nov. 27.--Congressman Wemple, prior to his departure to Washington, was given a brilliant reception by ex-Congressman Sanford, at Amsterdam, last night. All the prominent politicians in the central part of the State were present. The speeches called upon Mr. Wemple to see that a protectionist was elected to the Speakership.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 27.--The proposed extension from the McMinville and Sparra Branch of the Nashville and Chattanooga Railroad, at Sarta, to the Bon Air coal fields, will cost $20,000 per mile.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, Nov. 27.--Linda Huston, one of the prettiest girls in the pretty town of Nottingham, near Cleveland, married S.O. Davis, a Lake Shore Railroad conductor.
The three gentlemen who aspire to the Speakership have been long in the public service. Their character, their views, their parliamentary abilities are perfectly well known.
A number of gentlemen called on Inspector Byrnes yesterday and reported the loss of their watches and purses while they were reviewing the procession on Monday.

The Rev. John J. Riordan, of the Roman Catholic mission to help emigrants at Castle Garden, left St. Louis for St. Paul., Minn., last Saturday. While in St. Louis he visited the Trustees of the Mullanphy fund, which is said to amount to over $1,000,000.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 27.--When the Cincinnati Northern Road, which is a part of the Toledo, Cincinnati and St. Louis system, was ordered sold, the first mortgage bonds were suddenly offered in large numbers at 50 cents on the dollar.

The New-York Vocal Union gave its first concert of the present season at Chickering Hall last evening. The elaborately engraved tickets of admission contained the information that the entertainment was private, and it was known that the amiable assemblage of ladies and gentlemen composing the chorus of the Union were amateurs.

The cross-examination of Mr. Gaston L. Feuardent occupied the attention of Judge Shipman and a jury all day yesterday in the United States District Court, where the Feuardent-Di Cesnola libel suit is being tried.
ST. LOUIS, Nov. 27.--Buck Ewing, the high priced catcher of the New-York League base-ball team, is negotiating with the new St. Louis Club.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 27.--Tobacco men in this city and State are much agitated over developments in connection with the failure of the last -- Congress to appropriate money to pay the rebate on the tobacco stock which dealers held on May 1, when the reduction of tax went into effect.

Persons who are tolerably familiar with that chapter of ancient history known as the star route trial will be interested to know that ex-Senator GEORGE E. SPENCER, of Alabama, has been found. He appeared in the United States District Court, Washington, on Monday last, in charge of two officers.

NEW-HAVEN, Nov. 27.--Grand Juror Painter, of West Haven, is a character. He is the leader of the temperance wing of the town, and distinguished himself by his services when the body of Jennie Cramer was found on Savin Rock Beach.

NEW-ORLEANS, Nov. 27.--Herr Lasker, member of the German Parliament, who has just recrossed the continent by the Southern Pacific, arrived here to-day from Galveston, accompanied by his brother, who is a merchant of that city. He leaves to-morrow for Washington, where he will remain for several weeks watching the proceedings of Congress and the workings of the Government.

Saddartha, Pinafore, and Touch-Me-Not three horses belonging to Mr. Pierre Lorillard, arrived yesterday on the National steam-ship England, and were taken to the bonded stables of Robert Stoddard, at No. 600 Greenwich-street.

Alexander K. Falconer, convicted last week of writing a number of annoying love letters to Miss Kate Hale, daughter of a wealthy chair manufacturer, residing on Lafayette-avenue, Brooklyn, was called up for sentence before Judge Moore, in the Kings County Court of Sessions yesterday.

The annual meeting of the shareholders of the New-York, Lake Erie and Western Railroad was held yesterday. PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 27.--In the municipal election to-day Thomas A. Doyle was elected Mayor for the fifteenth time, after an interval of three years, by 2,358 majority, this being 700 more than he ever before received.
PHILADELPHIA,--Nov. 27.--Gen. Grant, who came over to Philadelphia last night, after attending the wedding of Miss Drexel, returned to NewYork on the 4 o'clock express.

LONDON, Nov. 27.--The Irish Government authorities have discovered that the Fenians, O'Riordan and Capt. McCafferty, for whom rewards were offered, are residing in Ireland and America, respectively. The Government is satisfied that they were not connected with the recent explosion at the Praed-street station of the Metropolitan Underground Railway.

Phoebe Jane Paullin, who was murdered near Eagle Rock, on the first mountain back of Orange, N.J., was killed in the same way that a pig or sheep is stuck. Officers investigating the case said the deed, looked as if it had been done by a butcher or some one accustomed to kill ing animals.
John Clark, a young man who claims to reside at No. 334 West Thirty-seventh-street, was arrested by Detective Sergeant Kush yesterday afternoon charged with being concerned in the policy business.

Among other honors in store for the German Crown Prince during his stay in Spain is an appointment as chief of a Spanish regiment. His uniform for that office has already been made.
LONDON, Nov. 28.--The steam-ship Gloucester, (Br.,) Capt. Peters, from New-York Nov. 12, has arr. at Bristol.

ALBANY, N.Y., Nov. 27.--In the Court of Appeals the motion recently made by the plaintiffs for a reargument of the appeal in the case of Williams against the Western Union Telegraph Company was to-day denied, with costs. This leaves the former decision intact, and finally settles the litigation in favor of the Western Union.

A fight occurred yesterday afternoon in the kitchen of the Metropolitan Hotel between Stephen Huhn, a kitchen helper, and John Pugh, a colored waiter, during which Huhn was stabbed in the neck with a pocket knife by Pugh and dangerously wounded.
NEW-ORLEANS, La., Nov. 27.--The failure of E.L. Raulett Co., cordage, bagging, c., is announced. No statement has been made.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 27.--A party of 11 hunters returned this evening from a week spent in duckshooting in Butler County, Mo.

RED BANK, N.J., Nov. 27.--William H. Laird, one of the most prominent citizens of Englishtown, has sued his wife for absolute divorce.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 27.--There is 40 per cent. less iron ore in sight here than has been usual at this season in 12 years.

PARIS, Nov. 27.--A rumor was current this afternoon in the lobbies of the Chamber of Deputies that Admiral Courbet, with his forces, had been defeated in Tonquin by the Black Flags and his communications cut off. The rumors were given more credence because no official information is forthcoming.

NEW-ORLEANS, Nov. 27.--The merchants and business people are greatly annoyed and discommoded by the enforcement of the new regulation of the Postmaster-General requiring the delivery of mail by carriers instead of putting it in the boxes of renters, and the Postmaster here has received numerous letters of protest and remonstrance.

Horace Porter states that the use of his name as a Trustee in the articles of incorporation was without his consent or knowledge, and that as soon as he learned of it he sent a communication forbidding the use of his name in connection therewith.

The Church of the Heavenly Rest was filled with friends and invited guests yesterday noon to witness the marriage of Miss Julie De Forest, daughter of Mr. Cornelius V. De Forest, to Mr. George P. Benjamin. The ushers were Mr. O. W. Buokingham, Mr. Lindsay C. Ivory, Mr. William D. Eilis, and Mr. William E. Thorne, of Cincinnati.
Three hundred and fifteen children at the Colored Orphan Asylum, at One Hundred and Forty-third-street and Tenth-avenue, will expect a Thanksgiving dinner to-morrow.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 27.--The arguments in the case of Dinsmore against the New-Jersey Central and Philadelphia and Reading Railroads were concluded this afternoon. The court-room was filled to its utmost capacity, many prominent citizens and a large number of ladies being present.
CINCINNATI, Nov. 27.--The District Court gave a unanimous decision this morning in favor of Hawkins, Democrat, in the contest for the office of Sheriff brought by Beresford, the Republican candidate.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Nov. 27.--Jack Splann has bought the stallion Endymion for $10,000.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Nov. 27.--Max Kohn, a Danish sailor on the Albatross, was killed with a knife to-night on Cumberland-street, in this city. He became involved in a dispute at a disreputable house, and was stabbed to the heart twice. He died on the sidewalk. Eight persons have been arrested on suspicion, but the murderers have not yet been identified.

Six negro men and two negro women sat as prisoners in the dock at the opening of the Court of Oyer and Terminer yesterday. They were all indicted for grand larceny, but some of them were also charged with receiving stolen goods.

BOSTON, Nov. 27.--The Directors of the NewYork and New-England Railroad Company held a protracted meeting this afternoon of the closest character.

The horse attached to the coupe belonging to Overin Hastings that was badly injured by stepping and then falling on the broken end of an electric wire on Monday night was last evening not expected to live.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Nov. 27.--The strike of the railroad freight-handlers continues to cause much trouble to the officials of the roads, but they report that they are making fair progress with their business. Most of the roads have brought laborers from other points.

A hackman took to the police station is OneHundred and Fifty-second-street, at 1 o'clock this morning, the body of a man who had died in his cab. The man had taken the carriage at the Casino, about 11 o'clock, and was then intoxicated. He was about 30 years old and had in his pockets letters addressed to J. Humphrey, No. 109 Fulton-street. The office of Humphrey's Specific Homeopathic Medical Company is at that number.

MONTREAL, Quebec, Nov. 27.--S.W. Beard, the coal merchant of this city who lately failed for $500,000, was arrested to-day on a capias at the suit of John Taylor Brother. He was sent to jail upon being unable to furnish security.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 27.--A meeting of the Board of Trade was held to-day to take action on the question of sending a representative to the convention which is to be held at Washington on Jan. 16 to consider the matter of a national bankrupt law. After a prolonged discussion it was resolved to send a memorial to Congress on the subject, but no delegate to the convention.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Nov. 27.--The Free Traders scored a victory in return of their candidate yesterday to represent Lennox County in the Dominion Parliament. Sir John Macdonald formerly represented Lennox, but was recently unseated on a charge of corrupt practices having been resorted to in the election by his agents.

SALEM, Mass., Nov. 26.--Mayor Low, of Brooklyn, has given to the city of Salem where he was born, as Trustee, the sum of $2,500, it being an addition to his gift of $5,000 in 1874, and designated the Low Educational Fund. The object of the fund is to aid worthy boys through college.

EASTON, Penn., Nov. 27.--Edgar Grover and Robert Leh, aged, respectively, 8 and 10 years, while on their way to school this morning were struck by a train on the Lehigh and Susquehanna Railroad at Catasauqua and instantly killed.
PITTSBURG, Penn., Nov. 27.--A telegram received here states that Sergt. Mason has accepted an engagement to appear at the Museum in this city. His wife and child are not to be exhibited.

WORCESTER, Mass., Nov. 27.--The Rev. Dr. William R. Huntington, Reotor of All Saints Church, today tendered his resignation, having accepted a call from Grace Church, New-York.

PEORIA, Ill., Nov. 27.--Joseph Jefferson, who was to play here to-night, was prevented by the fact that at 4 o'clock this morning he was struck with sudden and complete loss of voice, supposed to be caused by playing at Rockford last night when suffering from a severe cold. His physician says he may possibly be able to talk again within a week or 10 days, but possibly not before the expiration of a month.

MATAMORAS, Mexico, Nov. 28.--The house of the Rev. Father Miguel Cabo, at Ixcaquintla, State of Puebla, was attacked a few nights ago by a band of robbers. The priest and two servants were killed, and a niece of the priest was severely wounded. The robbers rifled the house of its valuables.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Nov. 23.--Zelda Seguin, of Emma Abbott's troupe, says the reports of bad feeling in the company are true. There is a disposition to carry reports from artist to artist that are detrimental to each and are producing serious discord.

HIGH POINT, N.C., Nov. 28.--The following is a corrected report of yesterday's heats for the Derby Stakes in the field trials here: In the first series Princess Helen beat Countess C., Bryan beat London Ben. Pride of Dixie beat St. Elmo IV., and Poater beat Bob White.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 28.--The citizens of Newport by a vote to-day defeated by 326 majority the proposition to purchase a lot and build an asylum for the poor at a cost of $33,000. The proposition to sell the city's interest, $50,000, in the Newport and Wickford Railroad and Steamboat Company and to use the proceeds to extinguish the city's debt was also defeated by 38 majority.

MONMOUTH, Ill., Nov. 28.--Isaac Davis, a farmer, living near Youngstown, 20 miles south of here, this morning killed his brother James in a dispute over the division of a crop of corn jointly owned by them.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Nov. 28.--Commodore W.J. Kountz, who was convicted of libel, was today sentenced to 30 days in the County Jail and to pay a fine of $100 and the costs of prosecution. He was locked up in a common cell.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Nov. 28.--Dr. James C. Buck, a prominent resident of Braddock, Penn., was to-day sentenced to five years and six months in the penitentiary on account of his connection with the Gordon gang of highwaymen.

The final interment of the remains of Fathers Lafont, Aubril, and Barbier, of the order of Fathers of Mercy, will take place this morning, in the new stone and brick vault in the ground in the rear of the temporary structure known as the Church of St. Francis de Sales, in Broadway, in the outskirts of Brooklyn.

DUBLIN, Nov. 28.--The Freeman's Journal is informed that within a fortnight more than 30 persons have been arrested, charges with conspiracy to destroy the residence of a County Mayo landlord by explosives and with belonging to the Fenian Brotherhood.

ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 28.--The Supreme Court has rendered a decision which shows that that judicial body is down on dealing in futures. The case in which the decision was rendered was an appeal from the Richmond Superior Court.

BATAVIA, N.Y., Nov. 28.--On Oct. 13 Howard Parsons, a pupil at the Institution for the Blind, was attacked with diphtheria in a malignant form, and on Oct. 20 he died. Three other pupils contracted the disease from Parsons, and two of these died.

MONTREAL, Nov. 28.--That there has been a decline in bank stocks during the last half-year is, of course, well known, but there are probably few persons outside the actual stock market who have any idea to what extent the decline has gone during the last three months, that is to say, since Sept. 1.

The estate of the late District Attorney John McKeon is estimated at $200,000. His will is dated Dec. 8, 1882. A legacy of $1,000 is given to John Dunnigan, a subpoena-server, and $1,000 in cash to Mr. McKeon's stepdaughter, Jeannette T. Walker.

WATERBURY, Conn., Nov. 28.--The public indignation against Truman J. Smith, the Watertown farmer, who assaulted his wife and broke her leg a month ago, having quarreled with her because their children were all girls, culminated ...
PETERSBURG, Va., Nov. 28.--Information has been received here of the murder of Thomas Bragg, colored, in Lunenburg County, by Dick Mitchell and John Jones.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 28.--The Convention on International Arbitration resumed its session to-day. Bishop Simpson presiding. A general discussion was had on the subject of arbitration as a substitute for war and the establishment of an international congress for arbitration.
Gen. James Grant Wilson, the author, who has just returned from Europe, resides at No. 15 East Seventy-fourth-street.
Miss Lillie A. Tan Allen was married last evening to Mr. Charles F. Scott, at the residence of her father, G.W. Van Allen. No. 137 East Fiftyfifth-street.
BRADFORD, England, Nov. 28.--Two thousand five hundred operatives in Sir Titus Salt's mills have been thrown out of employment in consequence of a strike of 60 spinners.

Officer William Swayne, of the Thirty-first Precinct, was told at 2:45 yesterday afternoon that a man had shot himself in Riverside Park near Eighty-second-street. Going to the spot, he found the man already dead and lying on his back, with his left hand hanging by his side and his right ...

Bad blood has been developed in the Feuardent-Di Cesnola suit between two of the counsel, Messrs. Bangs and Stickney. This has resulted apparently from an excess of interest in behalf of the respective clients of the two attorneys.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Nov. 28.--About three weeks ago Mrs. Osborne Bailey, of this city, formerly a Miss Whitridge, of Baltimore, received a letter from an uncle in the latter place stating that he was ill and asking her to come and nurse him.

Senator Henry B. Anthony, of Rhode Island, the senior Senator in Congress, is seriously ill at the Fifth-Avenue Hotel. He arrived in this City on Tuesday, on his way to Washington to attend the opening of Congress.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 28.--The long pending suit of Henry C. Terry, a member of the Bar, to obtain from the city a fee of $50,000 for services in connection with the transfer of the Oxford turnpike to the municipality, was decided to-day by the Master to whom the case had been referred.

NORWICH, N.Y., Nov. 28.--In the Dwight trial there was some testimony taken to-day, but considerable time was lost by the arguments of counsel as to points brought up in connection with the testimony. The cross-examination of Dr. Joseph H. Chittenden, of Binghamton, was continued.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28.--If appearances and the best indications obtainable to-night are to be depended upon Mr. Carlisle cannot only be confident of his election to the Speakership, but he can depend upon reaching the position by a very handsome majority of the Democratic members of the Forty-eighth Congress.
The most unique dramatic company that over appeared in this country arrived here yesterday by the Hamburg steam-ship Lessing.

The supply of sunsets of assorted sizes and colors, which are furnished to this locality, is running short, and the Signal Service Bureau, in order to economize, has exhibited the same style for the last two nights.

Among the immigrants who landed yesterday at Castle Garden were Amelia and Anna Bader, 13 and 9 years old, respectivaly. The girls had crossed the ocean alone to join their father, who came to this country last May, leaving them with an uncle in Germany.
COLUMBIA, S.C., Nov. 28.--A bill was introduced in the State Senate to-day to repeal the Civil Rights bill passed by the State Legislature in 1870 under the reconstruction regime.

Mr. Overin, one of the owners of the horse prostrated and tortured on Monday evening by contact with a fallen Brush electric light wire on Fifth-avenue, said yesterday that there was no prospect of the animal's recovery. It could stand, and, when prodded, could feebly waggle one hind leg, but there its powers seemed to cease.
RALEIGH, N.C., Nov. 28.--The firm of W. B. Jarvis Co., at Greenville, N.C., are reported to have failed yesterday. The liabilities are stated to be $60,000; assets not given.
PITTSBURG, Penn., Nov. 28.--It is stated here that President Kline, of the Glass-workers' Association, who has been in New-York for some time, has about closed an agreement with several ...

ERIE, Penn., Nov. 28.--Efforts are being made to erect a crematory in Erie or in a convenient town between Cleveland and Buffalo. David Cummings, of Conneaut, a scientific farmer and an enthusiastic believer in the burning of the dead, is at the head of the enterprise.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28.--For some time workmen have been laying an underground telegraph and telephone cable between the Capitol and the Office of Public Buildings and Grounds.

CINCINNATI, Ohio., Nov. 28.--A dispatch to the Commercial Gazette from Mineral Point, Ohio, tells of a novel trial which has just been concluded in that place. A 15-year-old daughter of Thomas Gordon was kidnaped by Robert Reuder.

CHICAGO, Nov. 28.--A long and somewhat exciting meeting of the Iowa pooled lines was held here to-day, the result of which was simply to defer a settlement of the difficulties and continue the present uncertainty.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Nov. 28.--William Kennedy, a white seaman of schooner Victor Pugh, was arrested this morning for the murder last night of Max Kohn. He was fully identified by the friends of Kohn, the murdered man, and by Charles ...
PITTSBURG, Penn., Nov. 28.--Andrew Wilbert, the boy who was held for the murder of Frank Reed, a companion, has been exonerated by the Coroner's jury on account of his extreme youth.

Police Captain Williams, the efficient regulator of the Twenty-ninth Precinct, has been presented with a trio of American relics, upon which he places a high valve, by Mr. Charles Swift, a generable gentleman living in West Thirtiethstreet.

SCRANTON, Penn., Nov. 28.--At a meeting of the stockholders of the Scranton Steel Company yesterday it was unanimously agreed to increase the Capital of the company from $600,000 to $1,500,000 for the purpose of building a new blast furnace.

ALBANY, Nov. 28.--A decision was announced to-day by the Board of Railroad Commissioners in the matter of the complaint of the Chamber of Commerce and others against the trunk lines alleging discrimination against dry goods shipped to the West.
The Brooklyn Puritan Church has during the past year realized its expectations of prosperity. The net increase of revenue during the year ending Nov. 19 has been $2,860 66.
A grave was dug in the little cemetery in the valley between the mountains back of Orange, N.J., yesterday, and the body of Phoebe Jane Paullin was lowered into it.

PARIS, Nov. 28.--M. Ferry, Prime Minister and Minister of Foreign Affairs; Gen. Campenon, Minister of War, and Admiral Peyron, Minister of Marine, attended the meeting to-day of the Committee of the Chamber of Deputies upon the Tonquin credits.

What business have a New-York Police Justice and a New-York Police Captain to help a man who has lost money in gambling in the smoking-room of a British steamer on the high seas to get back his money from the winner?

TORONTO, Ontario, Nov. 28.--A cable dispatch from London to the Globe says the nonelected Directors of the Hudson Bay Company have issued circulars complaining that while most of the shareholders left the recent meeting without voting, under the belief that the re-election of the committee would be unopposed.
PITTSBURG, Penn., Nov. 28.--The Dispatch reports the suspension of the Kittanning Rolling Mills. The men were paid off yesterday, and the mill will shut down for an indefinite period.

Wearied out with the endeavor to penetrate the bosom of a ward politician far enough to find his soul, the Socratic dialectician of THE TIMES was reclining in the luxurious corner of a Sixthavenue elevated car.

The new Board of Directors of the NewYork, Lake Erie and Western Railroad yesterday re-elected the old board of executive officers. An annual dividend of 6 per cent. on preferred stock was declared, payable Jan. 15.

Soon after 9 o'clock yesterday morning gentleman drove hurriedly up to the Thirty-second Precinct Police Station, in West One Hundred and Fifty-second-street, and asked to see the body of the young man who had been found dead in a hack.

A remonstrance was yesterday announced to be in circulation against the assumed design of the Park Commissioners to establish the alleged zoological collection on the meadow north of the reservoir in Central Park.

As Officer John Godfrey, of the Twentythird Precinct, was riding on the front platform of a Third-avenue car, between Eighty-eighth and Eighty-ninth streets, last night, his neck was caught by the sag of an electric wire, and he was slightly injured.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28.--Several consultations have been held during the last two days between the Virginia Senators and the friends of Mr. George C. Gorham and the other Republicans who were caucus candidates two years ago for positions in the Senate.

At 2:15 o'clock this morning fire broke out in the rear of No. 51 Crosby-street, occupied by Girard Loota as a macaroni factory. The building and its contents were destroyed, causing a loss of about $15,000. A man, whose name is unknown, was taken from a room in an adjoining building unconscious from suffocation, and at 2:30 o'clock it seemed probable that all efforts to restore him would fail.

LONDON, Nov 28.--A Cairo dispatch to Reuter's Telegram Company dated to-day says the report of the capture of Khartoum by El Mahdi's forces is unfounded. The difficulty in persuading the Turkish officers of the contingent ordered for ...
MADISON, Ind., Nov. 28.--Nathaniel Lee, an aged and respected farmer, was to-day swindled out of $5,500 by the three-card monte game.

TROY, N.Y., Nov. 28.--A decree of divorce was to-day granted on the report of Orin Gambell, Referee, by Judge Ingalls in the case of Susan Bontecou against Dr. Reed B. Bontecou. The parties were married in West Troy on July 18.
Of our two national holidays, Thanksgiving may be said to have a purely local origin; Independence Day was originally celebrated by all the thirteen States.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Nov. 28.--A strange and remarkable story comes from Covington, Ky. When Fort Sumter was fired upon a young farmer of Greenbrier County, West Va., left his wife and little boy and came to Cincinnati to enlist in the Northern army.

ALBANY, Nov. 28.--Ex-Clerk Edward M. Johnson is conducting a comfortable canvass for the Assembly Clerkship from this city. He has ensconsed himself in the cozy quarters provided by the State for the use of Assembly clerks after they have received authority to act as such.

A writer in a Boston paper says: "The author of 'The Grandissimes' had been in Boston but eight and forty hours, yet his table was covered with letters of pleasant invitation, with cards bearing names familiar as household words, and ...

Two more of the crew of the Northern Light were examined yesterday before. United States Commissioner Shields in the case of the United States against Capt. Joshua Slocumb, who is charged with cruel and inhuman treatment of his second mate, Henry Arthur Slater.
ALBANY, Nov. 28.--Senator Lynde, Chairman of the Senate Cammittee on State Lands in the Adirondacks, is here to-day and says that a new danger threatens the north woods.
PENN YAN, N.Y., Nov. 28.--The return of Sheriff Speelman from Michigan yesterday with a would-be murderer and fugitive from justice recalls attention to a remarkable case.

ALBANY, Nov. 28.--Court of Appeals, present the Hon. W.C. Ruger, Chief-Justice, and Associates, No. 244--Samuel S. Blass, respondent, vs. Royal L. Johnson et al., Administrators, appellants; appeal from a judgment of affirmance denying a new trial; the action was for assault and battery; argued by ...
The visit of the Crown Prince to Spain has thus far been very successful. ALFONSO has made him Colonel of a Spanish regiment and given orders to have a uniform made for him.

The Metropolitan Club will no longer play on the Polo Grounds. Two clubs playing on the same grounds last season proved to be unsatisfactory to the visiting clubs, and the result was that the American Association requested the managers of the Metropolitan team to find an inclosed ground elsewhere.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28.--Secretary Teller's letter to the Commissioner of Pension, declining to make an order admitting lawyers only to practice as pension attorneys, was not an answer to any suggestion made by Commissioner Dudley, but was intended as a reply to a communication from a number of reputable lawyers whose practice in part is before the Pension Office.

Milton J. Roberts, a man about 40 years of age, who boarded at No. 13 Abingdon-square, was reported to the police yesterday morning as having been missing since Saturday last. The books at Police Head-quarters were searched, but no record of the missing man was found.

Rafael Capabiana, of No. 35 Crosby-street, and Francisco Gulia, of No. 63 Thompson-street, quarreled over some trifling point on last Monday night, and the former stabbed the latter in the left side with a carving-knife, which he was in the habit of carrying about with him.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28.--The newly appointed Surgeon-General of the Army entered upon his duties to-day.

RALEIGH, N.C., Nov. 28.--A party consist ing of 35 prominent Boston manufacturers and capitalists arrived here this morning as guests of the city. Speeches were made by Mayor Dodd, Gov. Jarvis, and other prominent men. A banquet will be given the visitors to-morrow. The party will make a tour of the State, investigating its resources, c.
The forty-first annual meeting of the Society for the Relief of Widows and Orphans of Medical Men was held last evening at the Academy of Medicine, No. 12 West Thirty-first-street.

There was a large attendance last evening at the Thirteenth Regiment Armory, at Flatbushavenue and Hanson-place, Brooklyn, to witness an athletic exhibition under the auspices of the regiment's athletic association, and each event was ...
PARIS, Nov. 9.--The honors of the week have been divided between the elder Dumas and Mile. Fargueil, with a large share in favor of the latter.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28.--"For Congress," a play written more than a year ago by Mr. David D. Lloyd, for Mr. John T. Raymond, the production of which has been deferred repeatedly in order ...

FALL RIVER, Mass., Nov. 28.--Alderman Hurley and Councilmam Murphy, who engaged in a fight in Hurley's saloon last Saturday night, were arrested to-night and held under bail for examination on Friday.

Permission was granted by the Board of Aldermen on Oct. 30, 1877, to John M. Toucey to lay a 5-inch pipe across the City through Sixtyfifth-street for the purpose of transporting oil from Saddle River to Hunter's Point. It was approved by the Mayor soon afterward, and in due time the pipe was laid.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Nov. 28.--In the case of the discharged manager, Martin, against Miss Ober, proprietress of the Boston Ideal Opera Company, for breach of contract. Judge Hale to-day gave a decision in favor of the defendant.
PEORIA, Ill., Nov. 28.--Joseph Jefferson is still at his room under a physician's care. It will be impossible for him to appear again this week.
WILKESBARRE, Penn., Nov. 28.--John Lumson and Robert Richardson, two men employed as shaft sinkers at the Schooley colliery, near Pittston, met with an accident to-day which cost them their lives.
BALTIMORE, Md., Nov. 28.--The Grand Jury of Charles County, Md., have indicted the three Commissioners of that county for malfeasance in office.
Elbridge T. Gerry, President of the Society for the Prevention of Crime, has filed complaints with the Mayor against the concert halls in the Bowery which, he asserts, are the resorts of ...

Arias from "Il Trovatore" and "Boccaccio," rendered with the precision and perfectness of a cornet on a simple piece of wall-paper rolled in the shape of a cornucopia are not often heard, yet yesterday afternoon at the Tremont House two dozen men stood amazed and enchanted listening to such music.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Nov. 28.--There was a tragedy at Brunswick, Mo., last night, Charles Suess, a well-known citizen of that burg, at an early hour last evening left home telling his wife that he was going to the theatre.
During the last decade, since the first production in this country of Verdi's, latest and greatest opera, there has been no lack of prima donnas willing to attempt the arduous role of Aida.
OTTAWA, Ontario, Nov. 28.--According to returns received by the Department of Agriculture the number of cattle shipped from Canadian ports up to Nov. 1 of this year was 50,655, sheep, 100,113.

SAVANNAH, Ga., Nov. 28.--The Commissioners of Lunacy, summoned on the petition of Mrs. Anna M. Morgan, have adjudged her husband, Frederick M. Morgan, insane, Mr. Morgan is a German who, by a fortunate speculation, amassed in a short time over $50,000.

PRAIRIE DU CHIEN, Wis., Nov. 28.--The cyclone which passed to the south-east of this place on Sunday night completely wrecked three farm-houses and a number of outbuildings. A women named Mary Melvin was crushed to death in the ruins of her home.

Acting Superintendent Thorne summoned the Captains to Police Head-quarters yesterday and gave them directions in relation to the arrest of liquor-dealers who had been convicted of violating the excise law. Section 8, chapter 175, of the Laws of 1870, which is the statute under which the sale of liquor is regulated in this City, reads as follows:

A drowsy atmosphere pervaded the room of the Common Pleas, Equity Term, yesterday, and only a languid interest was shown by the persons present in the trial of the suit of the Metropolitan Elevated Railroad Company against the Manhattan Railway Company.

PARIS, Nov. 28.--In the championship billiard-match to-night Vignaux made up for lost ground by a series of brilliant runs, the best being 153, 119, and 115. At the close of the night's play Vignaux's score was 770 and Schaefer's 543. Each played 15 innings. The total scores for the three nights are: Vignaux, 1,800; Schaefer, 1,743.

Mozart's noble work, "Don Giovanni," was produced at the Metropolitan Opera-house last evening before a very large audience, which was evidently puzzled because it could not arouse itself to enthusiasm over the immortal music. "Don Giovanni," properly done, ought never to fail in touching the heart and waking unlimited admiration.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Nov. 28.--Sebastian Beck, a German shoe-maker, has returned to St. Louis after a term of seven years spent among the savages. He says he started for San Francisco from here seven years ago, and when camped somewhere ...
PARIS, Nov. 28.--The decree removing the prohibition of the importation of American pork into France, which was adopted in the Cabinet Council yesterday, is published in the Official Gazette to-day.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., Nov. 28.--Notice has been given that the State Board of Claims will hold an adjourned session in Buffalo, beginning Dec. 4. The board is Composed of the Hon. Lyman H. Northrup, presiding, and the Hons. George M. Beebe and Henry F. Allen, associates.

CHICAGO, Nov. 28.--Serious rumors are afloat that trouble has arisen among the managers of the Illinois Central Railroad, and it is alleged that the dissensions are such that a decided change in the officers will be soon announced.

The Grand Jury of the Court of General Sessions visited the institutions in charge of the Commissioners of Charities and Correction on Blackwell's and Ward's Islands yesterday, and made an inspection for the purpose of satisfying itself as to whether there is any abuse which demands attention.

There was no busier place in New-York yesterday than Washington Market, where the great annual purchase of the vain and self-important turkey was in progress. The turkey is vain only when subjectively considered; objectively he is not vain.
Steps are being taken to organize an International Bi-metallic Monetary Association, and a prospectus has been issued, bearing the signatures of U.S. Grant, Franklin Edson, A.A. Low, ...
LANCASTER, Ky., Nov. 28.--Ex-Judge George Denny, Jr., late this afternoon shot and killed James H. Anderson in the hallway leading to the former's law office.
MONTREAL, Quebec, Nov. 28.--Two hundred ship laborers, brought here by the Alian Company in the Spring, have gone to Liverpool for the Winter.

Capt. Morton, of the steam-ship Minerva, which arrived yesterday from Liverpool, reports that owing to rough weather he was 22 days in making the voyage. On Nov. 17, in latitude 50 and longitude 22 , the vessel was caught in a hurricane, which came from the north-west and south-west and continued for 12 hours.
AUBURN, N.Y., Nov. 28.--The decomposed remains of Daniel Welch have been found in his house at Union Springs. He has been dead 10 days.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Nov. 28.--At a meeting of the Trustees of the Agricultural College at Ames yesterday President Welch was removed by a vote of 3 to 2. These voting for removal were Mr. Wright, of Sioux City; Mr. Stryker, of Creston, and Mr. Gratton, of Waukon.
In a letter to the editor of the Philadelphia Press, Mr. BLAINE has announced his views on the question of taxation.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 28.--Peter Legoff, a French sailor, was arraigned before the United States Commissioner here this afternoon on a charge of mutiny on board the American bark Hannah McLeon, in the Bay of Algiers, in July last.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Nov. 28.--Patrick Kelly, Martin Cruse, Luke Horan, and Daniel Walsh, who were arrested in Scranton yesterday by United States Marshal Barring on the charge of passing counterfeit money, had a hearing before United States Commissioner.
OGDEN, Utah, Nov. 23.--A colored boy named Jones, 18 years of age, recently arrested for outraging a little girl 4 years old, was yesterday sentenced to 15 years' imprisonment.
MONTREAL, Nov. 28.--The cigar operatives strike here has ended, the workmen returning on the masters' terms after six months' idleness.
RICHMOND, Va., Nov 28.--A case of interest the tobacco manufacturers of the country was decided this evening by Judge Hughes, of the United States Circuit Court.

CHICAGO, Nov. 28.--George Jumbo and Jumbo George, two Nubians, who have been on exhibition here, while intoxicated created a disturbance at the Keller House, where they were stopping, and succeeded in frightening a number of inmates into the street. They were before a Justice of the Peace to-day and were sentenced to 30 days at Bridewell.

WORCESTER, Mass., Nov. 28.--Shortly after 2 o'clock a disaster occurred to passenger train No. 45, on the Boston, Barre and Gardner Railroad, leaving Winchendon at 12:20, and due in this city at 2:25 P.M.

NEWPORT, R.I., Nov. 28.--A colored girl named Burrell, daughter of C.S. Burrell, (colored,) while on her way home from school last Friday afternoon, was met by a ruffian, who placed one of his arms around her neck and with his disengaged hand cut off one of the braids of her hair.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 28.--The Philadelphia Press of to-morrow morning will contain a letter from the Hon. James G. Blaine to Mr. Charles Emory Smith, editor of the Press, stating Mr. Blaine's objection to the distribution of the surplus revenue of the Federal Government among the States, and proposing instead, it the national ...

MARYSVILLE, Ohio, Nov. 28.--Isaac White, of Pharisburg, Union County, surrendered himself to the authorities to-day, and stated that he had shot and killed David Teats, who resided near that place. The cause of the murder was the undue familiarity of Teats with White's mother.

The recurrence of the peculiar red light after nightfall--first noticed last Saturday evening--for three successive evenings, casts serious doubts on the theory that it is a phenomenon of refraction through watery vapor.
NASHVILLE, Nov. 28.--Information was received by the State Board of Health to-day that there are 15 cases of small-pox at Gadsden, Crockett County.

The funeral of the Rev. John Hall Magowan, late Pastor of the Canal-Street Presbyterian Church, took place yesterday afternoon from the Fifth-Avenue Presbyterian Church. The Rev. Dr. Alexander presided, and the Rev. Dr. John McIntosh, ...

LOCKPORT, N.Y., Nov. 28.--The commission appointed by the Supreme Court to appraise the damages of the Wilmer heirs for land taken by the Central Bridge Company for the piers and approaches of the cantilever bridge across the Niagara made an award to-day in favor of the heirs for $3,500.
After a lingering and troublesome illness for several months. Dr. William B. McGuire died on Monday at his residence, No. 315 East Forty-second-street.

There can be but one opinion as to the conduct of Capt. SLOCUMB, of the Northern Light. Whatever may have been the offense of the unhappy wretch whom he tortured, the fact that SLOCUMB treated him with inhuman barbarity is past contradiction.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 28.--Gen. Sherman was visited at his residence, on Garrison-avenue, last night, by a lunatic named E.R. Buckland, of Mattoon, Ill., who has the Presidential bee in his bonnet, and who claims to have a close acquaintance with all the leading national politicians.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Nov. 28.--Frank Sulzer, a traveling salesman for Jones Co., lumberdealers, of New-York, was found dead at the Grand Hotel to-night. Unopened letters from the firm, dated Nov. 14, were found on his person, and showed that he had not been attending to business for some time. He had been drinking heavily.
SHREVEPORT, La., Nov. 28.--The killing of Bill Owens by Tom Wilson assumes a very ugly aspect. Wilson and Owens were half-brothers and were living with Mrs. Owens and Miss Owens.

Roundsman Reynolds, of the Nineteenth Precinct, was on trial before the Police Commissioners yesterday, charged by Patrolman Lawrence Clarson, of the same precinct, with having collected money from several liquor-dealers in the district, ...

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28, 1883. Upon inquiry it is learned that the letter of William Walter Phelps to ex-Speaker Keifer, relative to a new departure in party methods by Republican Congressmen, was not private. It is expected that all of the correspondence will soon be made public.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 28.--Messrs. Matthews Kirkland, auctioneers, offered for sale to-day at the Exchange Sales-rooms the country seat known as Lyndhurst, the residence of the late Reverdy ...

Mr. Hen Rice, who was discharged from durance on Tuesday by Justice Patterson, after paying back $2,780 to Mr. Bob Solomon, which he had won from him at cards during their return trip from Europe on the Servia, celebrated his escape by "getting himself licked"--in the phraseology of an acquaintance--on the same evening, in a Broadway institution for the discouragement of temperance.
The foot-ball game at the Polo Grounds today between the Yale and Harvard teams will be the last of the intercollegiate series. The kick-off will be at 2:30 o'clock promptly.

CHICAGO, Nov. 29.--In the shipping grade there was a fairly active movement in cattle, and prices were firm and steady. The receipts were larger than any one had expected, but there was a good attendance of Eastern buyers, and after their orders had been filled comparatively few cattle remained.
NEW-ORLEANS, Nov. 29.--The fourth day of the freight handlers' strike has passed off without any exciting incident. The railroads are all bringing in laborers from points in the North and West.,

The foot-ball match between the elevens of Stevens Institute and the Pennsylvania University, on the Cricket Grounds at Hoboken, yesterday, was a short one, but, because the players were so evenly matched, very exciting.
Mrs. Elizabeth Clarkson, widow of the late Thomas Streatfield Clarkson, of Potsdam, by her last will and testament made a bequest for the benefit of Trinity Church, Potsdam, for church ...

CLEVELAND, Nov. 29.--The thing to be done just now in the fight against the re-election of Mr. Pendleton to the Senate and the starting of Henry B. Payne toward the White House, via a United States Senatorship, is to defeat Mr. John G. Thompson's election as Sergeant-at-Arms of the House, and powerful influences are at work to that end.

There was racquet and hand-ball playing all day at Sweeny's court, on East Thirty-fifth-street, near Third-avenue, yesterday. In the afternoon the best players were present to participate in a benefit to Michael Landy.

PARIS, Nov. 29.--A more hopeful feeling prevails here to-day in all circles, and a pacific solution of the questions between France and China is now regarded as possible, inasmuch as England is exercising her influence with both countries in favor of a peaceable settlement of the pending trouble.

Mr. Steele Mackaye's new folding theatre chair, which had its first trial on Monday night at the Union-Square, has thus far caused a good deal of amusement, not unmingled with indignation. The amusement rests with the people who are already seated, and is indulged wholly at the ex pense of those who are about taking their seats.

MACON, Ga., Nov. 29.--A fast mail train from Macon to Savannah ran over Ann Williams and Ed May, both colored, on a bridge near Davisboro, Ga. The bodies were terribly mutilated and thrown from the trestle into the creek.
The Gentlemen's Sons' Association of the Eleventh Ward enjoyed its Thanksgiving banquet last evening at No. 123 Columbia-street.

Much suspicion appears to have been cast in the Caucasian circles of Newport, R.I., upon the affecting tale told by a colored resident, of that town of an outrage committed upon his daughter by a ruffian who cut off one of her braids in the street, and subsequently renewed his attack and cut off the other when she was asleep.
TORONTO, Ontario, Nov. 29.--The Methodist University Commission, a large and influential body of Methodist clergy and laymen, has been in session here for two days.

Peter McKnight, tavern-keeper, of No. 1,103 Buttonwood-street, sailed on Saturday morning for London, England, to give his testimony on behalf of Patrick O'Donnell, whose case will be called for trial by Judge Denman on Friday, the 30th instant.

WORCESTER, Mass., Nov. 29.--The persons who were injured by the accident on the Boston, Barre and Gardner Railroad yesterday are all in a fair way to recover, except Mrs. Amasa G. Davis, of Hubbardston, whose spine is fractured, Nothing new has been developed regarding the cause of the disaster.
HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Nov. 29.--An order has been promulgated by the Brigade Office here abolishing the sale of intoxicating liquors at all military canteens.
A recent addition to the treasures of the National Museum at Washington consists of a technological collection of Sevres porcelain, the gift of the French Government.

BALTIMORE, Md., Nov. 29.--At the session of the Grand Commandery Knights of Pythias of Maryland to-night the following officers were elected: W.A. Hanway, G.C.; John S. Tyson, D.G.C.; C.C. Isaacs, G.C.; Charles W. Hatter, G.C.G.; C.A.J. Kahler, G.S.W., and Frank Hop kins, G.J.W.

PARIS, Nov. 29.--In the billiard contest to-night Vignaux scored 600 in 13 innings and Schaefer 163 in 12 innings. The only good run made by Schaefer was one of 75. The total scores for the four nights are: Vignaux, 2,400; Schaefer, 1,900.

The foot-ball season closed yesterday. Yalensians and the friends of Yale think it closed brilliantly. Harvard admirers think now it would have been more brilliant had it closed on Wednesday. The reason for the difference of opinion lies in the fact that the 11 men representing Yale defeated the 11 men representing Harvard by a score of 23 to 2.

The old envelope game of the little gilt paper boxes containing crisp new greenbacks, which has been played at every country fair and race meeting during the last 10 years, would seem to be rather stale for New-York.

M. Naundorff, who, as the son of the pretended Dauphin, son of Louis XVI. and Marie Antoinette, laid claim to have his title and rights recognized in the French courts about 10 years since, died lately at Breda, in Holland, in such distressed circumstances that his body was placed in a pauper's coffin and buried at the expense of a a charitable society.

The little schooner Santa Rosa arrived in port from Santa Barbara a few days ago. She comes up to this city twice a year to secure provisions, clothing, lumber, , for use on Santa Rosa Island, being owned by the great sheep-raiser, A.P. Moore, who owns the island and the 80,000 sheep that exist upon it.

It is hazardous business to deal in superlatives and comparisons when speaking of the Illustrated magazines, so highly excellent are they all and so progressive in their excellence; but the December number of Harper, made distinctively and worthily a Christmas number, tempts one to draw freely on the stock of both.
SEA SIDE PARK, N.J., Nov. 29.--A close and interesting pigeon-match was shot near Pleasantville this afternoon between William Griswold, of New-York, and Adolph Austin, of Philadelphia.
Daniel Boland, a stove-dealer of No. 310 Hudson-street, was complainant yesterday at the Jefferson Market Police Court against William Thompson, a young laborer of No. 17 Beachstreet.

The resignations of Marcus Beach and Simeon H. Smith from the Jersey City Board of Finance were placed in the hands of Mayor Taussig yesterday. The date at which the resignations are to take effect has not been made known yet, but it is understood that both the gentlemen decline to serve in the board after Dec. 1.

The annual report of the Chief of the Bureau of Statistics shows that the total foreign commerce for the fiscal year ending with June 30, 1883, was larger than for any previous year in the history of the country, having reached the imposing amount of $1,547,020,316--in round numbers a billion and a half.
Protection is now working out its own ruin visibly before the eyes or all people, as it has been doing any time during the last five years, though invisibly to the great majority.
DUBLIN, Nov 29.--Mr. Matthews, editor of the Tyrone Courier has been arrested on the charge of inciting the Orangemen against the Nationals.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29.--Gen. Rosecrans, member of Congress from San Francisco, has prepared the following measure, which he will introduce in the House at the earliest possible opportunity after its organization:

A lady mounted on a spirited horse rode out of Central Park at One hundred and Tenthstreet yesterday morning. While crossing the street her horse took fright and started off up Seventh-avenue at full speed.
Three-or-four years ago the "dome" of a Court-house in Illinois fell in with a great crash, and with fatal results, as we remember, to several workmen.

TORONTO, Ontario, Nov. 29.--A cable message from London to the Globe says: "Donald Smith has issued a circular to the shareholders of the Hudson Bay Company stating that as the Directors refused to inquire into charges against...

VARNER, Ark., Nov. 29.--After a quarrel to-day Frank Williams blew his wife's brains out by firing the contents of both barrels of a shot-gun into her head and then escaped. A large crowd is is pursuit of the murderer.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Nov. 29.--Frederick Armitage, of Orange, was shot dead this morning by the accidental discharge of C.A. Bullard's double-bareled gun while fox-hunting. Two shots had been fired at a fox and both men were awaiting the animal's approach with cocked guns when Bullard, in removing his gloves, let his gun slip and the contents of both barrels entered Armitage's head, killing him instantly. He leaves a widow and two children.

MACON, Ga., Nov. 29.--Two Georgia preachere, the Rev. J.W.P. Fackler and the Rev. E.S. V. Briant, both of the Baptist church, have made themselves subjects of comment. The case against the Rev. Mr. Fackler has been brought up by a suit for divorce preferred against him by his wife, who accuses him of drunkenness, infidelity, and a whole list of moral delinquenoies.

Thanksgiving Day was observed very generally in this City and its vicinity according to time-honored customs. The central idea of Thanksgiving Day appears, in spite of more serious things, to be dinner.
What would you say if that adroit diplomatist, the Marquis Tseng, turned out to be a simple Jesuit?

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29.--While Lieut. Garlington was riding a vicious horse in the park at the Soldiers' Home last evening, the horse ran agaiast a tree and fell, breaking the saddle-girth and one stirrup-strap, Lieut. Garlington's head received two severe cuts and his knee-cap was fractured. He was taken to the residence of the Governor of the Home, Gen. Sturgis, where he received medical attention, and where he now is. He is comfortable to-night.

SANDWICH, Mass., Nov. 29.--The schooner Albus, of Bangor, with a heavy cargo of lumber for Plymouth, sprung a leak at midnight last night while off Monument Point. Capt. Clay and the crew abandoned her this morning and landed safely here. Her cargo will probably be a total loss.
SPARTA, Ga., Nov. 29.--William Smith, who was to be hanged to-morrow for a series of heinous outreges, has succeeded in having his case carried to the Supreme Court.
Capt. Drumbeck, of the British tramp steamer Bell Rock, which arrived in this port, from Honolulu, on Monday night, has managed to get himself into a serious difficulty.

The solemn mass and reinterment of the remains of Fathers Lafont, Aubril, and Barbier, of the Order of Father of Mercy, attracted a very large number of persons to the Church of St. Francis de Sales, in Broadway, Brooklyn, yesterday morning.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Nov. 29.--Benjamin Albertson, of this place, has made application to Chancellor Runyon for the appointment of a receiver for the firm of J.C. Farr Co., the owners of a large saw mill and sash and blind manufactory here.

Many persons were unable to get into Plymouth Church yesterday morning. Upon the preach er's platform stood a tall basket filled with apples, oranges, pink, red, and yellow roses, crimson carnations, calla lilies, Autumn leaves, and ferns, and ornamented as to the edges and handle with purple and green grapes, ears of corn, and smilax.
The death of Gustavus Adolphus will be commemorated here to-day, Nov. 6, in the timehonored manner, with singing at the Gustavian ...

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29.--The Arlington Hotel was crowded to-night with Virginians--Republicans and White Readjusters--among the many being Gen. Mahone, Senator Riddleberger, the Hon. John S. Wise, Col. A.W. Jones, Gen. Steth Bolling, Attorney-General Blair, Asa Rogers, Jr., Auditor S. Brown Allen, Col. James D. Brady, R.T. Habard, and James G. Browning.

The Democratic journals and the leaders of the party are agreed in regarding the Speakership contest as a preliminary to the Presidential canvass of next year. On the one hand, Mr. CARLISLE'S friends say that if the party expect to win, it must make some show of having convictions on the only really important question before the people.
BERLIN, Ontario, Nov. 29.--Mrs. Bossenberger, age 25, died this afternoon from the effects of chloroform administered by Dr. Mylins for the painless extraction of teeth.

HAVANA, Nov. 29.--Gen. Badeau, United States Consul-General, has returned here from the United States and resumed his official duties. Mr. Joseph Springer, who has performed the duties of Consul-General during Gen. Badeau's absence, will take a furlough on Saturday next.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Nov. 29.--A skiff containing nine railroad hands, who had been employed on the Little Rock Railroad, while crossing the river this morning in a fog struck a coal-fleet above the mouth of Wolf River and capsized.

William Fraser, who was shot last Sunday night at a christening party at his house, No. 149 Mill-street, Peterson, N.J., by John Walker, died at the Ladies' Hospital in that city yesterday morning at 2:30, in great agony, from his wound. On Wednesday night about 9 o'clock it became apparent that his end was drawing near, and his wife and child and aged mother were sent for.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 29.--There has been added to the laboratory of Princeton College a large diffraction grating for stereoscopic work on the sun. The grating was invented by Prof. Roland, of the Johns Hopkins University.

The new number of Fors Clavigera, which is published to-day, contains Mr. Ruskin's impressions during a recent visit to Scott's country, and, in particular, a close description of Ashestiel, the house where Scott lived before moving to Abbotsford, and where the three Great poems were written and "Waverley" begun.
Mr. Johnson's books were in perfect shape at the time of his death and the rumor that he was a defaulter was promptly contradicted by his friends.
TORONTO, Ontario, Nov. 29.--During a quarrel here to-day a 13-year-old boy named John Irwin stabbed his mother in the forehead with a fork. The woman will probably die.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Nov. 29.--William T. McMillian, an old man, was knocked down and run over here to-day by a street car and instantly killed. The car was on a down grade and rounding a curve when the accident occurred. The driver and conductor were arrested.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 29.--Ex-Judge George Denny, Jr., who killed James H. Anderson at Lancaster yesterday after a most desperate hand-to-hand fight, is one of the most prominent Republicans in Kentucky, and a young man of fine character. Garrard County, where the tragedy occurred, is noted for its murders.
LYNCHBURG, Va., Nov. 29.--A desperate roadside encounter occurred last evening in Bedford County, 28 miles south of Liberty, between three well-known citizens of that county.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29.--James G. Blaine's proposition to distribute among the States and Territories the money received from the tax on spirituous and malt liquors has not attracted ...

M. Paul de Remusat, who has devoted his intellectual life to the construction of a literary monument to the memory of Mme. de Remusat, his grandmother, and M. Charles de Remusat, his father, has just issued another volume, (Messrs. Calmann Levy.) After having published his ...

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29.--Another day of the Speakership contest does not make any great change in the situation. Mr. Carlisle is everywhere except in the apartments of Mr. Randall, and is admitted to be far in advance of his competitors for the Speaker's chair.
If the fate of the birds of California depended on the result of a public trial, a most formidable indictment could be found against them.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29.--Commissioner Dudley has written a letter to Secretary Teller asking for a construction of the law regulating fees of pension attorneys, which will, if approved by the Secretary, strike at the worst feature of the present outrages practiced upon claimants.

"When you get to the top of the hill, turn to the left and keep going till you come to a large house with a hedge of arbor-vitae in front of it," said the wife of the druggist near the little railway station at Fordham. "That's where John B. Haskin lives."
OTTAWA, Ontario, Nov. 29.--Sir Charles Tupper, High Commissioner at London, England, yesterday cabled to the Department of Marine and Fisheries that the master, mate, and cook of the brigadtine.
Gen. George B. Carse, widely known in political and military circles throughout the country, died yesterday afternoon at the house of Mrs. Martin, on Barclay-street, above Sixth.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Nov. 29.--A terrible accident occurred near here last evening. Henry Costello and his aged mother were driving home to spend Thanksgiving Day, when their vehicle upset over an embankment and both were killed.

LONDON, Nov. 13.--Diplomacy on its travels is once more the fashion of the day. It is really surprising how completely modern facilities of locomotion have altered the method of intercommunication for those who "make history."

The Rev. Dr. John Hall preached to a large congregation in the Fitth-Avenue Presbyterian Church yesterday morning from the text, Second Thessalonians, v., 18: "In everything give thanks; for this is the will of God, in Jesus Christ concerning you."
BOSTON, Mass., Nov. 29.--Several interesting bicycle-races occurred at the new American Institute Rink to-day.
GLOUCESTER, Mass., Nov. 29.--Fears are entertained for the safety of six vessels of the fishing fleet, now overdue, viz.: The schooners Hattie ...
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29.--The Clerk of the House of Representatives has completed an unofficial but perfect roll of the new House.

About half an hour after the close of the performance at the Windsor Theatre last night Arthur McKenzie, an actor, stepped into the theatre to see a friend, Thomas O'Connor, an employe. Not finding him, he stepped into the lobby, noticing a strong smell of smoke, and discovered that a fire had broken, out in the region of the stage, probably in the dressing-rooms.

Thirty-four athletic young men, dressed in the handsome red, white, and blue uniform of the American Athletic Club, gathered in front of Pettit's Hotel, at Jamaica. Long Island, at 11 o'clock yesterday morning and shivered in the cold wind, while Arthur S. Oake, the club photographer, adjusted his camera.

The Windsor Theatre, which was called the Stadt Theatre until it was rented to John A. Stevens a few years ago and given up to combinations, had the largest seating capacity of any of the old places of amusement in the City. It was first opened in 1864, and was a very large building, with four or five galleries, and would hold over 3,000 people.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Nov. 29.--In the month of April, 1882, Capt. Roach, of Yarmouth, master of the bark Brazil, succeeded in saving the crew of the American schooner Nellie Bell, and it is now announced that the American Government has had prepared a gold watch valued at $100 for presentation to him. Capt. Roach, however, found a watery grave on a voyage from Cape Breton to Yarmouth a month ago.
The following letter from Gen. Grant was read at the meeting of the Arbitration League in Philadelphia, on Tuesday:

At a recent meeting of the California Academy of-Sciences, held at San Francisco, Eusebio Molera, a graduate of the University of Madrid, who has distinguished himself by his antiquarian researches, read a paper on the Aztec Calendar, or Mexican calendar stone, from which an insight has been obtained to the extent of the astronomical knowledge of the Aztecs.
PERU, Ind., Nov. 29.--B.F. Dow Co. manufacturers of agricultural implements, have made an assignment to James G. Blythe, Receiver. Their liabilities are $150,000, and their assets $300,000.

The quiet hamlet of Woodside, Long Island, was the scene yesterday morning, from midnight until 8 o'clock, of more deviltry and carousing than, in all probability, its inhabitants ever witnessed before.

The air on the mountains back of Orange, N.J., was crisp and bracing yesterday. The mercury went below the freezing point on Wednesday night, and, although the sun was bright and the skies were clear, the ice on the shallow pools by the roadside did not melt.

Dispatches from Baltimore, Philadelphia, Boston, Petersburg, Va., Princeton, N.J., Augusta, Ga., New-Orleans, La., and other places state that the day was generally observed as a holiday, business being suspended. Provision was made for the poor, and all who applied were bountifully supplied.

CLARKSBURG, West Va., Nov. 29.--In the Kinney murder trial at West Union to-day, in which William Kinney and "Big Bill" Kinney are charged with the murder of Barney Doyle and his two daughters on April 4 last, the confession of William kinney, made to Prosecuting Attorney ...
LONDON, Nov. 29.--It is stated that Prof. Nordenskjold, the Swedish arctic explorer, is planning an expedition to the south pole to be carried out in 1885.
Capt. Teachner, of the Liberian bark Criterion, which arrived yesterday from London, reports having had a very stormy passage. Heavy westerly gales prevailed until 60 west longitude was passed.

A party of Mormon misssionaries from Utah have been working actively for the last six months in the western counties, and I regret to hear that they have induced quite a large number of persons in the rural districts to join their egregious body.
TORONTO, Ontario, Nov. 29.--The Globe announces this morning that a conference has been arranged between Attorney-General Mo watt, of Ontario, and Mr. Miller, Attorney-General ...
CAIRO, Nov. 29.--Of 600 gendarmes who left Cairo for Suakim on Wednesday, 268 deserted on the railway journey from Cairo to Suez.

Fully 5,000 persons witnessed the races at Brighton Beach yesterday. The first race was for beaten horses; three-quarters of a mile. Pools-- Riddle, $200; Sugar Plum, $80; Gyantwa and Bob Johnson, $40 each; the field, $40.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 29.--The annual meeting of the Pennsylvania Peace Society was held in this city to-day. The annual report of the Executive Committee reviewed the work of the year and cited a number of cases in which national difficulties had been settled by arbitration.

Charles Pepperling, aged 19, a switchman of the Hudson River Railroad, was taken before Justice Patterson, at the Jefferson Market Police Court, late Wednesday afternoon, by Officer Parker, of the West Thirty-seventh-street squad, on the complaint of Dennis Darneher, of No. 441 West ...

Mr. Theodore Thomas, the distinguished orchestral leader, has given a few concerts in the South since he became a prominent factor in the development of musical taste, but they have indeed been few and have generally been attended with pecuniary loss.

Improbable as Wequetequock may seem, it is, nevertheless, a real Connecticut town, Last Fall there was a "revival" in Wequetequock, and a large number of women were "converted." Thereupon they fixed covetous glances upon the village school-house.
On his way to the carriage last night from the Grand Hotel the Hon. Joe Blackburn, of Lexington, Ky., stopped long enough to exchange a few words.

The members of the Cartaret Gun Club secured appetites for their dinners yesterday by shooting pigeons in their handsome park in the suburbs of Bergen Point, N.J. The crisp, keen air and bright sunshine added zest to the sport, and six handicap sweepstakes were contested.

The flames which broke out at 2:15 yesterday morning in the macaroni factory of Motto, Novelli Co., at No. 51 Crosby-street, was not extin guished until the building had been gutted and its contents ruined by fire and water. The loss on the building, machinery, and stock is estimated at $15,000.

MONTREAL, Nov. 29.--Notwithstanding the scheeming of the Canadian Pacific Railway Company to bull prices by buying up their own stock it shows a heavy decline on the local market. It declined yesterday from 58 to 57.
At the American Institute Fair to-day every lady purchasing a ticket of admission will be presented with a handsome memento. The fair closes to-morrow night.

Jupiter is morning star, December being the last month in which he will play this part for some time to come, for his increasing splendor and the early hour of his rising are sure indications that he is near opposition.
CAIRO, Ill., Nov. 29.--The engineers of the Texas and St. Louis Narrow Gauge Road refuse to move trains until they are paid their arrears of wages.

TOPEKA, Kan., Nov. 29.--Judge McCreary, of the United States Circuit Court, to-day delivered a decision in the St. Joseph and Western Railroad case, granting the petition of the plaintiffs by ordering the appointment of a Receiver.

MONTREAL, Quebec, Nov, 29.--A reaction set in in the stock market this afternoon, and the market settled down at the close with a falling off in prices and a decidedly easier tone. The shrinkage in leading stocks to-day as compared with the corresponding day last year is estimated at $4,400,000, and the whole list is not included.

BANKOK, Siam, Sept. 24.--The three days' festival is over at last, and the King of Siam's thirtieth birthday has undoubtedly been well celebrated. To say that it rained on the night of the ball would be needless, for when does it not rain on a day of public rejoicing? But, although ...
The Connecticut military organizations taking part in Monday's celebration of the centenary of Evacuation Day in New-York all returned yesterday.
The first noteworthy appearance of the steam whistle as an exponent of patriotism occurred at midnight on the hundredth anniversary of our Declaration of Independence.
Dr. Charles S. Hastings, formerly of this city, son of Dr. P.M. Hastings, has accepted an appointment to the chair of physics in the (Yale) Sheffield Scientific School.

All over the Pacific coast are to be found indelible traces of a long-forgotten and prehistoric race. While the investigation has been of but comparatively recent date, still enough has been discovered to show that an almost limitless field has been so far only dipped into in a few places most easy of access to the explorer.
