WASHINGTON, Nov. 29.--W.P. Canaday, of Wilmington, N.C., a member of the Republican National Committee from North Carolina, is a candidate for Sergeant-at-Arms of the Senate. He has many friends, and his chances are believed to be excellent. Col. George W. Hooker, who was Sergeant-at-Arms of the last House, is willing and anxious to fill the same position in the next Senate.

BOSTON, Mass., Nov. 29.--The Rev. Warren H. Cudworth, for many years the Pastor of the Unitarian Church in East Boston, and one of the most beloved men in his community, died suddenly in the pulpit today from apoplexy while offering prayer. It was at a union service in the orthodox Congregational Church.

The three Commissioners of the District of Columbia addressed to the PostmasterGeneral, two or three weeks ago, a letter in which they directed his attention to the publication of lottery advertisements in the newspapers of the District and asked him to consider the propriety of securing the enactment of a law excluding Washington news- ...

If a Southern Democrat is not a Democrat of equal standing in the party with Northern Democrats, that ends it. If Domocrats of the North will not vote the ticket because a Southern man is put on it, we have no respect for their democracy.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Nov. 29.--The Customs Department has issued new regulations for the governing of goods in transit in the United States from one Canadian port to another. These goods hereafter will be shipped in bonded and sealed cars. Formerly they were under United States regulations.
AUGUSTA, Ga., Nov. 29.--Hannan Coleman, colored, who lived near Hamburg, S.C., fell in the fire in a fit to-day and was burned to death.

That resident of the Fifth and Eighth Wards, were he Protestant or Democrat, or of whatever color, nationality, religion, politics, sex, age, taste, weight, or condition of servitude, who did not recognize the supremacy of the original Hound Guards as the one thing above all others to be thankful for yesterday, would be looked upon as little better than a horse-thief.
Venus is evening star and wins the place of honor as the most interesting member of the solar family during the month.

In the Government improvements at the mouth of the Willamette a dam was built across Pearcy's slough, which runs nearly parallel with the Columbia, and is separated from it by a rolling, sandy piece of land.

Deputy Coroner Donlin made an autopsy on the body of Jay Humphreys yesterday. He found that the young man's death was caused by failure of the heart, due to oedema of the lungs and congestion of the kidneys--in simple words, acute alcoholism.
Daniel Toffey Co.'s meat stand at Nos. 18 and 19 Produce-avenue, West Washington Market, was burned down yesterday, and several other stands were damaged.
B.H. and H.B. Luther, of Paradise, left last night for Rochester, N.Y., to visit their mother, Mrs. W.S. Luther. The former is accompanied by his wife and children.

LONDON, Nov. 29.--The Fifeshire Journal says: "Some time ago, Earl Selborne, the Lord High Chancellor. wrote a letter to a student stating that there was no law by which Mr. Lowell could act as Lord Rector of St. Andrew's University.
A curious scene lately occurred at St. George's, Hanover-square. A couple were about to be united in the bonds of holy matrimony, but as the lady had been defendant in a divorce suit, ...

PORTLAND, Me., Nov. 30.--The Press will publish to-morrow an abstract from Bank Examiner Richard's forthcoming report. The present number of savings banks in Maine is 54, and the depositors number 101,822. The total deposits amount to $31,371,868. The undivided profits on Nov, l were $860,981.

MONTREAL, Quebec, Nov. 30.--St. Andrew's Day was celebrated here to-day by the Caledonian and St. Andrew's Societies holding their annual meetings, and the members of the latter association partaking of a banquet in St. Lawrence Hall in the evening.

Mr. Frederick W. Vanderbilt has sold his residence, No. 693 Fifth-avenue, for $150,000, the sale having been made through his broker, Mr. Charles MacRae. Mr. Vanderbilt will at once remoive to the residence at Fifth-avenue and Fortieth-street, formerly occupied by his father. The change is made because the latter residence is more commodious and better adopted to his ideas of "the proper thing" in the way of a residence.

In 1880 500 Messina quail were planted in this vicinity. They were purchased by a gentleman interested in sporting and at an expense of 42 cents a bird. Add to this the cost of planting them and you will see it was quite expensive. The birds were planed in fields in the vicinity.
WORCESTER, Mass., Nov. 30.--John Denham, 35 years of age, of Warren, was ran over by an express train on the Boston and Albany Railroad yesterday and instantly killed.

Robert De Witt, of No. 420 Second-avenue, is lying in Bellevne Hospital with a pistol-shot wound in the left groin, inflicted by John Hughes, of No. 300 East Thirty-fourth-street. The affray in which De Witt obtained his wound was the end of a dispute which began in a low sporting-house at Woodside, Long Island, where Hughes and De Witt went to attend the Custy-Sweeny prize-fight.

There was a very narrow escape from what might easily have proved a fatal and serious accident to one of the shuttle trains on the spur track of the elevated road between the City Hall and Chatham-square stations yesterday morning.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Nov. 30.--John Loyd, editor of the Favetteville Express, was assaulted this evening by Samuel Hill because of an article which appeared in the Express. Hill struck Loyd a terrible blow with a club, knocking him down, and it is feared his skull is fractured.

MONTREAL, Nov. 30.--A French paper here says: "The Hon. Mr. Chapleau will be impeached at the next session of Parliament for his dealings while leader of the local Government. The Hon. Edward Blake and P.B. Casgrain, member of Parliament, will be his accusers on behalf of this province."

ASSBURY PARK, N.J., Nov. 30.--This village has seldom been in a state of greater excitement than it is at present. The cause of the agitation is a murderous affray which occured a mile out of town, in the village of West Asbury, during a Thamksgivinng Day jollification.

Four engines continues to play all day yesterday on the burning debris at the Windsor Theatre fire. In front, in the Bowery, the eastern sidewalk was crowded with hose, broken glass, twisted and bent rods, pipes, and fragments of signs and shutters. At the theatre entrance the glass-lettered sign "Windsor Theatre" swung back and forth in the breeze, the chandeller in the ...

The Rev. Father Joseph F. Mendel, priest of the Roman Catholic parish at Montclair, was arraigned in Judge McCarter's court, Newark, yesterday, on a charge of having assaulted John McCarthy within the church walls at a mass on the ...

Protectionist journals are a good deal exer cised ever the statements put forth by agents of cotton mills. One of these agents stated the other day that the value of the products of the cotton mills of Canada was $10,200,000 per annum, and ...

British schooner Howard came in yesterday with one of Howard Knolton's deers on board, which had been picked up about five miles out at sea. The animal escaped from the garden on Peak's Island last Summer and had not been seen since, probably having kept in the woods at the lower end of the island

NEW-HAVEN, Nov. 30.--The resignation of Dr. Arthur B. Coffin as resident physician at the New-Haven Hospital has been tendered, to take effect to-morrow. He has accepted the position of resident surgeon in Mount Sinal Hospital, NewYork. Dr. Morton, of New-York, a graduate of the Long Island College Hospital, will occupy the position here made vacant by Dr. Coffin.
LOUISVILLE, Nov. 30.--The trial of Judge Denny for the killing of Anderson at Lancaster was called to-day, but will probably not be held until next week. Denny is still in the Sheriff's custody.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Nov. 30.--An Italian laborer, Nichola Pistoia, employed at the excavations being made on the Naugatuck Railroad, went to New-York Wednesday morning and sent a draft for $109 to his wife and five children in Italy.

For several days past a striking and beautiful phenomenon has accompanied the sunset, and excited much comment. It is a blood-red coloring of the western sky 10 or 12 degrees high, and appears just after sunset, when the east is quite dark. Sunday night many persons supposed there was a large fire in the suburbs, and Monday evening several persons went some distance out Hammondstreet to ascertain where the blaze was.
The Montreal (Canada) Herald has reduced its price from 3 cents to 1 cent per copy.

The complaint in the suit of the Health Department against Jasmes Purdon and others, was dismissed by Judge O'Gorman, in the Superior Court, Special Term, yesterday. The defendants in this suit were the consignees and auctioneers of a large quantity of tea known as Pingsuey tea, which the Health Department asserted was adulterated and therefore unfit for use as food.

Ty Ty, Ga., Nov. 30.--Ambrose West, a coal-black negro, aged 18 years, died for murder to-day on a scaffold erected in an open field near Isabella, Worth County, under the most tragic circumstances ever incident to an execution in the State. Fully 1,200 spectators, mostly negroes, witnesses the hideous work. The prisoner was driven...

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 30.--In the Goerson murder trial, which has been in progress nearly two weeks, Mrs. A. Getz to-day testified that about March 1 she saw the prisoner's wife pull out of her pocket a bottle on which there was a label containing a picture of a skull and cross-bones. Dr. Goersen came in and took the bottle away from her.

PARIS, Nov. 30.--Admiral Courbet, commanding the French forces in Tonquin, has telegraphed to Admiral Peyron, Minister of Marine, as follows, dating his dispatch Ha-Noi, Nov. 23: "I am continuing my preparations for an advance."

CONCORD, N.H., Nov. 30.--Attorney-General Tappan returned from Laconia this evening, where he has been engaged since Monday investigating the circumstances connected with the triple murder and arson that occurred there on Saturday and Sunday.

NEWRY, Ireland, Nov. 30.--At a meeting of the National League, in this city yesterday, resolutions were passed condemning the action of the Government in prohibiting the proposed meeting of the Nationalists on Sunday, and declaring that they will assemble on Sunday morning, when, after the magistrate shall have read the proclamation, they will proceed to Warren Point and hold their meeting. The Orangemen have decided that.
SELMA, Ala., Nov. 30.--E.K. Marshall, the stage machinist of the Madison-Square "Rajah" company, was accidentally killed here this morning.

ALBANY, Nov. 30.--Wheeler H. Peckham was appointed to-night District Attorney of NewYork. It is understood that he was championed by Mr. Manning and Mr. Rufus W. Peckham, the brother of the appointee. The number of applicants for the place was very large, and the Governor has been subject to a very large amount of pressure.
VIENNA, Nov. 30.--It is stated that the Ulema of Mecca have formally condemned El Mahdi as an impostor.
CINCINNATI, Nov. 30.--Conductor Swift and Driver John Cosgrove, of Car No. 22, on the Gilbert-Avenue Line, were both shot by a half-drunken passenger at an early hour this morning.

ALBANY, Nov. 30.--The canals will be officially closed at midnight to-morrow night. The mild weather makes it certain that the number of vessels shut in by ice will be much smaller than any season for years past. Loaded boats left Buffalo as late as Sunday and Monday last, and the probability is all will get through.
CINCINNATI, Ohio, Nov. 30.--Joseph Jefferson arrived here last night. His voice has returned, and he is in a fair was toward recovering its full use.

The investigation of the charges preferred against Bowery and Chatham-street museums by Elbridge T. Gerry was continued yesterday by Mayor Edson. On statements presented the Mayor refused to renew tho license of the Bowery Garden, at Nos. 113 and 113 Bowery.
MONTREAL Quebec, Nov. 30.--The consecration of Dean Baldwin as Bishop of Huron took place in Christ Church Cathedral here to-day.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30.--Mr. R.T. Merrick, of counsel for the Government in the proceedings against ex-Senator Spencer, for contempt of court, to-day filed his interrogatories addressed to the defendant with the Clerk of the Court.

A short time ago Lawrence Feeney, a man about 70 years of age, living at Peekskill, horribly mutilated himself with a razor, and he was in the act of cutting his throat when he was found and secured. Since that time he has been out of his mind, and several times he threatened to take his life.

LANCASTER, Penn., Nov. 30.--A mortgage for $10,000,000 in favor of the Farmers' Loan and Trust Company by the Bankers and Merchants' Telegraph Company was received at the Recorder's office, in this city to-day.

WARSAW DEPOT, N.Y., Sept. 30.--The will of the late millionaire, Cyrus Jefferson, was admitted to probate to-day at Franklinville, Cattaraugus County.

CHICAGO, Nov. 30.--A special dispatch to the Daily News from Springfield, Ill., says: "The Fort Wayne, Peoria and Galesburg Railway Company was incorporated to-day to operate a road from Fort Wayne, Ind., to Galesburg, Ill."
There is a very general desire in mercantile circles for the passage of a bankrupt act at the approaching session of Congress, but there is not very close agreement as to what that act should be.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30.--Secretary Teller begins his second annual report with the statement that it is believed to be quite possible "with a wise and judicious treatment of the Indian question, to prevent the recurrence of hostilities between the Indian and his white neighbors that have marked nearly every year of our history."

James A. Byrnes, accompanied by a detective and a Police Sergeant, walked into the Coroners' office about noon yesterday and took a seat by the stove. He looked composedly at the dozen prlvileged persons who, attracted by the news of his detention in the morning papers, drooped in to take a look at him.

MILLEDGEVILLE, Ga., Nov. 30.--Twelve years ago Robert Humphreys, of Bartow County, grew jealous of the attentions paid his wife by other men. He watched for criminating evidence without avail.

For four days the detectives and local police officers and constables who are trying to solve the mystery of Phoebe Jane Paullin's murder have been looking for a tall man who went up the Eagle Rock road, on the Orange Mountain, the night she was killed. People who saw him differed in describing the manner in which he was dressed.

On Thursday Officer Cornelius Clark, of Hastings, went to Dobbs Ferry to serve a warrant on John O'Hare for disorderly conduct. He found O'Hare, and they had hot words. O'Hare's friends sided with him, and the words led to blows, in which Clark, getting the worst of it, drew his revolver and used it as a club.

While sitting in a cell of the Raymond-Street Jall, Brooklyn, yesterday morning, Robert Henry, ex-Sexton of Grance Mission Chapel, attempted to commit suicide by cutting his throat with a penknife. Henry was to be taken to Auburn yesterday at 8 A.M., to serve a two years' sentense for ...

PETERSBURG, Va., Nov. 30.--The County Court of Brunswick County has been engaged since Wednesday with the trial of Henry Tucker, a prominent merchant of the county, for the murder of Benjamin Kidd. The murder was caused by the accused man refusing to sell Kidd a drink of whisky. Eminent counsel are engaged on both sides. Owing to the prominence of the parties the trial excites much interest.

The New-York Board of Fire Underwriters held a meeting yesterday to take final action upon the report of the Committee of Surveys defining the characteristics of standard buildings, and fixing the additional insurance charges for deficiencies therin.
A new prospectus of the Century Magazine sets forth the varied and important festures which readers of that perioidcal will enjoy during the coming year.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Nov. 30.--A train on the Little Miami Railroad carrying the Angelo-American Show to Detroit, where it goes into Winter quarters, was wrecked at daylight this morning two miles north of Xenia, and a lively time followed with the wild beasts.
SHREVEPORT, La., Nov. 30.--Sheriff W.P. sample, of Mansfield, has arrested five white men charged with the murder of Judson Scott, at Kingston, in July 1881.

There have been several frightful murders within the last fortnight, and, as might have been expected, much has been said of the torments of remorse which the murderers must now be suffering. In point of fact murderers rarely show the slightest evidence of remorse. Good men suffer from remorse, but murderers, as a rule, do not know what it means.
NYACK, Nov. 30.--J.H. Miller, who lives at New City, about eight miles from this place, has been unfortunate in losses by fire this week.
ALBANY, N.Y., Nov. 30.--The official pluralities of State officers are as follows: Carr, 18,583: Chapin, 16,219; Maxwell, 17,568; O'Brien, 13,330, and Sweet, 18,842.

ALBANY, Nov. 30.--A close friend of Thomas E. Benedict, of Ulster, said to-day that that gentleman had an appointment ae Deputy Controller in his pocket from Controller-elect Chapin. At Controller Davenport's office both Mr. Chapin and Mr. Benedict are expected tomorrow.

BALTIMORE, Md., Nov. 30.--There is great excitement in the north-western section of this city to-day over one of the most shocking tragedies that has ever happened here. Mrs. Laura Riall, the young wife of Mr. John Riall, a travelling salesman, killed her two little children by cutting their wrists with a razor and bleeding them to death.

WORCESTER, Mass., Nov. 30.--The injured by the accident near North Worcester last Wednesday on the Boston, Barry and Gardiner Railway are, with one or two exceptions, doing well. Mrs. A.G. Davis, of Hubbardston, and Mrs. Holland Marble, of Holden, are at the City Hospital, and their recovery is very doubtful.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30.--The President to-day ordered that First Lieut, John M. Porter. Third Cavalry, be dropped from the army as a deserter. Lieut. Porter while on duty as Acting Quartermaster at San Antonio, Texas, defaulted to the amount of about $2,000 and fled into Mexico, about three months ago, since which time ...

NORWALK, Conn., Nov. 30.--The Railroad Commissioners of this State have formally approved the location and layout of the New-York and Connecticut Air Line Railway Company from the New-York State line to the city of New-Haven. The officers say:

ST. JOHN, Newfoundland, Nov. 30.--Placentia advices of to-day report the total loss of the British schooner Royal. Star, with all hands, numbering six, at Gooseberry Island, Placentia Bay. The date of the loss is unknown.
ST. LOUIS, Mo., Nov. 30.--The trial of Frank James on the indictment which charges him with taking part fn the Blue Cut robbery is on call at Independence, Mo., Dec. 4, but will, by agreement ...

PORTLAND, Me., Nov. 30.--Albert Webb Co., flour and grain dealers, No. 249 Commercialstreet, have made an assignment to Judge Nathan Cleaves. A statement of the liabilities of the firm has not yet been given.

LOUISVILLE, Nov, 30.--The Executive Committee of the Kentucky State Distillers' Association has called a meeting of all distillers at Lexington on Dec. 12 to form a pool for controlling the production of Kentucky whisky. There are over 200 distilleries in the State, which, dnring the seasons of 1881 and 1882, produced 32,000,000 gallons per season, running to the full capacity.

GLOUCESTER, Mass., Nov. 30.--A part of the old Murray Church, the first Universalist Church in America, built for the Rev. John Murray in 1780, and used ae a barn upon the Pearce farm since about 1806, was recently blown down, and the remainder has now been removed.
HAVANA, Nov. 30.--The Gazette to-day publishes the decree of the Spanish government abolishing the right of Cuban slaveholders to punish slaves with stocks and chains.

Steaming tumblers of hot Scotch whisky thickly dotted seven long tables in Delmonico's banquet hall last night. They danced and rattled their spoons merrily from time to time, as the enthusiasm of the jovial members of St. Andrew's Society vented itself in justy blows on the edges of the tables.

On Wednesday night Matron Webb, at Police Head-quarters, received charge of Laurentia Hoguet, 17 years old, the daughter of a woman who kept a concert saloon at No. 41 Bowery, which was swept away by the fire Thursday night. The girl said she had run away from her mother to avoid the attentions of her uncle.

The Executive Committee of the County Democracy, at its meeting last evening, Judge Maurice J. Power in the chair, resolved that the County Committee at its meeting next Tuesday evening should be requested to postpone the primary elections for members of the General Committee from Dec. 11 to Jan. 10.

George Flood, the young Englishman, who was arrested on the steamer Wyoming, on her arrival from Liverpool, Wednesday night, was arraigned before United States Commissioner Osborn yesterday, on an application from the British Government for his extradition on a charge of forgery.

PITTSBURGH, Penn., Nov. 30.--Col. Archibald Blakely, a prominent attorney and counsel for Milton Weston, of Chicago, a claimant of the Murraysville natural gas well, was arrested tonight for complicity in the late riot. Four charles were preferred against him, one of murder and three of felonious assault with intent to kill.

At the end of October the telephone was in operation in 36 German towns and cities. By the end of the year it is likely that 40 towns within the Empire will possess the advantages of the telephone, against 21 last year and 7 in October, 1881.

SANDUSKY, Ohio, Nov. 30.--At 5 o'clock this morning a noted desperado named Daniel James, of Castalia, in this county, entered a saloon at that place and provoked a quarrel with Emil Kuhn, of this city, who was attending a dance at that place. James struck at Kunn, and than drew a revolver to shoot him.

DERBY, Nov. 30.--The stockholders of the Derby Railroad, which runs to New-Haven, propose that, in consequence of the many benefits derived by that city, a part at least of its indebtedness be canceled.

The examination in the case of Capt. Joshua Slocumb, of the Northern Light, who is charged by his second mate. Henry Arthur Slater, with cruel and inhuman treatment on the voyage from South Africa, was continued before United States Commissioner Shields yesterday.
GLASGOW, Nov. 30.--The liabilities of Dobie Co., ship-builders of Govan, who failed on Tuesday, are 80,000.

PARIS, Nov. 30.--M. de Lesseps has issued a note in which he asserts that the Suez Canal Company can enlarge its canal upon its own land without being under the necessity of asking authority or money of any one.

The Bank Examiner has directed an assessment of 50 per cent. upon the stockholders of the suspended Union National Bank of Rahway. The stockholders have the option of surrending onehalf of theri stock. If the stockholders respond promptly to this demand it is expected that the bank will be reorganized and resume.
Andrew Hood died in the village of Peekskill, Westchester County, in 1864, leaving an estate estimated to be worth $100,000.

Three firemen were stunned, while the fire in the Bowery was raging on Thursday night, by a shock received from stepping on the wire of an electric light. A stronger battery would have killed them. As it was, they were only disabled from duty for half an hour or so at a time when their services were especially needed.

MILWAUKEE, Nov. 30.--D.J. Whittemore, chief enginneer of the Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul Railway, has been nominated for the Presidency of the American Society of Civil Engineers. The position, a purely honorary one, is considered a worthy object of ambition among the most eminent members of the profession of engineering.

LONDON, Nov. 30.--The trial of Patrick O'Donnell for the murder of James Carey was begun at 10 o'clock this morning before Judee George Denman, in the Old Balley Police Conrt. The approaches to the court-room were thronged. No person was admitted without a ticket.

We reached the gates of Yildiz Kiosk. A sentinel advanced toward us. Philippi Effendi leaned toward him, whispered the word Irade, the sentinel respectfully drew back, and by an avenue which, after a hundred yards turns to the right, we entered by a low door Yildiz Kiosk. Philippi Effendi went off for a moment to ask Osman Bey, the Chief Chamberlain, to conduct us to the Marshal's room, and he ushered us thither.
OTTAWA, Ontario, Nov. 30.--British Columbia is threatened with an Indian revolt which, if once started, no force at command at the Indian Department could put down.
Thomas W. Enos, why was arrested on Thursday, Nov. 22, for supposed complicity with Carroll in the coupon frauds at the Controller's office, was yesterday discharged from custody by Recorder Smyth.

WATERBURY, Conn., Nov. 30.--An epidemic has broken out among the dogs here. Attention was first called to the fact about two weeks ago, since which time over 50 canines, from the pet poodle to the valuable pointer, have fallen victims to the disease, which appears to be a sort of catarrh.
There is evidently something wrong either in the atmosphere or the interstellar spaces, or both. On Thanksgiving night a Tribune reporter saw a large comet coming directly at the earth.

SHELBY, Ohio, Nov. 30.--An attempt to arrest four burglars this morning resulted in the shooting of a man named Marshall and a baggagemaster, and the killing of two of the burglars. The other two were arrested. Marshall and the baggage-master were severely wounded, but may recover.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 30.--The committees of the Lehigh and Schuylkill Coal Exchanges met today and decided to make no changes in line and city and harbot prices of coal during the month of December.

In the Court of General Sessions yesterday, before Recoder Smyth the cases of Excise Inspectors Shortell. Alexander McKeever, and Lawrence P. McDonald, charged with violating the excise law by selling liquor on Sunday, came up for trial.

ST. LOUIS. Nov. 30.--The representatives of east bound lines held a meeting this afternoon to discuss the cut-rates made to New-York on passenger traffic by the Indianapolis, Bloomington and Western and Lake Erie and Western.
The following is the correspondence which has passed between Congressman William Walter Phelps and ex-Speaker J. Warren Keifer:

The United States Senate's Committee on Rules is at last making progress in its revision of the code by which the Senate's proceedings have been governed. Some of the changes already agreed upon deserve hearty commendation.

A well-known Harlem builder, Hugh Meehan, is erecting three houses at Nos. 1,693, 1,695, and 1,697 Lexington-avenue. On Thursday afternoon John Williams, 20 years old, was arrested as he was carrying lead pipe across the roofs of these houses in a bag.

The approach of a new year and the consummate excellence of this month's issue make proper and agreeable at this time a few words concerning Harper's Magazine, the prospectus of which for 1884 lies before us. Harper is now somewhat more than 30 years of age, and its career as mere matter of history has become of the first importance to American art as represented in Wood engraving.

CHICAGO, Nov. 30.--Officers of the Illinois central Railroad to-day made no denial of the truth of the dispatch, telegraphed exclusively by THE TIMES' correspondent, relative to the coming changes in the management of the road.

The firemen made serious complaints during the fire of the inconvenience caused by the electric wires, which are strung on short poles along the Bowery and in front of the buildings which were burned. The wires interfered with the raising of ladders, and the firemen were not inclined to meddle to any great extent with the wires for fear of serious injury to themselves.
TRIESTE, Nov. 30.--Two bombs were exploded last night in the yard of the anti-Italian newspaper Tagolatt. The explosion, however, was harmless in its effects.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30.--Civil Service Commissioner Eaton has returned to Washington from a trip to North Carolina and South Carolina, where he has been holding examinations in order that the quotas of employes due to those States in the various departments may be filled.

CHICAGO, Ill, Nov. 30.--Telegrams received here state that the Sault Ste. Marie Canal is frozen over, blocking navigation into Lake Superior. All the regular line propellers got through both ways, but one or two large steam barges were caught and will go into Winter quarters. As marine insurance expired to-day, navigation, except between adjacent ports, is practically closed for the Winter.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Nov. 30.--Herr Lasker arrived here to-day and will remain over to-morrow. He is receiving a good deal of attention from German residents. He goes from here to Washington, where he will familiarize himself with the powers and methods of the American Congress. In an interview, he said the liberals of Germany are free traders.

It is not to be denied that quite a number of the Texas papers are very favorably inclined to "the old ticket." But how the delegation to the National Convention new year will be made up is as problematical as who will be elected Speaker next month. Public sentiment is very far from being harmonious. There is plenty of time though, and sensible Democrats will not lose any sleep over the matter.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30.--Major A.H. Nickerson filed his answer to-day in the suit for divorce brought by Emma C.D. Nickerson, his first wife He makes a general denial of Mrs. Nickerson's allegations, and says that instead of being an affectionate and faithful wife previous to July, 1880, when she left this country, she had been most unkind, and, he had reason to believe, had bestowed her affections upon another man.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30.--Although the Randall men are still hopeful, and say that they will yet win, all the indications point to-night to the election of Mr. Carlisle by a large majority.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Nov. 30.--The work of reducing wages in the iron mills here goes bravely on. Oliver Brothers Phillips have cut down their employee 10 per cent. Mr. Oliver was a prominent member of the Tariff Commission.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 30.--Members of the committee appointed by the last Legislature to investigate the Executive Departments of the State have tried to secure a quorum half a dozen times but without success. They tried again to-day, but only one member. Assemblyman Chapman, of Essex County, was on hand. Hd adjourned the meeting until one week from to-morrow in Jersey City.

BOSTON, Nov. 30.--A cable dispatch was received to-night at the Harvard College Observatory announcing the discovery of a small planet by Palisa at Vienna. Its position on Nov. 28. 13 hours, 20 minutes.
Fire-escapes have been ordered on the Ashland House in Fourth-avenue, by Inspector, Esterbrook.
KEYPORT, N.J., Nov. 30.--During the last week Keyport and its vicinity have been very much excited over numerous robberies.

Joseph B. Sampson, Commissioner of Docks of Long Island City, was arraigned in the Essex Market Police Court yesterday by Sergt. Granger on a charge of insulting ladies in Grand-street. William Corkran, a newspaper reporter, appeared as a witness against the prisoner, and testified that he had seem him grossly insult a lady in front of a window of Ridley's store.

A cripple who says he is Albert Rossmore, of No. 160 Wooster-street, and that he came from Atlanta, Ga., was arrested yesterday by Officer James T. King, of the Broadway Squad. Rossmore was dressed in brown plaid, but he had made himself grotesque by placing a bright blue woolen skull cap on the crown of his derby hat.

MILWAUKEE, Nov. 30.--A sensation has been created in Milwaukee grain-dealers' circles by the intelligence that W.P. McLaren, the head of one of the largest houses in that line of trade in the North-west was about to retire from the business. Inquiry made of Mr. McLaren himself by a reporter to-day confirmed the report.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 30.--The Plate-glass Insurance Company, which was recently prohibited from doing business in Massachusetts, to-day brought suit for damages against the Real Estate Title Insurance Company. The plaintiffs aver that the Title Company made false statements as to the amount and value of the property of the plaintiffs. On the strength of these statements, it is said, the insurance company's license for Massachusetts was revoked.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Nov. 30.--Judge Hoadly returned to his home yesterday, and this morning was early at his law office. His friends remark that he looks grayer than he did six months ago, but the dejection that was observed during the campaign has passed away.

At the Metropolitan Opera-house last night "Rigoletto" was given for the second time. The cast was the same as on the previous occasion with the substitution of Signor Del Puente for Signor Guadagnini in the title role.

BRIDGEPORT, Dec. 1.--The entire interest of Mr. C.K. Garrison in the Howe Machine Company, consisting of 30,391 shares of the 40,000 shares of the entire capital stock of the company, has been sold in three equal lots to John P. Kennedy, Esq., S.G. The shareholders of the Postal Telegraph Company met yesterday and ratified the sale of their property and franchises to the Postal Telegraph and Cable Company. Mr. J.W. Mackey was present at the meeting, and about $15,000,000 was voted in favor of the sale.
MONTREAL, Dec. 1.--In the stock market the week closes dull, and, though inactive, there is a tendency in prices to improve. Bank stocks are firmer, and in most lines there is a fractional advance.

UTICA, N Y., Dec. 1.--Ex-Gov. Seymour was asked to-day his opinion of Mr. Blaine's plan for reducing the Treasury surplus. He said one very serious objection occurred to him, which was the tendency to lavish expenditure and the consequent corruption which it would entail.

DUBLIN, Dec. 1.--Alderman William Meagher, (Parnellite,) was to-day elected Lord Mayor of Dublin. The Liberal and Conservative members of the Corporation abstained from voting.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 1.--Grand Juror Henry W. Painter, of West Haven, who gained a wide notoriety as a member of the jury of inquest in the Jennie Cramer case, says he expects to be taken to jail next week, as he will make no effort to secure bonds in the suit for defamation of character against him.

MILWAUKEE, Dec. 1.--An experimental work has been going on for a short time along the Milwaukee and St. Paul Railroad Branch and the Brandon Branch, about 30 miles in length, the object being to determine whether or not the barbed wire of the fence on either side of the road can be utilized for telegraphic purposes.

BOSTON, Mass., Dec. 1.--The remains of Samuel Pierey, an actor who died in the small-pox hospital at Canterbury a year ago, will be taken up, placed in a sealed metallic coffin, and taken for reinterment to San Francisco, where the deceased belonged.

BOSTON, Mass., Dec. 1.--An attempt was made on Thursday evening to wreck the Washington express on the New-York and New-England Railroad. The train was passing through Walpole at a high rate of speed, when the engineer noticed an obstruction on the track and applied the brakes.

One of the most brilliant weddings of the season took place yesterday afternoon at Calvary Church, at Twenty-first-street and Fourth-avenue. Miss Anna R. Hall, daughter of Valentine Hall, Jr., was married to Mr. Elliott Roosevelt. The Rev. H.Y. Satterlee, Pastor of the church, performed the ceremony, which was after the English fashion.

COLUMBUS, Ga., Nov. 27.--The Talbot County nuptials, which terminated so sadly by the groom, Mr. J.H. Covington, being stricken with small-pox after his return from the honeymoon trip to Louisville, has resulted in the husband's death. The bride is now lying at the point of death from the same disease. Talbot County has been quarantined by surrounding counties.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Dec. 15.--Conductor Swift, who was shot by Henry Shafer on a street car on Walnut Hills yesterday morning, died tonight. Shafer is still in jail, the Judge refusing to admit him to bail until he hears the evidence on Monday next to determine the grade of his offense.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Dec. 1.--James Boyd shot and killed his son Alfred, aged 17 years, late this afternoon, at his home in Cumminsville. Boyd is a huckster, 49 years of age. Returning home this afternoon he found his son playing marbles on the common.

EVANSVILLE, Ind., Nov. 19.--Two large river steamers lay end to end at the wharf in Cincinnati. One was the Paris C. Brown, to sail for New-Orleans on Friday; the other was the Cons. Millar, to sail for New-Orleans on Saturday.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 1.--Matthew Lafferty a workman engaged in making the excavation for the laying of the electric light conduit on Chestnut-street near Broad-street, to-day struck a hard lump of earth which loosened itself from the deposit. Shifting his position, he placed his foot upon the lump, when it crushed in under his weight and a large black toad jumped out.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., Dec. 1.--The official closing of the canal found it free from ice. Some 80 boats are laid up here for the Winter. Not an accident or break has occurred on this section during the season. There were about 6,500 lockages here each way and the season was a prosperous one.

His wife, who called at Police Head-quarters, said that her husband was an instructor in gymnastics at the Hoboken Academy. When he left home he had a considerable sum of money with him.

CHICAGO, Dec. 2.--Cattle, native butchers' stock, including cows, heifers, bulls, and light fleshy steers, was in liberal supply, but as canners are now obliged to look to this class for a large part of their supplies, there proved to be nothing in excess of the demand, and there was a strong market throughout.

CHICAGO, Dec. 2.--The cigar-makers of this city are split into two factions which are hotly at war. The branch known as the Internationals had a meeting this afternoon. No peace was patched up with the Progressives, as the other faction is called, and therefore 1,000 of the Internationals will strike to-morrow morning unless the manufacturers agree to discharge all of the Progressives in their employ.

Mrs. Betsy L. Moody, who lives at Cape Elizabeth, was born Feb. 28, 1782, and is consequently in the one hundred and second year of her age. On Thanksgiving Day she took dinner at the house of her grand-daughter, Mrs. John Brown, No. 33 Ellsworth-street. Four generations were at the table. Mrs. Moody possesses all her faculties in a remarkable degree.

On the 29th day of November, 1854, just 29 years ago this Thanksgiving Day, four men, travelstained and weary from the fatigues of a long, uncomfortable, and uncertain journey, rested from their toils near what is now the intersection of First-street and Kansas-avenue in the city of Topeka.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2.--The report of Postmaster-General Gresham, which will be submitted to Congress to-morrow, shows that the revenues of the Post Office Department for the fiscal year ending June 30 last amounted to $45,508,692.61, and the expenditures to $42,816,700.56, leaving a balance available for outstanding liabilities of $2,691,992.05.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Dec. 2.--Thomas Camp, owner of one of the largest agricultural works in the South, at Covington, in this State, closed out his business yesterday. A weight of unavailable resources caused the trouble. The amount involved is not given, but is large. It is believed he will resume next Spring, after having settled his affairs.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2.--Supervising Inspector-General Dumont, in his annual report, gives the total number of accidents which occurred during the year as 84 and the total loss of life 284, showing a slight increase over the past year.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 2.--President Henry D. Welsh, of the American Steam-ship Company, denies the report that the line will be abandoned. BOSTON, Dec. 2.--The funeral of the late Rev. Warren H. Cudworth took place to-day at the Church of Our Father, East Boston. Although the weather was rainy the attendance very large, including members of the Grand Army, 1,000 strong.

Private advices from Rome state that the Vatican has decided to send Mgr. Sepiacci to the United States as apostolie legate to preside over the labors of the Plenary Council to be held here in 1884.

John Williams, who had been employed as song and dance man at Mike Cleary's, No. 270 Bowery, was charged in the Tombs Police Court yesterday with having broken a plate glass, worth $40, in the saloon window the previous evening.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Nov. 30.--In the District Court this morning, before a full bench, was commenced the hearing in the action brought for the purpose of reviewing, and, if possible, causing the court to reverse the decision of Judge Weland, of the Probate Court, in the matter of the estate of C.C. Washburn.

Two weeks ago the Board of Trade and Transportation, in pursuance of a resolution passed by its Directory, issued and distributed for the signatures of Cincinnati's business firms a memorial to be presented at the next session of Congress advocating the withdrawal from circulation of the trade dollar.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Dec. 2.--As a freight train on the Louisville and Nashville Railroad was about to start for the north this morning the boiler of the locomotive exploded. The engineer was badly scalded and will probably die. The fireman was badly hurt. A man named Allen, who was standing by, was struck on the head by a piece of flying iron and instantly killed.

When the Rev. William Walton, of Brooklyn, preached over the body of Phoebe Jane Paullin in the little Pleasant Valley church between the mountains back of Orange, N.J., he said the murderer might be in the edifice listening to his words.

Under a recent decision of the PostmasterGeneral, articles sent by mail as merchandise or as samples of merchandise are to be rated as mailable matter of the fourth class and charged with postage as much, at the rate of 1 cent for each ounce of fraction thereof, notwithstanding any printing such articles may bear or contain.

The new wing of St. Vincent's Hospital just completed, on West Twelfth-street, near Seventhavenue, will be opened for inspection on Sunday next from 2 to 9 o'clock P.M. The institution is under the charge of the Sisters of Charity, and ...

LONDON, Dec. 3.--The Sheriff will visit O'Donnell in Newgate prison to-morrow and inform him that he is to be hanged on Monday, the 17th inst. All the morning papers approve the verdict. The Times says: "It was impossible for the jury to arrive at any other conclusion.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 3.--L.C. Smith's mustang pony Ned, which defeated James Henderson, the champion five-mile runner of Delaware County, in a 200 yards' running race, at Echo Park, last Tuesday, was to-day distanced in a race of 100 yards by Fred Rogers, of Trenton, the champion of New Jersey. A large number of well-known sporting men were present and much interest was shown in the race.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Dec. 3.--At an early hour this morning the incendiaries who have been operating in this city so boldly for two weeks past changed their base from the west to the east side and fired the sausage factory of Adolph Heller.
Yesterday was the seventeenth and thus far the most uninteresting day of the hearing in the Feuardent-Di Cesnola libel suit, now on trial before Judge Shipman, in the United States District Court.
Somo 60 liquor-dealers of the east side have very recently organized an association under the name of the Liquor Dealers' Protective Union of the Tenth Police Precinct.

Sylvester F. Kneeland, President of the Metropolitan Elevated Railroad Company, was the only witness examined yesterday in the trial of the suit of that company against the Manhattan Railway Company and the New-York Elevated Railroad Company, before Judge Van Brunt, in the Common Pleas, Equity Term.

The first Family Circle Dancing Class ball was held last night at Delmonico's, and was the opening ball of the season. The scene was most bright when the cotillion was begun. Ladies in elegant new costumes were grouped within the large ball-room, which was decorated by Klunder. Between the mirrors were plaques, centred with roses of various hues and edged with smilax and fine evergreen work.

The guns of Castle William surprised shipmasters and ferry passengers by the discharge of a national salute of 21 guns at precisely 11 o'clock yesterday forenoon. It was a signal to those who understood the matter that at precisely that hour 100 years ago the British evacuated the last bit of American soil and left the colonies to arrange their own form of government without further interference.

VALENCIA, Dec. 3.--The newspaper Las Provincias, of this city, publishes a letter from Barcelona, stating that an insurrectionary plot has been discovered among the members of the battalion of rifles forming a part of the garrison there.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Dec. 3.--The steamer Frederick de Barey was damaged by fire to the extent of $60,000 at her wharf here this morning. She is insured for $40,000. She was built at Wilmington, Del., in 1881, at a cost of $78,000.
The Kings County Democratic General Committee met last evening and called the primaries for the election of officers of the Ward Associations and delegates to the General Committee for Monday next.

At the annual meeting of the Board of Managers of the New-York Bible and Fruit Mission yesterday, at No. 416 East Twenty-sixth-street, the Treasurer reported that the expenditures of the mission during the past year were $14,200 and the receipts $200 less.

The fifth, annual dinner of the Alumni Association of St. Francis Xavier's College was eaten in Pinard's last evening by upward of 150 gentlemen, representatives of every class from 1859 to 1832, inclusive, being present. Among them were the Rev. Dr. Brann, the Rev. Father Campbell, S.J., Vice-President of the college; the Rev. Fahter Pardoe, S.J., the Rev. Dr. Healey, the Rev. Father Lane, the Rev. Father O'Reilly, the Rev. Dr. McGean, ...

LONDON, Dec. 3.--The Paris correspondent of Reuter's Telegram Company transmits a dispatch from Hal-Phong, Tonquin, which states that, owing to the attack by the Chinese upon Haidzuong, Nov. 17, a state of siege had been proclaimed at the latter place by Admiral Courbet.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3.--With the exception of the diplomatic gallery, which had no occupants, the galleries of the Senate Chamber were filled, although not crowded, some time before the hour of 12. The occupants spent their time chatting with friends, pointing out to one another the distinguished statesmen who were stirring about on the floor below, ...

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Dec. 3.--Mary Fritz, a young woman about 20 years of age, living with her parents on Lexington-street, purchased an ounce of laudanum yesterday and took it this evening and concealed herself under the bed. She was discovered and taken to the Fourth Precinct Station, where at midnight two doctors were attending her, with small hopes of saving her life. Disappointment in love is said to be the cause.

The modest gentleman from the south bank of the Ohio who has just been elected Speaker must be somewhat startled at the assortment of evils which his election is to bring upon his party and the country.

When United States Commissioner Osborn last Saturday adjourned the examination on an application for the extradition of George Flood, the young Englishman who is charged with forgery by the British Government, be said that he did so ...

George A. Drew, of No. 159 West One Hundred and Twenty-eighth-street, was standing at the foot of the steps to the up-town station of the Sixth-avenue elevated railway at Twenty-thirdstreet at 9 o'clock Sunday night, when his watch was stolen.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Dec. 3.--An extra panel of jurors was drawn to-day in the Supreme Court now sitting in this city and presided over by Judge Merwin, preparatory to the trial of Charles Higham for the murder of Frederick W. Eames. This will probably be one of the most celebrated cases known to Northern New-York.

Frank Hart came from Boston a few weeks ago, and on Saturday night he was drinking in a saloon at Fourteenth-street and Eleventh-avenue, and got, as he termed it, "bilin' full." Among his friends were Charles Rafferty and Jeremiah Curtin, ...

NEW-HAVEN, Dec. 3.--Admiral Foote Post, G.A.R., held a meeting on Saturday night and elected officers. Comrade F.J. Hart presented the post with a memento of the battle of Gettysburg, a shell recently picked up by him on Culpeper's Hill, Va. It has been handsomely mounted to form the oil receptacle on a cigar-lighter.

The Aqueduct Commission, Mr. Dowd being absent, met yesterday for the purpose of hearing any objection that might be offered to the proposed modified line for the aqueduct, but no one appeared to make argument.
Judge Van Brunt, in the Court of Common Pleas, yesterday rendered his long-anticipated decision in the suit of Frederick Schwab against Rose Coghlan, the actress.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Dec. 3.--Mrs. Ellen Taylor Lovell began a suit for divorce to-day against her bnsband, Edwin Osborn Lovell, a well-known citizen, and the papers filed make a variety of sensational charges.
The following notice is posted up in a conspicuous place in the Hepworth Sugar Machineworks at Glenwood, a little north of Yonkers:

Fifteen hundred invitations were issued to the reception which opened the Art Loan Exhibition in aid of the Bartholdi statue pedestal fund at the Academy of Design last evening. From 8 o'clock to 10 a steady stream of people poured through the doors of the Academy.

"Lucia" was again presented at the Metropolitan Opera-house last evening with the same cast as appeared before in this opera. This work affords Mme. Sembrich her brightest opportunities for the display of those vocal accomplishments and the lovely voice which have made her reputation.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Dec. 3.--Kate Kane, the lady lawyer, who gained considerable notoriety a few months ago by throwing a glass of water in Judge Mallory's face while the judicial gentleman was hearing a case, left Milwaukee to-day for Chicago, where she will endeavor to make a livelihood by writing letters to newspapers. She was disbarred at the time of the contempt, and since then has been acting as correspondent for St. Paul and Chicago papers.

ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 3.--The Court of Appeals to-day transacted the following business: No. 333-- John Hanegger et al., appellants. vs. Henry Wetstorn et al., respondents; appeal from a judgment of affirmance of the Superior Court in favor of the defendants ...

BALTIMORE, Dec. 3.--The Trustees of Johns Hopkins University, at their monthly meeting today, accepted the resignation of Dr. Charles S. Hastings. Professor of Physics in the university. Dr. Hastings has been tendered the Chair of Physics in Sheffield School of Science, in Yale College, and will accept.

Elijah M. Wilson, manager of the Langham Hotel. Fifth-avenue and Fifty-second street, was sued by Beinecke Co., wholesale butchers in Fulton-street, in the Supreme Court, for $11,795. They recovered a judgement and Sheriff Davidson ...

NEW-ORLEANS, Dec. 3.--The conference committees on the differences between the freight handlers and the railroads met to-day, at 11 o'clock, and the session lasted till 1 o'clock, when the committees adjourned, after adopting the following resolution, as a basis of adjustment:
A meeting of the Charity Organization Society, the main objects of which are to root out professional beggary, to discourage indiscriminate charity, and to help all who deserve help, will be ...
The annual report of the Columbia College Board of Trustees to the Regents was discussed at the regular monthly meeting yesterday.
William Belden, of No. 841 Fifth-avenue, was a complainant in the Yorkville Police Court yesterday against Thomas Sullivan, of No. 1,038 Third-avenue.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3.--The Star of this evening has the following: "Mr. Richard A. Elmer, the Second Assistant Postmaster-General, has returned from New-York, where he has been ...

The Democrats have discharged their duty not grudgingly and hesitatingly, but with an mention and emphasis that show their hearts were in their work; and that work is inspiriting and gladdening, we believe, to every Democrat who is more of a patriot than a politician.

The fast steam-ship Alaska, of the Guion Line, which reached her pier from Liverpool 24 hours late yesterday morning, ran down a pilotboat off Fire Island soon after 12 o'clock, Sunday night, and sunk her, with her crew, all on board perishing.

Capt. Laub, of the steam-ship Thingvalla, which arrived yesterday from Copenhagen and Christiansand, reports having had a very stormy passage. The weather was not moderate for 12 hours at a time during the whole voyage.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 3.--The pool-sellers whose places were closed by the police have won a victory, the Grand Jury having ignored the bills of indictment against them.
In a short speech delivered at the opening of the Electric, Manufacturing, and Miscellaneous Stock Exchange yesterday afternoon, O.D. Baldwin, President of the Fourth National Bank, calmly remarked.
John Fiske, of Cambridge, Mass., is at the Everett House. Jerome B. Parmenter, of Troy, is at the Westminster Hotel.
When the Grand Jury for the December term had been sworn in yesterday by Chief Clerk Sparks, of the Court of General Sessions, Judge Cowing told it to confine its attention mainly to ...
CLEVELAND, Ohio, Dec. 3.--Baggage Master Longacre, who was shot by burglars at Shelby, Richland County, last Friday, died this morning. Marshal Sutter is improving.
"A Subscriber" is informed that Emerson died on April 27, 1882.

Officers of the New-York, West Shore and Buffalo Railroad stated yesterday that no agreements had been made with either the Pennsylvania or the Grand Trunk Railroad Companies. That negotiations were pending with each of the companies named was not denied. It was stated yesterday that the Pennsylvania Railroad people were preparing to make a definite proposition to secure control of the West Shore.

FONDA, N.Y., Dec. 3.--Clark Kline, manufacturers of knit goods in Amsterdam, made an assignment this afternoon. The failure has caused considerable excitement. About 100 hands are thrown out of employment.

UTICA, N.Y., Dec. 3.--While train No. 18 on the New-York Central, which arrives here at 3 A.M., was between Syracuse and Utica to-day Conductor Burtis found a nude man in the closet of one of the coaches. The car window was open and the clothing had evidently been thrown out.

Immediately west of the ground on which stands the Amity Baptist Chapel, at No. 310 West Fifty-fourth-street, are six four-story frame tenement-houses. They are known to the police as Central Park Terrace Flats and to the vulgar as "Coon Flats," they being inhabited by respectable colored families.

A company of gentlemen will celebrate the one hundredth anniversary of the evacuation of New-York to-day in a novel manner. On the evening of Nov. 25, 1883, after the City had been occupied by the patriot forces, a party of military and civic dignitaries sat down to dine in FRAUNCES'S Tavern, in Broad-street.

NORWICH, Dec. 3.--Mr. and Mrs. John McAlpin celebrated, their golden wedding at their residence in Montville Thanksgiving Day. They were married 50 years ago in Scotland at the ages of 22 and 24 years respectively.

MATAWAN, N.J., Dec. 3.--While most of the respectable citizens of Monmouth were returning from their devotions last night a motley crowd of muffled men were wending their way to a resort not many yards from Cheesequake Creek, which divides Monmouth and Middlesex Counties, near South Amboy.

BIRMINGHAM, Dec. 3.--On Oct. 15 the 6-yearold daughter of Thomas Carr, of this place, fell off the edge of a wall by the side of a road in Shelton, just across the Housatonic River. The embankment was unprotected by a railing and the fall of 12 feet resulted in the death of the girl. A suit for damages is to be brought.

PETERSBURG, Va., Dec. 3.--Henry Tucker, who has been on trial in the County Court of Brunswick for the past week for the murder of Benjamin Kidd, has been acquitted. The courtroom was crowded each day during the continuance of the trial.
The annual election of the Young Men's Democratic Club, held yesterday at the club-rooms, resulted tn the election of the following officers:

BUFFALO, Dec. 3.--Mitta A. Cook, a blackeyed, ruddy complexioned young woman, is plaintiff in a suit against Mary E. Pettibone for trial in the County Court this morning. The plaintiff lived in the town of Boston and belonged to a temperance society.

CINCINNATI, Dec. 3.--A close friend of Senator Pendleton said to-day than there was no doubt Pendleton would receive 35 votes in the Democratic caucus on the first ballot, which would be increased to considerably more than the necessary 42 as soon as the complimentary votes for Ward, Converse, and Hurd had been cast.

A white-haired, shrill-voiced boy, about 8 years old, rode down town with his parents on the Sixth-avenue elevated road yesterday. He gazed curiously at two or three up trains which whizzed by the one he was in, and in a voice that sent a thrill through every person in the car piped out: "Pa. how do these cars turn around?"
TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 3.--Grand Scribe and Secretary Lewis Parker, of the New-Jersey Grand Lodge, Independent Order of Odd-fellows, is having his annual report printed.

John Boston or John Watkins, the colored man who was arrested in New-York on suspicion of having been implicated in the murder of Phoebe Paullin, the victim of the Orange Mountain outrage, had no connection with the crime as far as can be learned.

MOBILE, Ala., Dec. 3.--Sigmund Vogel, who failed on Saturday, died of a broken heart. He was enterprising and presumably successful in business. He had a large house and a full stock and advertised extensively.

FONDA, N.Y., Dec. 3.--The failure of Clark Klien, of Amsterdam, is more serious than was at first supposed. The liabilities are said to be in the neighborhood of $200,000. The assets cannot be determined until an inventory shall have been taken by the Assignees.

ALEXANDRIA, Va., Dec. 3.--A white man named Wade and a colored man were caught by the falling of a bank of earth at a cut on the Virginia Midland Railway, near this city, this morning. The white man was killed and the colored man seriously, if not fatally, injured.

It is not probable that Ira C. Bellows, indicted for complicity in the frauds in the Water Register's Bureau, will be tried in the Court of Oyer and Terminer to-day, although his case has been set down for trial.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Dec 3.--Legal circles are to-night agitating the matter of the consigning of Henry W. Painter, M.D., of West Haven, the venerable and self-important Grand Juror, and the leading officer of that town, to the County Jail to-day in default of $1,500 bonds in a civil suit for slander brought against him by Miss Mamie ...

NEW-HAVFN, Conn., Dec. 3.--A sensation was created here late this afternoon by the announcement that a decomposed human arm, apparently that of a man, had been found in a rusty tin chest near the lime-kiln in Fair Haven by a laborer who carelessly opened the box.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 3.--Capt. John G. Eldrige, of the steamer Westover, reports having passed a sunken schooner off Cove Point, above the mouth of Patuxtent River, at 9 A.M. yesterday. The mastheads were above water and all sail standing. The name of the vessel could not be ascertained. The wreck is dangerous, and bears south-east by east east from Cove Point light.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3, 1883. The Adjutant-General of the Army has received official information of the surrender at the camp on Poplar River of fivo lodges of Sitting Bull's forces from the British Provinces, numbering in all 33 persons. As all their friends are at the Standing Rock Agency, Gen. Terry recommends that they be sent thither.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Dec. 3.--John Mebane, a well-to-do colored man of this county, was taken before the Probate Court yesterday charged with horrible cruelty to his 18-year-old daughter, a very modest mulatto girl.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Dec. 3.--In the Supreme Court to-day, in the case of Receiver Farnsworth's petition for a writ of assistance to recover the possession of the Quidnick Mills from William Sprague, the court ordered Gov. Sprague to surrender the mills at noon to-morrow. Gov. Butler appeared for ex-Gov. Sprague.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Dec. 3.--Theodore Carling, who, with Smull, the horse-thief, and the negro Price, escaped from the Belvidere (N.J.) Jail on Nov. 15, was arrested by Sheriff William K. Bowers, of Warren County, N.J., while at work in the Ashley machine shop this morning, and he was taken to Belvidere this evening.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3.--Lieut. E.P. McClellan has been ordered to the Galena; Lieut. R.H. Townley to duty at the University of Nebraska; Ensign Louis Duncan to special duty at the Johns Hopkins University, Maryland. Leave of absence has been granted to Liut.-Commander F.A. Miller for three months, with permission to leave the United States.

The Commissioners appointed by Mayor Edson on Saturday to lay out a route for a new system of rapid transit in this City had not been officially notified of their appointment yesterday, and consequently no arrangements for their first meeting have yet been made.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Dec. 3.--General Manager Merrill, of the Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul Railroad, refuses eithe to deny or affirm the truth of the statement published in Chicago to the effect that an agreement had been entered into ...
BETHLEHEM, Penn., Dec. 3.--Some time since it was announced that the project for the union of the Northern and Southern provinces of the Moravian Church had failed.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Dec. 3.--It is now thought that the unidentified body of the dead Shelby burglar, now lying at Erie-street Medical College is Chapman, a member of the famous Foster gang and a son-in-law of Guy Foster, Sr.
BERLIN Dec. 3.--The German Foreign Office has issued a notification that the port of Foo Chow, China, is infected with cholera.

GREENSBURG, Penn., Dec. 3.--One hundred and fifty witnesses arrived here from Murraysville this morning to testify in the habeas corpus proceedings on behalf of the participants in the recent fatal riot over the possession of a natural gas well.

RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 3.--There is some disappointment among the Democratic protectionists of this State at the election of Mr. Carlisle as Speaker of the House of Representatives. The general sentiment all over this State favored Randall's claim to that position.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 3.--Capt. Albert H. League, of the tug Britannia, was drowned from his vessel yesterday afternoon, about 40 miles below this city. He started from the stern to go to the pilot-house and was not seen afterward. Capt. League was one of the oldest tug masters of this port, having been for more than 30 years in the business.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 3.--Information was received here to-day that Margaret Hazzard, the woman who shot Charles Reid, a brakeman, on Saturday night on a Philadelphia and Reading Railroad train, had taken a dose of Paris green at her home in Conshocken, and that her death was expected. Jealousy was the cause of her attempt to take Reid's life. The latter's condition is not considered critical.

At a meeting of the American Astronomical Society last night at the Packer Institute. Brooklyn Mr. G.P. Serviss spoke on the recent red light in the sky at sunset. He said this phenomenon was seen in San Francisco as early as Nov. 20, and subsequently in Havana and the Valley of the Mississippi.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 3.--The condition of Mrs. Laura Riall, who killed her two little girls on Friday last, and then attempted her own life by cutting her throat, is said to be much improved tonight, and it is probable she may recover. She is able to sit up in a chair and take nourishment, though she cannot speak. Her husband has not seen her since the time of the tragedy.

It is rarely that one now hears from a Presbyterian pulpit a sermon in defense and approval of hell. This may be due either to a growing disbelief in hell or a conviction that it is a subject which should not be mentioned for fear of casting a gloom over the congregation.

The name of the woman who was assaulted by Petrolman George Ryan, of the Fifth Precinct, at Thomas-street and West Broadway, on the night of Wednesday last, as was described yesterday in THE TIMES, was Mrs. Margaret Gallagher, the wife of a journeyman horse-shoer employed in McCann's blacksmith's shop on Thomas-street.

MATAWAN, N.J., Dec. 3.--The detectives who have been working up the case of the Monmouth County thieves and incendiaries are very confident of success, and expect to arrest John Drum and Henry Jackson, the only two of the gang at liberty. Their head-quarters have been discovered near Middletown. Chief of Police Frank Pattison and several other constables from different points went out this afternoon to arrest them.

ALBANY, Dec. 3.--Almost daily some one of the candidates for the Speakership and Clerkship of the next Republican Assembly flits through this city, bound either for the south or west in search of members who have votes to deliver at the NewYear's night caucus.
Yesterday Detective Sergeants Crowley and William Adams arrested John Thombson, alias Big Jack, and Walter Moffatt, as suspicious persons, in Bleecker-street.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Dec. 3.--The agitation in Manitoba is already bearing results. The Government has opened up valuable lands for settlement, and the Canadian Pacific Railway has promised to make a reduction of 20 per cent. on their charges for transport of grain.

The Congregational Club of New-York and its vicinity met last evening at the Vienna Bakery, at Broadway and Tenth-street, and considered the question of marriage and divorce. After enjoying a dinner the members of the club drew out their chairs from the table and listened to the discussion, which was opened by the Rev. Samuel W. Dike, ...

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 3.--A middle-aged German, of respectable appearance, was taken to police head-quarters this afternoon from Frankford, where he had declared himself to be a murderer. Charles Uhl, a farm hand, employed at Cornwall's, Bucks County, wa8 summoned to the city, and stated at the hearing that ...

Mr. Patrick Bresnan, of Astoria, Long Island, called at the Brooklyn Police Central Office last night and reported that his adopted daughter, Addie Bresnan, aged 13, had been abducted yesterday morning by Capt. G.I. Gordon.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3.--The transactions of the United States Supreme Court to-day were as follows:

INDIANAPOLIS, Dec. 3.--The Hon. Joseph E. McDonald, in an interview upon the election of Mr. Carlisle, says: "I am greatly pleased over the election of Mr. Carlisle. He is a safe, conservative man, who does not hold extreme views."
Quatta, an Indian squaw, and wife of Yellow Hawk, who, with other. Indians, has his wigwam in a hall at Harlem, was found astray Sunday night, and was sheltered at Police Head-quarters.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3--The following card has been furnished by Mr. John A. Walsh for publication:
NEWCASTLE-UPON-TYNE, Dec. 8.--Messrs. Solater Procter, corn merchants of this place, have falled. Their liabilities are 60,000.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Dec. 3.--Harold, son of the Rev. J. Lockington Batee, voting Trustee of the New-York, Pennsylvania, and Ohio Railroad, is lying at the point of death with scarlet fever in the Charity Hospital here.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3.--A largely attended caucus of Democratic representatives was held to-night in the hall of the House, for the purpose of considering the questions raised to-day in connection with the Chalmers-Manning contest.

The General Navigation Society of Italy, which was recently formed by the union of the two great steam-ship companies, the Florio and the Rubattino, has lately hired on contract a number of English chief engineers and second engineers.

POUGHKEEPSIE, Dec. 3.--Several cases of alleged bribery at elections are to be considered by the Grand Jury which was sworn in to-day. Referring to these cases Judge Edgar M. Cullen today closed his address to the jury as follows:

FONDA, N.Y., Dec. 3.--David Davis, foreman of the knitting mill of Maxwell Brothers, Amsterdam, has eloped with Ella Balcom, one of the women employed in the mill. Davis leaves behind him a wife and three children. Mrs. Balcom is a "grass" widow.

ST. JOHN, New-Brunswick, Dec. 3.--At a meeting of the stockholders of the St. Croix Cotton Mills, at Milltown, the plan for continuing business suggested by the stockholders in Providence, R.I., was considered and approved.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Dec. 3.--A report from Digby says that while the Government steamer Newfield was towing a new ship last night near that place the hawser parted, and the new vessel went ashore near Point Prim light-house, striking against the bluff of the rock.
Emigration Commissioner Starr, although an old resident of New-York, has on several occasions been mistaken for a verdant countryman by "bunco" steerers.
BALTIMORE, Md., Dec. 3.--The American to-day reduced its price from 3 cents to 2 cents.
The direetors of the Chicago, Rock Island and Pacific Railroad met yesterday and declared the usual quarterly dividend of 1 per cent. on the stock. This dividend is payable Feb. 1.

NORWICH, N.Y., Dec. 3.--After a three days' recess, the trial of the Dwight case was resumed to-day. The first witness called by the plaintiffs to-day was Mrs. T.F. McDonald, of Binghamton. She testified that she was the half sister of Walton Dwight. He came very often to her house, and after she was married, in 1873, she saw him very frequently.
John H. Morrell, proprietor of the large storage warehouses at Fourth-avenue and Thirtysecond-street, made an assignment yesterday to Commissioner of Emigration Edmund Stephenson.
WESTPORT, Conn., Dec. 3.--Three months ago Mr. Edward H. Nash, of this town, went to England for the purpose of studying church architecture, in view of builidng a new Episcopal church here.

Of the 500 subscribers required for the stock of the Real Estate Exchange and Auction Room (Limited) 115 had been secured yesterday, and $115,000 stood to the credit of the new Exchange in the United States Trust Company, where the books are opened for subscription.
There is apparently no law or power capable of defending the patrons of the Brooklyn City Railroad Company from the outrages daily put upon them by that brutal and conscienceless corporation.

RED BANK, N.J., Dec. 3.--A decided sensation was created in this place at the reported defalcation of John Clevins, who left town under suspicious circumstances on Saturday afternoon. Clevens has been driver for the Central Express Company here for many years.

KINGSTON, Ontario, Dec. 3.--Recently a party of 15 Americans, with 40 dogs, secured a large number of deer in the country back of Kingston. About 100 carcases were sent into the United States and a large number were left in the woods. Parliament will be asked to provide a remedy for such wanton hounding and killing of deer.
EAU CLAIRE, Wis., Dec. 3.--Great excitement prevails over the discovery of a valuable silver mine near Bovd. about 35 miles from here.
DES MOINES, Iowa, Dec. 3.--The Trustees of the Iowa Agricultural College make a statement regarding the removal of President Welsh, in which they say Mr. Welsh has been physically unable ...

BUFFALO, N.Y., Dec. 3.--News has just been received from Farmersville, Cattaraugus County, of the murder on Saturday of Mrs. Charles Clark by her husband. The couple had been married about five years. Clark is 31 years old and a drinking, worthless fellow. His wife was 10 years younger.
NEW-ORLEANS, Dec. 3.--The struggle for the control of the Cotton Exchange to-day was very exciting.

An act was passed by the Legislature of 1882 empowering the Commissioners of the Sinking Fund of this City to extend a lease made to the German Hospital in 1866 by extending its term to perpetuity and increasing the area of land granted to it for a nominal rental.

The Kings County Electric Light Company petitioned the Brooklyn Aldermen yesterday for permission to erect poles and put wires in the streets and avenues of Brooklyn, the company to pay the city $3,000 a year for the privilege.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Dec. 3.--The canals are closed. They are clear of ice. Eighteen grain and 20 salt laden boats have reaches their destination here. Their cargoes are to be reshipped by rail. There are no boats on the Syracuse levels of the Erie or Oswego Canals en route, and the boats owned in this locality have all reached their Winter quarters. The business of the past year exceeds that of many recent years.

Many long-haired, hollow-eyed, unwholesome-looking men, and a still greater number of oddly dressed, queer-looking women, gathered in Part II, of the Supreme Court, Circuit, Brooklyn, yesterday, to hear the trial of a suit brought by William A. Heney against "Dr." Francis A. Monck, to recover $375 for services rendered.

ST. MONTREAL, Quebec, Dec. 3.--A Director of the Exchange Bank admitted to-day that the board would be satisfied if it netted 30 or 35 cents on the dollar. It is generally believed that, instead of this, the shareholders will be called on for at least a portion of their double liability.

LANCASTER, Penn., Dec. 3.--William Hinder, who was supposed to have stabbed George Lawrence during a fight yesterday morning, was given a hearing to-day, and showed that he was innocent of the charge. Albert Gardner was also arrested, charged with the same crime, and to-day he admitted having stabbed Lawrence, but said that the act was done in self defense. Lawrence, the victim, is still in a critical condition.

WESTPORT, Conn., Dec. 3.--A wooden building erected here 75 years ago on the Saugatuck River for a grist mill was destroyed by fire last night.

TORONTO, Ontaria, Dec. 3.--The stoutly contested case of Hately against the Merchants' Dispatch Company came up in the High Court of Justice this morning on application by the defendants to set aside plaintiff's verdict.

WINSTED, Conn., Dec. 3.--The Rev. L.H. Hallock, Pastor of the Congregational Church of West Winsted, has resigned his charge. BALTIMORE, Dec. 3.--The British steam-ship Mentmore, which sailed for Liverpool Saturday and returned last night, was in collision with the schooner John Devall, Capt. Kelly, of New-Haven, in ballast, off Point Lookout, at 12 o'clock Saturday night. The steamer had her port bow stove and received some damage aloft. The schooner received very little damage. The Mentmore will be repaired immediately and be ready to sail on Wednesday or Thursday. She was loaded with cattle.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Dec. 3.--The remains of Mrs. Minnie Hanks, the young married woman who died on Wednesday, but whose body showed some signs of life on Friday, which led to the suspicion that it might be a case of suspended animation, were to-day transferred to the receiving vault, decomposition having set in.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Dec. 3.--Daniel Naurse, a member of the Denman Thompson troupe, who took the part of Sheriff in "Joshua Whitcombe," was discharged here last week.
CAIRO, Dec. 3.--The European population of Khartoum has taken refuge at Berber and the Egyptian Government has ordered the local chiefs at the latter place to protect the fugitives.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 3.--Capt. Henry Smith, of the schooner Annie, of Baltimore, reports that on Sunday noon, when off Rock Creek, Edward Brown fell overboard from the jib. The yawl-boat was immediately lowered and capsized, throwing August Temple into the river.
ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 4.--The Governor has appointed Adolph L. Sanger Loan Commissioner for New-York in place of Charles P. Birnie, whose term of office has expired.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Dec. 4.--In a quarrel on Saturday night, at a church near Cassville, Mo., between William C. Black and William Brown, the latter a son of the clergyman, Black was stabbed four times and killed instantly. Brown fled.

Anderson at Lancaster last week, was acquitted this afternoon, the magistrates deciding in these words: "We have agreed that it was a case of self-defense, and the prisoner is, therefore, discharged," Mr. Denny received the congratulations of the entire community.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4.--A caucus of Republican Senators was held this morning, but not more than 10 Senators were present. Senator Sherman occupied the chair. A resolution was offered and unanimously agreed to authorizing the Chairman to name a committee of seven Senators to rearrange the Republican membership of the Senate committee.

BATON ROUGE, Dec, 4.--J.S. Wigley, a member of the Grand Jury, while returning to his home last night was fired upon by two unknown men and fatally wounded. His assailants escaped.
Officers came to this City from Matawan on Monday in search of John Thomas, alias John Drum, and Henry Jackson, well known thieves in that neighborhood.
LONDON, Ontario, Dec. 4.--The members of the Bailey branch of the Salvation Army were pelted with rotten eggs at Dorchester last night by a gang of ruffians.

A large number of property-owners in the annexed district, or their representatives, appeared before the Park Commissioners yesterday to discuss the proposition to lay out public parks near the entrance to High Bridge and on the Port Morris side of the district.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Dec. 4.--At 1:30 o' clock this morning Henry Lammerding, a bar-tender for Jake Aug, a Vine-street saloon-keeper, was fatally shot by Charlie Beck. Beck entered Aug's clubhouse and asked for a drink. Lammerding refused to give it to him for the reason that he had taken enough. Beck thereupon drew a pistol and shot Lammerding twice. Lammerding is still alive and may recovor. Beck has been arrested.
