At a meeting of the Tariff Association yesterday the scheme prepared by a special committee to regulate the rate of commission paid to fire insurance brokers, and to prevent the payment by brokers of rebates to the insured, was rejected and the committee discharged.

LYNCHBURG, VA., Dec. 4.--Several weeks ago Isaac Robinson, colored abducted Ella Redmond, a young white girl, daughter of a Charlotte County farmer. On Saturday last Robinson and the girl were found living with a negro family in Appomattox County. The girl was taken home and the negro incarcerated in the Charlotte County Jail.

CITY OF MEXICO, Dec. 4.--The Administration is sustained by the House of Representatives which has passed the bill regulating nickel currency by a large majority. W.C. Perkins, of the road department of the Mexican Central Railroad, committed suicide yesterday. The cause is unknown.
CHICAGO, Dec. 4.--One of the most important factors in the troubles between the Iowa pooled lines has been the relations between the roads west of the Missouri River.

ALBUQUERQUE, New-Mexico, Dec. 4.--A man named Johnson, who last week shot and killed a cowboy named Brantley near Coolidge, New-Mexico, because he had reported him for stealing cattle, was lynched on Sunday night.
MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Dec. 4.--This city boasts of being the oldest in the State and will on July 13, 1884, arrive at her one hundredth birthday.
It has often been a mystery to the world what becomes of the thousands of pictures painted in Paris during a twelvemonth and exhibited at the annual Salon and other gallories.
Considerable interest has been excited throughout Austria by the proposed new marriage law, the debate on which began in the Lower House of the Hungarian Parliament to-day.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Dec. 4.--It is reported that the body of Capt. D. Browne, who was drowned in the disaster to the steamer Princess Louise yesterday, has been recovered. The names of the two or three others who were lost, and reported as unknown, are Michael Dady and Alfred Hiltz. Dady was formerly second officer, and Hiltz second cook of the Government steamer Newfield. Hiltz leaves a wife and three children in Halifax.
Mrs. Frank Waller, wife of the artist, gave a reception last evening at her residence, No. 31 West Fifteenth-street.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Dec. 4.--To-day Mrs. Neff, of Harmony, had her leg amputated. On Saturday her son carelessly shot her with a rifle, which he was cleaning. The family are in indigent circumstances, and the accident places them under town support.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4.--An interesting defense of A.B. Webb, one of the pension attorneys recommended by Commissioner Dudley for disbarment, was made by the Rep. Dr. Sunderland in a hearing before the Secretary of the Interior.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 5.--A suit entered in Common Pleas Court No. 1 to-day by Mrs. Mary Wattles against the Old Ladies' Home disclosed a strange little story. Mrs. Wattles is the widow of an officer of the war of 1812. She has been brought from easy circumstances to the verge of want by her love for the poor.
State Senator Stewart, of Pennsylvania, says in a published letter that he does not intend to be ever again a candidate for a public office.

CHICAGO, Dec. 5.--A report has just reached the city that the immense rendering-tank connected with the canning establishment of N.K. Fairbank Co., at the stock-yards, exploded this evening. It is rumored that five men were buried in the ruins, but no particulars have as yet been received.

EASTPORT, Me., Dec. 5.--A dispatch to the Sentinel from Flagg's Cove, Grand Manan, says the schooner William A. Pen, Capt. McDonald, of Gloucester, ran ashore on the southern head of Grand Manan last night and will probably break up. the crew have not been heard from.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Dec. 5.--F. H. Campbell, station agent of the Louisville and Nashville Railroad at Paris, Tenn., shot and killed Frank Williams yesterday. The difficulty grew out of the discharge of Williams, who had been employed as a clerk by Campbell.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Dec. 5.--The result of the trial of John A. Mitchell, a Charleston city detective, charged with forcibly preventing colored men from registering during the registration of 1882 and resisting arrest by a United States Deputy Marshal for that offense, has again demonstrated that no jury can be obtained in South Carolina that will convict violators of the United States election laws. The evidence was clear and direct.

"Ernani" was repeated at the Academy of Music last evening with the same cast as was heard in the opera before. The audience was large and very enthusiastic over a performance which was, as a whole, worthy of praise.

BIRMINGHAM, Dec. 5.--Lord Lorne delivered a long lecture here last evening upon Canada and its products. He particularly praised the salubrity of the climate, and said fevers which were too common in the United States were unknown within its boundaries.
MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Dec. 5.--A new railroad was organized in this city to-day to be known as the Lake Traverse, Sanborn and Carrington Road.

Fire broke out early yesterday morning on the first floor of No. 244 Bowery and caused about $4,500 loss to occupants of the building. NORWICH, N.Y., Dec. 5.--Mr. Laroque continued his argument for a non-suit in the Dwight case to-day. He took up the third point, where Dwight claimed he was insured in various companies, but in which he never had any insurance. Referring to the Connecticut Mutual, he said they issued their policy and sent it in directly to Mr. Harding, their Binghamton agent.

The question of removing a poor woman's house, which stands in the way of the Dock Department's operations at Seventy-eighth-street, North River, came up at the meeting of the board yesterday. The woman begged to be permitted to remain in her present place until April.

The new Hamburg steam-ship Moravia arrived at this port yesterday. She was built at the yard of Engels Co., on the Clyde. Her dimensions are: Length, 360 feet; breadth of beam, 42 feet, and depth of hold, 35 feet. She measures 3,738 tons gross and 2,117 tons net.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5.--Mr. Walter Perrine, Jr., of Trenton, N.J., was married at the Epiphany Church this evening, to Miss Addie Slack, daughter of Major and Quartermaster Slack, of the Marine Corps.

The Brooklyn New-England Society held its annual meeting last night in the Directors' room of the Academy of Music, that city, Joshua M. Van Cott occupying the chair. An election for Directors for the current year resulted in Messrs. D.B. Silliman, Hiram W. Hunt, and George H. Fisher being chosen for another term to succeed them selves.

Fire Marshal Sheldon yesterday continued the investigation into the origin of the fire which resulted in the destruction of the Windsor Theatre, by taking the statement of John Fornam, the watchman on duty in the theatre.
RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 5.--Mr. Mahone said to-day: "I am delighted with the victory of Mr. Carlisle. Nothing could have suited me better."
Mr. Charles H. Leland was elected President of the Sixth National Bank yesterday to succeed Mr. Francis Leland.

CALCUTTA, Dec. 5.--The Marquis of Ripon is now satisfied, that his unpopularity as Viceroy of India was really due to his supposed opposition to Mr. Carlisle, and not as stated, to his connection with the Ibert bill.

MILWAUKEE, Dec. 5.--All doubts as to the guilt of Edward J. Bennett and his wife, Elenor, who are under arrest on a charge of arson, were set at rest at a late hour last evening by a voluntary confession which was made public today.

The lack of sufficient rehearsal, which has been a striking feature of the present season at the Metropolitan Opera-house, was evident in the firs performance of Boite's "Mefistofele" last evening, as it was in the first performances of "Mignon," "Lohengrin," "Robert," and "Don Giovanni."

WASHINGTON, West Va., Dec. 5.--At Cadiz, Ohio, late last night, Rallo McCoy, a son of Postmaster McCoy, was stabbed three times and fatally wounded by Thomas Blackford. The stabbing grew out of a quarrel over some trivial matter.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5.--The committee appointed by the Republican caucus of Senators to arrange anew the committees of the Senate were busy yesterday and to-day, and will probably make a report to-morrow morning in the caucus that is to meet at 10 o'clock.

LONDON, Dec. 5.--Mr. Guy, O'Donnell's solicitor, is endeavoring to induce the members of the jury that convicted O'Donnell to sign a memorial, which is to be presented to Sir William Harcourt, Home Secretary, asking him to commute the death sentence of O'Donnell.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Dec. 5.--James Galbraith, a machinist, has for several months been searching for his young wife. Her disappearance has also alarmed her parents, who live on a farm at Goodground, Long Island, and they are now assisting in the search.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5.--Mr. Cox, in an interview upon the election of Mr. Carlisle, says: "I am delighted with it--immeasurably delighted. Mr. Carlisle is a man in whose conservatism we all of us have great confidence. I myself, as you know, helped his election as much as possible."

BALTIMORE, Md., Dec. 5.--For six days Mrs. Laura Riall, who last Friday murdered her two children and cut her own throat with a razor, has lingered in terrible torture. She has prayed for death to relieve her from her sufferings.

DANVILLE, Va., Dec. 5.--Green Miller, a negro, was last night shot by Policeman Williams, and the wound will probably prove fatal. Miller was beating his wife, and Policeman Kennedy, attempting to arrest him, was resisted and choked by Miller.

RUTLAND, Vt., Dec. 5.--Myers, Clark, and Safford, three members of the "Birds and Feathers," the youthful band of counterfeiters which was unearthed a few weeks ago near Jamaica, were arraigned before Judge Wheeler today and pleaded guilty. Myers was sentenced to six months in the House of Correction, Clark to 18 months in the State prison, and Safford was reprimanded by the court, and sentence suspended during his good behavior.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 6.--Thomas Rafferty and John Buchanan were to-day sentenced to seven years and six months each for setting fire to a warehouse in the northern section of the city. A number of recent fires in that portion of the city were attributed to a gang of tramps with which the two men were affiliated.

CHICAGO, Dec. 6.--Three supernumeraries employed at the Grand Opera-house have been arrested upon suspicion of having committed various thefts, which members of dramatic and opera companies have reported. Jewelry was found in their possession which has been identified as having been stolen. In the room of one of the accused men the police found 15 watches and other property of a like nature.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Dec. 6.--Seven shocks of earthquake occurred yesterday at Rovenden Springs, Ark. They lasted 40 seconds and broke glassware and crockery in the stores and houses. BOSTON, Dec. 6.--The breaking of a pulley in the Monataquot Mill, at South Braintree, to-day caused the fall of the heavy shafting and the bursting of the fly-wheel, fragments of which did damage to the extent of $5,000. The greater loss will be caused by the temporary stoppage of the mill until repairs can be made.

GLOUCESTER, Mass., Dec. 6.--Three more of the missing fishing vessels have been given up for lost. They are the schooner Sultan, with a crew of 14 men; the Maud F. Leighton, 12 men, and the Ruth Grover with 12 men. The schooner Rutherford B. Hayes has been absent on a Georges trip for six weeks, and great anxiety is felt for her safety. Three others are also overdue.

STONINGTON, Conn., Dec. 6.--William Watson, an employe of Haley Chesebro, was seriously and probably fatally injured this evening, being struck by an express train between the junction and his house and thrown a distance of nearly 100 feet. Although no bones are broken he is in unconscious condition. He was the only son of a widowed mother.

To-day physicians announced the boy crippled for life.

Vogel, who died suddenly two days after his disastrous failure in the clothing business, left $25,000 in the hands of banks and individuals here in the shape of notes indorsed by his preferred creditors, Messrs. Thoonfelt and Henry Barnstein. To-day the indorsement on $18,000 of this paper was pronounced to be forged.

SCRANTON, Penn., Dec. 6.--Thomas Lyons, a prominent local Democratic politician, was instantly killed yesterday afternoon by the fall of the roof in the Coal Brook mine at Carbondale.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Dec. 6.--Near Anderson, Ind., last evening, John J. Johnson was shot by Coleman Hawkins and dangerously wounded. After the shooting Hawkins returned home and shot himself, dying instantly. Both were wealthy farmers. The trouble was about a ditch between the farms.

Craig, Secretary and Treasurer of the Montreal Loan and Mortgage Company. The report, however, turned out to be untrue, as the gentleman in question turned up at his office before midday.

TRENTON, N.Y., Dec. 6.--The Trenton Iron Company closed its rolling-mill temporarily last night. Two hundred and fifty hands are thrown out of employment. It is expected that work will be resumed on Monday at reduced wages. The outlook at all the iron and wire mills here is unpromising.

Col. Michael W. Burns, who has been very ill since election day, died this morning at 1 o'clock. His wife was present at his bedside with several friends, including Charles H. Trainor, John Graham, Joseph F. O'Brien, John F. Condon, and Francis Redmond. During the day many friends had called. Death had been looked for at any time during the night.

BOSTON, Dec. 6.--In the test case against Billings, Clapp Co., wholesale druggists, the defendants were found guilty to-day of selling tincture of opium containing a less quantity of morphine than that prescribed by the pharmacopoeia. They were fined a nominal sum and will take the case to the Superior Criminal Court.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Dec. 6.--Superintendent Fletcher to-day appointed Sarah Stockton physician of the female department of the Insane Hospital. She is a graduate of a Philadelphia and a Chicago college as well, and has had experience in Boston hospitals. This is the first official recognition of a female physician in the history of the State.

LONDON, Dec. 6.--The Prince of Wales has been re-elected Grand Master of the Grand Lodge of Freemasons of England.

CHICAGO, Dec. 6.--Tolman Wheeler, of this city, who has already made a number of valuable gifts to the Episcopal Church, has deeded the church a valuable tract of land in the western division of the city, and advanced $200,000 toward the erection of a church preparatory school. The design is to be after that of Oxford, the prominent features of the structure being a chapel and a library to contain 10,000 volumes.

DUBLIN, Dec, 6.--The Pope has sent a con-- gratulatory letter to Cardinal McCabe commending his pastoral letter, which was read in the Catholic churches on Sunday last, denunciatory of secret societies.

MADISON, Conn., Dec. 6.--One of the most conspicuous persons at the funeral of Eldridge F. Johnson, the North Madison farmer whose mutilated body was found on his charcoal pit last Monday, was John Whipper, the young man whose name is popularly mentioned as the probable murderer.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Dec. 6.--Agnes Gates, aged 33, a married mill operative in East Providence, started to walk to Pawtucket on Wednesday afternoon on the railroad track. To-day she was found drowned in a small pond in the woods at East Providence.

BOSTON, Dec. 6.--At a meeting of the creditors of Philip E. Newman Co., boot and shoe dealers, of Grand Rapids, Mich., and South Bend, Ind., a statement was presented of the firm's affairs showing the liabilities to be about $31,000 and the nominal assets $7,000. An offer of 40 per cent, was submitted, but the proposition was not accepted.

CINCINNATI, Dec. 6.--The Cincinnati Baseball Club has been threatened with loss of grounds, the lease upon the old grounds having expired and the club having been unable to get a renewal. To-day, however, the club succeeded in leasing new grounds for five years, located four squares nearer the centre of the city.

LONDON, Dec. 6.--At the Bow-Street Police Court, this morning, William Wolff, the Socialist, and the Frenchman Bondurand were arraigned, charged under the Explosive act with having in their possession explosive substances for an unlawful purpose.

READING, Penn., Dec. 7.--Marcus Einsein, a Jew, was found dead in his cell in prison this afternoon suspended from the ventilator by a rope. No cause is known for the suicide.
OTTAWA, Ontario, Dec. 7.--The total revenue of the Dominion for the five months ending Nov. 30 was $14,256,082. The expenditure during that period amounted to $11,738,411.

BUFFALO, Dec. 7.--Mr. M. Pewis Fillmore, son of the late ex-President Fillmore, has sold the house owned and occupied by the latter from 1858 up to the time of his death for $26,000. It is situated on Delaware-avenue, facing Niagara-square, too far down town for a fashionable residence. The house will be turned into a boarding-house. It is said that it originally cost $70,000.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 7.--At a meeting of the New-Jersey Sanitary Association this morning papers were read by State Geologist Cook, Prof. Brackett, of Princeton College; Prof. Pierce, of Rutgers, and others. A long discussion was had on school hygiene.

BRADFORD, Penn., Dec. 7.--Charles Clark, who murdered his wife at Farmersville, Cattaraugus County, N.Y., on Saturday last, was captured to-day at his father's home, at Linden, in the same county. He cut his own throat when captured, but the wound is not fatal.
The tree stump near which the head of the murdered Phoebe Paullin, on the Orange Mountain, lay when the body was discovered two weeks ago, has been cut almost entirely away by curiosity hunters.

CHICAGO, Ill., Dec. 7.--J.W. Mackay, formerly in charge of the foreign department of N. K. Fairbank's great lard house, was arrested today while attempting to negotiate at the Union National Bank a forged draft on a bank in London for $12,000.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Dec. 7.--The sentence of death which was passed on Greenwood and Harding for the murder of an old man named Maher, at Sandwich, Ontario, last Spring, and which was to have been carried out Dec. 14, has been commuted to imprisonment for life. Greenwood, who escaped from jail at Sandwich last month, is still at large. The Government has offered a reward of $500 for his arrest.
Nicholas Marie, a Frenchman, 78 years old, who boarded at No. 20 University-place, died last night of shock due to injuries received by being run over by a car of the Broadway Line.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7.--During the short recess that Congress has taken the members of the House who have nothing else to do employ their leisure time in arranging for Mr. Carlisle the important committees of the lower branch.

The new serpent seen by Capt. GREEN, of the Long Branch Life-saving Station, is by far the ablest snake on record. It was seen while Capt. GREEN and his crew were in a small boat fishing at a short distance from the shore.

Mr. Gaston L. Feuardent rested his case yesterday in his libel suit against Louis P. Di Cesnola. The day's hearing was begun with the cross-examination of Augustus Saint Gaudens, the sculptor. He testified that in his opinion the statue of Aphrodite and Eros was a monolith from the head down.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Dec. 7.--John Koop, the murderer of Amanda Fluke, at Perth Amboy, was brought here from Philadelphia at 5 o'clock this afternoon, and committed to jail to await his arraignment and trial. His identity has been established by men from Perth Amboy.

READING, Penn., Dec. 7.--The 100 striking nailers of the Pottstown Iron Company received notice of discharge to-day and were paid off. The company's officers say they will not resume until they can procure men who will work at the wages offered. Many of the discharged nailers left for other points.
The final public hearing as to the proposed modified Hudson River line for the new aqueduct to a point near Sing Sing was had before the Aqueduct Commission yesterday, the Mayor being absent.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Dec. 7.--James M. Underwood, for the murder of Robert J. Pendergrass, a wealthy planter of Yell County, was hanged today at Dardanelle, Ark., in the presence of 3,000 persons. Underwood waylaid and shot his victim from an ambush. He confessed the deed and imputed the incentive to the murder to the wife of Pendergrass, for whom he had formed a passion. He reiterated this story on the scaffold.

Policeman William Conroy, who shot Peter Keenan in Patrick Cody's saloon at No. 322 East Thirty-sixth-street, on Saturday night, Nov. 3, was put on trial before Judge Cowing, in Part I, of the General Sessions, yesterday.

The Rev. Dr. Richard Lalor Burtsell, Rector of the Church of the Epiphany, will deliver the sermon at the last mass in the Church of St. Benedict the Moor, at Bleecker and Downing streets, to-morrow morning.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Dec. 7.--The Board of Officers of the Cincinnati Chamber of Commerce to-day considered a motion to cancel the contract with the Western Union Telegraph Company for furnishing the market reports and giving it to the Blatimore and Ohio Company.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7.--Charges that there has been a misappropriation of a portion of the $300,000 provided by an act of the last Congress to reimburse the Cherokee Nation for certain lands have been published recently.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Dec. 7.--William T. Addis, of Bayne City, has made an assignment to Natt A. Norton, of that place. Addis has been engaged in lumbering and railroading. His liabilities, which are nominally equal to his assets, are about $75,000.

FREEHOLD, N.J., Dec. 7.--Charles Delanay, the negro who robbed Joseph Perren, of Long Branch, and who committed an assault upon Perrin's 5-year-old daughter, was tried to-day and convicted. Judge Walling sentenced him to 12 years at hard labor in the State prison.

WASHINGTON, Penn., Dec. 7.--L.P. Beaseh of California, this morning by mistake took a dose of poison, supposing it to be a remedy for a pain in the head. He became very ill, and is thought to be dying.

MONTEREY, Mexico, Dec. 6.--Timetis Hernandez has been sentenced to be publicly shot here on Dec.10, for a murder committed two years ago. This will be the first execution of the kind in this State since Gen. Jullenue Querre was shot by order of Gen. Trevino in 1876.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 7.-Harrison Preston, of Reading, Penn., who was recently convicted of forging a name to a postal money order, was sentenced to-day to imprisonment for two years in the penitentiary. George W.G. Boyce, convicted of stealing a letter containing $15, was sentenced to undergo an imprisonment of one month and to pay, a fine of $10.

Woodcock was caught in Washington and Sanford was sent there for trial. They pretended to be water inspectors, and by that means gained admission to the houses.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., Dec. 7.--William A. Munson, Pension Agent, has been indicted in the United States District Court for violation of the pension laws. The examination was postponed until January.

ATLANTA, Ga., Dec. 7.--Ransom Montgomery, an old colored man, extensively known, died suddenly in this city of paralysis of the heart. In 1845 Ransom was a slave and living on the Deforr Ferry place, near the Chattahoochee River bridge.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7.--Naval Boards have been appointed to inspect the Saratoga and Jamestown, at New-York, and the Portsmouth, at Norfolk.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Dec. 7.--The bodies of Henry Gray, Arthur Wood, and James Chipman, who belonged to the crew of the ill-fated Princess Louiso, were found to day. Like the other two found the bodies were in almost a nude state, and the heads and faces were very much disfigured.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 7.--Out of 18 cases of small-pox at Gadsden eight have died. The disease is at last under control, and if the people in the surrounding country will attend more carefully to vaccination there need be only a few more, if any, cases. In the town many deaths have occurred.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Dec. 7.--The wheat freight ring, it is reported, is likely to incur losses reaching from $2,000,000 to $3,000,000 by the decline in freights. Wangenheim Co. and Waterman Co. will not lose any serious amount, nor will the regular wheat shippers, whose charters have been mainly taken at profitable rates.

A fine bag of boys was made on Monday last in Pike County, Penn., by Mr. ANGLE. He was engaged in hunting, and while passing through a thicket suddenly flushed two small-boys, both of whom he brought down with a single discharge. The small-boys were not killed--the shot used by the hunter being very light--but they were so disabled that they were readily retrieved.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Dec. 8.--William Green, of Cane Creek, Andersen County, was bitten by a rabid dog last June. The wound healed up and had been forgotten. Yesterday Mr. Green called for water, which was given him, when he went into convulsions, which continued until this evening, when he died in terrible agony of hydrophobia.

Princess Dolgorouki, who recently purchased a splendid hotel in Paris, has abandoned her intention of passing the Winter there, and has left for Berlin, en route for St. Petersburg, where she is to reside till the end of January. The Princess is accompanied by her three children, and they are attended by a numerous suite of ladies-in-waiting, tutors, and governesses, and a secretary, and by quite a large establishment of servants.

LOWELL, Mass., Dec. 8.--The Pioneer Telephone Company has sold its franchises and property to the New-England Telephone Company at the rate of one share of Pioneer stock for four shares of New-England. The Pioneer Company has had control of the Boston and Lowell extra territorial business and its contract for this had two more years to run. It has been paying over 30 per cent. dividends.
At First Division Head-quarters the tender has been received of the resignation of Capt. James J. Horgan, Company E, Eighth Regiment.

CITY OF MEXICO, Dec. 8, via Galveston.-- The Libertad newspaper asks the Government why Don Carlos Rivas returns to Mexico. The official organ of the Government replies that Senor Rivas is recalled because he reaches no settlement with the bondholders and that the President knows of no new arrangement. The reply of the Government organ was telegraphed to Senor Mariscal a London for publication.

INDIANAPOLIS, Dec. 8.--The unveiling of the Morton statue will take place on the 15th of January, the anniversary of his inauguration as Governor. The pedestal, in the centre of Circle Park, is now complete.

BOSTON, Mass., Dec. 8.--President Capen, of Tuft's College, in his annual report, states that while the tendency of public opinion appears to be toward the co-education of the sexes, it has been found to be at present inadvisable to admit women to Tuft's College. He again recommends a special endowment for the Divinity School, which is now dependent upon the college funds.

BOSTON, Mass., Dec. 8.--Mr. F.K. Ballou, of Boston, who has been engaged on Government contracts at Mystic, Conn., states that he left that place openly; that his employes will be paid: that his bondsmen will not suffer, and that he alone will bear the loss involved in the work on his contracts.

The Colonel was in his shirt sleeves, and had been wrestling hard with a long row of figures, which presumably represented his profits on the season at the Academy of Music.

--The Industrial and Art Exposition for Baltimore is beginning to be more than a theory. Subscriptions for over $50,000 are assured, and the committee believe that the ground for the exhibition can now be bought, leaving a surplus for a building fund.

MATAWAN, N.J., Dec. 8.--The Drum brothers and the rest of the Red Bank fire bugs have waived an examination and will appear before the next Grand Jury. To lessen the chances of trouble with them while in confinement they have been locked up in separate cells.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Dec. 9.--George Smith, 13 years old, while playing with a toy pistol on Thanksgiving Day, received a wound in the hand, which resulted in lockjaw, and death occurred yesterday, despite constant medical attendance. The boy's suffering's were intense for several days before he died. His father is an Englishman, who lately arrived in this country.

WAY CROSS, Ga., Dec. 9.--At 12:40 o'clock to-day the Savannah fast mail train ran into a Brunswick and Western passenger train at the crossing of the two roads. LANCASTER, Penn., Dec. 9.--The Penn Iron Company, of this city, have informed their puddlers of a 10 per cent. reduction, to take effect on Dec. 15. It is probable the works will shut down, as the workmen refuse to accept the reduction.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 9.--Mayor Harry Lewis, of this city, issued an order to Chief of Police Webster last night, directing that the street hubbub of the Salvation Army be done away with.

The Chicago Tribune of Saturday contains nearly a page of telegrams concerning the condition of new corn in Illinois, Iowa, Indiana, Kansas, Nebraska, and Dakota, embracing all of the "corn belt" especially susceptible to sudden changes in the harvesting season. The reports show, as a whole, that new corn in Illinois, Indiana,, and Iowa is not in a very satisfactory condition.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Dec. 9.--While boiling fire clay at the Lookout Rolling Mill last evening, James Gillespie fell into a large vat of the liquid clay and before he could be extricated was boiled to death, the flesh dropping from his body in flakes.

Mr. and Mrs. Christopher C. Brooks, of this city, lost their youngest son, Christopher C. Brooks, aged 17 years and 5 months, by death from paralysis of the heart, in Brooklyn, N.Y., Wednesday afternoon, under peculiar circumstances. The remains arrived in Baltimore yesterday ...

BOSTON, Dec. 9.--The fire in the hold of the British steam-ship Otranto, lying at the State Dock, South Boston, which started yesterday afternoon, was got under control this morning.
HONG KONG, Dec. 9.--It is expected that the French will advance on Sontay to-morrow (Monday.)
CONNERSVILLE, Ind., Dec. 9.--It has been ascertained that the umbrella man killed by James Selby on Friday night last was Frank McHenry, of New-York.

NEW-HAVEN, Dec. 9.--Candidates for positions in the Yale University boat crew have been requested to present themselves at the college boat-house every afternoon this week. A longer course of training than ever will be required this year, as a new stroke is to be learned.
No new players have been engaged lately by the base-ball clubs of this City. In other League and American Association cities the clubs have added new players to their ranks.

Aged eggs are divided up among tanners, morocco dressers, confectioners, and fine papermakers. The tanners take the yolk, and never question the freshness of the product; the confectioners and paper men are eager for the foaming white.
A black-mailing scheme is offered as a motive for the reported assault upon and robbery of the Rev. J.O. Bache, in Fifty-first-street, last Thursday evening.

"It is only practical Christianity that is worth anything," said the Rev. Dr. Howard Crosby, speaking last evening for the "Gospel Mission to the Tombs," at the Eighteenth-Street Methodist Episcopal Church.

Judge Luke P. Poland, of Vermont, is perhaps the most striking of the new Congressmen. He has a slender, well-built form of full 6 feet, and though now nearly 70 years of age he stands as straight as a telegraph pole in his oldtime uniform of navy-blue broadcloth and gilt buttons.
An immigrant woman named Mrs. Paulson, who took passage on the White Star steamship Celtic, which arrived from Liverpool yesterday, is supposed to have committed suicide during ...
The concert at the Metropolitan Operahouse last evening was attended by a smaller audience than its predecessors, but the entertainment was interesting and was received with continuous applause.
Nearly all of the seats in All Souls' Church (Anthon Memorial) were occupied yesterday afternoon, and the Rev. R. Heber Newton's lecture on "The-Book of Genesis" was listened to with much interest.

The Rev. Mr. Truve, Pastor of the Baptist Church at Gothenburg, Sweden, gave the congregation of the Church of the Epiphany, at Sixty-fourth-street and Madison-avenue, yesterday, a graphic account of tha missionary work now in progress in his native country.

For the last two or three weeks detectives have been engaged in a search for James S. Fox, a boy 19 years old, who used to be a driver in the employ of the Delaware, Lackawana and Western Express Company.

A young man, wearing a resolute expression of countenance and a clerical frock coat, made his appearance about 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon in that particularly fragrant corner of Long Island known as Hunter's Point.

Frank Eberhard, who was arrested in Bridgeport, Conn., Saturday, charged with forging a check for $200 on the Park Bank, of this City, is a tinsmith, but has never been very Ready in pursuing his occupation. His father Francis Eberhard, lives at Willis-avenue and One Hundred and Forty-first-street, and is in ...

SYDNEY, New South Wales, Dec. 9.--The intercolonial conference, before adjourning, passed resolutions against the landing in New Guinea of convicts from other islands, and against recognizing purchases of land in New Guinea before British dominion over that island has been established.
The fascination exercised by the North on the people of middle Europe and the united. States is only second to that of the South, which has hitherto had Italy for its main centre of attraction.

The representation of the "Birds" of Aristophanes, by a company of undergraduates, is something more than a continuation of the series of revivals of the Greek drama begun with the "Agamemnon" at Oxford, and continued by the " OEdipus" at Harvard, and the "Ajax" at Cambridge last year.

Two small boys--the one a bootblack and the other a little more ragged and without visible means of support--were among the listeners, yesterday, to the preacher who usually discourses on Sunday from the steps of the City Hall. The speaker was extremely sonorous and energetic.

PATRICK O'DONNELL, while on the way to the Cape of Good Hope, shot and killed CAREY, the Irish informer, on whose evidence the Phoenix Park murderers were convicted. Nothing can be said in extenuation of the assassins of CAVENDISH and BURKE.
HONESDALE, Dec. 9.--Among the death notices in a local paper of a Southern county in this State on Friday last appeared the following:

A drove of Texas steers was put ashore from a cattle-boat at Forty-fifth-street, East River, yesterday, and driven into the slaughter-house of Schwarzschild Sulzberger. One of them broke loose and ran toward First-avenue. Emanuel Stiner, a slaughterer, who was going to work tried to head the unruly beast, but was tossed 20 feet and hurt severely. The bullock was checked at Forty-seventh-street and Firstavenue and driven back to the slaughter-house.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Dec. 9.--At the Mercantile Library Hall to-night James F. Gein and wife, of New-York, were giving a Spiritualistic performance, toward the close of which Gein stepped into an ante-room at the near of the stage to rest after the exhausting cabinet exhibition. When followed two minutes later by his wife he was found dead on the floor. An examination by a physician present, showed that death had resulted from heart disease.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9.--It is generally understood among the members of Congress that the holiday recess will be taken within a week or 10 days.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 9.--Young Fred Ely went to his sriend Dave Tilden's room in the Ontario House this morning and helped himself to some money in Tilden's pocket. Charles Ainger, Tilden's chum, mistook Ely for a burglar and shot him in the neck. The bullet plowed around to the right side of the neck, barely missing the jugular, and was extracted. The wound is dangerous but not fatal. Ely refuses to prosecute Ainger.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 9.--The Democrats are in power in the Cleveland City Council, and, after long deliberation, have decided to redistrict the city wards so that there will be 3 or 24 instead of the present number--18.

The interior of the Lexington-Avenue Baptist Church was tastefully decorated with flags and banners yesterday, in honor of the fifteenth anniversary of the organization of the Sunday-school out of which the church grew.

ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 9.--Judge Osborne, who is holding a session of the Supreme Court here, said to-night that he understood that District Attorney Herrick would offer a motion to-morrow to enter a nolle prusequi in the cases of A.D. Barber, "Ed" Phelps, and another, charged with attempted bribery and corruption in the Senatorial contest in 1881.

George Franck, of Orange, who tried to kill himself Friday afternoon, was much better yesterday. The date of the letter which he wrote to his wife before drawing the razor across his throat was in ink and legible. The text of the letter was in lead-pencil, and an almost undecipherable scrawl. BRANFORD, Conn., Dec. 9.--Mrs. Samuel Pond has only just received the particulars of the death of her husband, Captain of the Providence schooner, the C.H. Sprague, which occurred Nov. 27 off the coast of North Carolina.

It was not a thousand years ago, nor a thousand miles from Rochester, that a party of gentlemen sat down to play a quiet little game of "five-cent ante." In fact, several games of fivecent-ante were played, for the party was a large one.

One of the watchmen on Bedloe's Isand and a laborer named Hayes went out on the Bay in a small boat yesterday afternoon. They were evidently under the influence of liquor, and when in the Buttermilk Channel the boat was capsized. The crew of the tug Bertram, which was passing at the three, rescued the men with a great deal of difficulty. They were landed at the Battery and were sent to the Chambers-Street Hospital.

NORWICH, Conn., Dec. 8.--The decision of the Supreme Court respecting the Civil Rights act awakened much interest among the colored people of this city, and thus far they have been alone in the State in taking action.

NEW-ORLEANS, Dec. 9.--The Italian Consul, Count Marefoschi, called on the Mayor yesterday to state that from 1,000 to 1,500 Italian laborers were in the city and without work, and liable to commit excesses.

The Right Rev. Mgr. Quinn, Vicar-General, at 7:30 o'clock yesterday morning said the mass for the members of tha Society of St. Vincent de Paul in the Chapel of the Blessed Virgin Mary, in St. Patrick's. Cathedral, Fifth-avenue.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9--Marshal Paul Strobach, of Alabama, who arrived here to-day, is indignant about the publication in the papers of a dispatch emanating from the Department of Justice representing that all of his deputies have been discharged for official misconduct.
Four young men led a Catholic priest into the Chambers-Street Hospital soon after 12 o'clock this morning. The priest wore a clerical garb, with the exception that the collar was missing.

CHEYENNE, Wyoming Territory, Dec. 9.-- Articles of incorporation were filed yesterday by the Wyoming, Yellowstone Park and Pacific Railway Company. Among the incorporators are L. Dupont, powder manufacturer; A.R. Converse, President of the First National Bank, Cheyenne, and Gov. Hale, of Wyoming.

HARTFORD, Dec. 8.--The people and the active politicians do not get very far apart in the little State of Connecticut. The force at the disposal of the office-holding politicians is small and they are compelled, by a regard for their own interests, to respect.

The bar-room in Lyric Hall presented a somewhat chaotic appearance at about 8 o'clock last night. Gentlemen in all stages of excitement and good humor were all talking together and gesticulating furiously.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Dec. 9.--The Pittsburg, Cleveland and Toledo Road, which runs from New-Castle Junction to Akron, by way of Youngstown, is just completed and a formal opening will occur some time next month. Twelve new passenger coaches have just been received.

On behalf of Mr. Theodore Thomas the statement, sent by cable from London through the Associated Press, that the projected tour in this country of Mme. Materna, Herr Winkelmann, and Herr Scarja had been abandoned, is contradicted.

WATERBURY, Conn., Dec. 9.--Benjamin Brown, a colored waiter, who was arrested at Ansonia on Wednesday for a robbery at the Eldridge mansion, at Norfolk, Conn., last Summer, will have a hearing to-morrow at Norfolk.

SCRANTON, Penn., Dec. 9.--Vincent Wilson shot and fatally wounded Frank Thomas at Taylorville, a short distance from Scranton, at midnight last night. The tragedy took place on the principal street, near the Post Office, and caused intense excitement.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 9.--The great oil strike below Youngstown some months ago has not fulfilled expectations, but a new excitement has sprung up in a lower belt of territory. In Raccoon Township, just over the border in Pennsylvania, a number of farms have been leased by ...
NEW-LONDON, Conn., Dec. 9.--Groton people are as indignant as ever over the failure of George S. Avery to marry Mrs. Charlotte Avery, but the talk of tar and feathers has subsided.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Dec. 9.--About three years ago Tom Johnson came to Cleveland from Indianapolis and bought a one-horse street railroad running from the Square to the suburban town of Brooklyn. It was necessary for him to run over the tracks of the West Side Road, a powerful corporation that ...

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Dec. 9.--Francis J. Parmenter, a respectable and inoffensive citizen, 52 years of age, engaged in the wood and coal business, was found dead in his barn in Bassettstreet about midnight last night. His skull had been terribly fractured, presumably by blows ...

At a meeting of the Central Labor Union yesterday afternoon, in Odd-fellow's Hall, in Second-street, a resolution was adopted calling upon the President, "in the interests of humanity and the American people, to use his prerogative for a stay of proceedings" in the case of the convicted O'Donnell.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Dec. 9.--A brutal prize-fight was fought on Saturday afternoon at the borough of Parsons between two young miners named Thomas McGarin and Michael Cox, between whom there was a rivaly as to each other's ability to hit the hardest.

NEW-LONDON, Dec. 9.--Janet Cochrane, of Millstone Point, Waterford, a suburban town of this city, puts in a claim, and with good reason, to the unsettled estate of John Russell, "the miser printer," who died in New-York City last May, leaving some $60,000 in cash in City banks, the earnings of long years of faithful, honest toil at the case.
TOMBSTONE, Arizona, Dec. 9.--Five mounted men raided the town of Bisbee last night. They killed J.C. Tappiner, J.A. Nolly, and D.A. Smith, and wounded ...
The total receipts into the Treasury of Pennsylvania during the year ending on the 30th ult. were $6,775,430.

BOSTON, Dec. 10.--The Harvard Freshmen eleven have finally declined the challenge of the Yale Freshmen eleven to play off the tie in foot-ball. Harvard's reasons are that it would be difficult, if not impossible, to get into playing trim in the short time left, and that the men cannot spare the time from their studies.
NEW-HAVEN, Dec. 10.--The drug store of Carroll C. Davis, of Walpole, N.H., was robbed of over $7,000 worth of registered bonds and a considerable amount of property in stock Friday night.

These last seven years have given occasion to the Americans and to their foreign friends to give utterance to many congratulations about the happy result of that struggle of a century ago [the war of independence.]

MONROVIA, Penn., Dec. 10.--George W. Morrow, living near this place, has a stone quarry on his farm. While digging away the earth and stones to reach the surface of the rock to be quarried, he came upon a large number of large stones, different from any found in the neighborhood.

ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 10.--A curious case of robbery is reported at Bath-on-the-Hudson, opposite this city. About 1 o'clock yesterday morning, Mrs. Mary E. Whitney, who has been living apart from her husband for the past six months, was startled from her sleep by the consciousness that there was an intruder in her bedchamber.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Dec. 10.--Mr. Rogers, the missing Lewis County Treasurer, was seen at Norwood Saturday, and went east from there. Being of an excitable temperament it is believed that he became insane because he could not make his books balance. He thought he owed the country $4,000, when the country owed him $17. Friends are searching for him.

ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 10.--Wheeler H. Peckham, who was recently appointed District Attorney of New-York to fill the vacancy caused by the death of John McKeon, has sent the following letter of resignation to Gov. Cleveland:
GLOUCESTER, Mass., Dec. 10.--It is feared that four more of the overdue fishing vessels are lost, making nine in all with at least 120 men on board.
CAIRO, Dec. 10.--The troops recently dispatched to Suakim had not arrived there on the 2d inst, when the defeat of the Egyptians near that place occurred.
WALDEN, N.Y., Dec. 10.--The Rev. William W. De Hart has not preached in his church here for two Sundays. He blacked the eyes and skinned the nose of his chorister, John Best, two weeks ago to-night.

The trial of the suit brought by Fewster Williston against John E. Parsons and others, Executors of the late Hugh Maxwell, to recover damages sustained by the plaintiff, when Mr. Maxwell was Collector of the Port in 1851, has been in progress before Judge Coxe and a jury in the United States District Court for the past week.

DETROIT, Mich., Dec. 10.--The steam barge Enterprise was sunk on Lake Huron this morning and seven lives lost. The Enterprise was coming down in tow of the tug Balize. When this side of Port Austin she signalled the tug that she was sinking.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10.--Members of the Republican National Committee are beginning to arrive for the meeting to be held on Wednesday, and delegations of citizens of various cities are also coming in to try to secure the National Convention for their respective towns.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Dec. 10.--The Supreme Court to-day refused to discharge the receiver of the Quidnick Company, but amended its decree so far as to authorize the Quidnick Company to sell its real estate, mills and machinery. It is understood that the mills at Arctic and Aquidneck will be at once offered for sale.

LONDON, Dec. 10.--Owing to the growing excitement in Irish circles in this city relative to the sentence of O'Donnell extra guards have been stationed at all the prisons and Government officers as a precaution against any effort that may be made by O'Donnell's Irish friends in the way of reprisals.

The police of Orange and some of the detectives at work on the Phoebe Paullin murder case cling to the notion that there is something in the clues that lead up to George Franck, the beer bottles who attempted suicide.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10.--Representative Frank Hiscock, of New-York, gave a small dinner party to-night at the Arlington, in honor of Congressman and Governor-elect George D. Robinson, of Massachusetts. Speaker Carlisle and a number of Representatives and Senators were among the guests. Mr. Robinson's days in Congress are numbered, as he will resign during the holiday recess, in order to take the oath as successor of Gov. Butler.

With a black patch over his left eye, Assistant District Attornes O'Byrne appeared in the Court of Oyer and Terminer yesterday to prosecute Amedee Bigot for the murder of Mrs. Harriette Renaut. The crime was committed on Aug. 11, 1880, at No. 14 Thompson-street, where Mrs. Renaut lived. Bigot cut her throat with a razor, and afterward cut his own throat.

John Kirk, a good-for-nothing fellow, 26 years old, was yesterday charged in the Essex Market Police Court, before Justice Duffy, with No. 357 Madison-street, and stealing her bankbook. He was sentenced to 12 months in the penitentiary, and then he struck at his mother, but was caught by the court officers and hustled out of the room.
The elevation of ALFRED TENNYSON to the peerage was almost a foregone conclusion. The honor would no doubt have been conferred upon him years ago if he had been a rich man.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10.--Judge Wylie this morning, before proceeding with the business of the court, referred to the case of ex-Senator Spencer, charged with contempt, in refusing to obey a subpoena to attend as a witness at the first star route trial. He said it seemed to be understood that the court was to decide the case this morning.

During last week 96 subscribers were added to the stockholders of the new Real Estate Exchange and Auction Rooms, (limited,) and the subscriptions now amount to $211,000. Among the more prominent of the property-owners who placed their names on the books of the Exchange ...

Testimony in support of the theory outlined by Assistant District Attorney Fellows at the opening, last Saturday, of the trial of Policeman William Conroy for the murder of Peter Keenan, was introduced in the Court of General Session yesterday. John Buckley was the first witness called.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Dec. 10.--The Postal Telegraph Company has stretched across the bed of the Mississippi a cable which connects it with the East. The company has nearly completed its line between here and Chicago, and will begin operations here by the new year.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Dec. 10.--T.O. Sparks, a Williams College Senior from Manchester, Vt., was arrested to-day for stealing a gold watch and a sum of money from W.A. Phelps, a Sophomore, who roomed near him. Failing to get bonds.

Proceedings in a Case of forgery, the Amount involved being 30,000 francs, were abandoned yesterday in the Jefferson Market Police Court, under peculiar circumstances. Shortly before 10 o'clock in the morning Officer Thomas Gonnolly, of the Sixteenth Precinct, was on post in Seventh-avenue.

NEW-ORLEANS, Dec. 10.--The Austrian bark Josip, Giurieevich master, arrived yesterday from Cape Town, South Africa. She left Cape Town Oct. 15, and as part of her freight had 23 ostriches, all of which reached here alive, with Mr. E.J. Johnson, of Maine, Agent of the American Ostrich Company, a corporation organized under the laws of Maine.

LIMA, Dec., 10, via GALVESTON.--La Tribuna published a letter from Yea to Gen. Iglesias stating that Ayacbuico was occupied by Gen. Bermudez with a force of infantry and cavalry, and that shortly afterward Caceres occupied the town. The latter is now preparing to leave for Lima.

FALL RIVER, Mass., Dec. 10.--From recent investigations it has been learned that more speculative insurance business has been carried on in this city than in any other place in the country, not even excepting Pennsylvania, which enjoyed an unenviable reputation a few years ago for the glaring frauds perpetrated under the very eyes of the companies.

The Rev. Father Mendel, of the Montclair (N.J.) Roman Catholic church, who is charged with having assaulted John McCarthy at a mass at the church three months ago, was before Judge McCarter in Newark yesterday for examination. McCarthy testified that he had gone to mass and tried to get out to escape the collection.

The Special Committee of the Chamber of Commerce to whom was referred the subject of the preservation of the Adirondack forests organized yesterday by electing Morris K. Jesup Chairman. It was resolved to circulate for signatures petitions asking the Legislature to make the Adirondack region State property.

George H. Meyers, a clerk employed by ex-Assemblyman Robert B. Roosevelt, was also the collector of the rents on Mr. Roosevelt's property. He collected $17,912 50 between May 1, 1881, and July 22, 1882, but only accounted for $15,649 32, leaving a balance of $2,263 18 unpaid.

WATERBURY, Conn., Dec. 10.--A communication is published here this afternoon relative to a recent dispatch giving an account of the finding some years ago of the remains of a crew who had died from scurvy on "Big Shelter Island, off the Chinese coast."

TROY, Dec. 10.--A paper is being circulated among all the knit goods manufacturers of the country, and signatures are asked to a resolulution to run their mills on three-quarter time from Dec. 15 to April 15. Ex-Mayor Bogue is the committee appointed to canvass Cohoes, and he says he has obtained the signatures of all but two ...
NEW-HAVEN, Dec. 10.--The Empire Transportation Company and the New-England Transportation Company have decided to consolidate their business. The agreement goes into effect Jan. 1.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10.--With a view to settling the serious troubles that have been attended with murder and other crimes, existing between the Central Pacific Railroad Company and settlers upon the Moquelumne grant in California, the Secretary of the Interior has requested the Attorney-General to bring a suit in the united States Court to set aside the patent in order to determine the question of title.
Mr. MOROSINI was present at the opening of Judge VAN BRUNT'S court yesterday morning, but he did not bring with him the books of the firm of W.E. CONNOR CO.

PERTH AMBOY, N.J., Dec. 10.--Notwithstanding the statement made by the woman at Quakerstown, who admits that she is Amanda Flucks, and that although at times she lived with the self-confessed murderer, John Koop, she was never in Perth Amboy.

ANDERSON, Ind., Dec. 10.--This morning about 10 o'clock the boiler in Shipley Brothers' saw mill at Clay Pool, Ind., exploded, completely wrecking the building. John Haddix, the engineer, was instantly killed, his head and arm being torn from his body. Harris Ramsey had one leg torn off and received such injuries about the head and back that he cannot possibly live.

Brown of Chicago. In his complaint Brown avers that he was employed to watch over ...

GOSHEN, N.Y., Dec. 10.--Dr. E.W. Martin, one Milk Inspectors under the direction of the State Board of Health, inspected the cheese factory of Lawrence Durland, at Chester, N. Y., a short time ago. The firm manufacture Neufchatel cheese, of which they sell 5,000 daily, principally in New-York.

A collision occured shortly before 4 o'clock yesterday morning, in the East River, opposite Williamsburg, between the Grandstreet ferry-boat Commodore Perry, and the tug-boat McMahon. The latter was bound up the East River, while the ferryboat was crossing from the Williamsburg side.
In the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday five persons were held for selling liquor on Sunday. John Renker, of No. 540 Hudsonstreet, was committed for selling liquor without ...

UTICA, Dec. 10.--About a year ago Dr. Thomas Spear, of this city, who for a score of years had been regarded as a respectable physician, was indicted for criminal malpractice resulting in the death of a woman, and was released on $10,000 bail, his wife and son-in-law becoming sureties.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10.--The enormous proportions to which the practice of granting public lands to railway corporations has grown within recent years has attracted a great deal of attention and has been the subject of severe criticism by many persons.
The Chamber of Deputies has granted the amount of credit asked by the Government for the prosecution of the Tonquin expedition by a vote of 381 to 146.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 10.--Edward P. Conkling, Prosecutor of the Pleas for Hunterdon County, entered a nolle pros, this afternoon in the Supreme Court, in the matter of the indictment for libel obtained by Senator Carpenter, of Hunterdon County, against Lawrence S. Mott, editor of the Trenton Times. This discontinues the case. The civil suit for $10,00 damages brought by Senator Carpenter against the Times Publishing Company had also been settled.

LONDON, Dec. 10.--The Mark Lane Express, in its weekly review of the British grain trade, says: "The weather has been frosty, and there has been snow in the south and in the midlands. During the week there was rather more pressure to sell English wheat, and values were consequently weaker.

Primary elections were held last evening in the 25 wards of Brooklyn and in the five county towns of Kings County to elect delegates to the Democratic General Committee and officers of the ward and town associations. Mr. Joseph C. Hendrix, the late Democratic candidate for Mayor, was re-elected to the General Committee Committee remains under the control of the McLaughlin influence.

The case of Ira C. JAMESTOWN, Dec. 10.--Thomas Harcraft, of Westfield, aged 65, committed suicide by cutting his throat on Sunday during mental aberration. He leaves a widow and daughter. He was of English birth and was a farmer by occupation. He leaves a large property.

Dr. Willard Parker, who has been seriously ill for some time past, was very much improved yesterday, and at a late hour last evening his son, Dr. Willard Parker, Jr., said that the chances of his recovery were good, his strong constitution having been greatly in his favor. His disease is pyelitis of the right kidney.

BALTIMORE, Md., Dec. 10.--A dispatch from Cambridge University, England, announces that Prof. Sylvester, of Johns Hopkins University, has been elected Savilian Professor of Mathematics in the University of Oxford. The election was held on Wednesday last. It is understood that he accepts the appointment and will henceforth be enrolled as a Professor Emeritus on the staff of Johns Hopkins.

PARIS, Dec. 10.--In the Chamber of Deputies to-day the debate upon the Tonquin Credits bill was resumed. M. Pelletan reaproached the Government for its colonial policy, and compared the events in Tonquin with what had been done in Tunis.

Father Hoyt, who were struck with paralysis in the pulpit of St. Ann's Church on Saturday morning, is very low, and it is not expected that he will recover.

Police Commissioner Jourdan, of Brooklyn, yesterday submitted his annual report to mayor Low. The total strength of the police force, including Superintendent, Inspectors, Captains, Sergeants, detectives, roundsmen, patrolmen, and doormen, is 665 men.

The funeral of the late Col. Michael W. Burns took place from St. Peter's Church, in Barclay-street, yesterday morning. The casket containing the remains rested at the head of the broad centre aisle while a solemn high mass was celebrated.

Hood was sustained in his decision, made at the Kentucky Conference, whereby Bishop W.H. Hillery was silenced, and his conduct on that occasion severely criticised and strongly condemned.

Mr. and Mrs. James Stebbins gave a large ball last evening at their residence, No. 20 East Thirty-seventh-street, in honor of the entrance of their daughter, Miss Blanche Stebbins, into society. Over 500 invitations were sent out. Miss Stebbins was dressed in white.

ALBANY, Dec. 10.--In the Court of Oyer and Terminer to-day District Attorney Herrick moved that a nolle prosequi be entered in the cases of A.T. Barber, Edward Phelps, and Charles Edwards, indicted for bribery. The motion was made in view of the acquittal of Mr. Sessions.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Dec. 10.--Five Germen young men of this city, four of whom are Otto Haelgenberg, Max Reich, Robert Reich, and Walter Schultz left their boarding-house early this morning to go down the Niagara River duck shooting. The name of the fifth member of the party has not been ascertained.

TROY, N.Y., Dec. 10.--Peter Powers, a farm hand employed by Elmer Waite, of Easton, Washington County, was brought to this city on Sunday night in a dying condition. During the afternoon, on a hay mound, he took off his shoes, and pointing a gun at his chin pulled the trigger with his toe. A portion of his chin and nose were taken off, and his face is badly burned.

In Justice Naeher's court, Brooklyn, yesterday, James L. Buchanan, a confectioner, of No. 75 Broadway, and James H. Hathaway, of No. 185 South Fifth-street, preferred counter charges of assault against each other.

While returning from Calvary Cemetery last evening, the drunken driver of a coach drove off the Blissville, Long Island, bridge into Newtown Creek. The driver escaped unhurt. John Nulty, of No. 175 Mott-street, this City, the occupant of the coach, received injuries which will probably prove fatal. The horses were drowned, and the coach was totally wrecked.

TROY, Dec. 10.--While a non-union molder named Harrison was in a saloon, Sunday night, on Fifteenth-street, a pistol was fired through a window. The ball took effect in his scalp. He fell senseless, but is now out of danger.

Greenville, Miss, Dec. 10.--A difficulty occurred at a political meeting between a colored man named Homer and Frank Montgomery. Sam Finlay, a white man, was seriously injured and three negroes were shot one, Homer, being killed outright, one so seriously wounded that he is not expected to live, and the other slightly wounded. A Coroner's jury found that Homer was killed by Montgomery and Finlay. The trouble was caused by local politics.

LA CROSSE, Wis., Dec. 10.--A number of boys, while playing about a haystack in this city this afternoon, discovered the emaciated, but living form of Louis Anderson. It appears that the stack fell on and buried him on Nov. 17, and that he has been there ever since through some very severe weather without food or water. He is a mere skeleton, but is able to speak, and it is believed that he will survives.

BANGOR, Me., Dec. 11.--The Mapleson Concert Company appeared in the opera-house here this evening. The company has been traveling through Canada with great success. Davis was on his way to Chicago. He was arrested and brought to Amsterdam to-night, where he will be prosecuted for deserting his wife and family.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Dec. 12.--At noon today Mrs. Patrick McCaffrey, aged 70 years, was found lying across her cook's stove burned to a crisp. It is supposed that while preparing dinner she was seized with apoplexy and fell on the stove. She leaves a family of grown-up children.

The Sophomores and Freshmen of the Columbia School of Mines have been unable to settle their differences as to the carrying of canes by the Freshmen this Fall, and consequently the rushes have been frequent.

ALBANY, Dec. 12.--Those Democratic State officers who were so fortunate as to be elected last month are preparing, with much deliberation, to violate the spirit of the civil service reform law passed last Winter by a Legislature of their own party.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Dec. 12.--The Irish State Convention, called to amalgamate all the Irish organizations in Wisconsin in behalf of Ireland, began its session at the Academy of Music to-day with over 400 delegates, representing the several benevolent, military, and certain religious societies of the Irish in every corner of the State.

"Which seats can you give me for to-morrow evening?" he asked of the man in the box-office. "Can give you a couple in 'Q' [the seventeenth row from the orchestra] in gallery seats."
ROME, Dec. 12.--Signor Mario died of angina pectoris after an illness of two days. His dying charge was to present his homage and farewell to Queen Victoria.

SING SING, Dec. 12.--The village of Tarrytown was shocked this morning to learn of the terrible death of a very highly esteemed lady, a long resident of the place.

CHICAGO, Dec. 13.--Some malicious fiends entered the synagogue of the Jewish congregation of Anshe Russia at the corner, of Clinton and Judd streets last night and made sad havoc of everything perishable.

GIRARDVILLE, Penn., Dec. 13.--Small-pox has again broken out here, three young girls be ing sick with it. A meeting of the Town Council will be held to take action in regard to closing the public schools to prevent the disease from spreading.

CINCINNATI, Dec. 13.--The American Base-ball Association concluded its business tonight. The proceedings were harmonious from the beginning and the delegates go home feeling that the interests of the national game were never so well guarded as now or the outlook brighter.

DENVER, Col., Dec.13.--One of the largest cattle sales on record was consummated here today. H.D. J.W. Snyder Co., of this city bought of Snyder Brothers of Georgetown, Texas, over 29,000 head of cattle and 400 horses, for a consideration of $600,000 cash. The former firm now owns nearly 54,000 head of cattle and 1,000 horses.
The arbitrators appointed to hear the arguments on the appeals from the percentages awarded by Commissioner Fink in the east and west bound pools met yesterday at the Commissioner's office.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 12.--The commission of medical experts appointed by Gov. Pattison to inquire into the mental condition of John McGinnis, convicted of killing his mother-in-law, has forwarded to the Governor majority and minority reports.

Jenks for appellant, submitted for respondent. No. 170--William B. Scott et. al., appellants vs. Charles Morgan, respondent argued by Henry P. Starbuck for appellants, George J. MATAWAN, N.J., Dec. 13.--Charles M. Delaney, the colored man from Long Branch who was charged with making an indecent assault on the 5-year-old daughter of George Perrine, was sentenced to State prison for two years. He was also charged with stealing a quantity of jewelry, for which an additional sentence of 10 years was added.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Dec. 13.--The political trials in the United States Circuit Court at Columbia were brought to an abrupt end today by Judge Bond, who ordered all the cases to be continued until the next term of the court.

Several human lives were imperiled by a fire which started at 4 o'clock yesterday morning in the cellar of the three-story frame building No. 204 Madison-street, the lower portion of which was occupied by Garrett Redman as a stable and feed store.

Gen. Alexander S. Webb, President of the College of the City of New-York, read a paper upon the relation of the Military Service Institution to the National Guard before the institution, on Governor's Island, yesterday afternoon.

There was great excitement in Southstreet at noon yesterday. A large and disorderly crowd witnessed the return of the ferry-boat Garden City to James-slip enveloped in flames and emitting dense volumes of smoke.

ST. CHARLES, La., Dec. 13.--Last night while Robert Landry, James Collins, and George Thielmann were attempting to arrest a man named Thomas Cole, who is wanted in Texas for horse stealing, Landry and Collins were fired at by Cole, and Laudry was seriously wounded. Thielmann then fired at Cole and killed him.

BATAVIA, Dec. 13.--One of the most important lawsuits ever tried in this county has just been amicably settled, after over five years' struggle in the courts and the disbursement of large sums of money for costs.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Dec. 13.--There was a rich scene in the St. Louis Circuit Court to-day-, in which Henry Boemler, a prominent attorney, and Benjamin Von Phule, a real estate dealer, played prominent parts.

Mr. Felix Moscheles, the eminent London artist, held a reception yesterday morning in the studio building at Twenty-fifth-street and Fourth-avenue. A numuer of artists, nearly all of whom were ladies, were present to see Mr. Moscheles paint a portrait from life and to hear a few remarks about art.
PITTSBURG, Penn., Dec. 13.--The SpencerClayburgh divorce proceedings were the talk of the town to-day. Public sympathy is almost entirely with Miss Spencer.
Capt. Burnap, of the British steam-ship Glendowe, which arrived yesterday from Lisbon, reports that on Dec. 9, in latitude 34 58' and longitude 53 5', he encountered a dismasted vessel.

City Controller Young, of Jersey City, submitted his annual statement of the condition of the city finances to the Board of Finance last Wednesday evening. The bonded and floating debt is $13,670,095. This does not include the water debt, $4,833,000, which is self-sustaining. There is due to the city in unpaid taxes $4,771,849.60, to which is to be added $2,941,422.80, due for assessments for street imporvements and sewers.

ATLANTA, Ga., Dec. 13.--The Colored Educational Convention had a quiet but interesting session here this morning, the time being taken up in five-minutes speeches on the educational situation in Georgia and the best way to increase the school facilities.

The great social event of the week in New-York was Vanderbilt's ball. * * * The host seems to have been in excellent spirits. He did not talk stocks, did not give out points to buy Lake Shore, New-York Central, at any other stock he is anxious to get rid of, and said to everybody that he was in excellent health, "having had a very easy Summer of it, and bothering but little about business."

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 13.--Switch Superintendent John Lucy found a paper package in a freight car opposite the ladies' entrance to the Union Station in this city to-night which contained bonds worth over $7,000. They were handed over to Chief of Police Webster.
WASHINGTON, Penn., Dec. 13.--Lizzie Zelt, a girl of 18, was so badly burned last night by the explosion of a lamp that she will probably not recover.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13.--The nomination for Commissioner of Internal Revenue of Mr. Walter Evans, who was appointed by the President after the last Congress adjourned, is now before the Finance Committee of the Senate and will be acted upon soon.

BOSTON, Dec. 13.--At its meeting to-night the Boston Civil Service Reform Association prepared a bill for legislative enactment providing for the adoption of civil services rules in the State Government.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Dec.13.--This evening while James W. Mackey, one of the wealthiest farmers of Scottsboro, Ala., was deriving home in his carriage, three rowdies rode up beside him on horseback, firing several shots in the air, which so frightened the horse that Mr. Mackey was thrown out of the carriage on his head, breaking his neck and killing him instantly.

SAVANNAH, Ga., Dec. 13.--The down night passenger train ran into the up freight near the 92-mile post, on the Central Railroad of Georgia early this morning. Both trains were wrecked. J.F. Wilson, of Davisborough, Ga., was killed; G.H. and S.B. Stephens, of Bartow, Ga., were badly wounded; Fanny Freeman, (colored,) of Milledgeville, Ga., had a leg broken; Fireman Mike Falvev was badly injured.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13.--During the session Of the Senate to-day President pro tem. Edmunds called Mr. Ingalls to the Chair, and then introduced a resolution to the effect that the Senate proceed to the election of a President pro tem.
SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Dec. 13.--Charles McLaughlin was shot and killed here to-day by Jerome B. Cox. The tragedy was the result of 17 years' litigation.

At large audience assembled yesterday afternoon at the hand-ball court No. 159 East Thirty-fifth-street to see the champion, Phil Casey, play single-handed against William Courtney and Frank Reynolds. The contest was to decide a private bet.

The Society for Instruction in First Aid to the Injured will begin its third year under the most favorable auspices. In 1881 and 1882 the number of pupils reached 540, which was increased last Winter to 995.

WINNIPEG, Manitoba, Dec. 13.--There are no new developments regarding the dead-lock on the Canadian Pacific Railway. One train went south this morning. New engineers are expected to-night, when all express trains will be equipped and sent out. The engineers held a meeting today, but nothing of importance resulted. Superintendent Egan refuses to recognize the President of the Brotherhood in the matter.

A new game of billiards has been originated as a substitute for the champions' cushion-carom, and eight-inch-continuous-balk-line games by the Collender Company.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 13.--Four vessels which departed from, and were bound to, this port at various periods since July 27 have never been heard from, and are supposed to have been lost at sea. One of the vessels, the new schooner Joseph Hilton, sailed from Darien, Ga., on Sept. 4 with 400,000 feet of lumber, under the command of Capt. Rodgers and a crew of seven men.

RALEIGH, N.C., Dec. 13.--The Rev. Dr. A. A. Watson, of Wilmington, has been unanimously elected Bishop of the new Episcopal diocese by the convention at Newbern.

The managers of the Home for Old Men and Aged Couples, at No. 487 Hudson-street, gave their yearly reception yesterday afternoon to friends of the institution. Addresses were made by Assistant Bishop Potter, the Rev. Dr. Tuttle, of St. Luke's Church, and the Rev. Mr. Lobdell.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Dec. 13.--Besides the additional 10 pounds of wheat that the millers are allowed to import for each barrel of flour exported, the Government have given an assurance as to all the demands of the millers respecting the reduction or absolute abolition of the grain duties.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Dec. 13.--The ceremony of conferring the pallium on Archbishop Elder, the successor of the late Archbishop Purcell, took place at the cathedral here to-day. The pallium was brought from Rome by a special messenger, the Rev. Dr. Smith. After the procession of clergymen entered the sanctuary, Bishop McCloskey, of Louisville, celebrated pontifical high mass.

BALTIMORE, Md., Dec. 13.--A match game of chess was played this afternoon and evening between Dr. Zukertort, of London, and Mr. Alexander G. Sellman, of this city. Dr. Zukertort had the opening move, and Mr. Sellman played the French defense. On the forty-second move Dr. Zuketort resigned, giving the game to his opponent. The play began at 4 o'clock and concluded at 9:45.

The annual meeting of the New-York Coffee Exchange occurred yesterday. The President, Mr. B.G. Arnold, made an address, and the Treasurer, John F. Scott, submitted his report. The total receipts from the sale of seats have been $178,000.

A daring attempt was made on Wednesday evening by two second-story thieves to rob the residence of Mr. Charles Blauvelt, an attache of the Register's Office, at No.13 West One Hundred and Thirty-fourth-street.

LONDON, Dec. 13.--The solicitors and friends of O'Donnell have found six of the jurors who convicted him.
The passenger agents occupied the entire day yesterday in the discussion of the proposed interior pools, but no decision was arrived at. The matter will be again taken up to-day.

The fair in the basement of St. Stephen's Church, in East Twenty-eighth-street, is attracting much attention, and the hall is filled every evening with persons desirous of assisting the Rev. Dr. McGlynn in reducing the debt on his church and other property.

TORONTO, Ontario, Dec. 13.--A fight took place in Albert Hall, this evening, between Billy Dacey, the champion light-weight of Brooklyn, and Harry Gilmour, champion lightweight of Canada, for the receipts of house, about $500.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13.--In March, 1881, soon after President Garfield's inauguration, the attention of the country was centred upon the efforts of the Senate of the United States to decide, by a vote of the two parties therein represented, who should hold the offices in the gift of the upper branch of Congress.

The patients and other inmates of Charity Hospital, Blackwell's Island, were entertained last evening in the ampitheatre of the hospital in a manner which they highly appreciated. Mr. Frank Lincoln gave one of his dramatic and humorous recitals, assisted by Miss Bischoff.

DETROIT, Dec. 13.--In the United States court this morning Dr. Robert L. Douglass, of Stony Creek, Washtenaw County, on a plea of guity of forging pension papers, was sentenced to the Detroit House of Correction for four years.

LONDON, Dec. 13.--Mr. W.E. Forster, M. P., ex-Chief Secretary for Ireland, addressed his constituents to-night at Bradford. He said that in any franchise bill that the Government might introduce in Parliament he inferred that they intended that it should include Ireland;

FALL RIVER, Mass., Dec. 13.--The investigation of the insurance frauds causes much discussion among the policy-holders of mutual benefit companies, of whom there are several thousand in this city. The business has been going on for two years, and many fraudulent claims have doubtless been paid. The matter was first mentioned when the insurance frauds were unearthed in Pennsylvania, and for several months has been quietly discussed here.
CLEVELAND, Dec. 13.--On the evening of Dec. 23, 1873, Dr. Dio Lewis spoke on temperance in Hillsboro, Highland County, Ohio.

The Commissioners recently appointed by Mayor Edson, under the Rapid Transit act, to consider the necessity of providing further railway facilities for this City, in accordance with the increase of its population and business interests, held their first public meeting last evening at the Fifth-Avenue Hotel.

The State Charities Aid Association met yesterday afternoon at No. 6 East Fourteenthstreet. Mr. Charles S. Fairchild presided.

ROME, Dec. 13.--The body of Signor Mario, the tenor, was buried to-day. The funeral ceremonies were attended by a large assemblage of notable persons, including Signor Cusino, Queen Victoria's master of music. WASHINGTON, DEC. 13.--Capt. Potter, commanding the Lancaster, reports, under date of Marseilles, France, Nov. 21, an act of bravery on the part of Matthew Gillick, boatswain's mate, and J.F. Aver, ordinary seaman, in rescuing a French boy from drowning at the risk of their own lives.

NYACK, N.Y., Dec. 13.--John Ryan, 60 years old, of Blauveltville, and Edward McDonald, aged 65, of Piedmont, were run over and killed by an express train on the West Shore Railroad near this place this afternoon.

PARIS, Dec. 18.--The health of M. Rouher is improving. He takes a long drive daily. A bomb was thrown into a house on the Rue Crozatier to-day and, exploding, did considerable damage. It is believed that the bomb was intended to injure the Police Commissary, who resides in the house.

The Orange police have struck no new clues in the Phoebe Paullin murder mystery. The inquest was resumed at Orange last evening. Several witness testified as to the time they went up the mountain on Saturday, Nov. 24, and to having seen a buggy on Eagle Rock-avenue near the scene of the murder.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Dec. 13.--An order has been read to the employes of the Pennsylvania Steel Company stating that a reduction of forces and wages will occur after Jan. 1. No estimate of the reduction was stated, except that it would be in accordance with the value of their services. It is also stated that there are no orders for rails after that time. This is supposed to be the cause of the order.

TORONTO, Ontario, Dec. 13.--Rufus Rand a butcher, was arrested to-day at the instance of John B. Dow of New-York, and lodged in jail. Rand supplied horses to lumbermen in Portland, Me., and failed last year. He afterward was indicted in New-York State on a charge of larceny at the instance of Dow, whom he owed $3,300. To escape arrest Rand came to Canada, settling in this city.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Dec. 13.--The courtroom in this city was filled to-day with people anxious to listen to the trial of Charles Higham for the murder of Frederick W. Eames. The shooting occurred in this city on April 20 last.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Dec. 13.--Merriam A. Montgomery was convicted of murder in the second degree at Northampton to-night after the jury had been out three hours, and was sentenced to Concord for life. Justice Allen remarked in dismissing the jury that the verdict was according to the facts.
