KANSAS CITY, Mo., Dec. 13.--Frank James was released on $3,000 bail at 3 o'clock this afternoon. He was immediately rearrested on a charge of killing Cashier Sheets at Gallatin in 1868. The case in which James was bailed is the Blue Cut train robbery.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Dec. 13.--After a long season of activity in the coal regions, half time went into effect to-day. The day was beautiful, and the streets were crowded with miners purchasing goods for the holidays. For the first time in many years the miners have managed to accumulate a little money, and are therefore better prepared to go on half time than they have heretofore been.

CANTON, Miss., Dec. 13.--At the field trials here to-day, in the all-ages stakes, Sue won the first prize, Gath the second, and Harrison's London and Grousedale divided the third. The special pointer prize was won by Tyler. The champion stakes will be contested to-morrow, with Sue, Gath, Foreman, and Harrison's London as entries.

Ex-Postmaster-General Thomas L. James was yesterday appointed Assignee of the estate of the insolvent firm of Ferdinand Mayer Co.
BOSTON, Dec. 13.--The wrestling-match this afternoon between H.M. Dufur and J.H. McMahon, for the heavy-weight championship of the world and $250 a side, proved a fiasco.
Mayor Edson has written a letter to the Corporation Counsel in reference to the proposed extension of the Ninth-avenue surface railroad through the Boulevard from Sixtyfourth ...

District Attorney Olney sent a letter to the Board of Estimate and Apportionment yesterday in reference to the desire of the Grand Jury of the Court of Oyer and Terminer for an appropriation of $20,000 to pay the expense of a proposed investigation of the City departments.
ATLANTA, Ga., Dec. 13.--The will of David Ruth Dillon, who died in New-York City on the 10th of October last, leaving an estate of over $1,000,000, is under contest.
NORWICH, N.Y., Dec.13.--The jury in the suit of Anna N. Dwight against the Germania Life Insurance Company, after being out 52 hours returned the following verdict this afternoon:

Prof. C.A. Johnson, of Hamilton, Ontario, the Ethiopian philosopher, who has recently proved to the satisfaction of the leading scientists of Thompson and Sullivan streets that the earth is a flat body instead of an oblate spheroid, ...
The question, "Shall our ships be built at home or be purchased abroad?" was laid before the Union League Club last night in a long report from the Committee on Political Reform.

FONDA, N.Y., Dec. 13.--John I. Davis, ex-Assemblyman and a prominent citizen of Montgomery County, died about a month ago. This week his will was offered for probate before Judge Westbrook, when objection was raised by James G. Davis, of New-York, a nephew, and an adjournments was ordered.

PARIS, Dec. 13.--The Paris publishes a telegram from Saigon stating that a revolution has taken place at Hue, and that the King of Annam has been killed. The Ministry have no information relative to the report.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Dec. 13.--Thomas Simon, an English miner, aged 30, while engaged in sinking a shaft at Nanticoke this morning, was instantly killed. The platform upon which he was standing gave way, and he was precipitated to the rocky bottom, 40 feet below, and was crushed in a horrible manner.

The Republicans of Kings County held primary elections last night to select 38 of the 117 delegates to the General Committee and officers of the ward associations. There were several contests upon purely local issues in several of the wards, the result of which had not been announced at midnight.
POUGHKEEPSIE, Dec. 13.--A story was recently brought to light here which involves the happiness of two women and one man, and the latter is now a fugitive from justice.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Dec. 13.--J. O'Connor the Waukesha agent of the Iowa Great Eastern Mutual Life Insurance Company, of Anamosca, Iowa, was arrested to-day by the Sheriff of Waukesha County, on a request from State Insurance Commissioner Spooner, who alleges that the company is devoted to the "graveyard insurance" business, and has no license.

The first "assembly" of the season attracted a brilliant throng of dancers to Delmonico's last night. The decorations consisted of rich hangings over the windows and drapings of smilax, which gave the large ball-room a very attractive appearance.

At a meeting of the Society of Medical Jurisprudence and State Medicine, last evening, officers for the ensuing year were elected, as follows: President--William Barnes; Vice-President--Dr. E.J. Bermingham; Secretary--Dr. N. E. Brill; Financial Secretary--Max F. Eller; Corresponding ...

OTTAWA, Ontario, Dec. 13.--Advises have been received here showing that a large gold find has been made in the Rocky Mountains, a mile or so north of Podmore. The surface find was of copper, assaying at 160 pounds per ton, and under that is the gold.

BATAVIA, Dec. 13.--In the case of Mrs. Gibson, on trial here for forgery, the jury, after being out 21 hours, failed to agree and were discharged to-day. The defense was an alibi. A new trial will probably be had.
An examination was held yesterday in the case of Thomas Porter, who is charged with entering the flat No. 407 East Seventy-eighth-street on May 30, threatening the life of the wife ...
Mr. Daly has revived his very bright adaptation from the German, entitled "SevenTwenty-Eight; or, Casting the Boomerang," with evidences of immediate and substantial prosperity.

The defeat which the Egyptians have sustained near Suakim is evidently serious, but the real wonder would have been to find so, bungling a reconnoissance, by so small a body of troops, escaping disaster.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Dec. 13.--Percy Jacobus, Secretary of the Eureka Consolidated Mining Company, was arrested to-day on 16 charges of embezzlement. The total amount of his alleged stealings is $50,000.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Dec. 13.--There was a most remarkable railroad accident in the southern part of the city at noon to-day. The North-western track crosses the St. Paul Road at Washington-street. As the train from Madison was coming on the North-western Road a St. Paul train was starting out for Chicago.

The delegates from the trades-unions of Paris who are now on a visit to this country returned to New-York yesterday from a tour in the New-England States, and were entertained last evening by the United French Societies of New-York.
Miss Kate F. Brundige, daughter of Mr. Rufus M. Brundige, was married last evening to Mr. Vernon C. Brown, in the Church of the Holy Trinity, Forty-second-street and Madison-avenue.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 13.--Judge Baxter to-day in the United States Court appointed J.E. Martin permanent Receiver of the Ohio Central Railrod and Coal Company; A.W. Scott as general local counsel and counsel for ...

OTTAWA, Ontario, Dec. 13.--Reports of a heart-rending charcter come from people along the coast of Labrador, who are in a starving condition. The land is of a very inferior quality and is not capable of sustaining human life, and the inhabitants follow fishing and hunting for a livelihood.
The testimony in the trial of William Conroy for the murder of Peter Keenan, on the 3d of November last, was all in yesterday afternoon when the court adjourned until to-day.

The forty-eighth annual meeting of the Society for the Relief of Half-orphan and Destitute Children was held at the asylmn, No. 67 West Tenth-street, last night. The reports of the Board of Managers, the physician, and Treasurer were read. The remainder of the evening was devoted to exercises.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Dec. 13.--Ex-Gov. R. E. Fenton was sued to-day by a relative named M.L. Fenton for $40,000 alleged to have been overpaid by him to the defendant on lumber contracts. Each has able lawyers, and the contest promises to be a stubborn one.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13.--The case of the Burrow-Giles Lithographic Company against Napoleon Sarony, which was argued in the United States Supreme Court this afternoon, relates to a photograph of Oscar Wilde, and involves the ...

RICHMOND, Me., Dec. 13.--Louis E. Hopkins, known here as "Slim Jim," and Lorenzo H. Turner, while on a spree last night, killed an Indian called "Old Joe," in the northern suburbs of this town, and ravished his wife.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13, 1883. Mr. James A. Thompson, Acting Deputy Controller of the Treasury, was stricken with paralysis this afternoon while at his desk in the department.
In a letter just received by the Hon. C. M. Howe, of this city, from his daughter, wife of the Rev. J.H. Roberts, missionary of the A.B.C.F.M. ...

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Dec. 13.--Warner Tiffany, merchant tailors and gentlemen's furnishing goods, assigned to-day to W.O. Benedict. The amount of their assets is thought to be sufficient to cover their liabilities. The firm has been doing business for two years. The cause of the failure was too many competitors and a longcontinued dull season.
CAIRO, Dec. 13.--Advices from Suakim state that the French gun-boat Infernet has left that place.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13.--In accordance with his previous notice Mr. Frye called up in the Senate to-day the report of the special committee to prepare new rules for the government of the Senate.

Banks of rich flowers were strewn over the desks of the chapel of the school of the Collegiate Reformed Church, No. 160 West Twentyninth-street, last night, and one side of the hall was covered with the American and Dutch flags,

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14.--It is now asserted on the authority of several Democratic Congressmen that Speaker Carlisle will be ready to name the standing committees of the House of Representatives by Thursday next and possibly by Tuesday.
The Dutch brig Marie, Capt. Porter, which arrived yesterday from Anguilla, narrowly escaped being run down by a steam-ship on Dec. 7 in latitude 34 50' and longitude 71 55'.

SING SING, Dec. 14.--An affray took place at the prison here this morning, which came very near being attended with fatal results. John Stephens, a hall-boy on Gallery No. 13, and Dennis Gardner, similarly occupied on Gallery No. 20, ...

The Board of Estimate and Apportionment began business yesterday by making a transfer of $5,500 from the unexpended balance of the appropriation for drinking fountains for the purpose of repairing and renewing waterpipes.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Dec. 14.--Yesterday four boys, two sons of Sydney Weagle, and two sons of Israel Weagle, of Denmark, Queens County, went skating on Grand Pre Meadow. This morning the bodies of all four were found together in a brook which runs through the meadow.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 14.--After the Louisville and Nashville train discharged its load of passengers this morning one of the trainmen reported a sick man on board. The man was taken from the train to the city dispensary.
LONDON, Dec. 14.--The steamer Auk, from Liverpool for Rotterdam, was wrecked in the gale which prevailed last Tuesday, and her crew of 21 men were drowned.
CHARLOTTE, N.C., Dec. 14.--In the valley at the foot of king's Mountain, in Cleveland County, is the white cottage of Farmer William Logan.
After the acrimony of the election of Speaker and other officers of the House of Representatives comes the acrimony of the apportionment of "good places" on the standing committees of the House.
NEW-ORLEANS, Dec. 14.--The election of delegates in the 17 wards of the parish of Orleans to the Democratic State Convention, to meet in Raton Rouge on Tuesday next, occurred to-day.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Dec. 14.--Advices from Yokohama state that the Japanese Government is indignant at an imposition practiced at the Boston exhibition. The exhibits described by the Boston Journal as a rare collection of ancient historical works of art were modern and were manufactured expressly for sale. The Government had nothing to do with the exhibit. A valuable private collection sent by an English amateur collector failed to arrive in time.
HILLSBORO, Ill., Dec. 14.--In the Emma Bond case to-day Lawrence Heinlein, an uncle of Lee Pettis, one of the indicted men, testified. He gave the results of an examination of the school house ...
Senator D.M. Sabin, of Minnesota, is at the Gilsey House.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Dec. 14.--The people of this city are congratulating themselves over the complete success of a popular subscription to a fund to erect a fire-proof building for the Young Men's Association Library.

ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 14.--In the Court of Appeals to-day an order was made for a farm of the court, to be held at Albany on Monday, Jan. 14, 1884, at 10 o'clock A.M., on the calendar of which shall be placed ...
WATERTOWN, N.Y., Dec. 14.--In the Higham murder trial to-day five jurors were secured. The jury will probably be completed tomorrow.

The home of "Pinafore" is no more. While the preparations for last evening's performance at the Standard Theatre were being completed, about 6:45, the smell of smoke caused Edward Smith, the gasman, to glance upward ...

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14.--Although Mr. Thomas C. Platt is said to be out of politics, he is keeping his hand in with a little practice now and then.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Dec. 14.--Lilian Spencer consented to talk to-day in reference to her marriage with Clayburg and of the circumstances which led to it. She said: "That marriage was procured by fraud.

PAOLA, Kan., Dec. 14.--George Orr, age 17, went yesterday afternoon to the house of Monroe Trumble, an old blind man living half a mile from here, and, after a short conversation, shot and killed him. He also brutally beat old Mrs. Tremble about the head and face, and fled after robbing the house of $80. A posse of 25 citizens is searching for the murderer.

The standard Theatre was built in 1875 by ex-Judge Dowling and Mr. Joseph Hart on leased ground. It was first called the Eagle Palace Theatre, taking its name from the figure of a large golden eagle in the national coat of arms which crowned a handsome dome over the uppermost window of its facade on Sixth-avenue.
The electric motor which was placed on the Saratoga, Mount McGregor and Lake George Railroad by the Daft Company has been repaired and is now said to be running satisfactorily on the road.

Bon Louis Henri Martin, the famous French historian and politician, died at his home in Paris yesterday. He was born Feb. 20, 1810, at Saint Quentin, (Aisne.) where his father was Judge of the civil tribunal.
A young German Hebrew went to the Great Northern Hotel, a cheap lodging-house at No. 268 Bowery, on the 5th inst., and hired a room on the third floor. He registered himself as Dutchford.

Two handsomely dressed young ladies, accompanied by a middle-aged man, got off the train at Dobbs Ferry yesterday afternoon and, after looking around as though they expected to be met by some one, went to Peterman's Hotel, near by, and made inquiry whether a young gentleman had been there asking for them.

FONDA, N.Y., Dec. 14.--The financial gloom which prevails in Amsterdam has effectually killed the city charter project. At a meeting last night of the Citizens' Committee a quorum was not present. The primary object of the meeting was to hear reports from the Committee on Boundaries, but no one was present to speak on behalf of that body.

CHICAGO, Dec. 14.--A week ago Mayor Harrison found that his thorough-bred Kentucky horse was "off his feed," and in order to give it some rest sent it to a farm in Indiana owned by George Hankins, a prominent gambler.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 14.--Charles Uhler, special officer at the Bijou Theatre, was put on trial before Judge Elcock to-day on the charge of assaulting Albert Fili. Fili went to the theatre on a free pass.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14, 1883. The Committee on Rules was announced in the House to-day as follows: The Speaker, Messrs. Blackburn, of Kentucky; Randall, of Pennsylvania; Keifer, of Ohio, and Reid, of Maine.

George W. Dunn and wife declined to see a score of visitors who sent cards up to their apartments at the Windsor Hotel yesterday. Mr. Dunn was not seen around the hotel during the day, except in the corridors leading from his own room to his mother's.
OTTAWA, Ontario, Dec. 14.--A disgraceful scene occurred at Kingston last night in connection with an election held under the auspices of St. Paul's Church. The feature of the evening was a bazaar.

A well-dressed woman, with a pretty little girl, called at the Brooklyn Police Central Office last evening and said she had been deserted by her husband and left without means in a strange city.

The will of the late William H. Dykman, of Yonkers, was offered for probate in the Westchester County Surrogate's Court, at White Plains, yesterday. Counselor L.C. Platt made objection to the probate of the will on behalf of some remote heirs. The estate is estimated at $50,000.

Carl Martin, charged with the murder of Henry Bolle, was acquitted last night by a jury in the Court of Oyer and Terminer. Bolle was employed in a labor agency at No. 152 Greenwich-street. He was killed there on the night of Sept. 29 last.

NEW-HAVEN, Dec. 14.--At a meeting of 15 stockholders of the Boston and New-York Inland Railroad Company in this city last evening, George Cook, of New-Haven, was re-elected President and George E. Spare, also a New-Haven, ...

The annual meeting of Plymouth Church was held last evening immediately after the close of the prayer-meeting. The Secretary, Gen. Christensen, reported a total membership of 2,555, comprising 864 males and 1,691 females, an increase during the year of 7.

RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 14.--Both houses of the General Assembly have passed a resolution instructing the Virginia Senators and requesting the Representatives in Congress to use their best efforts to secure the unconditional and immediate abolition of the internal revenue system.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Dec. 14.--Martha T. Benjamin, aged 36, is a school teacher at Upper Hopewell, town of East Fishkill. Three weeks ago she said she was insulted on her way home after school by a rough-looking man.

While Frederick Ryberg, the watchman in the Casino, was making his rounds in the building while the performance was in progress last Wednesday night, he found the door of a small room on the buffet floor fastened.

NEW-HAVEN, Dec. 14.--The number of volumes in the Yale College Library is given in the new college catalogue, now out, as about 107,000, exclusive of many thousand unbound pamphlets.

As soon as the bustle and confusion incidental to the assembling of a dense mass of human beings in the Court of General Sessions yesterday subsided, the counsel for Policeman Conroy, on trial for murder, began his address to the jury.

WILMINGTON, Del., Dec. 14.--Lewis F. List, convicted of murder in the first degree in killing George B. Taylor, and his father, Lewis List, convicted of murder in the second degree as accessory to the same crime, were sentenced this afternoon, the motion for a retrial in the case of the younger man having been refused.
CAIRO, Dec. 14.--The Governor of Dongola telegraps to the Khedive that the Kowawcer tribe report that Hicks Pasha was alive and safe at Birket on Nov. 15, ...

TORONTO, Ontario, Dec. 14.--Messrs. Collins and Worthington, representing American capitalists, waited upon Sir Leonard Tilley today, to confer with him regarding additional protection to the manufacturers of iron.
Much excitement prevails in Jersey City over the alleged fraud practiced on the American Legion of Honor by Dr. Rufus W. Peacock.

NEW-ROCHELLE, Dec. 14.--The Consolidated Railroad Company has just acquired a section of land parallel to its road, lying between NewRochelle and Rye. The tract is eight miles in length, and the contracts for laying tracks will soon be awarded.

Mr. E.B. Fabri, of Drexel, Morgan Co., and Mr. Endicott, of Boston, have been requested by the Executive Committee of the Oregon Transcontinental Company to examine the books and securities of that company and report to the stockholders as soon as possible.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Dec. 14.--G.W. Blymeyr, editor of the Democratic Times of Defiance, has brought suit against F.C. Cully, editor of the Definace Express, laying his damages at $2,500. The suit is based on a charge in the Express that the political influence of the Times could be purchased for a small consideration.
A circular from the Chief of Police of Wilkesbarre, Penn., was received at Police Headquarters yesterday stating that Miss Nellie Cooley left her home in that city on Sunday night, Dec. 9.
In his annual report to Mayor Low Health Commissioner Raymond says the health of the city of Brooklyn during 1883 has been better than in any year since 1879.

BOSTON, Dec. 14.--A distinguished audience assembled in Tremont Temple this evening to tender a farewell reception to Matthew Arnold. Mayor Palmer presided and spoke briefly. Wendell Phillips expressed the admiration felt for Mr. Arnold by the people of Boston, to which that gentleman responded. Among those present were the Hon. Robert C. Winthrop, Oliver Wendell Holmes, Dr. Samuel A. Green, and the Rev. Dr. Bartol.

TORONTO, Ontario, Dec. 14.--The Globe recently published a letter from a Canadian named Switzer, who, having deserted from the American Army, was followed into Canadian territory and arrested there by American soldiers.

The Methodist Conference Association of this City held a public temperance meeting at the Central Methodist Church, on Seventh-avenue, last evening. The Rev. Dr. Smith presided. The Rev. Dr. Todd delivered an address upon the growth of intemperance. The speaker differed with those persons who claim that the drinking ...

Early yesterday morning Boone A. Seers, aged 69 years, of No. 198 Water-street, entered the Second Precinct Station-house, at York and Jay streets, Brooklyn, covered with blood and bearing on his face and head several jagged wounds.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 14.--The Coroner today concluded the investigation into the cause of the death of Sebastian Appel, who died on Aug. 5. When the case was first reported it was stated that the deceased man was a victim of foul play.
It was stated at the office of the North River Construction Company yesterday that the entire amount of the $5,000,000 of bonds offered ...

MATAWAN, N.J., Dec. 14.--The suit brought by James H. Bradley, the chief property-owner in Asbury Park, to have the assessment of his property equalized with that in Ocean Grove, was decided against the Commissioner of Tax Appeals for Neptune Township. The reduction will cause Mr. Bradley's property, originally assessed at $163,000, to be assessed at $45,000. It is expected the suit will be carried to the Supreme Court.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Dec. 14.--Between 2:30 and 3 o'clock this morning the watchman on board the Government steamer Napoleon III. discovered that the ship was on fire, flames breaking out from the oil-room, amidships. When the firemen reached the scene smoke was pouring in large volumes from below. The flames were extinguished after two hours of hard work.

GALVESTON, Texas, Dec. 14.--A dispatch from Laredo to the News says: "It is reported that Gen. Cuellar refuses to obey orders from the City of Mexico to arrest Quintones, Mayor of New-Laredo, on a charge of complicity in the Mexican National train robbery. It is alleged that several of the robbers are known to be in Laredo, but no one is willing to assume the responsibility of making affidavits against them.

NEWBURG, Penn., Dec. 14.--A serious riot took place last night at the Blue Mountain Tunnel, near here, between Italian and negro laborers. During the night two of the latter broke into the shanty containing the provisions for the laborers and were discovered in the act.
PERTH AMBOY, N.J., Dec. 14.--The fixity of purpose of the New-Brunswick police to make out John Koop, now confined in the County Jail, a murderer is as steadfast as ever.

CHICAGO, Dec. 14.--Sellers had no occasion to find fault with to-day's cattle market. The demand on Eastern account was unabated, and as there was a falling off in the receipts of rather more then 3,000 head, the market gained a little in strength.
Simeon J.M. Bear is an inventor of devices for the conveyance of intelligence by electricity.
Mr. William E. Eaton, of Boston, has lost four children by diphtheria within six days.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 14.--Emil Mueller, age 15, was caught and instantly killed this evening in the elevator at Lincoln's furniture warehouse. He was found dead with his head lying in a box which he took up with him. He lived at the Boys' Home.

The Brown University Club of NewYork gave a dinner at Clark's, on Twenty-thirdstreet, last evening. Covers were laid for 30. The members of the club are Alumni resident in New-York of Brown University, and the President is W.W. Hoppin, Jr.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 14.--A dispatch from Fort Smith, Ark., tells of the putting to death near there of Levi James for the murder of James Fulsom. Both were native Choctaws.

David Brown, of No. 54 Ridge-street, was a complainant yesterday in Essex Market Police Court against his son Edward, age 23, who, while intoxicated Thursday night, beat his mother and sister.
PARIS, Dec. 14.--Advices from Hai-phong of the 7th inst. state that the murder of King Hiephema of Annam was instigated by China.
WORCESTER, Mass., Dec. 14.--Last September Hiram Chase, of this city, disappeared from the home of the father of his first wife in Millbury under circumstances indicating that he had drowned himself.

Bradstreet's reports 249 failures in the United States during the past week, 3 more than the preceding week, 19 more than the same week of 1882, and 84 more than the same week of 1881. About 73 per cent. of the failures were those of small traders, whose capital was under $5,000.

Whoever has followed the reports of the suit to set aside the modified lease of the Metropolitan Elevated Road to the Manhattan must be considerably impressed with the futility of legal proceedings as a means of discovering anything which anybody has any interest in keeping concealed.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Dec. 14.--W.P. Roger, Lewis County's missing Treasurer, was indicted by the Grand Jury, now sitting at Lowville, of embezzling trust funds belonging to the county to the amount of $1,500.

NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., Dec. 14.--Edward Barrett and John J. Duvallay were arraigned in the Superior Court to-day for complicity to defraud the United States Benefit Association, the Bay State Beneficiary Association, and the Equitable Relief Association by procuring insurance on unsound lives, and pleaded not guilty. The cases against all the parties indicted for similar offences in Fall River will not be tried until after the court adjourns to Fall River.

WINNIPEG, Manitoba, Dec. 14.--Canadian Pacific trains are beginning to move regularly. Three express trains left here this morning for West, East, and South, with higher officials of the company at the lever.

The trial of Capt. Joshua Slocumb, of the ship Northern Light, on an indictment charging him with cruel and inhuman treatment of Henry Arthur Slater, his second mate, was continued in the United States Circuit Court yesterday.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Dec. 14.--The report of the investigation of the committee of the Board of Managers of the Western House of Refuge for Juvenile Delinquents shows that the most cruel and inhuman treatment has been inflicted upon the boys by officers and subordinates. The board to-day dismissed three overseers and other subordinates.
Object teaching--originally invented by Mr. Squeers--is very popular nowadays, and it is just possible that at times it is carried rather too far.
A small party of Russian immigrants, who had paid their way to this country by pool ing all their money, landed at Castle Garden yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec 14.--Several Senators have to-day complained somewhat excitedly because the vote on McCook and Gorham in the Republican caucus on Thursday was incorrectly reported in THE TIMES of to-day.
Rossini's always popular comic opera, "Il Barbiere di Siviglia," was given once more at the metropolitan Opera-house last evening. The audience was large, brilliant, and enthusiastic.

CHICAGO, Ill., Dec. 14.--Last Saturday, Corcoran, the pitcher for the Chicago League Club, telegraphed that he would sign for 1884, but he has since written President Spalding not to send the contract, as he has signed with the Chicago Union for next year. He has been informed that he will be expelled from the League.

BRIDGEPORT, Dec. 14.--The Bridgeport Hospital Assocition last evening elected the following officers: President--P.T. Barnum; VicePresident--ex-Mayor Jarratt Morford; Secretary and Treasurer--Dr. George F. Lewis.

LONDON, Dec. 14.--Binns, the hangman, has arrived at Newgate Prison to make his preparations for the execution of O'Donnell.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14.--A Democratic member of Congress from Michigan said to-day that in a recent trip through that State he found a strong feeling among his party friends in favor of Judge Thurman, of Ohio as the next Democratic nominee for President.

The bills which Mr. DINGLEY, of Maine, has prepared with the object of promoting a revival of American shipping interests cover substantially the same ground as the measure reported last Winter by the joint committee of which he was a member.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 14.--In the longstanding case of John T. Morris against the National Color Printing Company, Alfred D. Chancellor, Receiver, filed a petition to-day in the United States Circuit Court for leave to sell the property of the company.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Dec. 14.--A legal question has been raised in this city as to whether Max Grossman, President of the Freie Gemunde [Society of Free Thinkers] has authority to marry people. Ha has performed one ceremony only, but his predecessor in office performed many.

ROCKVILLE, Ind., Dec. 14.--A man named John Bonner, residing in this Vicinity, locked his wife out of doors because she refused to supply him with money to continue a drinking spree. She went to the woods with her children, and while building a fire her clothing caught fire and she was burned to death.
One hundred members of the New-York Association of Cornell University sat down to the fourth dinner of the organization, in Martinelli's, last evening.

LIMA, Dec. 14, via Galveston.--El Bien Publico publishes a telegram stating that Arequipa has been evacuated by the Chilians. It also publishes the President's letter to Caceres, assuring the latter of his perfect security.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Dec. 14.--P. Sullivan, manufacturer of ladies' shoes, of No. 53 East Third-street, made an assignment to-day to J.B. Mannix. His liabilities are estimated at $35,000. No statement of the assets is given, but Sullivan thinks they will equal the liabilities.
The passenger agents yesterday discussed the question of the best methods for the formation of the interior pools, but arrived at no conclusion.

The burning of the Garden City, happened at the time of day when there is the least travel over the Long Island City ferry. The fire broke out just as the boat had left the slip, and the pilot was a brave and competent man.

The Herald's exclusive information as to Col. L.P. Di Cesnola's having been made a Brevet Brigadier-General was shown in the United States District Court yesterday to have been published in August, 1865, over four months after he asserts that President Lincoln verbally conferred the title upon him.
MATAWAN, N.J., Dec. 14.--Three more of the notorious gang of thieves that have infested Monmouth County were taken by Chief of Police Patterson, of Red Bank, to the Freehold Jail yesterday morning.

SOUTH NORWALK, Conn., Dec. 14.--Mr. George W. Day, a prominent citizen and business man of this city, died suddenly yesterday afternoon. He attended store in the forenoon, going to dinner at 2 o'clock. He ate as usual, and as a side dish partook of canned peas.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., Dec. 14.--THE TIMES of Aug. 12 and 14 contained dispatches from Lockport relative to the career of George W. Burgess, who swindled the First National Bank of this city out of $179 on a forged certified check on a Syracuse bank.

But little additional information could be obtained yesterday relating to the last days of Lillie M. Lugenbeel, formerly the wife of exSenator Christiancy, of Michigan. Mrs. Dr. Dupre, at whose house in Brooklyn the unfortunate woman died on Thursday morning, was very outspoken in regard to the affair.
The Orange police are still going on the suspicion that Frank, the would-be suicide, who is now almost recovered, is cognizant of the murder of Phoebe Paullin.

GALVESTON, Texas, Dec. 14.--A dispatch from Fort Davis says: "Juan Duran, the Mexican who murdered a Chinaman 50 miles south of Fort Davis last Winter, was executed within the walls of the County Jail at 1:25 o'clock this afternoon in the presence of a guard of 50 Deputy Sheriffs.

S.H. Kneeland testified in the elevated railway suit yesterday that he did not, as Cyrus W. Field said, agree to leave the matters in dispute between the roads to Mr. Huntington. A document signed by Metropolitan stockholders opposing the October agreement was introduced.

Mr. George F. Stearns, the Secretary of the Connecticut Valley Hardware Company, of Chester, Conn., called at Police Head-quarters yesterday and reported the mysterious disappearance of Eugene B. Higgins, the book-keeper and traveling agent of that organization.
Had yesterday morning's sun been permitted to shine in upon Horticultural Hall it would have revealed only a few bare tables and some chairs.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 14.--Frances Josephine Farrar, the only child and heiress of Joseph F. Farrar, formerly a wealthy insurance agent in this city, was found to-day, after a long search, by Frank Wolf, a lowyer.

OTTAWA, Dec. 14.--Much interest has been taken in Canada to-day in three elections held in the Province of Ontario for the local Legislature and one held in West Middlesex, in the same Province, for the Dominion Parliament. In the elections for the Ontario Legislature both the political parties exerted themselves to the utmost, ...

TROY, N.Y., Dec. 14.--West Troy citizens are rejoicing to-night over the receipt of an order revoking the order of last week making the above place a letter carriers' office under charge of the Postmaster of this city. The first order was to have gone into effect Jan. 1, ...

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 14.--The library of the late Chief-Justice Sharswood was disposed of at public sale to-day. The prices realized were small and far below what was paid for the books. The bidders were few.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Dec. 14.--William Hunt, second steward of the steamer Josie Harry, has just arrived in this city, having walked up through the swamp from Reeves's Landing, 15 miles below, where he reports the Harry was burned at 3 o'clock this afternoon.
ST. LOUIS, Dec. 14.--A grand reception which was to have come off at Gen. Sherman's residence to-night has been postponed indefinitely through the invasion of his home by the small-pox.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 14.--The annual meeting of the National Land Company was held to-day, and the following Directors were elected; Sidney Dillon, Frederick L. Ames, Henry McFarland, S.T. Smith Bayard Butter, Barthold Schlesinger, and William S. Gottsberger.

William Cronk, of Ava, and his brotherin-law, Alexandria Flick, of the same place, went on a hunting expedition to the North Woods in November. They went to what is known as Ox Bow, on Moose River, by way of White Lake Corners.

The Liquor-dealers' Protective Union of the Twentieth Ward met yesterday at No. 269 West Thirty-fourth-street and elected the following officers for the ensuing year: President-- M. McKenna; Vice-President--Peter McGowan; ...

FONDA, N.Y., Dec. 14.--Last evening a party of West Shore Railroad track employes were returning to St. Johnsville on a hand-car. While traveling at a high rate of speed the pumphandle broke, throwing W. McGrain and H. Mulligan from the car. McGrain's injuries, though painful, are not serious. Mulligan is fatally hurt.
Washington Raynor, an oysterman, of Freeport, Long Island, went out to see the sights Thursday evening, and men two enchanting young ladies, Maggie Smith and Frances Dean.

BIRMINGHAM, Conn., Dec. 14.--Chief of Police Martin arrested two tramps to-day who were begging on the streets. One of them the Chief thinks is probably the tramp who cut off Milkman Thompson's nose in Bridgeport Wednesday.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Dec. 14.--A strike of the coal miners in the third pool, Monongahela River, has been ordered for Dec. 20. The men have been working at a reduction of one-quarter of a cent a bushel, and the strike is for the purpose of getting th district price, which is 3 cents a bushel. About 1,000 miners are affected.

A famous General and archaeologist was one day walking in Central Park, when he encountered a little girl who seemed in great distress.

The statement is made that since THE NEW-YORK TIMES reduced its price from 4 to 2 cents its circulation has more than doubled and is increasing rapidly. This will be good news to those who like to see merit and enterprise fittingly rewarded.
A party of seven Arabs, six men and one woman, arrived on the steam-ship Burgundia on Dec. 12, and have since remained at Castle Garden.

Knickerbocker Council, No. 572, Royal Arcanum, held its annual election last evening at the Council Room, No. 220 East Fifteenthstreet. Among those present were Curtis H. Peck, Grand Regent of the State of New-York; Debuty Supreme Regent Frank F. Cummings of Delware.

WINNIPEG, Manitoba, Dec. 15.--The trouble on the Canadian Pacific Railway has not perceptibly advanced toward a settlement. The company succeeded in sending out three passenger trains this morning, but the freight traffic is at a complete stand still. The mounted police have been ordered out to protect the property of the company at several points west of Regina.

One of THE TIMES'S reporters dropped in at the office of the Actors' Fund a few days ago and found the Executive Committee engaged in the consideration of applications for relief. "We get all kinds of letters here," said the Chairman.

A new match has been arranged between Vigneaux and Schaefer for $1,000 a side. It will be played in the Grand Hotel, Paris, commencing on Jan. 10. It will be 3,000 points up, 600 being played on each of five nights, and will be the 8-inch-balk-line game.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Dec. 15.--Three jurors were secured in the Higham murder trial to-day, when the court adjourned until Monday. Judge Merwin allowed the ten jurors thus far sworn in to go to their homes.

LONDON, Dec. 15.--The Khedive has not yet taken the final step of resignation, but he has threatened that unless England will furnish him with a guarantee that she will send troops to reconquer the Soudan, or at least consent to allow the Turkish troops to suppress the Mahdi, he will abdicate his throne.

ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 15.--The following is taken from reports made to the Railroad Commissioners for the year ending Sept. 30, 1883: Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railway Company--Earnings, $4,423,218; payments, $4,301,483; ...
CHICAGO, Dec. 15.--Contrary to general expectation, east-bound freight shipments did not fall off this week, and this is believed to be due to a cutting of rates on the part of some of the lines.

ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 15--The Board of Railroad Commissioners are engaged in the preparation of their annual report, and will present it to the Legislature, as required by law, on the 15th of January next.

Eight or ten ticket speculators clamored in front of Harrigan and Hart's Theatre in Broadway last evening and blew their fingers trying to keep them warm. There were plenty of good seats for sale on the sidewalk, and the speculators were liberally patronized.

Small spruces and firs are shipped from places along the line of the Knox and Lincoln Railroad to New-York, who the trees are in demand for Christmas trees. Between 1,000 and 2,000 trees can be packed on a car. One contractor has an order for 15 car-loads to be sent to NewYork. He received from 50 cents to $5 a tree.
CHICAGO, Dec. 15.--Alfred Digby Howard is the junior member of the firm of Kirchoffer Brandon, solicitors, of Winnipeg, Manitoba, and until about a week ago bore an unblemished reputation.

Around the ruins of the Stanard Theatre were gathered yesterday groups of women and children, endeavoring to get in through the undamaged portal to have a look at the charred and half-burned seats and balcony timbers, which is all that remains of the auditorium.

The Jersey City police have not succeeded in bringing any further facts to light in connection with the alleged American Legion of Honor fraud. The impersonator of Miss Eva Williams cannot be found.

MADRID, Dec. 15.--King Alfonso openep the Cortes this evening with the usual ceremony. In his speech the King deplored the late insurrection among the military. Referring to his recent journey, he declared that the object of it was to pay debts of friendship and affection and to strengthen the bonds of friendship between Spain and foreign nations.

"There is not a word of truth in it, my dear boy--there is not a word of truth in it," said the manager of the Castle Garden Bear Garden to a TIMES reporter, as he slapped the latter on the back, rearranged his necktie, pushed down his scarf-pin, buttoned up his coat, and slipped $5 up his sleeve.

The earliest men tion of tarantismus is found in the works of Nicolas Perotti, who died in 1480. It appeared first in Apulia, and at the time of this author, seems to have fairly well established itself as a disease in that Province.

A dispatch from Washington to THE TIMES last Thursday said that the PostmasterGeneral had issued a circular letter to Postmasters directing them to exchange the three and six cent denominations of postage stamps and stamped envelopes for others of different denominations.

Bill Billings, the Boston tanner, was the first distinguished American composer. There may have been some original tunes invented in the New-England colonies before Billings's time, but nothing is known of them. Billings was the prototype of "the Yankee psalm-tune music teacher."

Conroy's fate, so far as the Court of General Sessions can settle it, is sealed. The 12 conscientious citizens who constituted the jury in his case, after having been locked up all night, having been in deliberation 16 hours, at 10:30 o'clock yesterday brought in a verdict of "guilty of murder in the first degree," the penalty of which is death.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15.--Some of the wise Democratic members of Congress are a little worried because no caucus of their party was held this week.

PANAMA, Dec. 6.--Ielesias, President of Peru, continues to employ his utmost exertions to reorganize the country, but he has to face many difficulties--the enemy in one part of his country montoneros in another, and insurrectionary, turbulent, and murderous Indians let loose in another.

The fortieth annual report of the NewYork Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor has been issued in pamphlet form. Between Oct. 1, 1882, and Sept. 30, 1883, there were 4,559 separate families relieved.

The basement floor of the new chapel in the interior court of the Foundling Asylum on the block of land between Sixty-eighth and Sixty-ninth streets and Third and Lexington avenues is very nearly completed.

NORRISTOWN, Penn., Dec. 15.--The jury in the case of James Jack, charged with the murder of his wife in July last, returned a verdict this evening of not guilty. Mrs. Jack was found dead in bed on the night of July 4, having been strangled.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Dec. 15.--On the morning of Thanksgiving Day the people of this city were startled to hear that the dead body of the wife of Capt. E.T. Johnson, for many years a prominent lawyer here and lately a Pension Bureau Supervisor stationed at Knoxville, Tenn., had been found on her bed.

Mr. Bradlee, an architect, has proved beyond all dispute that Portland cement does expand. He filled three glass bottles with cement, and closely sealed them. One of the bottles burst in two days, and other in eight days, and the third in ten days.

Thomas Young, a liquor-dealer, and at one time quite well known in Brooklyn ward politics, was sent to jail on Oct. 20 charged with the murder of his wife, whom he had shot in her mother's house, No. 95 Tompkins-avenue, on the day before, because she had refused to live with him.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Dec. 15.--Following the example of other maritime Provinces, British Columbia, is now demanding a special allotment out of the Halifax Fishery Award as due for injuries done fisheries of that Province in allowing American fishermen in their waters.

RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 15.--Senator Riddleberger was in the city last night and attended a caucus of the Coalition members of the Legislature. His presence here at this time, it is supposed, is to confer with his party friends in the Legislature in regard to important measures ...
The relations between the yacht Captain, G.F. Jones, and Elizabeth Patterson, by whom he has had four children, were discussed in a Police Court yesterday.

The statement of operations of the NewYork Central and Hudson River Railroad for the fiscal year ending Sept. 30, 1883, made public yesterday by I.P. Chambers, the Controller of the road, shows the gross earnings of the system to have been $33,770,721.82, the largest in its history.

Capt. Winter, of the North German Lloyd steam-ship Rhein, which arrived from Bremen yesterday, reports that at 9 A.M. on Dec. 12, when in latitude 43 43' and longitude 55 18', he passed the abandoned wreck of the schooner Anniola, of St. John, Newfoundland. The bowsprit, mainmast, head of foremast, and the rigging of the schooner were gone.

The Houston Post, speaking of the "15 Mormon missionaries" soon to be sent to Texas to make converts, quietly advises to "send no men that cannot be permanently spared."

CHICAGO, Dec. 15.--Francis Adams, Corporation Counsel of Chicago, who has been connected with the law department of the city for many years, has been forced to resign on account of ill-health, and Mr. Fred S. Winston, a young Yale man well-known in New-York, has been appointed to fill the vacancy.

Since midsummer, when Mr. CARL SCHURZ found it impossible to preserve at once his self-respect and his connection with the Evening Post, that unfortunate journal has been "run"--though hardly edited--in a way that forcibly recalls a weekly publication which the Post some years ago absorbed into its venerable bosom.

MACON, Ga., Dec. 15.--The marriage of Mr. Brown Riley and Miss Mattie Hose, in Houston County, was preceded by serious obstacles. The lady is the daughter of Judge Hose and had been sought by many admirers.

The suspicion which has been directed against George Frank, the Orange beer-bottler, culminated yesterday in his arrest for the murder of Phoebe Paullin on the West Orange Mountains. Frank's own testimony at the inquest first turned the finger of suspicion upon him.
The Mystic Boat Club held their annual dinner at Clark's, on Twenty-third-street, last evening. Covers were laid for 25. The centre piece on the table was a representation of a large boat in nougat.

On the Pacific coast of the United States, the disturbance has taken the form of striking and unusual phenomena at sunset, the West appearing in a blaze of brilliant red light, far surpassing the ordinary vesper glow.

Information was given to the police yesterday that Benjamin F. Smith, a merchant of No. 130 Water-street, and living at No. 148 West Forty-seventh-street, was missing. The fact was reported by a son-in-law of Mr. smith, who said that he did not return home from his place of business on Friday evening, and has not since been seen or heard from.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., Dec. 15.--The Morgan mystery will not die. The latest information concerning the disappearance of Mr. Morgan, 57 years ago, was given to the public last week, in the town of Newfane, near Lockport, by the Rev. Mr. Stoddard, who has been lecturing against Freemasonry.

BOSTON, Dec. 13.--I met John A. Walsh yesterday in the cafe of Young's Hotel. He is a large, fine-looking man about 40 years old. He dresses in the height of the fashion, his manners are easy and his conversation fluent and polished.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Dec. 15.--A prize-fight took place at dayliglit this morning in a barn on the New-Brighton Road, several mile from Allegheny City, between John Fox and James Greener, for a purse of $200.

Miss Willett, one of the talented members of John McCullough, company, which is to play in Erie next Tuesday, has retired from the company, and has gone back to New-York with the pronounced determination to never again appear upon the stage.

INDIANAPOLIS, Dec. 15.--The Republican State Central Committee have determined upon a meeting on Jan. 15, at which the date of the State Convention will be agreed upon and arrangements made for the State campaign. The Republican editors of the State also meet on that day to talk over matters connected with the coming canvass.

Mr. Burnett, private Secretary to Henry M. Teller while that gentleman was representing Colorado in the United States Senate, was in the city yesterday, and related a very entertaining story, which he said not half a dozen people in the country had heard.

It has been arranged that, during Mr. Edwin Booth's engagement at the Star Theatre, his place will be taken on Saturday nights by Mr. W.E. Sheridan, an actor who is not known to this public, though he has won reputation in other places. Mr. Sheridan made his first appearance, therefore, last night, as Sir Giles Overreach in Massenger's play "A New Way to Pay Old Debts."

NEW-ORLEANS, Dec. 15.--Charles E. Black was to-day elected President of the Cotton Exchange by a majority of 50 over Stanley O. Thomas out of a total vote of 330. It was an amicable, though animated, struggle, continued over from the last annual meeting, when there was no choice.

The second concert of the Philharmonic Society took place last evening at the Academy of Music. The solidity of the programme has already been mentioned. The performance, however, was of such a nature as to chain the attention of the large audience from beginning to end.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15.--Senator Vest's resolution of inquiry in regard to the Yellowstone National Park will probably bring to the Senate some interesting information from the Interior Department.

PADUCAH, Ky., Nov. 25.--The tranquil way that packet Paris C. Brown nestled in the mud and rested her starboard side affectionately against the rocky Kentucky Shore was something beautiful. She had a way of making herself at home anywhere.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Dec. 15.--Bishop Gilmour, of the Cleveland Diocese, is negotiating for the purchase of a valuable lot on Euclid-avenue, near Kennard-street, for the erection of a large Catholic theological college. Such an institution has long been his dream, and he has been shaping the finances of his diocese with that end in view.

Since the announcement first made public some months ago that Sir Theodore Martin had completed his memoir of Lord Lyndhurst, prepared largely from the papers and letters held in the possession of his family, its final publication has been looked forward to with considerable interest and curiosity.

At the Theatre Comique "Cordelia's Aspirations" is still a popular play. Miss Davenport's engagement with "Fedora" will end on next Saturday night.

BUFFALO, Dec. 15.--The proposal to divide Erie County, which was talked about for a time as if it were to be a reality, has been definitely voted down in the Board of Supervisors, and no more will be heard of it at present. A majority of the country Supervisors, with whom the proposition originated, voted against it. The city was willing to cut loose from the rest of the county.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Dec. 15.--The Rev. Dr. Wise, President of the Hebrew Union College lectured last evening on intermarriages between Jews and Gentiles. He took the ground that such marriages are not forbidden by the Mosaic law.

A statement of facts relative to the NewYork, West Shore and Buffalo Railroad was made by Gen. E.F. Winslow yesterday. The North River Construction Company, he explained, was organized with a capital of $10,000,000, which was paid in and applied toward constructing and equipping the West Shore Railway.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Dec. 15.--The crank who calls himself John Washington, and who has been hanging around the residence of Mrs. Garfield under the impression that he was to marry her daughter Mollie, has been held in custody but as none of them has appeared, he was to-day committed to the County Infirmary by the Probate Judge.

Surrogate Townsend, of Queens County, filed his decision yesterday, removing Benjamin J. Smith from the Executorship of the estate of the late Horace Rowland. Smith resides at Seaford, in the town of Hempstead, Long Island. He claims that the estate owed him money, and began suit against himself as Executor, so that he was both plaintiff and defendant. The Surrogate in his decision says that such conduct will not be tolerated by the court.

Mr. Isaac W. Cotton is a New-Hampshire man who is well known through the Southern States, and the little adventure with which he met a few days ago in the swollen waters of Steel Creek, just beyond the Mecklenburg line in South Carolina, will be of interest to his friends in the South and will startle his friends in the North.

LONDON, Dec. 15.--The scaffold upon which O'Donnell is to be hanged is being erected, Hangman Binns is inside of Newgate Prison and will remain there until the hanging has taken place. O'Donnell sleeps well and takes his meals regularly.

LONDON, Nov. 27.--A first night at the Haymarket is always an important event of the theatrical season. Such a one we had at Mr. and Mrs. Bancroft's theatre, the most elegant and luxuriously comfortable play-house in London, on Saturday evening, when Mr. Arthur W. Pinero's new four-act comedy of "Lords and Commons" was produced for the first time.

NEW-ORLEANS, La,, Dec., 15.--Manager Goodwin, of the Clara Morris combination, has received a dispatch from citizens of Galveston, Texas, who are said to represent $100,000,000 worth of property, who unite in sending an invitation to Miss Morris to visit their city and give performances. The invitation has been accepted. Miss Morris has just closed one of the most successful engagements ever played in New-Orleans.

Acting Superintendent Thorne said yesterday that no special orders had been issued to the police to govern their action in enforcing the excise law to-day, as the instructions given recently were still in force.

Edson and Fowler, Lord and Lady Bury and servants, and several other ladies and gentlemen from England. Satisfactory progress is being made in the work of recounting the vote on the second amendment. The errors and discrepancies between the vote actually cast and that returned, thus far discovered, induce the belief that the amendment was fairly carried at the recent election.

LONDON, Dec. 15.--The Paris correspondent of the Times says he has reason to believe that China has submitted the basis of an arrangement of the Tonquin question to the judgment of England. It seems certain, he says, that, despite all assertions to the contrary, there are no Chinese regulars at Bac-Ninh or Sontay, and thus the taking of those places by the French could no longer constitute a casus belli.

George W. Dunn persisted in denying himself to callers at the Windsor yesterday, but the affable hotel clerk sent up the cards of those who desired him to. BOSTON, Dec. 15.--Irving has been doing an immense business at the Boston Theatre, and his success has been marked. The receipts for the week amounted to $18,845.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Dec. 15.--The Commercial Gazette has a three-column account of the career of Mrs. Alice Paige, the wife of Simon B. Paige, the millionaire lumberman of the Northwest, who was found dead, with a bullet wound in his head, on March 11, 1882, in his room in a Davenport (Iowa) hotel.

TROT, N.Y., Dec.16.--The trestle used in erecting the new canal bridge at Crescent, Sara toga County, fell on Friday, precipitating five men a distance of 20 feet to the bottom of the canal. All of the men were injured. Staats Fonda had three ribs broken and received dan- gerous internal injuries. Frank Silvernail had a leg broken and wounded about the head. The crash was heard a mile away.

WASHINGTON, Dec.16.--Representative Dudley C. Haskell, of Kansas, died in this city this morning after a lingering illness. Mr.Haskell, who was one of the young members of the present Congress, was born at Springfield, Vt., March 23, 1842, but removed, in 1855, to Kansas.

It is declared that the Judges of the Court of Appeals, being about to move into the sumptuous-quarters provided for them in the new Capitol, wish to solemnize their sittings by wearing gowns, such as those now worn by the Judges of the Supreme Court of the United States.

"La Sonnambula" will be given a final performance at the Metropolitan Opera-house this evening. Signor Campanini will be the Elvino, and will be heard for the last time this season. Those who know a great tenor when they hear one will not miss the performance.
WASHINGTON, Dec.15.--The relative positions of the two political parties in the approaching Presidential contest have been defined.
The Aqueduct Commissioners have adopted a route for the new aqueduct from the Harlem River to a point at Maurice-avenue near and south-easterly from Sing Sing.

The dry goods store of Simon Strauss, No. 21 Avenue B, was entered by burglars on last Thursday night and robbed of over $1,000 worth of goods. The burglars scaled a fence in the rear of the building, and by forcing open a basement door, which was insecurely fastened, gained the cellar beneath the store.

WILLIAMANTIC, Conn. Dec.16.--James Warren, of Stafford, Tolland County, has sued one of the noted "Dr.Sweets," of Lebanon, for malpractice in setting a broken limb. The case will speedily come to trial, and the damages are laid at a high figure. As all the parties are well known, it excites no little comment. The Sweets are a family of so-called "natural bonesetters," the fame of which was at one time national.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Dec.16.--A sharp contest is being waged between millionaire Flood and Senator Sharon for the control of the Ophir mining stock. Proxies are at a premium of $3 a share. It is stated that Mr.Sharon has secured a majority. The stock has risen from $6 to $11.75. The election will take place on the 19th inst.

MONTPELIER, Dec.14.--Less than one third of the voters in Vermont are Democrats. When Barstow was elected Governor in 1882, his Democratic opponent received less than 28 per cent. of the whole number of votes cast, and in 1880 the Democratic candidate for Governor was supported at the polls by only 21,245 voters out of 70,684.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Dec.16.--A collision occurred yesterday morning on the Germantown branch of the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad, west of Sixteenth-street station. The engine of an incoming passenger train was derailed and several of the passengers severly hurt. Jennie Evans, residing at Oak-lane, was severely cut about the head and body, and Lizzle Picot, of the same place, was seriously bruised on the head.

WASHINGTON, Dec.16.--With respect to the report that some of Mr.Gorham's friends in the Senate are so embittered by their failure to secure his nomination for Secretary of the Senate, that they will "bolt the ticket," or absent...

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Dec.16.--The Rev. Father O'Hara, Pastor of St.Mary's Catholic Church, this city, in a sermon delivered to-day denounced the teachings of Henry Ward Beecher as demoralizing to the youth of the land and injurious...

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Dec.16.--It was intended that the investure of Archbishop Elder with the pallium the past week should be followed by a meeting of the priests of the diocese for the purpose of discussing means for the payment, or partial payment, of the great debt left by Archbishop Purcell.
A dense cloud of tobacco smoke filled Irving Hall yesterday afternoon, dimming the dingy frescoes on the ceiling, and poured in a thick blue stream out of the half-opened gallery windows.
MONTREAL, Quebec, Dec.16.--Mr.Morris, representing the creditors of the Graphic Company, presented a petition in the Superior Court yesterday for a winding up order to issue against the company.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Dec.16.--Coroner Bollman, of this county, while he still keeps a Pinkerton detective at work upon the murder of Eldredge F.Johnson, the North Madison farmer, whose body was found on a burning charcoal heep with his skull crushed in, two weeks ago, is by no means sanguine that the guilty person will be discovered. So far his clues have availed him little.
Herr Zukertort played 31 games of chess simultaneously in Baltimore on Friday night last and won all but one. This week he is to play there 10 simultaneous games blindfolded.

The North German Lloyd steam-ship Elbe, which arrived yesterday from Bremen, brought 10 cases of animals and birds for the Central Park Menagerie. The collection consists of leopards, beavers, and several smaller animals; swans, cockatoos, and canary birds. Mr.Herman Reiche, the importer of animals, was a passenger on the Elbe. He brought with him a llama, an antelope, a zebra, and six monkeys.

SCHOHARIE, N.Y., Dec.16.--The will of Jehiel Larkin, late of Sloansville, Schoharie County, has been offered for probate, and objections made by Alexander Larkin and John Markle, nephews of the deceased.

Persons passing through the Beekmanstreet side of Fulton Market last week were attracted by a large display of what at first appeared to be gold fish, swimming restlessly about in a large tank, opposite the office of E.G. Blackford.

The working men of this country can learn no good thing of such foreign visitors as the delegates from the French trades-unions who have recently come here to study the condition of American laborers.

FONDA, N.Y., Dec.16.--It is reported that a movement will be made when the Legislature meets to dismember Hamilton County. The plan is to annex the town of Morehouse to Herkimer County, Long Lake to Essex, Indian Lake to Warren, and add Arietta. Benson, Hope, Lake Pleasant, and Wells to Fulton County.

CLEVELAND, Dec.16.--The spectacle of brother arrayed against brother in a brisk theatrical war is to be witnessed here this week. George T.Clapham, manager of Thatcher, Primrose and West's Minstrels, is fortified at the Euclid-Avenue.
NEW-ORLEANS, La., Dec.16.--The West Indian steam-ship Haytian Peter, from Colon, reports that matters at Aspinwall were lively and the Panama Canal on a boom.

The Union Association, which is in opposition to the American Association and the National League, has not fared as well as its projectors thought it would. At first it was stated that clubs in St.Louis, Chicago, Cincinnati, Boston, Brooklyn, Washington, and Richmond were eager to join, and that good grounds and strong clubs would be secured in every instance.
MATAWAN, N.J., Dec.16.--Two large coal barges, owned by M.F.Ross, of New-Brunswick, were sunk off Atlantic Highlands yesterday.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Dec.16.--A dispatch from Dubois, Penn., says: Just as the people were returning from church this morning, names were discovered in the second story of the American House. The Fire Department was promptly on hand, but before the engines could get to work the fire had gained such headway that nothing short of a miracle, it was thought,

The Right Rev. Mgr. T.S.Preston delivered the third of his advent lectures in refutation of infidelity and atheism, in St.Ann's Church, Twelfth-street, last evening, taking for his subject. "The Creation of the World."

Mr.Charles Wood, a gentleman 61 years old, while insane, yesterday morning, jumped out of a second-story window of his residence at No.158 East Sixty-first-street, and falling into the area in front of the house received injuries which resulted in his death soon after.

ELMIRA, Dec.16.--The failure of B.C. Wickham Co., bankers, in Tioga, Penn., has been followed by another misfortune in almost direct connection with it on a smaller scale. The bank had been carrying over $20,000 in paper issued by the extensive cigar manufacturing concern of Voorhis, Aiken Co.

WASHINGTON, Dec.16.--The following transfers in the Fourth Artillery have been made: Capt. John Egan from Battery K to Light Battery B; Capt. George G.Greenough from Light Battery B to Battery K. The officers thus transferred have been ordered to join their proper batteries without delay.

The weak spots in the present law restricting Chinese immigration are to be patched by the passage of a new bill which has the unanimous support of the California, Oregon, and Nevada delegations in Congress. READING, Penn., Dec.16.--About 2 o'clock this morning Mr.Daniel Shelhan was aroused by the noise of a scuffle in front of his house. On opening a window he found two men fighting desperately, one of whom fell heavily.

The curious New-Yorker who dared to consult his exposed thermometer at 7 o'clock yesterday morning found the mercury standing at 16 above zero, a rise of 6 since midnight, and only 3 colder than it had been, 24 hours previously.

The concert given at the Metropolitan Opera-house last evening was is many respects the most interesting of the series. Rossini's "Stabat Mater" was the feature of the programme, and, though it was found advisable to shorten it by the omission of the quartet, "Sancta mater," the remainder of the work was given in a manner that showed evidences of careful preparation.

The examination of E.W.Corey and Dr. Rufus Peacock on a charge of having defrauded the American Legion of Honor will be resumed before Judge Stilsing, in the First District Police Court, Jersey City, to-morrow morning, and some interesting, if not startling, developments are expected.

A significant advertisement appeared in the "Personal" column of our esteemed contemporary, the Herald, the other day. The advertiser desired to know the address of some person "understanding the application of Baumschiedtism."

READING, Penn., Dec.16.--Peter Heller, aged 50 years, while seated in a room with his wife late to-night, suddenly whipped out a razor and cut his throat from ear to ear. He ran out of the horse, and fell dead on the pavement. The cause is assigned as melancholy from sickness contracted in the army.
Capt. "Willegered of the North GermanLloyd steamship Elbe, which arrived yesterday from Bremen, reports a very stormy passage.

The Rev. R.Heber Newton concluded his review of the Book of Genesis at Anthon Memorial Church, which was filled to its utmost capacity, yesterday afternoon. The second division of Genesis, he said, opens at the twenty-ninth verse of the eleventh chapter, and runs through the rest of the book. It is occupied with the traditions of the patriarchs.

STONINGTON, Conn., Dec.16.--The arguments in the Wequetequoe cases, those against S.Marius Stanton and others of the School Committee, for assaulting F.Virginia Briggs and her Spartan band of female warriors at the time of the famous school-house riot, were finished last night by candle-light. Justice Crump reserved his decision until next Tuesday morning. The heat of the fight is undiminished.

Dispatches published yesterday in THE TIMES indicated trouble among the missionaries of the Presbyterian Church in widely separated portions of the globe, Egypt and Alaska. A young woman who said her name was Mary Brauen, but who refused to give her residence, was detected on Saturday evening stealing a gold ring from the jewelry counter at O'Neil's fancy goods store, at Sixth-avenue and Twentieth-street.

During his recent visit to Copenhagen Tennyson was asked to dine at the palace, but he was unable to accept the invitation for the reason that he had no dress-coat with him. This reason is declared to be "characteristic."

Fire Marshal Sheldon has ascertained that Mr. J.H. Finn, of the Rice Standard Opera Troupe, was not the man who obtained a key from Doorkeeper Hannibal Taffe, of the Standard Theatre, and afterward rushed out and announced that the theatre was on fire.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Dec. 17.--Messrs. D. M. E.G. Halbert, wholesale and retail dealers in dry goods in this city, filed an assignment today for the benefit of creditors. Their liabilities are between $300,000 and $400,000; their assets are probably $100,000.
CINCINNATI, Dec. 17.--The Board of Health some time ago informed the Board of Education that the Colony school-house on Walnut Hills was in an unhealthful and unsafe condition.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17.--The National Republican, which appears to have that access to Mr. Roscoe Conkling which is denied to ordinary newspapers, has been annoyed by a story published in the New-York Herald, in which it is represented that Mr. Conkling is a party to a combination to make Mr. John A. Logan the Republican candidate for President.

Edmund J. Rough, the man who was arrested for having attempted to set fire to the Casino on last Wednesday night, was yesterday indicted for attempted arson in the first degree by the Grand Jury of the Court of General Sessions. He was arraigned in the afternoon, but his counsel asked to be allowed to postpone the plea until Thursday. He was committed for trial.

The large ball-room at Delmonico's presented a most brilliant appearance a little before 12 o'clock last night. Ladies in elaborate costumes of richest fabric were gliding over the highly polished floor, accompanied by gentlemen in conventional evening dress, which served to set off the warm colors worn by their companions.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 17.--John H. Clark and James Ryan sparred four rounds Marquis of Queensbury rules for a silver trophy valued at $200, presented by the Philadelphia Sparring Club, this evening. Clark got in more clean declared the match a draw. There was great excitement, the audience wishing the men to fight it out.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Dec. 17.--State Senator Eckley B. Coxe to-day addressed a letter to his constituents, notifying them that he would not be a candidate for reelection under any circumstances.
TORONTO, Dec. 17.--The Court of Common Pleas has given judgment in the Jarrard extradition case, dismissing the prisoner's motion for discharge and ordering his remand into custody for extradition.

ATLANTA, Ga., Dec. 17.--In the play of "The Silver King" to-night during the first act Frank C. Bangs fainted and had to be carried off the stage. The audience was dismissed and their money was refunded. Too much morphine administered by a physician is supposed to have been the cause of his illness.

A new emotional play, written by Mr. Leander Richardson, called "Expiation; or, The Old, Old Story," was produced for the first time last evening in the Brooklyn Park Theatre. The play is in four acts, which are shown in three very elaborate set scenes, and it brings into action but eight characters, six male and two female.

Yesterday was a pretty chilly day all over the country, and especially in the West and the New-England States. In the Ohio Valley the temperature yesterday morning ranged from 10 to 15 below that of the previous 24 hours.

The brokers in the Stock Exchange sent the prices of the so-called Villard stocks up several points yesterday when they heard that Mr. Henry Villard had resigned as President of the Oregon Transcontinental Company and as President of the Oregon Railway and Navigation Company.

The Chamber of Commerce of this City is engaged in an important public service in its endeavor to have measures taken for the preservation of the forests of the Adirondack region.

FREDERICKTON, New-Brunswick, Dec. 17. --Mrs. George N. Johnson, her daughter, Miss Ella Johnson, and a young son were thrown from a carriage yesterday. Mrs. Johnson's face and head were badly bruised, and she will probably die. Miss Johnson had her nose crushed and her right eye torn from its socket, and was injured internally; she is in a precarious condition. The boy was uninjured.

James W. Bosler, of Carlise, Penn., was stricken with apoplexy yesterday morning, and died in his office about noon. Mr. Bosler was about 52 years of age. He was born in Cumberland County, Penn., and was educated at Dickinson College, Carlisle.

VANCOUVER, Wyoming, Dec. 17.--A grand rally was held here last night in honor of the passage of the women's suffrage law. Leading politicians, irrespective of party, are getting up a petition to President Arthur to appoint Mrs. Durway, the leader of the women's enfranchisement cause, Governor of the Territory.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Dec. 17.--Articles of agreement were filed in the State Department today for the merging of the Sea-board, Pittsburg and Great Western Railroad Company and the Delaware, Water Gap and South-western Railroad Company. The line of the former company extends from Greene Village, Franklin County.
The Hamilton College Alumni will have their annual dinner to-morrow evening at the Hotel Dam.

ATLANTA, Ga., Dec. 17.--A week ago a smooth-faced little fellow wearing a skull-cap turned up at Markham and wrote on the register, "Samuel B. Curtis and wife, Utica, N.Y." The lady waited in the parlor and the two were assigned to a room.
MONTREAL, Dec. 17.--John Hennessy, discount clerk of La Banque du Peuple, is a defaulter to the amount of $15,000. His uncle has made good the deficiency.

The Rev. Dr. Joshna Morsell, while conducting the services in Grace Church, City Island, on Sunday, motioned for a window to be opened and sank down in the pulpit as though in a faint. He was found, however, to have died from heart disease.

Reviewing the incidents connected with the trial and condemnation of O'DONNELL, the slayer of CAREY, the informer, it must be said that the international complications that have arisen are utterly causeless and impertinent.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14.--A decision was rendered by the Supreme Court of the United States today in the original habeas corpus case of the Sioux Indian Crow Dog, who was tried in the District Court for the First Judicial District of Dakota for the murder of another Sioux Indian named Spotted Tail, and, upon being found guilty, was sentenced to suffer death.

The Hon. Webster Flanagan, the gentleman who electrified the Chicago Convention by asking, "What are we here for?" has gone to Washington, and the inquiry arises, "What is he there for?" It is hinted that his trip has something to do with the succession to the comfortable place now occupied by Judge Morrill.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Dec. 17.--The large cigar factory of Voorhis, Aiken Co., at Tioga, has suspended business, pending the settlement of the affairs of B.C. Wickham Co., bankers in Tioga. Nearly 200 cigar-makers are thrown out of work.
The performance of "La Sonnambula" given at the Academy of Music last evening did not differ materially from the representation of the opera reviewed about three weeks ago in these columns.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Dec. 17.--The preliminary examination of Sheriff Brewster, John Dominick, A.M. Ancoin, J.D. Houston, Mike Early, D. Douglas, and D. Donovan, accused of having committed murder at the Seventh Ward poll on Friday, took place before Recorder Ford to-day.
PARIS, Dec. 17.--Prince Jerome Bonaparte has decided to become a candidate for election to the Chamber of Deputies from Barbzieux, Department of Charente.

LONDON, Dec. 17.--A Hong Kong dispatch to Reuter's Telegram Company states that a French expedition, composed of 6,000 men, with a flotilla of gun-boats and steam launches, started several days ago from Hanoi for Sontay. The troops were landed seven miles from the town, and encamped without meeting the Chinese or firing a shot. The assault upon Sontay was expected to be made on Dec. 12. The Chinese force is estimated at 20,000 men.

KINGSTON, Ontario, Dec. 17.--The Napanee stage, while crossing the Grand Trunk Railroad track near Cataraqui to-day, was run into by an up express train, and Mrs. Armitage, Mrs. H. Wartman, and Mrs. Gorrie were killed. The stage-driver was slightly injured.

Capt. George I. Gordon was put on trial in the Hudson County Court of General Sessions, in Jersey City, yesterday, on the charge of abducting and betraying Addie Bresnan, of Astoria, Long Island. Judge McGill presided, and a gilded American eagle stretched its wings on the wall back of him.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 17.--The German steam-ship Prinz George, Capt. Felde, from Palermo, which lost three men during a cyclone in latitude 34 57' on Dec. 1, reached her dock at this port to-day. The story of the Prinz George's passage is a thrilling one.

Commissioner Fink announced yesterday that the New-York, West Shore and Buffalo Railroad had formally applied for admission to the trunk line pool. The application did not state whether the road intended joining both the East and West passenger and freight pools, but this was likely. The matter would be the subject of future negotiation, but the road would be gladly welcomed in the "happy family."
WHEELING, West Va., Dec. 17.--Advices from Doddridge County say the people are inBig Bill Kinney has been given publicity, as he was not harmed by the mob.

William P. Parsons and his son Ambrose M. Parsons, composing the firm of W.P. A.M. Parsons, builders, at Madison-avenue and Eightyfirst-street, made an assignment yesterday to John C. Orr, giving preferences to John L. Haines $7,000; William Stanley, $3,000; Richard Kelly, $12,000; total, $22,000.

The annual Christmas festival at the New-York Foundling Asylum will be held on Friday, the 28th inst., from 1 to 4 P.M. The managers of the Asylum make an appeal to friends to make contributions of money or toys for presentation to the little ones on that occasion. During the past year 2,520 children and 507 homeless mothers have been sheltered and provided for at the asylum.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., Dec. 17.--Twenty-five members of Brith Kodesh Congregation threaten to resign if Dr. Landsberg's English ritual for Jewish worship is adopted.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 17--The interest in the trial of Rudolph Heine, charged with manslaughter, in having killed his wife by a kick, on a croquet ground, so crowded the Woodbury, N.J., court-house to-day that two men fainted owing to the bad ventilation.

The season of afternoon receptions and at homes has begun in earnest, and the present week will see a great many of them. Small teas are also popular, and there are yet many daughters to be introduced.

In the published excerpts from Matthew Arnold's lecture on "Emerson" the phrase "great, intelligent, sensual, avaricious America" is printed without quotation marks, as if it were Mr. Arnold's own utterance, whereas it is to be found in volume two of the Emerson-Carlyle correspondence in one of Mr. Emerson's letters. The phrase, which many have supposed to be original with Mr. Arnold, has given much offense, and the correction should, in justice to him, be made.

RALEIGH, N.C., Dec. 17.--A messenger has arrived here from Rolesville, a town about 15 miles distant, and brings the news that William Watkins, a boy about 16 years of age, was shot and killed last night within 200 yards of the house of Willis Watkins by some unknown person. It is thought that trouble about a woman caused the murder and a certain party is suspected.

A decision just handed down by the Supreme Court, General Term, sitting in Brooklyn, recalls a criminal case that attracted attention some years ago. Benjamin T. Babbitt had stolen from him by a clerk $250,000.
