Wool is one of the most important articles taxed in our tariff. It is necessarily a raw material, and that of the simplest and purest form. Not a pound of it can be consumed except in some form of manufacture.

FONDA, N.Y., Dec. 17.--The Assignees of Clark Kline, who recently failed in Amsterdam, have completed their inventory of the liabilities and assets. The former foots up $200,000. The actual assets aggregate $78,057 47. The real estate was found to be covered by mortgages. It is probable that the creditors in the third and fourth classes will receive nothing. Among these are S. Blaisdel, Jr., Co., $35,000, and John Consalus, $27,000.

BOSTON, Dec. 17.--The Medical Examiner this afternoon completed the autopsy on the body of Charles L. Perry, who died under suspicious circumstances at Boston Highlands yesterday.

CHICAGO, Dec. 17.--The leading produce markets were active, and most of them acted in unison. They were very strong early in the day and weakened later, thought the average closings on Change were higher than 48 hours previously. The lead was taken by wheat, the rest moving in sympathy therewith.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Dec. 17.--Ellen Poupard was put on trial for her life before Judge Arnold and a jury to-day, charged with killing Samuel Butler on Oct. 7. Antoine Renner was arraigned with her for complicity in the crime.

A circular letter has been issued by a committee of the Century Club, inviting subscriptions to a fund to erect a statue in Central Park to William Cullen Bryant. The matter has been under consideration in the club since last June. A committee, headed by the Hon. John Bigelow, was appointed at that time to receive subscriptions.

ROME, Dec. 17.--The Crown Prince of Germany arrived here at 12:30 o'clock to-day. MILWAUKEE, Wis., Dec. 17.--All of the Grand Army posts of this city are moving in an effort to get a National Home for the Widows and Orphans of Soldiers. Several posts to-night adopted a framed memorial to Congress setting forth the need of national homes for soldiers' widows.

BOSTON, Mass., Dec. 18.--The suspension of a member of the Brokers Board, Mr. W.P. Metcalf, of State-street, is announced. He is reported to be long on New-York and New-England stock. Mr. Metcalf states that his embarrassment is merely temporary, and that he will tide over his difficulties.
CONSTANTINOPLE, Dec. 18.--A great storm has caused much damage to houses in the town of Abadia. Six large ships and 15 coasting vessels have been lost and their crews drowned.

"Regulation of Inter-State Commerce." 2. "Strikes." 3. "Recent Decision of the Supreme Court on the Civil Rights Bill." 4. "Government Control of Telegraph."

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 18.--The trial of Elien Poppard, 20-years of age, for the murder of Samuel Butler, age 19, resulted at 4:30 this afternoon in a verdict of not guilty. Dr. George Kerr testified for the defense that from the circumstances of the case he thought that Butler's injuries, were probably occasioned by a fall, and that death was caused by concussion of the brain.
George A. Bennett, formerly one of the tellers in the Cashier's department of the Custom-house in this City, died in the Flatbush Lunatic Asylum on Monday.

PARIS, Dec. 18.--The Chamber of Deputies to-day voted the supplementary Tonquin credit of 20,000,000f. Prime Minister Ferry, replying to M. Lockroy, who had criticised the Government's Tonquin policy, said that the real question at issue was decided by the vote of confidence of the 10th inst., which could not remain a dead letter.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Dec. 18.--This afternoon fire destroyed the Occidental Hotel, at the corner of Fourth-street and Christy-avenue. The building was four stories in height and had a mansard roof. When the firemen reached the scene half a dozen women had their heads poked out of the windows and were screaming for help.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 18.--D.W. Blackburn, Treasurer of the Board of Supervisors of Keokuk, Iowa, has been found short in his accounts $12,500. Blackburn declares he does not known where the money has gone to.

LYONS, N.Y., Dec. 18.--The trial of Samuel Williams for the murder of James Hall attracted a still larger attendance here to-day. During the morning the examination of jurors was continued, and at noon the twelfth juror was found and sworn in.

MERIDEN. Conn., Dec. 18.--At a recent funeral service in the Catholic church here the members of the Ancient Order of Hibernians appeared in a body and wearig their regalia. Father Lawior refused to go on with the ceremony as long as they remained in the church. The members thereupon left the church, deliberated awhile, and returned without their badges, but the service had been hastened and was then over.

BANGOR, Me., Dec. 18.--The annual meeting of Maine State Grange opened hereto-day. The State Grange consists of the chief officers of subordinate Grangers, of which there are 178 in the State, 20 of which have a membership of at least 100.

The Rev. Dr. J.P. Newman addressed the Nineteenth Century Club last evening on the subject of "Buddha." He said that whether Buddha was an atheist or a theist was a question yet unsolved, but if he believed in a Supreme Being he said nothing about it.

TROY, Dec. 18.--Three hundred pounds of giant powder, which miners were warming near a stove yesterday at Lyon Mountain, Clinton County, exploded, considerably damaging the company's building. The miners narrowly escaped with their lives.

Dr. Rufus Peacock sat yesterday morning in the First District Court of Jersey City, carelessly twirling a pencil between his fingers and listening to the examination into the charge brought against him of having defrauded the American Legion of Honor, being the medical examiner of Union Council of that order.
DUBLIN, Dec. 18.--Joseph Poole was hanged at 8 o'clock this morning for the murder of John Kenny, on July 4, 1882. Poole and the attending priest remained in the prison chapel until nearly 8 o'lock.

HILLSBORO, Ill., Dec. 18.--In the Emma Bond case to-day Edward Burritt, a convict from Chester Penitentiary, who was in the jail at Taylorville with the three defendants, testified that he heard the three men consulting together and heard Montgomery talk about the piece of toenail which has been a link in the chain of evidence.

NEW-HAVEN Dec. 18.--It is now 10 days since the New-Haven police had their famous fight with the two New-Hampshire burglars, and which resulted in the escape of one and the capture of the other--a man who calls himself James Crandall.

MONTREAL, Quebec, Dec. 18.--Security for costs in connection with the petition for the winding up of the affairs of the Graphic Company has been given, and the company will have to answer in court within three days.

George W. Dunn and his wife, in the Coroner's office yesterday, faced 11 middled-aged men, who took oath that they would give a true and faithful verdict in the case of Rose E. Keiser, according to the evidence presented.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Dec. 18.--The Wanamie Colliery, employing a large force of miners and laborers, will suspend work to-morrow for a period of three weeks and probably longer. Inability to dispose of the coal mined is said to be the cause of the suspension.

At the reopening of the trial of August Muller, in the Court of Oyer and Terminer. yesterday, Assistant District Attorney O'Byrne admitted that the photographs sold by the prisoner to one of Anthony Comstock's assistants, and which were alleged to be obscene, were copies of pictures exhibited in the Paris Salon.
The Excise Commissioners have revoked the license of Adam Bischer of No.288 Bowery, for selling beer on Sunday, Nov. l8.

Between 1 and 6 o'clock yesterday morning the Mathesius grip was tested on the bridge railroad. Chief Engineer Martin, Engineer Mathesius, the inventor of the grip, and a number of other bridge engineers rode in the cars while the test teas being made. Engineer. Mathesius said he was entirely satisfied with his grip, and will submit a written statement of the result of the test to the bridge Trustees.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Dec. 18.--The trial of Charles Higham for the murder of Mr. F.W. Eames was resumed to-day. Coroner Charles M. Rexford testified to being called to the brakeworks on the 20th of April, where he found the body of Frederick W. Eames.

TORONTO, Ontario, Dec. 18.--Seventeen cars of freight and two engines were destroyed on the Canada Southern by a collision near Rodney. The loss will reach $100,000.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Dec. 18.--The loss by the fire last night in the Plankinton House will be adjusted at $10,000. There is an insurance of about $150,000 on the building and contents, and the pro rata amount among the different companies will be small. Workmen began immediately ...

WINNIPEG, Manitoba, Dec. 18.--The Canadian Pacific deadlock is practically ended. New engineers have arrived here, and the workshops will be opened to-morrow. The discharged engineers and firemen are disposed to make trouble and to commit depredations, but are restrained by the police.

COLUMBUS, Ga., Dec. 18.--Bill Lee is one of the most dangerous desperadoes in this section. He has for years defied the officers, and although he has committed many comes of a serious character, he has escaped arrest.
It was currently reported and generally believed at the Windsor Hotel last night that the Wabash and Missouri Pacific Railroads have determined to enter the new compact of the Union ...

The meagre dispatch from Columbus, Ohio, announcing that the Standard Coal and Iron Company had made an assignment has caused many inquiries in this City. The company had its office in the United Bank Building, but upon inquiry there yesterday it was learned that the office had been given up several weeks ago.
The examination of Christopher Kroos, charged with inducing the young grocery clerks known as the A B C Union to steal money from their employers, was continued yesterday before Justice Power.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18, 1883. Charles W. Dayton, ex-member of the Assembly from the Twenty-third New-York District, was to-day admitted to practice in the Supreme Court of the United States. He was introduced by Gen. Henry E. Tremain.

UTICA, N.Y., Dec. 18.--The entire equipments of the Bleecker-street horse railway were levied on to-day for $3,700, the amount assessed on the company for paving expenes the past Summer, and for which judgement had issued.

A dapper little gray-haired man, wearing a shiny silk hat and a neatly trimmed gray chin beard, tripped around the spacious lobby at Niblo's Garden last evening, and in a hard, dry voice urged theatre-goers to buy "orchestra chairs, $1.50 each; best seats in the house."

CHARLOTTE, N.Y., Dec. 18.--The death is reported here of Martin C. Battles, who has for years lived a life of perpetual terror in the Western Asylum for the Insane. He was about 42 years of age, and 20 years ago lived on his father's farm, in this town.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Dec. 18.--A man named Kahler furnished the police with information at a late hour last night that he had seen Miss Cooley, who left her home on Sunday night a week ago, in the vicinity of Humlock's Creek, and that she was making in the direction of the mountain at a rapid pace.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 18.--Rudolph Hein, who was found guilty of manslaughter in causing the death of his wife at Woodbury, N.J., was brought into the Court-house a few minutes after 5 o'clock t his evening to receive his sentence.

TORONTO, Ontario, Dec. 18.--Cataraqui, a small village three miles west of Kingston, is excited over two accidents which have occurred there. On Saturday night Isaac Powley, a wealthy citizen, was killed by Engine No. 41 on the Grand Trunk Railroad.

DENVER, Col., Dec. 18.--Last Saturday Mary Kofford called on Dr. Rose, a prominent dentist of Leadville, and made the startling request that he furnish her with a poison which could not be detected by an autopsy.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Dec. 19.--The Western Nail Association, at a meeting here to-day, discussed the question of shutting down the mills and reducing production. The session lasted nearly all day.

POUGHKEEPSIE, Dec. 19.--The examination of Harrington on a charge of assualt and attempted outrage on Miss Maria T. Benjamin, the East Fishkill school teacher, occurred today.

The trial before Judge Van Brunt, in the Common Pleas, Equity Term, of the suit of the Metropolitan Elevated Railroad Company against the Manhattan and the New-York Elevated Railroad Companies, was practically closed last evening. A solemn mass of requiem for the repose of the soul of the late Eugene Plunket, of this City, who died in San Antonio, Texas, on the 7th inst., was sung at 9 o'clock yesterday morning in the Church of St. Vincent de Paul, in West Twenty-third-street.

LYONS, N.Y., Dec. 19.--This was the third day of the trial of Sam Williams for the murder of James Hall at Sodus Point in January, 1882. An hour before the opening of the court every seat in the count-room was occupied. Jasper Newton was recalled to the stand and took up the narrative where he left off on Tuesday afternoon.

ATLANTA, Ga., Dec. 19.--To-day Judge John Erskine, Federal district Judge, forwarded his resignation to the President, he having passed the age at which Judges are allowed to place themselves on the pension list. It is his intention to pass much of his time in Europe, probably making his head-quarters in Ireland, of which country he is a native.

The British bark Star of Scotia, Capt. White, arrived from Australia a fortnight ago. The members of her crew state that they have been treated since their arrival in port very roughly, and have been compelled to work day and night.

In spite of the inclemency of the weather yesterday morning, the Special Term room of the Supreme Court was crowded with spectators anxious to hear the testimony in the divorce suit brought by Mrs. Florence M. De Meli against her husband, Henry A. De Meli, on the ground of cruel and inhuman treatment, beginning with their marriage, in 1870, and continuing until she fed from him, in Dresden, two years ago.

Thomas A. Kenny, Assistant Foreman of Engine Company No. 19, reported to the Board of Fire Commissioners, yesterday, a slight panic in Harry Miner's Theatre, in the Bowery, on the 14th inst., of which tho police were not informed.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19, 1883. A dispatch from the Minister of the United States at Stockholm informs the Department of State that on April 24, 1884, direct steam communication between this country and Sweden will be opened and continued thereafter by monthly trips between New-York and Gothenburg under the auspices of the North German Lloyds.

NEW-HAVEN, Dec. 19.--The Connecticut Progressive Union has just held its second annual convention and jubilation, over beer and wine and raw oysters. This association is coming to figure quite prominently in Connecticut politics, representing, as it does, near 3,000 voters, and as ...
Steam-ship Bothnia, (Br.,) McKay, Liverpool Dec. 8 and Queenstown 9th with mdse. and passengers to Vernon H. Brown Co.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Dec. 19.--At the Ophir Mining Company's election to-day there was a bitterly contested fight between Mr. Flood, who held control, and ex-Senator Sharon, who was anxious to possess it. The election was the most exciting since the great Hale and Norcross fight in 1868, when the shares of that company rose to $8,000.

A committee of the Council of Reform occupied the greater part of the time of the Board of Estimate and Apportionment yesterday. When the session began W.R. Stewart, of the State Board of Charities, recommended the purchase of a farm for the insane poor in the vicinity of the City.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 19.--The New-Jersey State Temperance Alliance continued its session at Camden this morning. A paper on "Restrictive Temperance Legislation" was read by Mr. Charles Rhoads.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19.--The Proteus Court of Inquiry was called to order at 11 o'clock this morning. Capt. James W. Powell, Sixth Infantry, was sworn. He was Acting Chief Signal Officer during the absences of Gen. Hazen--one occasion including the latter part of May and the first few days of June, l883.
An opinion was read at the meeting of the Board of Aldermen yesterday from the Corporation Counsel as to the right of the elevated railroads to store cars when not in use on their tracks.
KINGSTON, N.Y., Dec. 19.--The trial of John Moore for the Ellenville jewelry burglary occupied the entire time of the Court of Sessions to-day.

JOLIET, Ill., Dec. 19,--George Freestune, age 23, one of the boarders of the Auburn House, entered the room of the head cook, Jane Haycock, last night. He bound her head to prevent her screaming, and then assaulted her.
De Witt C. Littlejohn, of Oswego, is at the at the St. Nicholas Hotel. Bishop John Sharp, of Salt Lake City, is at the St. Nicholas Hotel.

WINNIPEG, Manitoba, Dec. 19.--The meeting of the Manitoba and North-west Farmers' Union opened this morning. Delegates from all parts of the Province submitted their credentials and expressed the views of the meetings they represented. A committee was appointed to draft a constitution.

DENVER, Col., Dec. 19.--The marriage of Bishop Henry W. Warren, of Georgia, to Mrs. Elizabeth S. Ileff, of this city, is announced to occur here on Dec. 27. Bishop Simpson will probably officiate.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19.--In his first prayer as Chaplain of the Senate, the Rev. Mr. Huntley, this morning, earnestly asked for divine blessings upon his predecessor in office who, in his daily walk and in his coming in and his going out, had pointed the Senators to the Lamb of God.
Mrs. Annie Mills, stewardess of the Grecian Monarch, was a passenger on a Fourthavenue horse car yesterday, as was also Justice Kilbreth.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19.--Both houses of Congress agreed to a resolution to-day to adjourn from Monday next to Monday, Jan. 7. The understanding in the House is that no business shall be transacted on Monday next beyond the announcement of committee appointments.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Dec. 19.--The Enterprise Machine Company, of Geneva, has made an assignment to P.W. Tuttle. Their liabilities are about 70,000. Their assets are not given. Seventy-five men are thrown out of employment by their suspension. It is thought that their liabilities may be met if time is given them.

Count Louis Palma Di Cesnola, LL.D., Colonel of Cavalry, Brevet Brigadier-General by verbal appointment and General by personal appointment, and Archaeologist and Director of the Metropolitan Museum, occupied the witness stand all day yesterday during the progress of the Feuardent-Di Cesnola case.
The first examination under the new civil service rules for places under the municipal Government of Brooklyn will be held on the evening of the 28th inst., in the Common Council Chamber.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Dec. 19.--The Express to-morrow will print interviews with several prominent citizens, business men, and manufacturers concerning the tariff and the need for a treaty of reciprocity with Canada. All but one favored tariff reductions and better trade relations with our Northern neighbors.
NEW-ORLEANS, Dec. 19.--The Democratic Convention at Baton Rouge wasted another day waiting for the report of the Committee on Credentials and finally adjourned until 10 o'clock to-morrow morning.

A station indicator was placed in the car of the elevated railroad between Third-avenue and the Thirty-fourth-street ferry, yesterday, and attracted a good deal of attention. The device was attached to the ceiling in the centre of the car.

At the meeting of the Aqueduct Commission yesterday, all the members were present. Mayor Edson presided, and announced that the commission would hear remarks in regard to the size of the new aqueduct, the proposition to build the Quaker Dam, and the course of the aqueduct from Sing Sing, whether to the Croton Lake or the Quaker Dam, if that structure should be built.

In response to an invitation of the Executive Committee of the National Prison Association, the Wardens of the prisons of this State, New-England, New-Jersey, and Pennsylvania, with other prison officers, met yesterday in parlor No. 90 of the Fifth-Avenue Hotel to discuss practical questions of internal prison management.
The city of Boston has licensed 2,758 liquor saloons. The Atlanta (Ga.) Consititution says that there is a steady stream of emigration from Northern and Middle Georgia to North Alabama.

OCALA, Fla., Dec. 19.--Major Couper, chief engineer of the Florida Southern Railroad, had a quarrel with a tie contractor named Burchfield, at Leesburg, last night, and the latter stabbed Couper fatally in the side.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Dec. 19.--W.J. Pearson, Postmaster at Batesville, Ark., was found dead in his room in the Hotel Barnum on Monday night. It is supposed he committed suicide, but the autopsy yesterday revealed nothing confirming that supposition. The Post Office authorities here say he was some $4,000 short in his accounts, and that his whereabouts had not been known for a week prior to finding him dead here.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Dec. 19.--Burglars last night entered the residence of E.J. Hoppins, Collector of Internal Revenue in this city, and stole $4,300 in money which he had taken home to pay an obligation this morning. There is no clue to the perpetrators.

PARIS, Dec. 19.--It is reported here that the Chinese forces have been concentrated at Hung-Hoa, about 20 miles above Sontay, on the Red River, and at Bac-Ninh.

BUFFALO, Dec. 19.--The mystery connected with the new American Midland seems from advices coming from one of the interested persons in this city to be in a fair way of being solved. The American Midland is the name of a new road for the construction of which a contract has just been awarded to George Potts, who has within a recent period completed certain work on the West Shore.

PARIS, Dec. 19.--"Sarah Barnum," the satirical biography of Sarah Bernhardt, written by her former friend, Marie Colombier, has been the cause of a duel between friends of the two women, and of a scandalous quarrel between the actress and the author.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Dec. 19.--Lieut. C.A. Clarke, of the regular army, and Miss Sadie Robertson, a native of this City, were married in the Methodist church to-night, in the presence of a, large throng. A reception followed at the residence of the bride's parents, some of the groom's relatives attending.
PETERSON, Utah, Dec. 19.--Two men, named Harrington and Robinson, who left here Monday on shooting expedition, were caught in a snow-slide and instantly killed. Harrington's body was found to-day.

Brown, Thomas Roche, Frederic Robie, C.C. Bedlow, J.W. Plaisted, and C.D. Livermore. A meeting will be held at some future date for organization.

BERLIN, Dec. 19.--The Emperor William and the Empress Augusta gave an audience yesterday to Cardinal von Hohenlohe at the royal palace.

CHICAGO, Dec. 19.--Great excitement has been caused among charitable, people by a discovery which the officers of the Humane Society claim to have made relative to a horrible state of affairs at the Working Women's Industrial Home in the suburban village of Lagrange.

ALBANY, Dec. 19.--Trains from the Grand Central Station yesterday carried from New-York nearly every prominent railroad official connected with the Vanderbilt system and the principal railway and civil engineers in the East, all bound for Niagara Falls,to assist at the opening of the new cantilever bridge.
At police trials yesterday Officer James Collings, of the Seventh Precinct, was found guilty of drunkenness and summarily dismissed from the force.

ST. JOHN, New-Brunswick, Dec. 19.--The schooner Frank and Willie arrived here to-day with the Captain and crew of the schooner Evergreen, which was wrecked on the American cost a few days ago. The Evergreen left here on Wednesday morning, bound for Boston.

A committee of the Council of Reform has submitted to the Board of Estimate and Apportionment a statement in regard to the estimates of certain of the municipal departments, which shows by means of a few samples of actual and estimated expense more forcibly than any amount of sermonizing could do the outrageous extravagance with which the public funds are wasted.

ATLANTA, Ga., Dec. 19.--There are evidences of renewed quarrels among the Republican factions of the State. J.E. Bryant is very anxious to be Marshal instead of Longstreet. Local politicians have hatched up a scheme for ...

NEW-HAVEN, Dec. 19.--The annual meeting of the stockholders of the New-York, NewHaven and Hartford Railroad Company will be held in this city on Jan. 9. The report of the Directors respecting the business and condition of the Company for the year ending Sept. 30, 1883, was printed to-day.

POUGHKEEPSIE, Dec. 19.--The case of J. H. Quinn, who was arrested yesterday morning charged with attempting to burn the Poughkeepsie Hotel, is a singular one. The fire would not have been discovered had it not been for a game of draw poker which was going on in one of the rooms.

AUGUSTA, Me., Dec. 19.--The annual stockholders' meeting of the Maine Central Railroad was held to-day. All the old Board of Directors were present with the exception of Jonas H. French and Willard P. Phillips. The stockholders were quite fully represented, and many ...

BATAVIA, Dec. 19.--Andrew Kennedy, aged 32, came to Batavia from Fredonia about two weeks ago and took up his residence in the family of Enoch Preble and wife on Walkerstreet, with whom he used to live in Jamestown during the Summer, the family removing here a few weeks ago.

The New-York Chorus Society gave its first concert of the season at Steinway Hall last evening. The programme was remarkably well chosen and was rendered in a manner which, while not quite perfect, gave evidence of conscientious preparation.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19.--A large meeting was held this evening at Ford's Opera-house by the Clan-na-Gael, to express, in the words of the call, "American opinion and feeling with regard to the judicial murder of Patrick O'Donnell by the British authorities." Congressman Robinson, of New-York, was called to preside. He stated the object of the meeting.

A single adjective expressive of purity was misapplied yesterday if used in speaking of the snow which made life miserable through the streets of the City, but every synonym might have been brought into play while looking over the expanse of crystal flakes in which Central Park was garmented. Laborers were busy clearing the walks and arranging for the comfort of the animals.

Miss Virginia Lee Lawrence, of Bayside, near Flushing, was married to Mr. Louis Meredith Howland, in St. George's Church, Flushing, yesterday. The bride is the daughter of Mr. Frederick N. Lawrence, recently the President of the New-York Stock Exchange.

The Floating Theatre Company was the subject of much discussion among managers and actors yesterday. The majority of them smiled and quoted personal experiences, while a small minority frowned and talked of impertinence. All insisted that the idea was far from being an original one, and that if the Trustees of the company would look to precedents they would see that "floating palaces" had always been a drug in the market.

TROY, Dec. 19.--It was generally known that an entertainment of some sort was to come off in Trumanvill Hall, Hoosick Falls, last night, but only a few score chosen spirits had received the "tip" that a lively set-to was to take place.

Franz Minch, 53 years old, and a native of Naumburg, Prussia, killed himself with a pistol yesterday in the back room of his liquor saloon, No. 232 East Thirty-seventh-street.

STONINGTON, Dec. 19.--The Wequetequock litigation continues to be the burden of excitement in this antiquated borough. The musty court-room, with its birch wood fire, is daily crowded with people from the farms and shops ...

When the Railway Commissioners were appointed in this State there were those who had hopes that the influence of the Commissioners would bring about the abolition of the car stove, which for nearly six months of the year stands in the corner of every railway car ready to set fire to it and burn the passengers whenever an accident occurs.

There are 45 saw manfacturers in the United States, and all but two of them buy the steel of which their implements are made. One large factory in Philadelphia and another in Middletown, this State, make the steel as well as the saws.

BOSTON, Dec. 19.--The funeral of Prof. Sophocles, late University Professor of Greek in Harvard College, was held this afternoon, the Rev. Dr. Peabody officiating. Several members of the Faculty and a large number of students ...

ROME Dec. 19.--The Crown Prince of Germany and King Humbert were present at a grand review of Italian troops to-day. Twenty thousand men were in the ranks. The weather was fine. Large crowds viewed the pageant and manifested great enthusiasm.

The members of the Alumni Association of Hamilton College held their annual reunion and banquet at the Hotel Dam, Union-square, last evening. Col. Emmons Clark presided, and with him at the table at three-score Alumni and ...

Early yesterday morning Martha Bergen, aged 17, while locked in a cell in the First Precinct Station-house, Brooklyn, attempted to hang herself with a corset-string, but was prevented from carrying out her purpose by the doorman.

TROY, N.Y., Dec. 19.--William E. Fox, of Hoosick Falls, has been on trial for two days on the charge of taking the body of Michael Garey from the grave in St. Mary's Catholic Cemetery, in that village. The indictment contained two counts, one charging Fox with robbing ...

The Vice-Presidents of the trunk line railroads met yesterday the executive officers of Western railroads in the joint Executive Committee and adopted an agreement which, they think, will prevent all cutting of freight rates in the future.

NEW-HAVEN, Dec. 19.--Dana B. Seaver, aged 50, traveling salesman for B.W. Allen Co., wholesale liquor-dealers, No. 47 Broadway, New-York, was found dead in his bed at the Grand Union Hotel this morning.

CHICAGO, Dec. 19.--Phosa McAllister, the actress whose company, has just closed an engagement at the Criterion Theatre, was in a peck of trouble to-night. The company was billed to appear this week in Clinton, ...

BALTIMORE, Md., Dec. 19.--A fire broke out this morning in the warehouses of the Baltimore warehouse Company, on Union Dock. Warehouse No. 1 was completely burned, and also the third story of warehouses Nos. 2 and 3.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20.--At 1 o'clock this morning it was not expected that ex-Gov. Lowe, of Maryland, would live through the night.
CALAIS, Me., Dec. 19.--William Wilson, Percy Truesdale, A. Rollins, and S. McFarland were drowned last night in St. Andrew's Bay by the capsizing of their sail-boat.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19.--In the United States Supreme Court to-day the following business was transacted: No.194--The Madison and Portage Railroad Company, appellants, vs. The North Wisconsin Railway Company; No. 195--The Wisconsin Central ...

There was a large attendance of persons interested in electric lighting in the Chamber of the Board of Aldermen yesterday, the proposition for placing the wires underground being under consideration. The Finance Committee reported an ordinance making it compulsory on ...

PITTSBURG, Penn., Dec. 20.--The strike of the Third Pool coal miners against a reduction of wages, ordered to begin to-day, was a failure. There was no suspension of work in the mines that had orders. The officers of the Miners' Association admit the failure of the strike, but assert that the men will come out within a week.

The temperature yesterday was from 5 to 10 below that of Wednesday, and the consequence was that much of the snow which fell on Wednesday remained on the ground. It was hard wheeling all over the City, and particularly in the down-town streets, where one might reasonably except to see the snow cleared away.

George Meins, the ex-Sing Sing convict, who was arrested as soon as he was discharged last week for having on the 30th of April last broken $1,800 worth of stove patterns belonging to Perry Co., the stove contractors, was on Monday indicted by the Westchester County Grand Jury for malicious mischief.

ALBANY, Dec. 20.--Congressman H.G. Burleigh, of the Seventeenth District, is taking an active hand in the Speakership contest. The Assemblymen in his section of the State have been favored with letters, in which Mr. Burleigh informs them that he has just returned from ...

The Brooklyn Club has recently made a change in its team owing to the engagement of Warner, formerly of the Philadelphia Club. Fennelly was engaged to play third base for the Brooklyns, but he has been released, and Warner will occupy that position.

John Campbell, a piano-maker and tuner living at No. 112 West Fortieth-street, died Wednesday night from the effects of a dose of arsenic. Campbell was somewhat addicted to drink, and had several times told his family that he meant to poison himself.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20, 1883. The board appointed by the President to prepare a plan for an expedition to be sent to the relief of Lieut. Greely and parts convened at the Signnal Office this afternoon and organized, with Gen. W.B. Hazen as President and Capt. Davis. Fourteenth Infantry, as Recorder. The board decided to meet at the Navy Department on Saturday when a general plan of procedure will be agreed upon.

CHICAGO, Dec. 20.--The leading produce mar kets were stronger on the average. Corn and provisions were moderately active and again higher, while wheat was quiet and tame, with an easier tendency. Oats were higher, in sympathy with corn.

Edmund G. Rough, the Casino fire-bug, was yesterday arraigned in Part I, of the Court of General Sessions. His first plea of "not guilty" was withdrawn and a plea of "guilty" entered, upon which he was sentenced to the State prison for a term of seven years.

A crowd of 300 men and women clustered around a red flag in Burling-slip yesterday morning. At 10 o'clock they were permitted to enter a large room, with bare, whitewashed walls, and inspect a, miscellaneous assortment of merchandise taken from passengers who had attempted to violate the revenue laws.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Dec. 20.--The elopement of Andrew R. Coleman, a prominent young jeweler, in business for himself at Red Bank, with Miss Lizzie Smith, of Throckmorton's Gully, on Monday night last, creates much excitement in this vicinity.

WINNIPEG, Manitoba, Dec. 20.--The Manitoba and North-west Farmers' Union resumed the discussion of the declaration of rights this mornings. Resolutions were adopted denouncing the right of the local Government to charter a railroad in Manitoba; to have absolute control of the public lands, including school...

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Dec. 20.--News comes from Higbee, Mo., that a deadly fight occurred between Cob and Mug Grove, brothers, near Burton, in the southern part of this county, on Monday last. Cob used his knife with such terrible effect as to cause the death of his brother last night. They quarreled about a young lady whose affections both sought. The murderer was arrested and taken to the Moberly Jail.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Dec. 20.--While William Hord, one of the wealthiest and most prominent citizens of Hawkins County, was sitting in front of a fire in his room yesterday he fell face forward into a bed of hickory coals. Mr. Hord was convalescing from a severe sickness, and it is supposed he fainted and fell into the fire. He lingered seven hours in terrible agony, when he died.

Until Wednesday it was supposed that the demon of secession had been rendered harmless, and that during this generation, at least, we should not be again compelled to take up arms to prevent the dissolution of our Union.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Dec. 20.--Great excitement was caused at noon to-day by the filing of the general assignment of Donald Gordon, one of the largest dry goods merchants in this city. Abraham E. Wollf is the Assignee, and 220 creditors are preferred, 151 of which are New-York City merchants. The liabilities are estimated at between $250,000 to $350,000.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Ill., Dec. 20.--Caleb Washburn quarreled with his niece, Jennie Washburn, last night, about a small amount of money, when the latter seized a heavy stick and struck the uncle on the head, inflicting a wound which proved fatal an hour later.

MONTREAL, Quebec, Dec. 20.--The General Manager of the Canadian Pacific Railway here has received a dispatch from Winnipeg stating that no more engineers are required.
PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Dec. 20.--Brevet Major-Gen. Thomas Jefferson Cram, Colonel Engineer Corps United States Army, retired, died suddenly in a Chestnut-street horse car this afternoon.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20.--Adjt.-Gen. Drum has been informed by telegraph from San Antonio, Texas, that Gen. McKenzie is seriously ill and unable to perform his duties.

The annual meeting of the Society for Improving Working Men's Homes was held at No. 43 West Thirty-eighth-street last night, and a gratifying report of last year's work was listened to. The object of this society is to "provide for the temporal welfare of working men...

PARIS, Dec. 19.--The scandal of the day is the appearance of a book called "Memoirs of Sarah Barnum," by Mlle, Marie Colombier, who writes with mud and ordure what purports to be the memoirs of Sarah Bernhardt, the authoress' ex-friend and directress during her tour in America.

CAMBRIDGE, Dec. 19.--The "Harvard Index," edited this year by Marshall Henry Cushing, '83, a member of the Law School, appeared to-day. The book is bound in a neat paper cover, with the title printed in crimson ink.

RALEIGH, N.C., Dec. 20.--About 1 o'clock to-day Guilford Soon, colored, was hanged at Kinston for feloniously assaulting Mrs. Eliza Jones, a widow. The hanging was public, and was witnessed by several thousand persons.
BUFFALO, N.Y., Dec. 20.--The great cantilever bridge over the Niagara River was formally opened to-day.

CHICAGO, Dec. 20.--The Hon. Charles B. Moore, of Ohio; C.P. Swigert, of Illinois; Michael Shannon, of New-York, and Oromandel Smith, of Maine, all Insurance Commissioners of their respective States, were in consultation all day to-day at the Palmer House.
MADISON, Wis., Dec. 20.--Insurance Commissioner Phil Spooner is waging a relentless war on bogus insurance companies. The recent disclosures show that the fraudulent companies, ...

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Dec. 20.--Charles A. Willard, ex-Lieutanant in President Hayes's old regiment, and an Indianapolis and Cleveland route agent, was arrested to-day for robbing the mails. He was caught by a decoy letter containing a two-dollar bill and a marked silk handkerchief and confessed his crime, admitting that his thefts had been practiced for four years. He was locked up in default of $2,500 bail. Willard has a wife and three children in this city.

The Aqueduct Commissioners yesterday heard further argument relative to the construction of the proposed Quaker Bridge Dam, the course of the aqueduct from Sing Sing northward, whether to Croton Dam or Quaker Dam, and as to the size of the aqueduct. Willis Blackstone was the first speaker.
CINCINNATI, Ohio, Dec. 20.--A little before noon to-day a young man entered the Central Police station and informed the Sargeant in charge that he had murdered his wife and wished to give himself up.
NORWICH, Dec. 20.--The authorities of Eastern Connecticut are about to begin an active campaign against the "tramp."

The North German Lloyd Steam-ship Company will start a line next April between this port and Gothenburg, Sweden. The steamships which will be used on this service are the Berlin and the Baltimore, which have heretofore run between Bremen and Baltimore. The vessels will leave this port every month.
Only one witness was examined yesterday in the trial of the suit of the Metropolitan Elevated Railroad Company against the Manhattan and New-York Companies.

Miss Anderson's photographs, as we all know, fill and adorn the shop windows from West to East, Bond-street to Cheapside. Few actresses, indeed, whether indigenous or exotic, have been so admirably displayed, not even Mrs. Rousby or Mrs. Langtry.

BOSTON, Dec. 20.--A bill in equity has been brought by Receiver Price, of the Pacific Bank, against the Directors and officers of the bank in the United States Circuit Court, in which the complainant seeks to hold them...

OSHKOSH, Wis., Dec. 20.--Mrs. Simon B. Paige, who is just now hard pressed by the relatives of her late husband, has made a statement to a local paper which contains some facts in addition to those already published. She says she did not write to Mr. Paige after his wife's death, ...

The First Union Presbyterian Church, Eighty-sixth-street and Lexington-avenue, was well filled last evening by a congregation gathered to witness the installation of the Rev. Wilbur F. Crafts as Pastor of the church. Christmas greens entwined the pillars, while ropes of ground pine were looped about the galleries, ...
Sunday, Dec. 23, will be the centennial of Gen. Washington's formal resignation of his commission as Commander-in-Chief of the Continental Army.

BALTIMORE, Md., Dec. 20.--A farewell reception was tendered Prof. Sylvester to-night at Johns Hopkins University, that gentleman having accepted the appointment of Savilian Professor of Geometry in the University of Oxford, England. Addresses were made by President Gilman, of Johns Hopkins; Matthew Arnold, Prof. Sylvester and others.
The Eastern Boulevard was alive with flying sleighs yesterday afternoon from Central Park to One Hundred and Sixty-fifth-street.

LONDON, Ontario, Dec. 20.--Georgo D. Evans, a book-keeper, was arrested to-day charged with by local and Chicago detectives obtaining $6,000 from Charles Van Doren, of New-York, one of the heirs of the Springer estate, at Wilmington, Del., which is valued at $20,000,000, by the use of a forged certificate of heirship. The prisoner was held for extradition.

BOSTON, Dec. 20.--At a meeting of the Governor and Council to-day a pardon was granted to George H. Richardson, of Charleston, who was sentenced for life in 1882 for murder in the second degree. Richardson killed his father. It now appears that the killing was accidental.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Dec. 20.--The Rev. George Alexander, of the East-Avenue Presbyterian Church, of this city, has accepted a call to the Pastorate of the University-place Presbyterian Church, in New-York City. He will enter upon his new charge early in January. Prominent citizens of Schenectady protested before the Presbytery at Albany yesterday against the change.
Two big chunks of that miserable kind of timber out of which some policemen are made, were on exhibition in the Supreme Court, Circuit, yesterday.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Dec. 20.--Frank H. Walworth, who killed his father, Mansfield T. Walworth, in New-York several years since, was married to-day to Miss Corinne Bramlette, daughter of the Union war Governor of Kentucky, whose widow resides here.

ATLANTA, Ga., Dec. 20.--This morning Mrs. Steele, alarmed at the prolonged absence of her father, D.R. Wadely, brother of the late President Wadely, of the Georgia Central, went to his room, and, effecting a forcible entrance, found him dead. On his person was found in money and railroad stocks over $70,000. An inquest showed that death resulted from heart disease.

Every good citizen ought to sympathize with Judge VAN BRUNT in his failure to find any precedent which would enable him to put the screws on MOROSINI in order to compel the production of GOULD'S books.

An auction sale of the leases of 178 offices in the new Produce Exchange Building took place yesterday, R.P. Clapp officiating as auctioneer. There was a large attendance just before the auction began, at about 3 o'clock P.M. ...

BOSTON, Dec. 20.--Mme. Etelka Gerster appeared here this evening, for the first time, an Adina in Donizetti's sprightly and melodious opera, "L'Elisir d'Amore." The performance, which was witnessed by an immense audience, was thoroughly successful.
GIBRALTAR, Dec. 20.--The British troopship Euphrates is ashore near Tarifa. A gunboat has been sent to her assistance. A tug has landed the women and children.

More than thirty-three years ago the Governments of the United States and Great Britain entered into a treaty with each other for the purpose of promoting the construction of an interoceanic canal through Nicaragua and of extending over it their joint protection.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Dec. 20.--Canadian sugar refiners are not satisfied with the tariff. They hope to secure a reduction of duty on raw sugar imported for refining purposes, as well as a drawback on all refined sugar exported.

The most disastrous conflagration Allegany County has known in years visited the village of Rushford yesterday morning. The fire originated probably from a defective flue in the chimney in the extensive dry goods store of Pratt Colburn, and destroyed the store and its contents.

ATLANTA, Ga., Dec. 20.--For several days Miss Mary Reicker, age 14, has been missing. She is a girl of engaging manners and retiring disposition. Her father, Mr. Reicker, keeps a saloon in Reicker's Hollow, and has made much money at his business.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Dec. 20.--Mrs. Martha Parsons has obtained a judgement against the New-York Central Railroad Company of $5,000 for the killing of her husband. This is the third time she has won the suit.

BELLEVILLE, Ill, Dec. 20.--This afternoon a young German named Henry Bobst, after filling himself up with whisky, went to Wilderman Station, four miles south of here, where he fatally shot Miss Mary Hammer, a former sweetheart.

The Board of Estimate and Apportionment yesterday received a letter from Mrs. Josephine Shaw Lowell, of the State Board of Charities, suggestine that the board should make no appropriation to the Commissioners of Charities and Correction for the support of the out-door poor.

WHEELING, West Va., Dec. 20.--Passenger train No. 1, east bound, over the Baltimore and Ohio Road, consisting of two engines, baggage, express, find mail cars, four coaches, and a sleeper, leaving this city at 8:45 this morning, struck ...
LYONS, N.Y., Dec. 20.--The trial of Sam Williams, the negro minstrel, on the charge of murdering James Hall, was continued to-day before a large audience.

Two boys escaped the ticket speculators in front of the People's Theatre in the Bowery last evening and entered the lobby. There they fell a prey to a Jewish-looking man, who represents the box-office.
At his death Lord Lytton left a letter in which he committed to his son the duty of dealing at discretion with his literary remains subject to certain restrictive injunctions.

LONDON, Dec. 20.--A portion of the crew of the Spanish mail steamer Saint Augustin, bound from Manila for Liverpool, have arrived at Dartmouth. They report that the steamer took fire on Sunday last in the Bay of Biscay. Eighty-two of the crew and passengers took to...
NASHVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 20.--This mornning the traveling derrick at the stone-yard of Oman Stewart fell with a crash, wounding three of the workmen--William Roberts, Thad Watson, and Mr. Turnbull.
Mme. Minnie Hauk is at the Everett House. James N. Tyner, of Indiana, is at the Gilsey House.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20.--The proceedings of the United States Supreme Court to-day were as follows: No. 1230 and No. 1231--The North American Neuchatel Rock Paving Company, appellant, vs. The District of Columbia; appeals from the Court of Claims; on motion of Solicitor-General Phillips, docketed and dismissed.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Dec. 20.--In the Higham murder trial this morning, the crossexamination of Robischung was completed, but no new facts were developed. William H. Pollard testified that he was under the pattern-room and hard the breaking of glass and two shots before...

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20.--The Signal Corps station at Washwoods, N.C., reports that the British steamer Ashfield, Capt. Whitehead, from Stockton to Baltimore, went ashore at 8 o'clock this morning on Pebble Shoal. The vessel is loaded with iron ore, and is about one mile from shore. She will probably get off. The crew of Life-saving Station No. 5 boarded her and offered assistance, but it was declined.

NASHVILLE, Dec. 20.--A gang of burglars are operating in this city. It was discovered this morning that they had entered the store of Webb, Stevenson Co., tinware-dealers, blown open the safe, and extracted $115.

At the meeting of the Trustees of the Actors' Fund, in Harrigan Hart's Theatre yesterday afternoon, A.M. Palmer presided in the absence of Lester Wallack, and Managers William Henderson, M.H. Mallory, John F. Poole, Harry Miner, and Billy Birch were present.
Miss Elia Marian Smith, daughter of Mr. John J. Smith, was married yesterday afternoon, in St. Timothy's Church, Eighth-avenue and Fifty-seventh-street, to Mr. Edward B. Sexton.

LAWRENCE, Kan., Dec. 20.--The burial of the late Dudley Chase Haskell tools place here to-day. The business part of the city and many residences were draped in mourning. Flags floated at half-mast, bells tolled, and business houses were closed.
NEW-HAVEN, Dec. 20.--President Watrous, of the New-York, New-Haven and Hartford Railroad, says he does not yet know who are the projectors of the fourth Connecticut parallel railroad.
The cross-examination of "Gen." Di Cesnola was concluded yesterday in the trial of the Feuardent-Di Cesnola libel suit.

POUGHKEEPSIE, Dec. 20.--Recorder Lown's court-room was again packed with spectators this afternoon when the case of John H. Quinn, charged with attempting to burn the Poughkeepsie Hotel, was called by the defense.
Mr. and Mrs. J. Kennedy Tod entertained the Thursday Evening Club last night at their residence, No. 20 Washington-Square. There was a collation by Pinard, and dancing.
In the statement recently made public by the Saturday and Sunday hospital Association of this City there is no word to indicate that any help is looked for from the great corporations.

The ship Samar, Capt. Miller, from Cebu, which arrived in the Lower Bay on Tuesday, came up to the City yesterday. This vessel passed through the Straits of Sunda three days after the great volcanic disturbance, which occurred in that region about Aug. 27.

Mrs. Mary McClane, the wife of John McClane, a, fireman, living at No. 44 Broomestreet, reported at Police Head-quarters last night that her adopted daughter, named Imogene McClane, 12 years old, was missing from home.
President Arthur reached New-York yesterday morning from Washinton at 9 o'clock, and went to the Fifth-Avenue Hotel. He was uuaccompanied, except by his faithful messenger "Aleek."

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Dec. 20.--The anthracite coal tonnage of all the carrying companies for the 11 months of 1883 ending Nov. 30 was 29,659,886 tons, an increase of 3,139,229 tons as compared with the same period last year. The stock of coal on hand at tide-water shipping points Nov. 30 was 696,380 tons, an increase of 91,515 tons as compared with the amount on hand Oct. 31.

CITY OF MEXICO, Dec. 21.--Trouble broke out to-day among the lower classes, caused by the nickel money. Nickely was refused in the city market this morning, and quarrels, with firing and cries of "Down with nickel," ensued.

CHICAGO, Dec. 21.--A large volume of cattle business was accomplished in the shipping branch of the market. There was a sharp demand during the forenoon, and the market developed a little more strength than on the preceding days of the week.
The trial of Capt. Joshua Slocumb, in the United States Circuit Court, on an indictment charging him with cruel treatment of Henry Arthur Slater, was concluded yesterday.

READING, Penn., Dec. 22.--Notice was given to-night for the closing indefinitely of the Philadelphia and Reading Coal and Iron Company's rail mill here on Jan. 1. Three hundred hands will be thrown out of employment. The cause assigned is dullness in the iron trade. This mill makes the larger part of rails used by the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad Company, and also furnished rails to other parties.

Augustus Gardner, who resides at No. 80 Lexington-avenue, is a watchman employed at the Stewart mansion, Fifth-avenue and Thirtyfourth-street. He has been greatly annoyed recently by tramps seeking for work, who have pestered him by their persistent demands.

GREENPORT, Long Island, Dec. 21.--Montauk Point is the most isolated and desolate spot imaginable during this weather. The frigid monotony of Winter has settled down upon that region, and now it is haunted only by sea fowl.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Dec. 22.--Some time ago Mrs. Garfield offered a bust of the late President Garfield to Hiram College, and last evening it was placed in the chapel with appropriate ceremonies, in which no show was attempted. A large company of students and citizens were present. President Laughlin made a short speech, appropriate music was rendered, and several speeches were made by members of the Senior Class of the college.

BALTLIMORE, Dec. 22.--Col. Elijah Stansbury, a member of the association of Old Defenders, was buried this afternoon from his late residence in this city.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Dec. 22.--The Chronicle will publish to-morrow the full text of the Huntington-Colton correspondence submitted in evidence at the trial of Colton now in progress at Santa Rosa. There are over 300 letters and they will occupy three full pages of the journal. They implicate many prominent United States Senators and Congressmen, and give the history of the efforts that were made against the Texas Pacific subsidy sinking fund.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Dec. 22.--The 40 runners who contested the preliminary heats in Makinson's foot handicap race at Echo Park today appeared exceedingly chilly as they toed the mark and awaited the signal shot for starting.

The Rev. William J. O'Brien was ordained as a priest of the Catholic Church in the Sulpician House, Rome, yesterday. He was formerly a resident of St. Michael's Church Parish, and was graduated from St. Francis Xavier's College in the class of '77.

The blind man, George Pippin, who has for many years showed wonderful ingenuity in handling freight, tending switch, c., at Shelburn Station, is dead. He had been blind from boyhood, and the skill he displayed at various kinds of work, including upholstering, which he followed as a trade for some time, was simply marvelous.

PARKERSBURG, West Va., Dec. 22.--John Brookover, an employe of the West Virginia Fibre Company at this place, while adjusting a belt this afternoon, was caught and whirled about a shaft several hundred times with great velocity. BALTIMORE, Dec. 22.--The centennial anniversary of the surrender of his command by Gen. Washington to the Continental Congress, at Annapolis, Md., on the 23d of December, 1783, occurring on Sunday, that event was commemorated to-night by the Maryland Historical Society by a dinner and speeches at the Carrollton Hotel. John H.B. Latrobe, President of the Society, presided. Speeches were made by Mr. Latrobe, the Hon. John L. Thomas, Mayor Latrobe, Gen. Phelps, and others.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Dec. 22.--Judge Reuben Lord, Jr., who sat in the celebrated Wequetequock school cases, and whose decisions in those causes resulted in the holding of a so-called indignation meeting at Stonington last Thursday evening, says that the action of the adherents of the Stanton-Palmer branch of the cases has caused him no uneasiness.

PADUCAH, Ky., Nov. 30.--The packet Paris C. Brown lay tickling her ribs against the rocky Illinois shore till 5 o'clock in the morning, and then resumed her journey. It was Wednesday morning, and five days from the date of leaving Cincinnati.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Dec. 22.--The body of a well dressed man was found lying on the Haddonfield (N.J.) turnpike about 7:30 o'clock this evening. Thomas Jackson, a Camden milk-dealer, who was on his way to Rowandtown, saw a man lying in the road.

LYONS, N.Y., Dec. 22.--In the case of Sam Williams, the negro minstrel, on trial for the murder of a colored man named Hall, the jury to-day, after an hour's deliberation, returned a verdict of acquittal. Williams left for his home in Auburn immediately, and was accompanied to the train by large numbers of his negro minstrel friends. Newport, the self-confessed accomplice, will probably not be tried until the May term of the court.
An unpleasant incident which occurred at a fair held in the Reid-Avenue Methodist Church, Brooklyn, some days ago, was made public yesterday for the first time.

CHICAGO, Ill., Dec. 22.--Judge Blodgett, in the Federal Court to-day, fined the three lottery agents, who were tried before him two weeks ago, $500 each for having used the mails in the dissemination of lottery literature. The convictions are the first under the Federal laws in this State.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 2.--Samuel J. Soper and Edward Soper, composing the firm of S.J. Soper Co., auctioneers, have made an assignment for the benefit of their creditors. PITTSBURG, Penn., Dec. 22.--Umpire Weeks, of the Coal Miners of the Fourth Pool Arbitration Board, has decided the wages question in favor of the miners, awarding them 3 cents per bushel. The operators claimed one-half cent less. The miners are jubilant over the award. The operators cannot be seen to-night, but they will probably accept the decision.

PARIS, Dec. 22.--The Anarchists who were arrested for advertising and promoting the projected meeting in front of the Bourse on Friday, the 7th inst., and other Anarchists who were indicted for manufacturing explosives here, have been tried, convicted, and sentenced to terms of imprisonment varying from one week to six months. When the judgement was pronounced upon the prisoners by the court, several people in the audience shouted " Vive anarchie!"

BLOOMFIELD, Ontario, Dec. 22.--Burglars entered the residence of Peter Jones last night and shot and killed Peter Lazier, who attempted to capture them. Two fishermen, Joseph Tompsett and David Lamder, who were tracked from Jones's house to their own, have been arrested as the murderers.

It has at last been definitely fixed that the "Alpine Rose," by Boyesen, the Norwegian novelist, shall be the next new production at the Madison-Square Theatre. This decision has been arrived at through the operation of various causes.

PARIS, Dec. 22.--A debate was held in the Chamber of Deputies to-day on M. Paul Bert's interpellation concerning the withdrawal of the prohibition against the importation into France of American salted meats.

PARIS, Dec. 22.--A banquet was given here this evening by the Minister of Foreign Affairs. Lord Lyons, the British Ambassador: Prince Hohenlohe, the German Ambassador, and other notables were present. The Marquis Tseng and his secretary excused themselves on the ground of ill health.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Dec. 22.--The Supreme Court decided, to-day, that the Board of Excise has full power in cases of license.

Four veteran sportsmen were seated around a glowing stove in a dimly lighted cabin on tho South Shore of Long Island one evening last week. They had had a long, cold, and fairly successful day after ducks. Their damp clothing had been exchanged for dry and their heavy boots for slippers.
NEWBURG, N.Y., Dec. 22.--Edward Radigan, of Sullivan County, blew out the gas in his room here last night, and died to-day from as phyxiation.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 22.--A big sensation was caused in financial circles here to-night by the announcement that Sylvester T. Everett, President of the National Bank of Commerce, had been asked to resign his position and that he had done so.
Dupont Post, No. 13, Sons of Veterans, Brooklyn, will give its annual ball at Turn Hall, Monday evening, Jan. 21.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22.--In the Criminal Court this morning, in the case of ex-Senator Spencer for contempt, Judge Wylie rendered his decision.

MONTREAL, Dec. 22.--The commercial situtation has undergone no change of late. The wholesale business in all departments is unprecedentedly dull, and the retail trade far from being up to the standard of former years at this festive period.

No translation of a Greek classic has ever appeared in this country which was at once so true to the original and clothed in such simple, vigorous, idiomatic English as the version of the Apology of Socrates, of Crito, and parts of Phaedo which were issued by the Scribners three years since.

BOSTON, Mass., Dec. 22.--Shaw Brothers, the large tanning firm which recently failed, have proposed the following to their creditors: First--To pay 33 1/3 cents on the dollar in cash to those who choose to accept the same, to be paid within 60 days from Jan. 1, 1884.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Dec. 22.--The threat of the glass-workers' committee at the late conference of manufacturers that if the latter did not accept the offer to resume work at the old wages on Jan. 1 the workmen would refuse to sign any contract, is said to mean that if the manufacturers do not agree to the workmen's terms on that date they will refuse to work on any-terms before June 1.

Mr. W.E. Sheridan made his first appearance in our City last night as Louis XI. He gace his performance of this character at the Star Theatre. The house was not full--Mr. Sheridan is yet ill-known among us--but the audience was responsive and attentive.

CHICAO, Ill., Dec. 22.--Specials to the Inter Ocean from Bloomington, Peoria, Mattoon, Pana, and other points in Central Illinois, report one of the heaviest snow-storms known in years, and the consequent delay of all railway trains and partial interruption of the telegraph service.

BOSTON, Mass., Dec. 22.--In the United States Circuit Could to-day, before Judge Nelson, in the patent suit of Marcus F. Norton and another against the city of Boston, which has been on trial for several days, the jury returned a verdict for the defendant.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Dec. 22.--Mr. Capen, Superintendent of Schools at Canton, and Mr. Joseph Morton, also of Canton, were killed by a snow-plow on the Boston and Providence Railroad between Canton and Canton Junction this morning.

On the occasion of the opening of the season at the Theatre des Italiens in Paris, the Figaro of Nov. 24 published a series of brief autobiographical sketches, more or less relevant to the history of the Salle Ventadour, and supplied respectively by Adelina Patti, Tamberlick, Nicolini, and Mario.

HAVANA, Dec. 22.--The police captured on board a steamer from Vera Cruz a noted criminal who had come to Cuba to organize a troop of bandits. Among his effects were found important papers showing that the services of bandits are used to foster political agitation.

MERIDEN, Conn., Dec. 22.--H.M. Rigney, of New-Haven, and Frank Kane, of New-Britain, ran a 100-yard foot-race here to-day, for a purse of $500 and the State championship. Rigney won by half a yard in 10 3-5 seconds.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22.--The joint resolution appropriating an extra month's pay to the discharged employes of the two houses of Con gress was sent to New-York yesterday for the President's signature. He telegraphed to-day that it had been signed, and this afternoon the employes were given their extra pay.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22.--The President will, it is understood, appoint Chief Engineer Charles H. Loring to be Chief of the Bureau of Steam Engineering, to take the place of Commodore W.H. Shock, retired.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22.--First Lieut. John J. Dougherty, Eleventh Infantry, has been relieved from duty in the Recruiting Service and will join his company in the Department of Dakota.
The benevolent-looking lady who stood in the little ticket office of the National Academy of Design was kept so busy yesterday that she scarcely noticed how bitterly cold the atmosphere was.

A most eccentric funeral ceremony took place in Paris on Thursday last. A speculator, M. Penguilly, died a few days previously. He was well known in the journalistic world, having shares in most of the successful Paris papers.

The Redwood Gazette advocates the building of houses of concrete. That experiment was pretty thoroughly tried in Winona several years ago, but it was soon abandoned. One building fell, and the walls of others have crumbled.
